fields.headline: Rufus darkens the Ipswich dream
fields.standfirst: Champions League hopes are set back in defeat by Charlton
fields.trailText: Despite dominating much of the game, Ipswich's hopes of a Champions league place next season suffered a severe blow at the Valley last night.
fields.body:
Real Madrid and Juventus can rest a little easier after Ipswich Town's chances of taking an improbable place in next season's Champions League suffered a severe blow last night.

Many said the Suffolk bubble would eventually burst but, though they still have two relatively easy games remaining, they must now also rely on slip-ups by Leeds and Liverpool to recapture third place.

Still, a Uefa Cup place remains a remarkable achievement for a team in its first season back in the top flight, and Charlton too, who were promoted alongside Ipswich, still retain an outside chance of joining them in the tournament. The London club are already guaranteed their best league finish since 1954.

Ipswich dominated most of the first half with their sweeping, majestic passing game and created plenty of chances after the break too. But Charlton's reserve goalkeeper Sasa Ilic produced some important saves and in the second half his side reorganised to 4-4-2, closed Ipswich down more and reaped the reward.

But Ipswich also assisted their downfall with two pieces of suspect defending which contributed to Charlton's two goals.

The first came after 11 minutes. Richard Rufus cleverly played in John Robinson down the right. The winger looped in a cross to the near post where Mathias Svensson, a late replacement for the ill Jonatan Johansson, nipped in front of Titus Bramble and headed past Richard Wright. It was a rare error by the highly coveted Bramble.

Having dominated the early stages Ipswich were surprised to be behind. On eight minutes they had nearly scored when Martijn Reuser uncorked one of his trademark free-kicks and hit a post from 35 yards.

It did not take the visitors long to get back on level terms. On 19 minutes Reuser took a short corner to Jim Magilton, received the ball back and then from about 25 yards out on the left chipped a hopeful ball into the area.

The nearest players missed it, then one by one so did those behind. By the time Ilic realised the ball was heading his way it was already sneaking in by the far post and his late dive was a mere token.

Ipswich's delightful pass-and-move football then laid siege to Charlton's goal and Ilic made amends twice over for his dozy reaction for the equaliser. He pushed away Jermaine Wright's header and saved well from Marcus Stewart.

Charlton broke out just once more before the break when Wright blocked bravely at the feet of Scott Parker, who had to be substituted because of a resulting injury.

The change in Charlton's formation and attitude paid immediate dividends. After 56 minutes they won a free-kick wide on the right which Claus Jensen floated in. Eventually the ball went to the other side where Graham Stuart, Parker's replacement, had arrived unobserved. He cut inside and slightly mishit his shot. But the big defender Rufus, up for the dead-ball kick, turned and diverted the ball up and beyond the despairing Wright.

Almost immediately that man Reuser nearly equalised again, Ilic brilliantly tipping over his 20-yard free-kick.

But this time Ipswich's ascendancy was short-lived. Robinson, then Shaun Bartlett went close and, though the visitors pressed hard towards the end, even a point proved elusive.

Can Ipswich still make the Champions League? "Why not?" challenged George Burley. "Who knows what can happen." One could see the straws in his hand.

Charlton Athletic (3-5-2): Ilic; Rufus, Todd, Fish; Robinson, Parker, Jensen (Konchesky, 86min), Kinsella, Powell (Stuart, 38); Bartlett, Svensson (Lisbie, 77).

Ipswich Town (4-4-2): Wright; Makin, McGreal, Bramble, Hreidarsson; Wright, Holland, Magilton, Reuser; Stewart (Burchill, 66), Armstrong.

Referee : R Styles.

Top of the table fixture run-in

Ipswich: Man City (h), Derby (a).

Leeds: Arsenal (a), Bradford (h), Leicester (h).

Liverpool: Bradford (a), Newcastle (h), Chelsea (h), Charlton (a).

webTitle: Pop review: The asexual appeal of Wheatus

fields.headline: The asexual appeal of Wheatus
fields.standfirst:
Wheatus
Astoria, London
Rating: **
fields.trailText:
Wheatus
Astoria, London
Rating: **
fields.body:
You wonder why Wheatus try so hard. Singer and guitarist Brendan B Brown races around the stage, shaking his sweat-drenched hair, and the kids in the audience jump up and down, trying to breathe and scream simultaneously. But they've been screaming ever since the lights went down. Wheatus are in the rarefied position of making their first trip to Britain following the success of their debut single, Teenage Dirtbag, a hymn to the geek getting the girl. It's a visit bathed in glory and Brown can't quite believe it. "Thanks for making us number one in your charts. We won't forget it," he says. Nor will we, as he throws platitudes our way, using that deferential, wide-eyed US charm to erode any misgivings about the music.

The songs are fun and quirky, but Wheatus know they've hit on a successful formula and continuously endeavour to repeat it. At the same time, they take bizarre pains to make each song a little different: percussionist and all-round entertainer Phil A Juinenez offers some frantic banjo-picking here, a balalaika there and a frenzied attack on a poor, unsuspecting accordion.

Not that the frighteningly young audience notice the variety of instrumentation. They just like the sunny and shouty sound of songs such as Leroy, typical of the pop-rock college radio fodder that Wheatus churn out. It's the familiarity they love. Wheatus songs are like John Hughes movies with guns and crack instead of saccharine morality, matched to an AC/DC-meets-Britney melody.

Love Is a Mutt from Hell is the story of a dysfunctional relationship, with a couple whining - something Brown, with his nasal voice, was born to do - about the fact that each one knows when the other pees. Sunshine threatens: "There's a rocket I built, it's under my kilt, it's coming to blow you away." But despite the bravado, Wheatus are a completely asexual band - and this is part of their appeal. Whether it's Brown reminding fans to bring tape recorders to their shows ("You pay for this, you might as well take something home with you," he sweetly says), or Juinenez throwing himself off the drum riser, Wheatus are here to entertain.

Teenage Dirtbag is the highlight, but new single A Little Respect, a cover of Erasure's 1980s hit, is great too. It makes the mums and dads here smile, amused as heavy drums and speeding guitars replace the disco beat they know. The kids, meanwhile, scream on.

Wheatus play Newcastle University (0191-261 2602) tonight and the Leadmill, Sheffield (0114-221 2828), tomorrow.

webTitle: Comedy review: Ardal O'Hanlon exorcises Father Dougal

fields.headline: Ardal O'Hanlon exorcises Father Dougal
fields.standfirst:
Ardal O'Hanlon
City Varieties, Leeds
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Ardal O'Hanlon
City Varieties, Leeds
Rating: ***
fields.body:
Just as people think of John Cleese as Basil Fawlty, it's impossible to see Ardal O'Hanlon without remembering him as Father Dougal, the eejit priest in Father Ted. O'Hanlon has tried hard to exorcise the eejit. He's written a dark, complex novel, Talk of the Town, attempted comedy drama with the flop Big Bad World, and again returns to stand-up. Desperate to escape his Father, O'Hanlon bounds on stage at City Varieties in a decidedly un-Catholic, outsize tartan suit. It doesn't work. You can almost hear the audience thinking: "Why is Father Dougal wearing a horrible big suit?"

To his credit, O'Hanlon could have any audience in raptures just with a five-minute stint as the daft priest, but he refuses to compromise. Stand-up is where he started, and stand-up may be where he'll one day finish, since there'll always be a demand for a certain type of self-mocking Irish joke. There are jokes about Irish boy bands, jokes about Irish morbidity, and a very funny one about discovering a lost tribe of Irishmen in the Amazon jungle. O'Hanlon is certainly entitled to his indulgence, but perhaps he reaches a bit too quickly for the safety net of jokes about his homeland.

Although O'Hanlon is brilliantly analytical on marriage and casual sex, he tends to coast. He has the classic, mildly agitated conversational delivery of many a great Irish comic, but it's wasted on mundane subjects such as hotels. More promisingly, he tackles genetic modification and the pace of modern life, but unlike watching, for instance, Ed Byrne, you don't feel you've learned anything or had your preconceptions challenged. Ardal has more in his locker - lest we forget, he campaigned for Danny McNamee, wrongly imprisoned for the Hyde Park bombing. But having achieved mainstream success, he seems reluctant to test the boundaries of a mainstream audience.

Perhaps this is getting him down. Occasionally he seems thoroughly lost for words - "I don't know what to say . . . you can probably tell" - and his act triggers laughter rather than uproar. Perhaps Ardal could do with some spiritual guidance. At least heaven has sent an excellent support act: Will Smith plays a sexually frustrated, socially inadequate "posh boy" with wonderful aplomb.

Ardal O'Hanlon plays Derngate, Northampton (01604 624811), tonight, then tours.

fields.headline: Monkey goes to Montreux
fields.standfirst: Monkey awards an alternative gongs to the badly behaved hacks and PRs who made the annual pilgrimage to Montreux
fields.trailText: Monkey awards an alternative gongs to the badly behaved hacks and PRs who made the annual pilgrimage to Montreux.
fields.body:
Another year, another set of awards from the chocolate-box setting of Montreux in Switzerland. While Lenny Henry can bask in the glory of his Golden Rose this morning, lesser delegates at the festival can content themselves with Monkey's own set of gongs.

For those unfamiliar with the Rose D'Or festival, it is an annual pilgrimage for lig-starved hacks and PRs to an eighth-floor suite of the Intercontinental, the swish hotel overlooking Lake Geneva, where the flow of beer is only matched by the flow of showbiz flannel.

The Michael Barrymore award for self-restraint goes to Times media correspondent Paul "mine's a pint" McCann. After a lunchtime booze-up with top media contacts (well, all right, the Channel 5 press office) McCann stumbled into ITV's Popstars press briefing a little too refreshed. McCann filled a gap in the questioning with this gem lobbed at the bemused band members: "Is there a dark side," he inquired, mysteriously. It later turned out that McCann had meant to ask about the "down side" of fame, which disappoints Monkey, who had been looking forward to that Times photo spread: "Popstars - the parallel universe."

Staying with a musical theme, the Geri Halliwell award for self-importance goes to Myleene from Popstars, whose enthusiasm for fame knows no rivals. Describing the highlights of her celebrated status, she told of the fans who had camped outside the Hear'Say home in north London. "It's like a mini-Graceland," she said. You see, this is what one No1 record does to your sense of proportion.

The Robbie Coltrane award for worst piece of hotel-room misbehaviour goes to the TV team who frightened the fish in Lake Geneva with carefully-aimed beer bottles projected from the balcony eight floors up in the Royal Plaza. Apparently in memory of the year Coltrane threw his television set out of his window, one group of badly-behaved PRs launched a competition to see how far into the lake they could aim their empty receptacles. No-one owned up the next day, but Channel 5 chief spokesman Paul Leatherissued this statement to staff: "The hotel management team complained about bottles being thrown into the lake from the 8th floor suite. Not only is it dangerous, but it is illegal. I assured them that it didn't happen but if it did, I was the best."

The Victor Meldrew award for miserable behaviour goes to Angus Deayton. After accepting an invitation by the BBC to travel to a delightful mountainside restaurant for dinner with executives, other telly stars and assorted hacks, Mr Deayton declared his disapproval of the seating arrangements and refused to be placed with The Sun's Emily Smith. He then sat by the wall, flanked by two BBC executives and failed to be witty, warm or engaging to anyone who dared to come anywhere near him.

Lifelong achievement award for services to smoothies - stand up Nigel "the charmer" Havers. Not only did he remember everyone's first name, the newspaper they worked for and their shoe size, but he left the dinner organised by the BBC by indulging several female journalists' fantasies with a lingering smacker. "We were all wafting in a cloud of hormones," said one delirious hackette. Angus Deayton, watch and learn.

The Anne Robinson award for talking about your salary goes to the Daily Mail showbusiness editor Alison Boshoff who surprised everyone at a press conference when she accepted Johnny Vaughan's challenge to reveal her own salary. "I am on seventy-two and a half thousand and worth every penny of it," she beamed to the baffled star. Vaughan still refused to talk numbers while other hacks gasped in awe. But one did break ranks. "Alison," he gushed admiringly, "you are worth far more than that." Is Alan Yentob planning a dawn raid? Monkey should be told.

The Uriah Heep award for sycophancy is awarded collectively to the BBC. As Johnny Vaughan arrived in the eighth floor suite for his press conference he was followed by 12, yes 12, corporation executives. The most star-struck was drama and entertainment supremo Alan Yentob, who could barely contain his enthusiasm for the newly signed big-money presenter, patting his shoulder repeatedly. Just remember, this is the man who only a few years ago branded Frank Skinner greedy for demanding, er, lots of money.

The Alan Yentob award for forgetfulness goes to ....Alan Yentob. When he presented his passport at the airport upon departure for Geneva, he was met with a bemused look. "I see you've changed sex since the last time you were here," the official said. Surprise, surprise Yentob had, of course, taken his wife's passport to the airport.

A special Pride of Britain award for LWT's countess of spin Zoe McIntyre, who (literally) jumped off the side of a mountain in a para-glider, as part of a PR stunt to promote Claire Sweeney's new ITV show. Surely this was taking the job a little too seriously, especially when like McIntyre you are afraid of heights and afraid of flying.

The 'we're just good friends' award goes to Graham Norton who brought Castaway star Ben Fogle to the Brit awards earlier this year prompting speculation of a courtship. The Channel 4 star explained how they were simply worlds apart. "When we were spotted I turrned to him and said 'you too are on stage'. And he turned round and said, 'U2, golly, they are just the cat's pyjamas'." It must have been that year on Taransay. Either that or a nasty knock on the head, Ben.

And the award for brass neck goes to the customs lady at City Airport who apprehended three hackettes - two from the Sun and one from Monkeyland on their return from Montreux. "Are you aware of the kinds of things you are not allowed bring from one country to another?" she enquired. "Yes," replied one, naturally thinking of the repeated warnings about foot and mouth, "Food". Wrong answer. "No... drugs and firearms," she snarled, after a pause to much hilarity. After forensic tests on all luggage, computers and Toblerones proved fruitless, she had to let them go.

And finally, a return to Angus Deayton who left Montreux before he could officially be told his Have I Got News for You show had lost out to Lenny Henry, Anne Robinson, Popstars and everything elese. Unwittingly, he ended up in the vicinity of journalists once again on his plane home, one of whom overheard him say this: "Well it must have been very difficult for foreign juries to understand even with subtitles, because everyone talks over the top of each other". Yes, Angus, yes.

fields.headline: Recall
fields.standfirst:
Alhambra Studio, Bradford
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Alhambra Studio, Bradford
Rating: ****
fields.body:
She winds her leg up the pole like a creeper up a trellis, then hangs upside down and whips off her bra, breasts defying gravity thanks to silicone. If Gypsy Rose Lee turned striptease into an artform then Soho pole artist Ninon gives contemporary choreography a new dimension in Darshan Singh Bhuller's latest dance drama, which looks at the lives of two Asian men hooked on strip clubs.

Bhuller believes in total immersion for his Singh Productions, and he has been trawling New York clubs to find out why women strip. The result is a thought-provoking piece originally sparked off by the case of an Asian wife who was jailed for killing her brutal husband but later freed after a women's rights campaign.

fields.headline: Maurizio Pollini
fields.standfirst:
Royal Festival Hall, London
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Royal Festival Hall, London
Rating: ****
fields.body:
Both of Maurizio Pollini's recitals this season in London have included Schumann - the Davidsbundlertanze and the F minor Sonata last autumn, the early Allegro Op 8 and Kreisleriana here. It's music that brings out the best in him; where his approach to some parts of the repertory can be dour, he finds a sense of adventure in Schumann, and fresh corners of his output to explore.

Hardly anyone plays the Allegro in concert nowadays. It is all that was completed of a projected B minor Sonata, and shows the young composer trying to reconcile three different tendencies in his music - freewheeling invention, flashy display and the rigour of a classical sonata form. It's not entirely successful, but Pollini provided all the clarity it needs, unerringly identifying those moments when Schumann's own voice emerges from the whirl of figuration and strenuous thematic working, and turning them into uncomplicated poetry.

Kreisleriana balances form and lyrical content well-nigh perfectly, and this reading did not try to tip the scales either way: the bone structure of each of the eight pieces was effortlessly clear, the pacing nearly always faultless. The extrovert numbers had all the necessary athleticism and some magical transitions; the introspective ones were just occasionally pushed too hard, but in the fourth piece they also found themselves in dark territory, and in the sixth in an almost trance-like self-contemplation. Perhaps an element of fantasy was missing, though: Schumann's imagination was not allowed to fly quite as freely as it can.

The score of Kreisleriana was dedicated in 1838 to Chopin, who returned the compliment the following year with the second of his Ballades. Pollini played all four of them, with the Op 45 Prelude in C sharp minor as a palate-cleansing hors d'oeuvre. Each contained things to admire. In the First there was the sleight-of-hand to sneak in the second subject and the cumulative power of its dramatic climax; the furious eruption of the second theme in the Second made the contrast with its innocent opening complete. In the Third, the symbiosis of the two main themes was made to seem the most natural thing in the world, while all the constituent parts of the Fourth were welded into a seamless unity, every detail under immaculate technical control.

A version of this review appeared in later editions of yesterday's paper.

webTitle: Opera review: Bicycle races and suicide at ENO

fields.headline: Bicycle races and suicide at ENO
fields.standfirst:
From Morning to Midnight
Coliseum, London
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
From Morning to Midnight
Coliseum, London
Rating: ***
fields.body:
Sooner or later David Sawer was bound to write an opera. His instrumental music has such a sense of drama and vivid imagery that it always seems to be enacting some unrevealed piece of theatre, some unspoken plot. Now English National Opera has offered him the chance to show what he can do. The result is From Morning to Midnight, adapted by the composer from a play by the German expressionist Georg Kaiser, and given its premiere here.

The canvas Sawer has given himself is ambitious: the cast is large, with many doublings, there's a full chorus and an orchestra bolstered with all manner of percussion. Yet the story itself is a slender one. It depicts the tragic mid-life crisis of a bank cashier who, having become infatuated with a mysterious Italian lady, steals all the money from his till and embarks on a day-long descent into suicide that takes him via a bicycle race and a nightclub to his death in a Salvation Army hall.

There is, though, plenty of incident, to which the orchestral music at least responds ingeniously; there are some brilliantly imagined devices, sonorities that seem totally fresh and pertinent. But the same score would support a silent movie equally effectively, especially one as intelligently directed as this staging by Richard Jones. When the voices enter there is a real sense of anticlimax, for Sawer's flat vocal writing cannot carry convincing expressive weight.

As a result, none of the characters has any inner life: even the Cashier is little more than a cipher, and his big solo scene, when he delivers a nihilistic credo, fails to register an emotional impact. Everything is distanced, and the irony (and jokes) wear thin far too soon. There is only just over 100 minutes of music, but the proportioning is uncertain and the final three scenes really sprawl - there are too many bicycle races, too many nightclub hostesses, too many souls saved.

ENO has done the piece proud, however. Jones's production, in contemporary settings by Stewart Laing, is full of telling detail - it's reassuring to see a new opera getting the best possible support from its director - and the cast maximise what they are given. John Daszak as the Cashier works hard to make his character into a flesh-and-blood human being, while Kathryn Harries is suitably exotic as the Italian Lady, and Linda Kitchen and Susan Bickley are both outstanding in their multiple roles. None of them, though, can really get their teeth into their parts; only Martyn Brabbins, who conducts the work with impressive assurance, has something substantial to work with.

In rep until May 15. Box office: 020-7632 8300. A version of this review appeared in later editions of Saturday's paper.

fields.headline: The networker
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Work
fields.trailText: Timesheet: Actor's agent
fields.body:
Timesheet: Actor's agent

Lee Moone, 37, actor member of booking co-operative, London

8:30am: Gets up, has a cup of tea and gets ready for work.

9:00: Leaves the house, catches bus and tube.

10:35: Arrives at office in east London. Grabs a coffee and checks the fax machine for messages from casting directors. It's mostly junk mail this morning, but there's one about a car commercial in Paris. Neil, a member of Lee's co-op, fits the description so he faxes back his details.

10:40: Checks the Castweb website for information about castings and productions this week. Reads PCR, a printed list of all the productions that are going on.

12:00: Takes a call from an agent offering Chloe, another member of the co-op, a touring job with a children's theatre starting in Birmingham next week. Rings to see if she wants the job. She does.

12:30pm: Rings Clare at the casting department at The Bill to see if there are any castings this week. "Nothing."

1:10: Jacket potato for lunch from the cafe outside the office. "It's bit quieter between one and two because the casting directors are at lunch. We catch up on admin. There are 17 people in the co-operative so we all take turns to run the office one day a week."

2:15: Isabel, a colleague, arranges interviews for prospective new members who want to join the co-op. "We're looking for older actors at the moment because we need to have a good cross-section of of people - it makes us more marketable."

3:45: Excitement. Rachel's cheque has arrived for a part she played in Family Affairs on Channel 5. "Actors pay their subscriptions to the co-op on commission, or a flat fee. The cheque is made out to the co-op, so I run down to the bank before it closes and write Rachel a cheque."

5:00: Takes a call from Richmond theatre. Someone has called in sick and they need a person to crew backstage for a show. Lee agrees to do it - "I'm a bit short of money this week."

5:50: Getting ready to leave the office, when an urgent call comes in for a casting for a Maltesers commercial first thing tomorrow morning. Sends off Jackie and Josie's details, then rings them to make sure they are available.

6:01: Late for the train so has to leave Isabel to lock up the office. Dashes for the train to Richmond. Gets there just in time before the show starts.

10:00: Show finishes. "I could go home, but I'll hang around a bit until the rest of the crew finish to have a drink or six with them."

12:10am: Arrives home exhausted and falls asleep on the sofa.
Interview by Laura Milne

Pay check: What you can be for £60,000

 Chief executive, Royal Naval Museum, Portsmouth

 Assistant MD, chain of UK sex shops

 Physiotherapist, private health club, Lancashire

 Chairman/woman, Equal Opportunities Commission

 Anti-hacking expert, Reading

 Head of external relations, Greater London Authority

On the radar: Guilding the lily

Describing a company's business practices as "medieval" will soon be a compliment, according to Professor Thomas Malone, of Massachusetts Institute of Technology. He argues that 13th-century-style guilds could be the modern worker's best hope in an era of declining union power. There is a model for his vision of loose affiliations of new-economy workers banding together to get health benefits, employment rights and cheaper insurance - the "new guild" Working Today. So: wage-bargaining will be off the menu, but at least the Worshipful Company of Java Developers will get to wear glamorous robes and be given the freedom of the city of Solihull. Ah, progress.

Debunker: Holy professional

If you, like so very many of us, are wondering what the hot-diggety to do with all those loaves and fishes stacking up on your desk, then here is the answer to your prayers. Jesus, Inc: The Visionary Path: An Entrepreneur's Guide to True Success by, of course, Laurie Beth Jones. She (blonde, apple-cheeked, crocodile-smiled) has made a fortune (a chunk of which she has ploughed into an orphanage in Mexico. Obviously) penning a variety of helpful, ecclesiastically enhanced manuals with titles such as Jesus in Blue Jeans and Jesus, CEO.

Her theory? Why be an entrepreneur, when you can be a "spiritreneur"? Why indeed. Jones (let's call her LBJ - everybody else does) encourages her readers to look at the management approach of Jesus Christ. By taking inspiration from the scriptures, we can all bring a bit of spirituality into the workplace. There will be plenty of fishing boats, vineyards and days when the vending machine coffee magically turns into vino verde. Won't there? Frankly, Charles Harvey, who is head of communications at the Institute of Professional Managers, is doubtful. "You would have to think George Bush was a great and glamorous president to believe that sort of approach to management," he says. Debunker fears for the future of the American people.

fields.headline: Surge in mortgage lending
fields.trailText: Mortgage lending has surged to record levels as homebuyers rush to take advantage of lower interest rates and the competitive home loan deals on the market.
fields.body:
Mortgage lending has surged to record levels as homebuyers rush to take advantage of lower interest rates and the competitive home loan deals on the market.

An unprecedented £6.5bn worth of loans for house purchase were approved by the big British banks in March - 53% up on February's £4.2bn, it was disclosed yesterday. The number of remortgages -where borrowers move their home loan to another lender - was also "spectacularly high", said the British Bankers' Association.

The figures coincided with new data from Nationwide building society showing house prices rose 0.8% in April. But the society also disclosed that the annual rate of house price growth has fallen to its lowest level for more than four years, largely as a result of the slowdown which gripped the property market for much of last year.

The BBA said about 85,100 loans for house purchase were approved in March, compared with 56,900 in February, while the number of remortgages jumped 39% to 56,400.

Spring is traditionally the peak home-buying season but BBA director general Tim Sweeney said the new figures suggested levels of demand well in excess of the usual seasonal upturn.

"With falling interest rates and lower variable rate mortgages from banks, customers are now being presented with more attractive financing options and this must be driving activity in the mortgage market," he added.

The strong upswing in the mortgage market is expected to last for several months, particularly as the latest figures do not take into account April's base rate reduction, which will have further improved affordability.

Nationwide said the picture was upbeat, reporting that house prices rose in April for the third time in four months. The 0.8% rise translates into a £38 a day increase for the average homeowner and lifted the average price tag to £86,244.

A spokesman said the typical UK property now costs 6.6% more than a year ago - the lowest annual rate of price growth since August 1996 and down on this time last year, when house price inflation was running at 17.5%.

fields.headline: Barclays to cut overdraft rate
fields.trailText: Barclays is planning to cut the overdraft rate on its current account next month for the first time in five years.
fields.body:
Barclays is planning to cut the overdraft rate on its current account next month for the first time in five years.

The bank, which has some 8m current account customers, intends to cut the rate from 18.8% in June.

Martin Binder, head of current account product management, said the bank was also considering setting overdraft rates in a more personalised way rather than having a standard rate.

By deciding to cut its rate, Barclays would appear to be the first of "big four" to reduce their overdraft rate to below 18%.

New entrants into the current account market - particularly Halifax and Abbey National - have set their overdrafts at around 10% to break the traditional reluctance of bank customers to move their accounts.

NOP research, commissioned by the Halifax, found that the average customer was overdrawn for 80 days a year.

Barclays has recently introduced a new current account designed to reward "loyal" customers, which has a lower overdraft of 12%. The bank admitted yesterday that the rate for the current account used by the majority of its customers would be unlikely to fall to that level.

"Dropping interest rates from June seems overdue at the very least," said Anna Bradley at the National Consumer Council.

fields.headline: Will the other banks follow?
fields.trailText: Despite Barclays announcement that it is to cut its overdraft rate for the first time in five years, the other banks which make up the high street "big four" have no plans to follow suit.
fields.body:
Despite Barclays announcement that it is to cut its overdraft rate for the first time in five years, the other banks which make up the high street "big four" have no plans to follow suit.

Customers of HSBC, LloydsTSB and NatWest will not see any change to their overdraft rates in the near future. An HSBC spokeswoman said that, while the bank had no immediate plans to reduce its rate, it was keeping a close eye on the situation, while NatWest confirmed that everything was under review.

LloydsTSB says it will remove its £5 authorised overdraft fee from September but that its overdraft rate will remain the same. However, customers of its paid for "value added" account will benefit from a one-off waiver of charges if they accidentally become overdrawn in the first 12 months of opening an account.

Customers of value added accounts pay a monthly or annual fee for extra benefits, one of which is reduced overdraft rates. NatWest, for example, charges £150 a year for its value added account but charges customers an authorised overdraft rate of 8.9%. This is substantially lower than the 18.38% overdraft rate charged to its standard current account customers.

Speaking on the Barclays rate cut, Stuart Cliffe, chief executive of the National Association of Bank and Insurance Customers, says: While we welcome this move by Barclays we would like to see all penalty charges removed for customers becoming overdrawn. This is the case in Europe where bank customers are sent a letter without being charged. The internet banking march is bringing in a new ethos of good value banking.

webTitle: Work: How to cut on costs

fields.headline: Flowers? Who needs them?
fields.standfirst:
Greg Dyke pointed the way forward when he cut out the croissants at BBC breakfast meetings. But how else can a penny-pinching boss slash corporate costs? Tim Dowling offers 10 tips

Guardian Unlimited Work
MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Greg Dyke pointed the way forward when he cut out the croissants at BBC breakfast meetings. But how else can a penny-pinching boss slash corporate costs? Tim Dowling offers 10 tips.
fields.body:
1 Breakfast

Greg Dyke began his war on costs by banning free croissants at Television Centre, the keystone of a cost-cutting, bureaucracy-shedding programme which he claims will save the BBC £20m a year. "The purge on consultants and expenses showed we were deadly serious about shifting resources into programmes," he says. "Spurred on by the sight of piles of uneaten croissants at the end of morning meetings, I moved against the second breakfast." This seems to have been a moral as much as a practical war on waste. He doesn't seem as upset by the free croissants as he is by the fact that no one was eating them. Perhaps they should have bought nicer ones.

2 Travel

The height of corporate excess has always been the corporate jet, a dubious necessity. A new light jet costs between £3m and £4m, and then you have to hire hangar space and a bloke to stand around polishing it all day. Greg Hutchings, former chief of the Tompkins group, was forced to resign last year when it was revealed that the company had no less than four corporate jets on standby to take him to his holiday home in Portugal.

3 Plants and flowers

"If people want fresh flowers on their desks then they can pay for them," says Dyke, a man who we can only hope never retires to set up a south coast B&B. Dyke's allergic reaction notwithstanding, many corporations routinely spend thousands on brightening up the soulless towers in which their employees toil.

Perhaps the most famous gratuitous leafy extravagance was last year's decision to decorate the ground floor of the new parliamentary office block, Portcullis House with 12 full-grown fig trees from Florida, at a cost of £30,000 per year. It's true - the trees are rented. It sounds like an awful lot of money to pay for the mere proximity of a dozen trees, especially when you realise that the same result could have been achieved with a packet of seeds, some dirt and a little patience.

4 Heat and light

How much does it cost to leave the lights on all night in your gigantic multistorey HQ? What about leaving them on in selected offices so that from a distance they form the shape of a Christmas tree, or your logo? Is this a good idea? Does it boost morale at companies where employees frequently receive memos telling them that if they want flowers on their desk they can pay for them?

5 Art

The art that hangs in foyers and on boardroom walls has to come from somewhere, and it doesn't come cheap. British Fine Art offers quality 19th-century portraits and landscapes to corporate clients "in order to motivate staff" as well as "conveying the required corporate image". Figures on a Bridge in the Mountain Valley, by Edmund John Niemann, is on offer for £12,000, so kitting out the boardroom, the corporate dining room and the employee smoking lounge with motivational art could put a serious dent in the company finances. Of course, you can always lease your paintings as if they were trees, making it possible to convey the right corporate image right up until the money runs out.

6 Magicians

There are no figures on how much the taxpayer shells out every year for conjuring-related expenses, but just last week Scotland Yard announced its decision to hire a magician to teach senior officers leadership skills. There may seem to be a difficult logical leap in such a concept, until you remember that good leadership is all about being able to do the cut-and-restored-rope trick without looking at your hands. This ingenious training course, entitled the Magic of Networking, would save the police £6,000 if it could be made to disappear suddenly.

7 Paper clips

Millions are spent on paper clips in corporate Britain, yet when you give them up for Lent you hardly notice the difference. According to recent figures from Visa, British businesses spend almost £30bn a year on low-value workplace supplies (such as paper clips, Sellotape and staples). There are tremendous savings to be made across the whole spectrum of office supplies, from staples to computers, and not just by forcing employees to do without. A new business known as e-procurement, whereby corporate purchasing is automated, centralised, rationalised and transacted entirely online looks set to save corporations trillions over the next few years. The national audit office has claimed that the civil service alone could save up to a billion pounds annually if it were to "fully embrace" electronic purchasing.

8 Team-building exercises

A growing phenomenon which uncomfortably straddles the line between training programme and Christmas piss-up, the corporate team-building weekend is generally budgeted as training rather than hospitality, based on the odd belief that two days of running around an assault course is somehow analogous to selling pension funds.

Motivation offers such exotic team building exercises as a week spent on patrol with the NYPD and an "Escape From Colditz" re-enactment. Clients include Gillette UK, Prudential and SmithKline Beecham, but more often than not one ends up trying to build a raft in a downpour with the help of dysfunctional colleagues from human resources. A sign that team-building weekends might not be all fun and games is the fact that higher-ups rarely feel obliged to attend. "You don't usually get upper management attending these things," says Scott Thomson of CTB-UK, which offers three-day team-building courses in Scotland at a cost of £450 per head.

9 Rebranding

As well as spending huge sums sending employees to "project review" meetings, which include heli-skiing, companies such as Andersen Consulting fork out millions to change their names to made up words like Accenture, so that everyone can criticise them for it. Obviously it is money well spent, although it is not obvious why. The Post Office has changed its name to Consignia, British Airways changed its tailfins and then changed them back again, and even the penny-pinching Dyke has just called for the BBC to lose its "Auntie Beeb" image. It is not clear how he will do it but you can bet it won't be free.

10 Chairmen/women

They are expensive to procure and even more expensive to get rid of. In addition to a £2.2m signing fee and £10.4m in share options, Marks & Spencer's chairman, Luc Vandevelde, is now to receive a further £650,000 for his first year's work, just as a thank you for presiding over the company's steady decline. At this point it is probably cheaper to keep him, but when he does go, M & S will almost certainly go right out and get itself another chairman. From where most of us are standing, these multi-million pound rent-a-suit figureheads are more or less interchangeable. Who needs them?

webTitle: Pop review: South Africa Freedom Day

fields.headline: South Africa Freedom Day
fields.standfirst:
Trafalgar Square
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Trafalgar Square
Rating: ***
fields.body:
In the middle of our squalid pre-election debate about racism, it was astounding to hear some words of praise for Britain from Nelson Mandela. Introduced by Tony "Photo Opportunity" Blair (who had taken his tie off to appear more democratic), Mandela stood on the Trafalgar Square stage on a cool, drizzly evening and offered a glimpse of a time when politicians used to be statesmen. "I am a proud and happy person to be here with the British people," he said. "A British people who have travelled the road to freedom with us."

Mandela's greatest gift may be his ability to banish cynicism from his immediate vicinity. This can have its drawbacks, such as reducing MC Mark Lamarr to a state of blathering sycophancy, but it did mean that the whole Freedom Day shebang passed off in an atmosphere of benign celebration. Not even the partial collapse of the stage, which held up proceedings for 40 minutes, could prevent the festivities from marching steadily to their pre-ordained climax.

However, it did mean that many artists had their performances drastically curtailed. No bad thing, in some cases. Atomic Kitten were restricted to the solitary You Can Make Me Whole Again, while one dance routine from Mel B was one and a half too many. Luckily, a sense of impending anticlimax was averted by headliners REM, whose 35-minute set conveyed a suitable sense of occasion.

Presumably not even the marketing might of Warner Bros records could claim credit for enlisting Mandela's support in launching the band's imminent new album, Reveal, but it was a gilt-edged opportunity to preview some new songs. Imitation of Life flashed back to a poppy, 1960s-ish REM, while the big beat of The Lifting underpinned resonant, stirring choruses. Audiophiles would have been aghast at Trafalgar Square's acoustics but, from quiet beginnings, She Just Wants To Be swelled to mini-epic proportions.

The punters, however, wanted singalong hits. The Great Beyond went over well enough, but the crowd didn't really start leaping up and down until they played Losing My Religion, featuring rock'n'roll madman Peter Buck on mandolin. For a finale they unleashed a souped-up Man on the Moon, garnished with Michael Stipe's idiosyncratic pastiche of Elvis Presley. A proper tour soon, chaps?

fields.headline: Young Dunn stuns Portsmouth
fields.trailText: Midfielder David Dunn was the driving force that helped Blackburn come from behind to the verge of a return to the Premiership.
fields.body:
David Dunn yesterday took the opportunity to emphasise just why he is regarded as one of the brightest young talents in the English game. And the tireless midfielder produced a display that put Blackburn on the verge of a return to the Premiership after two seasons.

Dunn, Blackburn born and bred and a product of the club's youth scheme, was the complete driving force as his team overcame the shock of falling behind to relegation-threatened Portsmouth to take all three points.

Graeme Souness, Blackburn's manager, has often complained that his team's demanding supporters can unnerve his players. The mood of the crowd yesterday was certainly not improved when Portsmouth were rewarded for their early dominance with a goal in the 12th minute.

Pompey, needing a victory to help escape the clutches of relegation, started with more zest and Mike Panopoulos's opening goal was well deserved. Jamie Vincent's cross from the left evaded the head of Craig Short and Panopoulos was left alone in the six-yard box to control the ball and poke it beneath Brad Friedel.

The ghostly silence was broken by the cheers of the small visiting contingent and, more than likely, a roar 15 miles down the A666 in Bolton.

Blackburn responded by pushing Portsmouth back and Craig Hignett, operating in the unfamiliar role of left wing-back, forced Andy Petterson to tip a 20-yard shot behind for a corner less than a minute later.

It was clear from his performance, though, that Dunn is as desperate as anyone to be a Premiership player next season. Displaying the box-to-box energy personified by Bryan Robson in his pomp, the England Under-21 captain twice saw long-range efforts go agonisingly close to equalising. A 30-yard drive struck the Portsmouth crossbar, and a lob from the edge of the area narrowly missed the target.

Blackburn thought that they had finally overcome Portsmouth's resistance just after the half-hour when their captain Garry Flitcroft scored from close range after Petterson dropped Damien Johnson's cross. However, the referee ruled that the goal keeper had been fouled by Flitcroft and the goal was quite rightly disallowed.

Blackburn's supporters were displaying little of the patience asked of them by Souness, but the steady pressure that forced Portsmouth further and further into their own half suggested that an equaliser would materialise eventually.

Just after the hour it finally came, Mark Hughes scoring one of the few tap-ins of his lengthy career. Berkovic's cross into the six-yard box was out of Petterson's reach and the Wales manager beat Dunn to the ball to record his sixth league goal for Blackburn.

Dunn was not to be denied the goal that he deserved, however. Once more he made a burst from centre circle before squaring to Berkovic level with the penalty spot.

The Israeli's shot was well saved by Petterson but the ball broke to Dunn, who scored from a narrow angle. It virtually made the game safe, but Marcus Bent ensured that the fans would have a comfortable final five minutes when he made it three from Matt Jansen's deflected pass.

"It was one of those games you know you're going to win," Souness said. "It's not the first time this year we've had to roll our sleeves up and work hard. I just felt if we kept knocking at the door we would eventually get our reward. And once we got the equaliser we always felt we would get another one."

Graham Rix, the visiting manager, was not too down-hearted as he faces the prospect of lifting his players for an absolute crunch match with Crystal Palace at Fratton Park. "I thought we did well and I couldn't ask for more from the boys, really. There were a few dejected lads in the dressing room but hopefully they have already started picking themselves up for the Palace game on Wednesday.

"If we keep the same attitude we've shown in the last three games, then we'll be OK," he added. "I still think we're more than capable of staying up and I'm more than confident that we'll get out of this situation."

The money spent on Blackburn's youth academy has been made worthwhile by the emergence of Dunn as a midfielder of true quality.

Best moment : Created his second-half goal from nothing, exploding from midfield, setting up Berkovic and being alert enough to follow up the rebound. It dragged Blackburn back into a game that had drifted from them.

fields.headline: Smith sacked as drop looms
fields.trailText: Alan Smith, the Crystal Palace manager, after being pelted with boos and season-ticket stubs as he left the field on Saturday, was sacked yesterday. It is the culmination of a disastrous run that began with six defeats in a row and now shows a haul of six points from 13 games.
fields.body:
Alan Smith, the Crystal Palace manager, after being pelted with boos and season-ticket stubs as he left the field on Saturday, was sacked yesterday. It is the culmination of a disastrous run that began with six defeats in a row and now shows a haul of six points from 13 games.

Palace have no room for manoeuvre but clearly the chairman Simon Jordan is anxious to exercise the little bit left to him. Palace will probably have to win their last two games to avoid leaving the top two divisions for the first time since 1977. Even then there is no guarantee, but shock treatment might help.

Smith's assistant Ray Houghton has gone, too, and Steve Kember, the chief scout, will take temporary charge. In the long run Steve Coppell may return for a fifth stint; the crowd chanted for him on Saturday. But the defender Dean Austin, reacting to Smith's dismissal, said: "Something had to be done. The players have not done what they needed to in the last few months."

In mid-February Palace were mid-table, basking on the back of a run to the Worthington semi-finals. Smith, tempted from his job as Fulham's academy director in August, had stopped the early rot of two wins in 15 games. In his first term of Palace office he took them to the Premiership. For most of the past 24 years they have been called a yo-yo side. Now the cord looks set to snap.

Jordan, who bought the club in July for £10.5m and stands to lose £5m by relegation, admits to misjudgment of the task and mistakes since. He made his money in mobile phones; he is losing it, to his own and fans' consternation, in a downwardly mobile club.

In an emotional interview on Palace TV before the match he said he "came in swinging". Seven games ago, he said, it was almost Smith who swung. Yesterday it was, and on Wednesday, at Portsmouth, or Sunday, it is likely to be the club. "This is the excuse season," said Jordan, though he never thought it would come to this.

Both men talked a better game than the side could produce under pressure. Smith had noted with pleasure some of his players at Fulham last week watching Wolves "of their own volition". Little good it did them. Palace won on mascots - two eagles to a wolf - and played like them too - bright-tailed and bushy-eyed.

Poor clearance of their lines enabled Andy Sinton's astute chip for Wolves' lead and, after both sides had adjusted to Keith Andrews's sending-off, Adam Proudlock escaped three defenders for the second.

Beforehand Michael Oakes tipped away Aki Riihilahti's drive. Between times David Hopkin, once a hero, never lightning, tried to strike twice. Afterwards Palace pressed frantically. But Smith conceded: "The game summed up our season: lots of play and chances, lack of nous and quality, shambolic defending."

He accepted the buck stops with him but added: "I could do without what I had to put up with this afternoon. Something has to come from inside. The mentality in the club is not strong. Players need to look at themselves."

The National Census does not ask about mirrors but for weeks Palace's future has looked a close shave. On Saturday there was only five o'clock shadow.

Man of the match: Michael Oakes (Wolves).

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to football.editor@guardianunlimited.co.uk

Palace will probably have to win their last two games to avoid leaving the top two divisions for the first time since 1977. Even then there is no guarantee, but shock treatment might help. Smith's assistant Ray Houghton has gone, too, and Steve Kember, the chief scout, will take temporary charge. In the long run Steve Coppell may return for a fifth stint; the crowd chanted for him on Saturday. But the defender Dean Austin, reacting to Smith's dismissal, said: "Something had to be done. The players have not done what they needed to in the last few months." In mid-February Palace were mid-table, basking on the back of a run to the Worthington semi-finals. Smith, tempted from his job as Fulham's academy director in August, had stopped the early rot of two wins in 15 games. In his first term of Palace office he took them to the Premiership. For most of the past 24 years they have been called a yo-yo side. Now the cord looks set to snap. Jordan, who bought the club in July for £10.5m and stands to lose £5m by relegation, admits to misjudgment of the task and mistakes since. He made his money in mobile phones; he is losing it, to his own and fans' consternation, in a downwardly mobile club. In an emotional interview on Palace TV before the match he said he "came in swinging". Seven games ago, he said, it was almost Smith who swung. Yesterday it was, and on Wednesday, at Portsmouth, or Sunday, it is likely to be the club. "This is the excuse season," said Jordan, though he never thought it would come to this. Both men talked a better game than the side could produce under pressure. Smith had noted with pleasure some of his players at Fulham last week watching Wolves "of their own volition". Little good it did them. Palace won on mascots - two eagles to a wolf - and played like them too - bright-tailed and bushy-eyed. Poor clearance of their lines enabled Andy Sinton's astute chip for Wolves' lead and, after both sides had adjusted to Keith Andrews's sending-off, Adam Proudlock escaped three defenders for the second. Beforehand Michael Oakes tipped away Aki Riihilahti's drive. Between times David Hopkin, once a hero, never lightning, tried to strike twice. Afterwards Palace pressed frantically. But Smith conceded: "The game summed up our season: lots of play and chances, lack of nous and quality, shambolic defending." He accepted the buck stops with him but added: "I could do without what I had to put up with this afternoon. Something has to come from inside. The mentality in the club is not strong. Players need to look at themselves." The National Census does not ask about mirrors but for weeks Palace's future has looked a close shave. On Saturday there was only five o'clock shadow. Man of the match: Michael Oakes (Wolves).  You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to football.editor@guardianunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Ricketts on the money to keep low-budget Bolton wondering
fields.trailText: Money had little bearing on football when Bolton last enjoyed a league victory at Oakwell way back in 1908 and this modern-day result for Sam Allardyce's team could prove that, even in this day and age, finances are still no guarantee of success.
fields.body:
Money had little bearing on football when Bolton last enjoyed a league victory at Oakwell way back in 1908 and this modern-day result for Sam Allardyce's team could prove that, even in this day and age, finances are still no guarantee of success.

In the week that Manchester United broke the British transfer record by spending £19m on Ruud van Nistlerooy, Bolton edged a step closer to competing with the Premiership champions next season with this hard-fought win against mid-table Barnsley.

Considering that Allardyce has taken his side to third place in the First Division after selling half of the team that reached the FA Cup semi-final last season, the Bolton manager has worked a footballing miracle.

The enforced sales of leading players like Eidur Gudjohnsen, Claus Jensen and Mark Fish raised almost £10m, but Allardyce has spent less than a tenth of that on replacements.

Michael Ricketts cost £250,000 from Walsall last summer, but his 18th league goal of the season against Barnsley gave Bolton a club-record 13th away win of the season and guaranteed them a top-three finish.

It may not be enough to help Bolton to take the second automatic promotion spot off Blackburn in the final week of the season, but the man ager's achievement in taking his club this far is already a great one.

"We now have 83 points and that's an achievement in itself," Allardyce said. "Ever since the start of the season I have had to pick up cast-offs from other clubs in order to get people in.

"Players like Nicky Summerbee and Matt Clarke came to me without playing for three months, but I had to throw them straight into the team. They have both played major parts in getting us to where we are, though.

"Breaking the club record for away wins is a great feat, but it will mean nothing if we don't go up. All I hope now is that we can go into the final game of the season against Sheffield United at the Reebok with a chance."

Blackburn could already have secured promotion to the Premiership by then if Bolton lose at Wolves on Tuesday night or Rovers triumph at Preston 24 hours later.

However, after riding their luck at Barnsley, whose midfielder Alex Neil was dismissed for a second bookable offence 25 minutes from time, Wanderers believe that the promotion race may yet have one more twist in their favour.

Allardyce regards Preston as the club "second only to Bolton in my affections" after starting his managerial career at Deepdale. That may change if David Moyes's team can overcome Blackburn.

It would certainly please the romantics if Bolton pipped wealthy Blackburn to the post.

Man of the match: Dean Holdsworth (Bolton).

webTitle: Gas safety crisis highlighted by insiders

fields.headline: Gas safety crisis highlighted by insiders
fields.trailText: The safety of Britain's gas pipes has become a cause for serious concern within the industry, and ministers have been   warned of fears of another Railtrack-style crisis, the Guardian has learned.
fields.body:
The safety of Britain's gas pipes has become a cause for serious concern within the industry, and ministers have been warned of fears of another Railtrack-style crisis, the Guardian has learned.

The system is under such stress that there are lots of accidents waiting to happen, according to industry insiders. Their concerns focus on:

 a critical shortage of maintenance engineers;

 the time taken to repair gas leaks;

 increased use of sub-contractors;

 the restructuring of Transco, the privatised monopoly which owns the gas pipes.

A Guardian investigation has discovered that Transco, which runs the mains and feeder pipes to 20m homes and businesses, is 950 engineers short of the number needed to maintain the system and repair gas leaks.

The number of leaks and the time taken to fix them has increased. In Yorkshire, for example, there were 150 "outstanding escapes" or confirmed leaks not fixed at the end of March, with the oldest outstanding job dating from November last year, according to documents seen by the Guardian. Industry sources say the number of outstanding escapes has nearly doubled in London and Scotland in the last two years.

In all Transco's 12 regional distribution zones across the country, staff are working such long hours that the company is breaking the law on the maximum 48-hour week. Transco's own documents warn that if the health and safety executive were to check on the hours being worked it might take enforcement action. Staff on standby are having to work 15-hour shifts to repair leaks.

Transco has been trying to solve some of the problems by increasing the use of contractors. Nearly 60% of its maintenance work is contracted out. But internal documents warn that questions over the competence of contractors need to be addressed. A letter from Transco seen by the Guardian shows that at least one of its major contractors, DCE, a large engineering contractor in East Anglia, has repeatedly failed to carry out work to the required statutory standards and has left a leak in a pipe after working on it.

The HSE is expected to have a special meeting in the next couple of weeks with the environment minister Lord Whitty and the employment minister Malcolm Wicks to discuss its review of safety and the problem of finding competent staff.

Transco is in the process of restructuring to separate its assets from operations, and then maintenance from emergency work. This has fuelled fears that the business could be broken up later. Insiders in the gas industry worry that the proposals will create "another Railtrack" by fragmenting the network.

Investigations into two fatal explosions after gas leaks from old corroded pipes in Scotland - at Larkhall in December 1999 and Dundee in October last year - have also highlighted serious problems with the network. An interim HSE report on the Larkhall explosion, in which a family of four died, was passed to the procurator fiscal (Scotland's public prosecutor) last September, and he is expected to announce in the next few weeks whether to prosecute Transco directors for culpable homicide or criminal negligence. One of the HSE inspectors investigating the Dundee incident used to work as a Transco engineer covering the area, the Guardian has learned.

The HSE has issued a statutory notice requiring Transco to replace all ductile iron pipes within 30 metres of buildings by the end of 2002, "because they may fail unpredictably through corrosion".

The HSE also wants Transco to speed up plans to replace the rest of its 62,000 miles of iron pipes, to renew them in 10 years instead of the 40 years the firm originally planned. A 20-year programme has now been agreed.

Transco is regulated by the industry watchdog Ofgem. Ofgem sets its prices, having negotiated with the company an amount for capital expenditure to invest in infrastructure. But Transco underspent by 23% in 1997 and 19% in 1998.

Ann Robinson, chair of the consumer watchdog Energywatch, said: "We expressed concern last year about Transco's capital underspend. We were worried about any possible impact on safety." In another echo of Railtrack, reports after the Larkhall incident found that Transco did not have an accurate record of its assets. The Guardian has learned that the company is still trawling through its data to establish the extent of the problem, and the HSE is investigating the state of Transco's records.

Transco made 1,000 engineers redundant four years ago as part of cost-saving measures. Its director of regulation, Chris Bolt, said the company had laid off staff because "the Ofgem price control envisaged efficiencies," but "we are not prejudicing our safety obligations in any way". He did not recognise the figures" for staff shortages, but said there was a general problem with finding engineers for the utilities. "We are expecting increased recruitment." On gas escapes, he said: "The majority are internal to the home and are not our responsibility, although we have to make the first call." If leaks were found in locations where engineers judged there was no hazard, the company was allowed to deal with them "at an appropriate time", he said.

Ofgem said its role was to protect the interests of consumers by promoting competition. "Safety is paramount," a spokesperson said. "We require them [Transco] to invest efficiently and effectively. They underspent on capital but were signed off by the HSE, so we were happy." The HSE said: "The duty to ensure safety rests with the duty holder [Transco]. Our job is to monitor compliance with the law."

Related stories
'It takes a bang for people to sit up and listen'
Will gas become another Railtrack?

webTitle: The return of the comedy keeper

fields.headline: The return of the comedy keeper
fields.trailText: There's always one. While everybody else in Barcelona was glad to see the back of Lorenzo Serra Ferrer, teenage keeper José Manuel Reina is missing him already. Because Charley Rexach's first move as new coach was to harshly drop him in favour of, you guessed it, Comedy Keeper Richard Dutruel.
fields.body:
There's always one. While everybody else in Barcelona was glad to see the back of Lorenzo Serra Ferrer, teenage keeper José Manuel Reina is missing him already. Because Charley Rexach's first move as new coach was to harshly drop him in favour of, you guessed it, Comedy Keeper Richard Dutruel.

To be fair to Dutruel, an act which breaks a season-long habit, the comedy keeping during Sunday's 1-1 draw with Celta was at the other end. Try as Pablo Cavallero might - and he didn't try at all - he just could not catch the ball, no matter how easy the save.

Dutruel, on the other hand, barely saw it - he certainly didn't when Alexander Mostovoi gave Celta an early lead with a superb strike from 20 yards.

Defensively, Barça were much improved, with the mop-topped Carles Puyol, a man as dirty as he is ugly, proving a useful addition to the back four. But Barça's problems were at the other end. With Kluivert out, Luis Enrique played up front, while Dani and Alfonso occupied their usual positions on the bench. Good player though he is, Luis Enrique's no centre-forward and he missed three clear chances as Barça failed to make their dominance count - Gabri's thumping equaliser proving a rare moment of quality finishing.

In fact, Barça's next best shot was the elbow that Puyol planted on Gustavo López's head. Somehow referee Julián Rodríguez Santiago (totally inept all night) missed it - despite the blood pouring down López's face.

The Argentinian winger waited until the final whistle to remonstrate with Puyol, who just laughed in his face. Short of going "oooh, mooody, mooody" there's no better way to wind someone up, of course. And so it proved as a quality punch-up ensued.

Celta coach Víctor Fernández wasn't surprised. After four "emotional" games between the two sides this season, he reckons "the players are sick of the sight of each other". It could be fun when they meet for a fifth and sixth time in the Copa del Rey in June.

Barça may have improved but Rexach admitted that it was "a bad result", particularly as Mallorca beat Zaragoza 2-1 to open up a four-point gap in the race for the fourth-placed Champions League place.

Third-placed Valencia also won, scraping a 1-0 win over strugglers Valladolid. Juan Sánchez moved above Plain Old John Carew as Valencia's top scorer with his twelfth of the season.

Veteran centre-back Miroslav Djukic insists that things'll be different when they face Leeds. "It's going to be war," he predicted. Probably, Miroslav, but what about the match?

Real struggle at home to Osasuna

Real Madrid's preparation for la Champions was pretty unimpressive too. They cruised through their match with Osasuna, only to fall behind to a superb free-kick from a Robbie Savage look-a-like with, appropriately enough, a girl's name: Pipa Gancedo.

The Man in the Moustache's men got the chance to equalise with a ridiculous penalty for a push (at a guess) on Luis Figo. Even he looked surprised and set the tone for a shocking personal performance by promptly rolling the penalty wide. Raúl got a lucky break to level just after half time and Madrid began to look like they actually cared, only to find Osasuna keeper Nuno in inspired form.

In midweek, Iván Rosado claimed to have "a feeling we'll get a point in the Bernabéu". They should have got even more - Rosado was desperately unlucky to see his shot hit the post after a fine run midway through the second half.

Nothing much has changed at the other end after no one in the bottom six managed a win. Racing and Rayo drew 1-1, while Numancia were beaten 3-1 by Villarreal. Real Sociedad lost 2-1 against Las Palmas, who had Vinny Samways back from injury. He provided the cross for Álvaro to score the winner with an unorthodox finish.

That result has probably secured Las Palmas's survival, and leaves la Real in trouble. John Benjamin - accused of being a dictator by midfielder Stephane Collet - was furious with his henchmen. "We keep making life difficult for ourselves. It's like we're throwing stones at our own roof", he ranted, raising his arm to 45 degrees (er, allegedly).

Oviedo are still in trouble, despite a 2-2 draw in Málaga. It was only the Carbayones' fifth away point all season, an almost perfect riposte to coach Radi Antic, who earlier in the week claimed the club had "seventeen players who're only good enough for the second or third division".

Oviedo keeper Esteban Suárez - the man who's conceded more than anyone else in la Primera - led the protests as the players demanded, and got, an explanation.

It was an eventful week for Esteban, who also had to endure some scathing words from Malaga's Uruguayan striker Dario Silva. "I just hope Antic keeps Esteban in the side", he joked, "so that he can continue saving shots just like he has done all season".

One of the great things about Dario Silva is that he's always prepared to put his money where his not inconsiderable mouth is - it was he who headed Málaga's second. It's just a shame that the much-anticipated war of words - or, better still, fists - never materialised.

Despite dropping two points, Málaga are still in with a shout of a Uefa place, especially after La Coruña beat Espanyol 1-0 and Alavés lost the Basque derby 2-0 in Bilbao.

More new managers

Charley Rexach isn't Spain's only high profile new manager in Spain. Yesterday Atlético Madrid coach Marcos Alonso got a lovely invite to the Ritz Hotel. Not for him free bath-robes, vol-au-vents and poncey canapés, though - he was met by sporting director Paulo Futre, who informed him that his services were no longer required. Carlos García Cantarero, currently reserve team coach, will replace him until the end of the season.

It might not have been solely Futre's decision, though - president Jesús Gil y Gil almost certainly has his fingers on another firing at Atléti, even if his pathological craving was temporarily checked earlier in the season. "I'd have sacked him 20 games ago," he said, "if we get promoted now it'll be a miracle". It'll be even more of a miracle if Atléti finally get what they really need - a new president.

fields.headline: Preston in line for a step too far
fields.trailText: Having reached another milestone in the short but highly productive reign of David Moyes, Preston can legitimately start contemplating the possibility that they may kick off next season as a Premiership club.
fields.body:
Having reached another milestone in the short but highly productive reign of David Moyes, Preston can legitimately start contemplating the possibility that they may kick off next season as a Premiership club.

They secured a place in the play-offs with a casual dismissal of Crewe and are now only three games away from emulating Manchester City's recent achievement of back-to-back promotions. And therein lies a problem.

Moyes has expertly guided his team through the leagues by drawing the best from a settled pool of players. This year's line-up bears a strong similarity to the one that won the Second Division last season, save for the additions of David Healy and Richard Cresswell.

Many of Joe Royle's woes have been attributed to the rapid ascent depriving him of rebuilding time, and Moyes may need to consider that he will face similar trials should his side emerge victorious in Cardiff at the end of May.

Crewe's manager Dario Gradi believes Preston should enjoy their moment and not be overly concerned if it all ends in disappointment: "Preston should go out there and enjoy the play-offs but not be too despondent if they fail because they need time to build.

"It is a big jump from the Second Division to the Premiership. Look at Manchester City: they have big crowds and all those resources and have struggled still."

Preston's trump cards, should they go up, will be the nous of Moyes and the potential of the strike pairing of the youngsters Healy and Jon Macken. In the week when the £19m signing of Ruud van Nistelrooy highlighted the obstacles facing emerging young talent at Old Trafford, the two former United players offered a glowing testimony to the benefits of life away from the champions. They shared Preston's first-half goals, the top scorer Macken adding two to Healy's opener, and gave Crewe's back four a torrid time with their pace and movement.

Healy acknowledged his new lease of life, saying: "I'm grateful to David Moyes for giving me the chance to play first-team football regularly. I hope to be at Preston for a long time and hopefully that will be in the Premiership."

Man of the match: Jon Macken (Preston).

fields.headline: No justice for Law
fields.trailText: Whatever the Football League disciplinary panel decides in Leeds tomorrow, where Chesterfield look likely to face a heavier punishment for alleged financial irregularities, there is no way the outcome can satisfy all parties involved.
fields.body:
Whatever the Football League disciplinary panel decides in Leeds tomorrow, where Chesterfield look likely to face a heavier punishment for alleged financial irregularities, there is no way the outcome can satisfy all parties involved.

The affair has left a bad taste in the mouth and has opened up the contentious issue of whether a football club should be punished on the pitch for events which occur off it.

Nicky Law, Chesterfield's embattled manager, should be preparing his flagging side for a top-of-the-table clash at Brighton tomorrow. But Law will not have that privilege.

"I won't be at Brighton," he said. "I don't suppose anybody took into consideration that Chesterfield have possibly their biggest game of the season on Tuesday night and their manager has to be at a hearing in Leeds."

For a manager in his first full season it has been a lot to take on board. Before Saturday afternoon's results Chesterfield had led the Third Division for all but one week of the season. Now, with two games left they look as likely to play in the Conference next year as the Second Division.

For Law the situation rankles. "I feel outside pressures have been put on the league. Certain chairmen in our division have kicked up a fuss, but I think the whole thing is undermining the league itself."

There was also criticism for the sports minister. "I heard Kate Hoey saying it wasn't a strict enough penalty but I can't remember her being at the original hearing and reading the books of evidence."

For Hull, Chesterfield's problems must remind them of how far they have come in recent months. In February they were served with a winding up order, as Chesterfield were last week, and locked out of Boothferry Park by its owner David Lloyd.

Yesterday's win, courtesy of goals from Kevin Francis and the substitute Rodney Rowe, after Chesterfield's Ian Breckin had cancelled out Mike Edwards' fifth-minute strike, left Hull needing one point to secure a play-off place. Indeed, depending on what happens in Leeds, Hull could even sneak automatic promotion.

Man of the match: Kevin Francis (Hull) .

fields.headline: Muted farewell from Tigana's men
fields.trailText: "Fulham's coming home," they sang, and "Bye-bye to the Nationwide". At long last Fulham leave the Football League, the body that did its best to destroy them in 1905 when it brought Chelsea, a team that had yet to play any kind of game, straight into the Second Division.
fields.body:
"Fulham's coming home," they sang, and "Bye-bye to the Nationwide". At long last Fulham leave the Football League, the body that did its best to destroy them in 1905 when it brought Chelsea, a team that had yet to play any kind of game, straight into the Second Division.

And the farewell too looked a little grudging, even if there was a big trophy and medals for everybody. St Helens got Tony Blair and Hear'Say. Fulham got three anonymous League functionaries.

And now for Fulham and the Premiership: they go together like designer lager and Emporio Armani. "We've got nothing to fear," said Lee Clark, who has now won this title with three different clubs, "if we carry on as we are."

They had some trouble on Saturday but came through with the help of a dodgy penalty. The draw was less than satisfactory to both teams - Fulham lost their chance of beating Sunderland's record points total and Wimbledon lost their last hope of promotion - but it hardly put a crimp in the title celebrations.

"The lads all enjoyed it," said the acting captain Andy Melville, who has also won this title three times. "The result was a little bit disappointing but the end was nice."

After conceding three goals to Crewe in midweek, Wimbledon were determined not to be undone in defence. They pulled the midfield back in a protective line and for long periods allowed Fulham to pass the ball around in front of them.

The champions still created chances: the lively Luis Boa Morte, probing the channel between Rob Gier and Darren Holloway, got clear through three times in the first 12 minutes and John Collins, of all people, failed to make clean contact with an inviting half-volley. Then Wimbledon took the lead - Maik Taylor gave away a penalty, which Jason Euell converted for his 20th goal of the season - and Terry Burton brought off one of his strikers for another midfielder.

The party was in danger of falling flat until Boa Morte ran at Holloway and persuaded the referee that he had been bodychecked. As Louis Saha had been substituted, the new Portuguese international took the penalty himself and scored his 21st goal of the season.

And that was enough. Wimbledon headed home immediately, Fulham fans followed later, happy to see the trophy safely into their keeping. The rain had stayed off the parade.

Man of the match: Kenny Cunningham (Wimbledon).
