fields.headline: Fans poop promotion party
fields.trailText: A draw was enough for Mark McGhee's Millwall to book a place in the First Division.
fields.byline: Scott Murray  at the Racecourse Ground
fields.body:
Millwall had hoped that Wrexham would not poop their promotion party. No worries on that score; after earning a draw against inspired hosts, Mark McGhee's side are going up. Sadly, a few of their fans still managed - predictably, tediously - some pooping of their own.

A pitch invasion, a stand rushed and 27 minutes' worth of stoppages - not to mention the small matter of a run-in with Stoke fans at Crewe on the way home - ensured that the worst elements of the Millwall fan base put their side's achievement in the shade.

Barely two minutes had elapsed when about 50 visiting fans decided that they fancied a new vantage point and spilled into one of the home stands. The Millwall chairman Theo Paphitis put the incident down to "a few fools who came in without tickets" who "made their way to where there was an empty seating area", and the manager Mark McGhee insisted that "there was no aggression". But you could tell from the faces of the home fans sent scuttling down the aisles that the encroaching supporters were not just after extra room to stretch their legs.

Police moved quickly to form an effective barrier, preventing any serious trouble at least, but having taken root in their new surroundings, the English invaders refused to budge for more than 20 minutes, shifting only when McGhee went over to plead for them to return to their end - as did the majority of away supporters.

When the game eventually restarted, a Steven Reid-inspired Millwall penned their hosts inside their box for a full five minutes, and an opening goal for the leaders seemed inevitable.

Predictable, then, that Wrexham exploded into life and scored themselves: Carlos Edwards skinned a flailing Lucas Neill down the right and rolled a perfect ball across the face of goal to allow Craig Faulconbridge to side-foot home in front of a suddenly subdued away contingent.

Wrexham could have had more goals in a half their manager Bryan Flynn described as "probably the best 45 minutes we've had all season". Time and again, young Lee Trundle received the ball with his back to goal, turned Sean Dyche inside out, and either sent in crisp shots or laid off to invite a team-mate to do the same. His man-of-the-match award was richly deserved.

But Millwall showed signs of improvement towards the end of the half - David Livermore's one-two with Neil Harris, which dismembered the home defence and nearly resulted in a goal, was the most exquisite moment of the afternoon - and they regrouped after the break, packing the midfield to nullify Wrexham's earlier threat.

The equaliser took all of six second-half minutes to arrive, Tim Cahill powerfully heading in Livermore's corner. Cue four-minute pitch invasion and an announcement that the game would be abandoned if the Millwall end went walkabout again.

The game died there, the final half-hour noticeable only for a tiresome running battle between Trundle and Matt Lawrence: on an afternoon when players needed to ensure events on the pitch did not influence events off it, both were booked for spiteful challenges, both were involved in an unseemly spat, both were lucky not to see red. Well done, lads.

Man of the match: Lee Trundle (Wrexham).

fields.headline: Blues stutter into familiar territory
fields.trailText: There was a strange atmosphere at St Andrews on Saturday. Birmingham City duly ended a dismal run of form to claim a place in the play-offs for the third season in succession, but only with a stuttering performance that left their supporters bemused.
fields.body:
There was a strange atmosphere at St Andrews on Saturday. Birmingham City duly ended a dismal run of form to claim a place in the play-offs for the third season in succession, but only with a stuttering performance that left their supporters bemused.

After the match, which was decided by Marcelo's cleanly taken 56th-minute strike, the manager Trevor Francis was in confident mood. "If we get anywhere near our strongest team out," he said, "Then we'll win the play-offs."

With Geoff Horsfield returning to fitness and Stan Lazaridis on his way back too, Francis may have reasons for optimism. But Birmingham have not looked like promotion material for some time, taking only 10 points from the last 13 games, and they laboured to create chances against an efficient but limited Grimsby side still waiting to secure their survival.

With Bryan Hughes out of sorts on the right wing, and £1m Curtis Woodhouse out of position on the left, the Blues failed to take any advantage of the Mariners' ageing back line in the first half. Opportunities were limited to a series of scuffs and two penalty shouts ignored by the referee Paul Taylor. "Our finishing was terrible", Francis admitted later.

According to Francis, it was Dele Adebola's introduction 20 minutes into the second half that changed the game. The addition of an extra striker, he said, opened up extra space in the final third.

If that was the case, then returns were swift, as within a minute Andy Johnson, the third Birmingham forward, finally controlled a ball in the box and found Marcelo who coolly turned and side-footed beyond Danny Coyne.

Sadly for Adebola that silent contribution was as good as his afternoon got. Barely five minutes later he scooped the ball over an empty net from no more than two yards out, ran on into the post, damaged his achilles tendon, and was substituted. That brought an end to Adebola's second comeback from injury in a month; his first had lasted 16 minutes.

Birmingham's play-off rivals won't be unduly troubled by this result. Grimsby were in the game until the death, Ian Bennett saving twice at the feet of Stuart Campbell in a frenetic last 10 minutes. There will be more strange days at St Andrews yet.

Man of the match: Danny Sonner (Birmingham City).

fields.headline: Unhappy family enjoys a day out at the Riverside
fields.trailText: Success may breed success, but it does not nurture harmony. For all the glittering silverware at Old Trafford, discord appears to be sweeping through Manchester United's trophy-drunk camp.
fields.byline: Dominic Fifield  at the Riverside stadium
fields.body:
Success may breed success, but it does not nurture harmony. For all the glittering silverware at Old Trafford, discord appears to be sweeping through Manchester United's trophy-drunk camp.

Roy Keane, who missed this match with a hamstring strain and starts a four-match suspension next week, may have played his last game of the season, but he continues to accuse his team-mates of "complacency", bemoaning their "average" European displays and urging the manager to bring in new faces.

United's other star names appear reluctant to follow his lead. "There are some players who have not done as well as they should this season, but you should always stick together as a team," said a more diplomatic David Beckham. "People have said there should be changes but this is a great team; we have won seven championships in nine years and were 13 points clear when we won the championship - not the sign of an average side.

"The manager makes the decisions. If he thinks the team needs strengthening, then he will. Next season is going to be special for the manager, the team and the fans. I want to be a part of that. I love the club and, if contract talks go well, then I'll be staying."

Those negotiations are on-going. "But there are limits as to where we can go both in transfer fees and salaries," said United's chief executive Peter Kenyon. "There is no evidence that David is bored at Old Trafford; he is a key player for us and we'd like to retain him."

As they would Teddy Sher ingham, last night given the PFA's player of the year to add to the football writers' award he claimed last week. The striker is still mulling over an extension to his contract with Kenyon denying he might swap United for Fulham.

Boro must wish they could plan that far ahead. Despite Saturday's latest home slump, safety is close - two points from their last two matches would keep Boro up - but Terry Venables must remain on tenterhooks for one more week at least. "We thought we could have finished the job," Paul Ince conceded, "but other results mean nothing much has changed."

Plenty has since El Tel became Teesside Tel in December. Boro have gleaned 27 points in that period with only the top six claiming more. Yet, with the survival mission yet to be accomplished, supporters and players are already fretting over what happens next: will he stay or will he go?

Half-measures clearly will not do. "People have been talking about Terry doing two days a week, but that would be no good," said Ince. "He would have to be here every day. You can't run a big club part-time.

"We need to know that he's committed. We don't want a coaching consultant and, for that matter, we don't want him back here for just another 12 months. He has to sign a four- or five-year contract because we have to address the long-term future of the club. We all hope he'll stay."

In the meantime, the quest for safety stutters on away from the Riverside. Boro have won only three times at home all season and against United they lapsed into over-caution, selecting five natural central halves. The champions' second string hardly broke into a trot, strolling around the Riverside oozing invincibility. Had United not won so easily, Boro's relegation rivals might have had cause to complain.

Phil Neville set them on their way after four minutes. The younger Neville's lame goalscoring record rivals only his brother's in United's ranks, but even Beckham would have been proud of the thunderous shot that flew past Mark Schwarzer into the net.

It took Ince's ongoing midfield tussles with Nicky Butt -"Put them in the middle of the park and the least you'll get is an argument," said Alex Ferguson - to spark the home side into life.

Yet the best chance came and went in the midst of their best attacking spell. Jason Gavin's 67th-minute volley was tipped on to the bar and Hamilton Ricard nodded goalwards. The ball would have crept over the line but the over-eager Ugo Ehiogu intervened; instead of goal celebrations, his touch merely prompted the offside flag.

United responded to their uncharacteristic sloppiness by introducing Ryan Giggs and Andy Cole from their mouth-watering bench. The Welshman duly sent Boro defenders scurrying and cut back for Beckham to shoot inside Schwarzer's near post.

The former Bradford City forward deserved better with two well-struck shots and was Boro's most potent attacker. "He's cool on the ball and a threat on goal," said Venables of his £650,000 signing.

Best moment: Having gathered the ball on the edge of the area, he nutmegged Michael Stewart before fizzing a shot inches wide.

Man of the match: Dean Windass

He has to sign a four- or five-year contract because we have to address the long-term future of the club. We all hope he'll stay." In the meantime, the quest for safety stutters on away from the Riverside. Boro have won only three times at home all season and against United they lapsed into over-caution, selecting five natural central halves. The champions' second string hardly broke into a trot, strolling around the Riverside oozing invincibility. Had United not won so easily, Boro's relegation rivals might have had cause to complain. Phil Neville set them on their way after four minutes. The younger Neville's lame goalscoring record rivals only his brother's in United's ranks, but even Beckham would have been proud of the thunderous shot that flew past Mark Schwarzer into the net. It took Ince's ongoing midfield tussles with Nicky Butt -"Put them in the middle of the park and the least you'll get is an argument," said Alex Ferguson - to spark the home side into life. Yet the best chance came and went in the midst of their best attacking spell. Jason Gavin's 67th-minute volley was tipped on to the bar and Hamilton Ricard nodded goalwards. The ball would have crept over the line but the over-eager Ugo Ehiogu intervened; instead of goal celebrations, his touch merely prompted the offside flag. United responded to their uncharacteristic sloppiness by introducing Ryan Giggs and Andy Cole from their mouth-watering bench. The Welshman duly sent Boro defenders scurrying and cut back for Beckham to shoot inside Schwarzer's near post. The former Bradford City forward deserved better with two well-struck shots and was Boro's most potent attacker. "He's cool on the ball and a threat on goal," said Venables of his £650,000 signing. Best moment: Having gathered the ball on the edge of the area, he nutmegged Michael Stewart before fizzing a shot inches wide. fields.headline: Smith and his Rams still fear final-day cull
fields.trailText: Here is a bold prediction: Derby County will be relegated this season. Bold because on the face of it their position looks relatively safe. Four points separate them from a relegation place with only two games remaining.
fields.body:
Here is a bold prediction: Derby County will be relegated this season. Bold because on the face of it their position looks relatively safe. Four points separate them from a relegation place with only two games remaining.

Those games: Manchester United away and Ipswich Town at home. Pause for a deep intake of breath.

The fact is that Arsenal retained their grip on second place in the Premiership ahead of Saturday's showdown against Leeds by inflicting on Derby their fifth league defeat in the last six outings.

And if this evidence against another top four (three, if Ipswich move up a place today) team is anything to go on there is every chance that Derby will still be on 38 points when the curtain falls. "I'm mildly concerned," admitted Jim Smith. "We might have enough with 38 points but we can't rely on it."

Certainly not. For desperate teams lurk below. To overhaul Derby, Manchester City would need a win and a draw from their run-in - Ipswich away and Chelsea at home. Difficult.

But improving Coventry would require two wins from a visit to water-treading Aston Villa then a home game against Bradford. Which is feasible.

Is it any wonder then that despite the relaxation of the national foot-and-mouth-culling policy, Jim Smith's Rams are still looking nervously over their shoulders.

And Derby's problems are not confined to form. For the visit to Old Trafford they will be without Seth Johnson, Deon Burton and Adam Murray through suspension, and very likely Craig Burley who went off injured here.

With Branko Strupar out for the season and Brian O'Neil, Taribo West and Daryll Powell struggling with injuries, Smith faces a worrying time. However he is not, he says, ready to accept the recent invitation of one of his predecessors, Brian Clough, to pack it all in and "come and play cribbage and dominoes with me".

Over at Arsenal the relative luxury of second place cannot disguise an underlying sense of anguish there too. Speculation about Arsène Wenger leaving for Barcelona will not go away while international call-ups threaten to further undermine the manager's intentions.

Having failed to persuade France not to use Thierry Henry, Robert Pires, Sylvain Wiltord and Patrick Vieira heavily during France's midweek friendly with Portugal, Wenger will learn today whether he will lose Nwankwo Kanu and Lauren for the Leeds game due to call-ups for World Cup qualifiers.

Henry and Pires started on the bench but they still managed to influence the outcome. Arsenal took the lead when the impressive Kanu picked up a loose ball after Ashley Cole's dizzying run, played a one-two with Wiltord and tapped in from close range.

Chris Riggott cleared off the line as Arsenal pressed for a second, but just before half-time Derby equalised against the run of play. Rory Delap's run ended with a cross which deflected off Tony Adams and found a diving Stefano Eranio unmarked at the far post.

Confidence renewed, Derby's threat grew. The referee was correct to refuse a penalty after Giorgi Kinkladze's backheel hit Cole's hand, and correct again to wave play on after Adams accidentally clipped Malcom Christie's heel as he headed for goal. But the signs were there. Horacio Carbonari and Kinkladze also went close.

But too much of Derby's approach was hit and hope. Arsenal's problem was trying to pass their way through a packed home defence. Enter the French. Henry went down the left, set up Wiltord and Mart Poom saved only for Pires to pounce on the rebound.

Man of the Match: Nwankwo Kanu (Arsenal)

fields.headline: Nash's take-aways curry favour with City dwellers
fields.standfirst: The recently signed keeper keeps hope alive for another week
fields.trailText: It is nothing more than a faint glimmer but in Manchester City's parlous position they will consider it altogether preferable to the dark abyss into which they had been staring.
fields.body:
It is nothing more than a faint glimmer but in Manchester City's parlous position they will consider it altogether preferable to the dark abyss into which they had been staring.

Only time will tell whether their recovery is too little too late but, City being City, it was perhaps inevitable that their season would have such a nerve-shredding finale.

Doubtless it was with this in mind that one supporter approached the manager Joe Royle on Saturday evening to ask whether City should have a government health warning. Life at Maine Road is never dull and, once again, the future of this old club is balanced on a high wire.

Anything fewer than four points from their final two games, at Ipswich a week today and home to Chelsea on May 19, will cost City their place in the Premiership and around £15m in lost revenue. Yet for the first time in what seems an age, there is a modicum of hope. Not a great deal, admittedly, but enough for Royle and his players to be clinging to gratefully.

It is certainly far removed from a few weeks ago when the morale inside Maine Road was not so much low as subterranean. At that stage their crude efforts, combined with a dangerous mixture of self-pity and fatalism, seemed certain to see the club limp apologetically back to the First Division.

Instead, having taken seven points from their past three games, they are hanging on to the coat-tails of the three clubs hovering above the relegation zone. Middlesbrough will be squirming with discomfort, as will West Ham, but it is Derby's tailspin that represents City's best chance. As Royle said: "We've got long odds against us but I think they may be considerably shorter now."

Barring Everton's defeat of Bradford, City's weekend could not have been much better, although Royle is realistic enough to appreciate that if West Ham had taken a fraction of their chances during a frenetic second half a funereal air would have engulfed Maine Road.

It was desperate, frantic stuff, with West Ham virtually camped in their opponents' half. Yet, somehow, City survived and the decisive moment, in the 23rd minute, when Shaun Goater's miscued shot deflected off Ian Pearce's instep to wrong-foot Shaka Hislop could yet be pivotal to their season.

"As far as we are concerned Lady Luck has had her blindfold on for us this season," said Royle. "This was the exception but we'll take all the luck that comes our way now."

As will West Ham. They were so vapid throughout the first half that it infuriated Harry Redknapp, who confessed to caustic words at the interval and, though he was reluctant to go public, could scarcely conceal his contempt about the contribution of his captain Paolo di Canio. Sadly there is something about away days that renders the Italian as limp as spaghetti.

It would be a major surprise if West Ham were to fall into the bottom three but Redknapp will be happy that a difficult season that has split at the seams since their FA Cup exit is nearing its conclusion.

Joe Cole and Michael Carrick are showing the effects of their first full Premiership campaign and with Di Canio all but anonymous their best moments stemmed from the Bulgarian substitute Svetoslav Todorov.

An equaliser would have guaranteed their safety and, in all probability, condemned City to the guillotine. But on the frequent occasions when the home defence threatened to capitulate, Carlo Nash repelled everything that the Londoners managed to put together.

Royle reckons that Nash's signing from Stockport could be the best £100,000 City have ever spent, and Redknapp wanted to know if the goalkeeper had appeared "out of the clouds" to make one particularly superlative save.

Nash is a picture of calm where his predecessor Nicky Weaver had been a tub of nerves. When Nash was playing for Stockport his local Indian restaurant rewarded him with a free curry for every clean sheet; City may reflect that if he helps them stay up he should be awarded the Freedom of Rusholme's Golden Mile.

A string of outstanding saves as West Ham threatened to turn the game on its head during a spell of concerted second-half pressure.

Best moment: The extraordinary point-blank save to block Svetoslav Todorov's volley when everyone else in blue went awol in the 70th minute.

Man of the match Carlo Nash

fields.headline: Leicester maintain their spirit even at the death
fields.trailText: People queuing up to have a pop at the spirit in Leicester City's team are wide of the target. It is the quality and depth of City's squad that critics such as the former player Steve Walsh should be questioning.
fields.byline: John Wardle  at St James' Park
fields.body:
People queuing up to have a pop at the spirit in Leicester City's team are wide of the target. It is the quality and depth of City's squad that critics such as the former player Steve Walsh should be questioning.

The stubborn defending of Peter Taylor's injury-hit side, notably Gary Rowett, indicated the attitude remains intact despite the worst run of results in the club's history.

The real concern should be Leicester's inability to compensate for the absence of injured players such as Matt Elliott, Robbie Savage and Muzzy Izzet. Damien Delaney and Matthew Jones were out of their depth in midfield, and Dean Sturridge, Ade Akinbiyi and the substitutes Arnar Gunnlaugsson, Stefan Oakes and Trevor Benjamin were similarly anonymous.

Most were bought by Taylor, so here was more ammunition for those who accuse him of frittering away income from the sales of Neil Lennon and Emile Heskey on untried players from the lower divisions.

The harsh reality for City is that Newcastle would not have been flattered by a four-goal victory and only the excellence of Tim Flowers ensured Cort had to wait until a minute from the end to claim the winner with a shot deflected in by Rowett.

"It was a cruel goal, but at least we showed that a shadow squad can come and fight at club like Newcastle," said Flowers. "The spirit will never die at our football club.

"People have written things which have hurt the gaffer and the players and I know he was quizzed about Steve Walsh's comments, but it's nothing to do with me. I'm just a thick footballer - that's all I do."

He did it superbly here, with two saves from Kevin Gallacher and Nikos Dabizas in the world-class bracket. Not bad for a 34-year-old who can play only after an injection normally given to pensioners who are waiting for a hip replacement. The same can be said of Newcastle's keeper Shay Given, troubled only once by Akinbiyi as Bobby Robson's defence finally kept a clean sheet at the 30th attempt.

Robson was not there to witness it, opting instead for a scouting trip to the Netherlands. He knows his squad requires an overhaul and the fact that fringe players such as Stephen Glass and Gallacher were among the better performers emphasised this.

With some season-ticket holders threatening not to renew, Robson needs to come up with signings who will persuade them once again that there is a brighter future at St James' Park. And he has to do it without sacrificing Kieron Dyer.

Man of the match: Tim Flowers (Leicester).

fields.headline: McAllister leaves Coventry deep in the relegation mire
fields.standfirst:
Midfielder returns to haunt former club with a killer goal from a free-kick
Big Ron's analysis of McAllister's free-kick
fields.trailText: Hundreds of Coventry fans clapped Gary McAllister off but the sportsmanship barely hid their pain. With two late swings of his right boot the Scot had left Gordon Strachan so deep in the mire that only a few tufts of ginger hair are still visible. McAllister, who departed Highfield Road last summer for nothing, returned to ruin everything.
fields.body:
Hundreds of Coventry fans clapped Gary McAllister off but the sportsmanship barely hid their pain. With two late swings of his right boot the Scot had left Gordon Strachan so deep in the mire that only a few tufts of ginger hair are still visible. McAllister, who departed Highfield Road last summer for nothing, returned to ruin everything.

By taking the corner from which Sami Hyypia headed Liverpool in front in the 83rd minute and curling in a fine free-kick soon afterwards, McAllister nudged Coventry closer to the First Division. His contributions kept Liverpool in the race for the third Champions League spot but the midfielder's celebrations were so muted it seemed even an Intertoto Cup place was beyond reach at Anfield.

"He was not overwhelmed with joy," explained Liverpool's manager Gérard Houllier. "He spent four years at Coventry and he likes the club, so it was sad for him to know he may have put an end to their presence in the Premier League." Hurting Strachan, his one-time Leeds and Scotland team-mate, must have heightened the emotions.

The four goals McAllister has scored in his past four matches, one of which took Liverpool into the Uefa Cup final, have highlighted not just the astuteness of Houllier's signing but how much the 36-year-old is missed at Highfield Road. No one has replicated the 11 league goals he got from central midfield last season.

Strachan, of course, is not throwing in the towel, though he seemed ready to hurl various other objects at the officials on Saturday. Coventry are such masters of the great escape it is no wonder he feels a 35th consecutive top-flight season may be attainable.

To stay up they must win at Aston Villa on Saturday and at home to Bradford a fortnight later and pray others slip up. Their best hope is that Derby lose at Manchester United and at home to Ipswich.

Coventry's display was both encouraging and deflating for their fans. They played with the energy and commitment Strachan demands. For long periods they matched and stifled Liverpool, applying pressure, but their failure to take chances cost them again.

Three times inside 13 minutes they might have scored, but none fell to John Hartson and each was wasted. The flow became a trickle once Liverpool tightened. "Six months ago this is the sort of game we would have lost," Houllier remarked, admiring his side's resilience. Twelve months ago this was a game Coventry might just have won, with Robbie Keane in the side.

Hartson's lay-offs and knock-downs created openings. But Strachan felt matters would be decided at set pieces, and McAllister proved him right. "Gary hasn't played all the games," Houllier said, "and that's probably why his freshness now is giving so much to us." A 10-month absence in 1997-98 because of a knee ligament injury may have elongated his career.

If McAllister was the executioner, Michael Owen was the catalyst. Only after his arrival in place of Robbie Fowler in the 63rd minute did Liverpool repeatedly get behind Coventry's back line.

The 21-year-old's pace and movement exploited the space Coventry left as they pushed for a winner. He would have scored four but for Chris Kirkland's saves and the hand Paul Williams used unnoticed to prevent one effort crossing the line. The impressive Hyypia scored from the corner, and if Liverpool win their game in hand they will take third place on goal difference.

When McAllister sent a free-kick beyond Kirkland, images of Eric Cantona came to mind. From March to May 1996 the Frenchman scored crucial goal after crucial goal to bring Manchester United the double, one defeating Liverpool in the FA Cup final.

McAllister may yet help Liverpool to two more cups and the third place which is their priority. Coventry's loss is Liverpool's gain.

Came on for Robbie Fowler in the 63rd minute and used his pace and movement to consistently trouble Coventry's defence.

Best moment : A 83rd-minute chip over Chris Kirkland stopped - unspotted by the referee - by Paul Williams' hand.

Man of the match: Michael Owen

fields.headline: Kilbane's spectacular kick at his critics
fields.trailText: A contest between two dreadfully out-of-forms teams, lacking the one striker, Kevin Phillips, with the class to transform the occasion, and with significance only for the dwindling band who expect Sunderland to be playing in Europe next season, somehow for one moment managed to surpass expectations.
fields.body:
A contest between two dreadfully out-of-forms teams, lacking the one striker, Kevin Phillips, with the class to transform the occasion, and with significance only for the dwindling band who expect Sunderland to be playing in Europe next season, somehow for one moment managed to surpass expectations.

After 54 minutes of hopelessly unchoreographed foot ball, Kevin Kilbane performed a spectacular overhead flick that gave an undeserved silver lining to a stinker.

The goal, and subsequent win, raised Sunderland's Uefa Cup hopes to a glimmer and was a personal triumph for Kilbane, who has found form just as the criticism of him was growing. How Sunderland needed his inspiration in the absence of the injured Phillips, who, his manager Peter Reid repeated afterwards, has not asked for a transfer.

Southampton, who have now gone more than 5 hours without scoring, could also do with a Phillips. The caretaker manager Stuart Gray's record in his five games is now one point and no goals and his claims on succeeding Glenn Hoddle beyond the end of the season are evaporating fast.

A succession of chances were spurned by the home side who, when they were not being thwarted by Sunderland's outstanding defender Jody Craddock and goalkeeper Thomas Sorensen, were let down by a complete lack of confidence in their scoring ability.

James Beattie, so potent in November and December, has scored one league goal this year, although he was denied by a dubious offside decision here after appearing to run from his own half; Marian Pahars, who hit six in the first eight games of the season, has scored once since. Southampton have struck only seven goals in 13 league games in 2001.

Their defence has seen them to safety and Sunderland did not create a clear chance until the second half, when Paul Jones saved well at the feet of Niall Quinn two minutes before Kilbane's sublime moment.

The winger claimed he meant to score, but Gray described it as a "freak goal". After the difficulty Kilbane has had in adapting since his £2.2m move from West Bromwich 18 months ago it seems fair to give him the benefit of the doubt.

"It's hard. Some people take to the Premiership like a duck to water and others take time to settle," he said. "But I feel I'm strong enough to overcome criticism and you've just got to take the negativity sometimes."

Man of the Match: Jody Craddock (Sunderland).

fields.headline: Gardner flourishes as Spurs and Villa go to seed
fields.trailText: Tottenham love living in the past. They appoint as manager, with indecent haste, the most revered old boy of recent times and on Saturday reserved the loudest acclaim for someone now appearing in a cameo role for the opposition. This is because, without the grace of a Glenn Hoddle or the elan of a David Ginola in a white shirt, Spurs are now a picture of plainness.
fields.byline: Russell Thomas at White Hart Lane
fields.body:
Tottenham love living in the past. They appoint as manager, with indecent haste, the most revered old boy of recent times and on Saturday reserved the loudest acclaim for someone now appearing in a cameo role for the opposition. This is because, without the grace of a Glenn Hoddle or the elan of a David Ginola in a white shirt, Spurs are now a picture of plainness.

Hoddle hopes to enrich the canvas but for the moment must endure blank days like this. He admits to being "very frustrated" at times, having to nurse a child of a team because of so many injuries and having to wait until July to stamp his style on the squad. In between speculation will whirl.

With Hoddle's budget uncertain - the reported pledge of £50m has been rubbished in some quarters - he must hope that some of the youngsters deployed here will save him a lot of money.

Anthony Gardner, for one, has a long and productive future on the obvious promise of this performance, utterly subduing Dion Dublin on only his second start. "Superb," said Hoddle of the gangling 6ft 5in defender. Blessed with good touch and deceptive pace - the 20-year-old is a former schools 200m champion - Tottenham may have found the rarity of a footballing centre-back.

Whether, in the worst-case scenario, Gardner can immediately fill the void that would be left by Sol Campbell's departure is a different question entirely. Hoddle expressed his reservations: "He's got good use of the ball but just needs to be more defensively aware and needs more experience." On this evidence, Gardner will get it.

Hoddle also has high hopes of Willem Korsten, even if sections of the crowd have abandoned them. "Willem's got ability. I've said to him 'there's a player there waiting to get out' ..."

Villa's manager John Gregory spoke in similar vein about the £9.5m Juan Pablo Angel. The striker had missed two previous games because of on international duty and was now missing with "a bug".

"We've got nobody who can score 20 Premiership goals," Gregory lamented. "We may have next season if I can get the Colombian fit and on the pitch. I am not disappointed with him at all. We have got a very good player there."

Man of the Match: Anthony Gardner (Tottenham)

fields.headline: Firm superiority
fields.trailText: Rangers did themselves no favours as Henrik Larsson took his goal tally for the season up to 50 to help Celtic achieve their first win at Ibrox since 1994.
fields.body:
It was the season in microcosm. Celtic solid and streetwise, if not overly spectacular; Rangers unable to sustain a challenge for any length of time and still mired in the foothills of creative football.

Celtic's first win at Ibrox since 1994 and their biggest league win there for the best part of 30 years came courtesy of three second-half goals suggesting that - despite a recent revival - Rangers' discipline and self-confidence remains paper thin.

As damning verdicts go, it was left to their manager to deliver the most stinging. "From the moment Celtic scored, the game was over,' said Dick Advocaat, despite there having been half an hour for an equaliser to be found. "From the moment Celtic scored, it was quite easy for them to score two or three."

A turning point was the easy header Rangers' Rod Wallace squandered in the 22nd minute, from one of the few open passages of play that troubled either goalkeeper during a tight first half, where the passes were conservatively executed and the obvious dangers such as Didier Agathe on the Celtic right were expertly shackled.

The intensity rolled down from the stands with its usual fervour. Neil Lennon - now almost a self-styled public enemy No1 - was roundly booed with every touch of the ball, but it did not stop him calmly directing play.

The few genuine openings during the first period came from errors or set-plays. Alan Thompson guarded his post well to clear a Wallace flicked header from a Jörg Albertz corner. Johan Mjallby got behind his marker, Tore Andre Flo, to redirect a free-kick across the face of the Rangers goal, but with no takers.

Significantly, Lubomir Moravcik's first goal in the 61st minute came from a free-kick rolled into the inside-left channel and held up long enough by Henrik Larsson for the Rangers defence to part as Moravcik burst through.

His second required taking a long ball under control, turning Fernando Ricksen and keeping his cool to slot the ball home from an angle.

Larsson needed to overcome an even tighter angle to squeeze the ball past Stefan Klos, whom he had rounded first. By now, Celtic had not only drawn the sting from the game but could afford to let slip a couple of further opportunities, not least a three-on-one attack that found the young substitute Sean Maloney quickly realising the significance of the occasion as he shot straight at the goalkeeper.

Man of the Match : Lubomir Moravcik (Celtic). #

fields.headline: Bradford are made to pay a double penalty
fields.trailText: With one mighty bound Everton broke free of the shackles of relegation but Bradford City must now contemplate life in the First Division after only two seasons in the top flight.
fields.body:
With one mighty bound Everton broke free of the shackles of relegation but Bradford City must now contemplate life in the First Division after only two seasons in the top flight.

Two victories in a row had provided the west Yorkshire side with a slender hope of avoiding relegation, and had they not missed two penalties they could have been looking at a third. But they have long been operating with an eye to rebuilding for next season and if they play with the spirit they showed on Saturday there is nothing to stop them bouncing back again.

Everton, meanwhile, can at least put their feet up but, approaching £30m in debt and with a mediocre squad, it is hard to see where they go from here except to engage in another battle against the drop.

Of the two Scottish managers Walter Smith appeared the most subdued and after three seasons of hard graft with little to show for it there is a feeling on Merseyside that he may be tempted to call it quits this summer.

Some fans have begun to doubt his ability to bring the good times back, though few would go as far as the editorial in the Speke from the Harbour fanzine which said: "Smith seems to have lost the faith of the majority of the supporters through his bewildering team selections and apparent tactical naivety. Unfortunately we're stuck with him as we can't afford to sack him."

The manager himself looked wearied by a season of turmoil and said simply: "I'm just glad we're not going to be involved in the last couple of Saturdays in terms of relegation."

Bradford took an early lead through an Andy Myers header and attacked with the self- belief of a team who knew they had nothing to lose. But Jim Jefferies, charged with cutting the wage bill from £13m to £5m as they face up to life in the lower division, said he had accepted two weeks ago that they were as good as down andis happy to take encouragement from his team's willingness to fight to the bitter end.

"I can't fault the players. They've had a real go and worked hard. OK we've made mistakes, but they've battled for each other and at least we went down showing that we're well capable of coming up with a challenge next year and getting back up."

In a ridiculously exciting game both sides went at each other hammer and tongs and the supporters in the Gwladys Street stand who were on their feet throughout could have provided the busybodies of Trafford borough council with enough paperwork to last them a month.

It took Everton at least a half to overcome their nervousness in front of goal but when they did Duncan Ferguson, who played as if his life depended on it despite being barely fit after a morning test on a groin injury, restored parity with a deft shot immediately after the interval. Then things got more interesting.

In the 55th minute Paul Gerrard saved Robbie Blake's penalty, awarded after Steve Watson had fallen over Benito Carbone. Then Niclas Alexandersson, arriving late at the far post, coolly volleyed Everton in front. Another penalty followed, for a handball by Watson, only for Carbone to scoop it harmlessly over the bar. As his salary accounts for about £2m of Bradford's wage bill, the Italian had probably just kissed goodbye to his yellow and amber shirt.

Alexandersson, gleaming with relief, said: "Once you're down there you're happy to get out of it and we know what it meant for the club to win today." But will Everton be passing Bradford on their way down next season?

Man of the match: Duncan Ferguson (Everton).

fields.headline: Women's football
fields.trailText: Arsenal close in on the title while Southampton teeter on the brink of relegation.
fields.body:
Days such as yesterday must make the women's game yearn for 2003 - the year the FA has earmarked for the league to go professional. Rain put paid to Liverpool's appointment for a little mutual consolation at second-bottom Millwall, but not until the red Peugeot carrying four team members was in Birmingham.

Happily for Charlton, hosting Doncaster Belles, the Beauwater Sports Ground was available. The home side won 2-0, although they cannot now catch Arsenal. Alexa Hunn set Charlton on the way 15 minutes after half-time and Tara Proctor capped a run down the left wing with a 30-yard shot for the second. The analysis was simple. "We lost our shape," said Belles' manager Julie Chipchase.

In contrast, Doncaster's structure off the pitch is growing ever more formidable. The club have a rare accessory in a sport so young that it still finds TVs on team buses a novelty: they have a heritage. They are the top flight's oldest and only independent concern. They run at a profit - the club shop took £150 when Arsenal visited recently - and work will soon start on a new 3,500-capacity ground, complete with a statue of the legendary Gill Coultard outside.

None of that will allay the disappointment of yesterday's defeat, which all but mathematically puts the title beyond them.

Both sides can claim to have had transitional seasons. Belles acquired a new midfield from Everton; Charlton won the league and cup last campaign as Croydon Women before an acrimonious switch delayed their season by three weeks while they waited for their soon-to-be former chairman to release their registration cards; he had discovered that the men's sponsorship deal depended upon the infinitely more famous ladies.

Both can look forward to giving Arsenal something to see in their rear-view mirror.

The leaders had a relatively restrained 3-1 win at Barry Town and need only two points to clinch the title.

Whereas Liverpool can thank the weather for the deferral of a certain fate, Southampton Saints' 5-2 home defeat to Sunderland in another relegation crunch leaves them on the brink.

Seven players were booked and Saints' Marie O'Brien sent off. Shelly Cox and the impressive Gemma Ritchie, who can "take a ball down from her ear with her foot" according to her manager, instigated a late, late fightback. But Sunderland's win edges them three points clear of the relegation zone.

fields.headline: Football round-up
fields.trailText: Inspired perhaps by Jean Tigana's success at Fulham, Watford will name Gianluca Vialli as their new manager before the end of this week.
fields.body:
Inspired perhaps by Jean Tigana's success at Fulham, Watford will name Gianluca Vialli as their new manager before the end of this week.

Vialli, sacked by Chelsea seven months ago, turned down an offer from Southampton in favour of the First Division club. He met a three-man subcommittee for the fourth time on Friday and accepted the job offer.

The club's 10-man board, ready to make up to £5m available to the Italian, will meet to ratify the appointment. Though Ray Wilkins is likely to become Vialli's assistant, the coaching staff will largely remain; continuity was one of the criteria set by the board in the search for Graham Taylor's successor.

Watford's hopes of reaching the play-offs were ended after a 1-1 draw against relegated Tranmere on Saturday.

West Bromwich's place in the play-offs was confirmed after they also drew 1-1, at home to Huddersfield.

In the Second Division Rotherham won a second successive promotion after a last-minute Alan Lee goal earned them a 2-1 win over Brentford and Reading were beaten 2-1 at Colchester.

Brighton will be confirmed as champions of the Third Division tomorrow if they beat Chesterfield at Withdean. The Seagulls' 4-1 win over Macclesfield on Saturday puts them two points clear at the top and a win tomorrow will render any points deduction for Chesterfield irrelevant.

webTitle: A bit of hard work never hurt anyone's chances

fields.headline: A bit of hard work never hurt anyone's chances
fields.trailText: Clare Tomlinson Despite Manchester United's domestic sucess, this has been a year for the underdogs, with Leeds and Ipswich leading the way with a simple philosophy.
fields.byline: Clare Tomlinson on the virtues of Leeds and Ipswich
fields.body:
There is something quintessentially English about the idea of the underdog. David gets our vote every time over Goliath. While we may applaud Manchester United's achievement in wrapping up, earlier than ever, their seventh title in nine seasons, isn't it much more fun to delight in the exploits of the unfancied?

When the fixture lists were published last summer, who would have thought that the semi-final of Europe's premier club competition would be all about the United of Leeds rather than Manchester. If that wasn't unlikely enough, what about the thought that tonight's game between Charlton and Ipswich will have an important bearing on Champions League qualification?

Yet both Leeds and Ipswich have confounded their critics. While the clubs differ in many ways - not least in terms of history and financial clout - their surprise achievements have been accomplished with a simple philosophy, based on a collective work ethic and refusal to be intimidated by reputations of more experienced contemporaries.

At Ipswich, the key has been to collect a team devoid of stars. Of those who would expect to be selected for the first team, only two have come from other Premiership clubs. And those two, Chris Makin (Sunderland) and Alun Armstrong (Middlesbrough) found themselves out of favour where they were.

The rest have come from abroad, from the Nationwide league or through the ranks. In all cases, Ipswich have given them their big chance. And boy, are they grateful. Even Marcus Stewart, who is challenging for this season's golden boot, was doubted by many when he arrived.

That gratitude translates into all that they do. Few Premiership clubs are more obliging or more helpful when it comes to granting interviews, which the players to a man undertake willingly and happily, as they do the enormous amounts of community work they undertake.

This attitude to hospitality, which was fostered by the free-flowing days of the Cobbold era, has been continued by the present administration, headed by David Sheepshanks. When the new England manager visited Portman Road earlier this season, Sheepshanks went out of his way to learn the Swedish for "tractor boys" so Sven could feel at home.

It all makes a difference, on and off the pitch. And when I suggested to George Burley earlier this month after their win at Southampton, that the Champions League was a possibility, the swift "behave yourself" that he shot me was belied by the twinkle in his eye.

Europe is an immediate reality for Leeds and although the clubs might be quite different - paying £18m for a defender is not in Sheepshanks' immediate plans - they have much in common.

Although big name players have arrived for big money, Leeds represents a huge opportunity for them in the way Ipswich does to Burley's men. The core of the side have grown up together and they have been joined by young, talented players with a point to prove.

First and foremost, they want to play for each other, anywhere they are wanted - just think of how many positions Dominic Matteo has filled this year.

This season has been extraordinary in many ways for the club, with injuries and a high-profile court case. But such is their ambition on the field that they have just played harder for each other. They also don't seem to want to do so anywhere other than Leeds.

When I spoke to Ian Harte last week about whether he might be off to Newcastle or even abroad, he looked at me as though I was mad. Why, he said, would I want to play anywhere other than Leeds?

It is this fearsome devotion to the cause and the braveness of youth which has nothing to fear which has propelled Leeds past Milan, Anderlecht, Lazio and Deportivo. It may yet also get them past Valencia, starting with the first leg of their semi-final this week, while Ipswich will be hoping that the same spirit will get them to the same competition next year.

Although that may be open to doubt, the one certainty is that you won't find Ipswich or Leeds players in the papers moaning about how things have to change or how they have to move on. Even Sir Alex Ferguson must be jealous of that.

fields.headline: Bilious Clough still fighting the old battles
fields.trailText: Martin Kelner At 66, Brian Clough remains gloriously bitter and twisted, spewing invective and bile at every opportunity. It's easy to forget that his ways are only recent football history.
fields.body:
Brian Clough is not a man to let sleeping dogs lie. His favoured approach with sleeping dogs is a sharp boot to the backside, followed by an exhortation to the slumbering animal to wake up and get its bloody act together. Age, I was delighted to see on Football Stories on Channel 4, has failed to mellow him in any way.

At 66, Cloughie remains gloriously bitter and twisted, spewing invective and bile, and fighting old battles despite the fact that at least one of his targets was not merely sleeping but, in the strict biological sense, dead.

Getting an unreconstructed Clough to rehash his famous disagreements with old adversaries such as Don Revie and Bob Stokoe was quite a coup for Football Stories. Having last seen a purple-faced Clough at Nottingham Forest's final Premiership match in 1993, when he did appear dangerously mellow - mellow as a newt, in fact - I had expected a programme lacking such a significant contribution from its central figure.

Then again, Brian Clough By His Friends was never a realistic prospect, except possibly as a candidate for World's Shortest TV Programme, alongside Dale Winton Talks Rugby League and The Gordon Brown Comedy Hour.

In the event Clough, sitting in a comfy old armchair, leaning forward and pointing for emphasis in time-honoured style, was more than capable of speaking for himself; the theme of his discourse roughly being " non, je ne regrette rien ", whereas those who had crossed him should damn well regrette tout .

Speaking of which, one is reluctant to side with the FA but Clough's message for Arsène Wenger - "We got you out of the shit in two wars, so don't come the fancy stuff with me" - gave you a strong clue as to why it was felt appointing Cloughie to the England job might not make a major contribution to international diplomacy.

Actually, watching Clough and hearing about his what now appear to be preposterous methods, it seems remarkable that he was such a popular candidate for England manager. It was also difficult to comprehend that what we were watching was such comparatively recent history. The Clough story seemed as distant and alien as a biography of some bizarre Victorian capitalist you might watch on the History Channel.

John McGovern, whom Cloughie signed for both Derby County and Nottingham Forest, said the first instructions the boss gave him were "Get your shoulders back and get your head up. You look like a girl."

Clough's preferred method of training his strikers was to stand on the training field holding a stick, shouting: "Hit the target." He would treat European matches as an excuse for a holiday, telling players who went early to bed to come down for a drink so that they would sleep better. These methods, remember, won two European Cups for unfashionable Forest.

Clough reminded me of Alan Latchley, the football manager invented by the late Peter Cook, who said he believed in the three Ms - "motivation, motivation, motivation" - and motivated his players by kidnapping their wives and leaving them in Skegness or somewhere.

Possibly the wackiest element of the programme was the fact that Clough was briefly taken seriously as a political figure. Michael Foot described him as a "great socialist" and the former MP for Derby North, Phillip Whitehead, described him as "a more articulate version of Johnny Prescott", which seems like a pretty awful thing to say about anybody.

Clough was, of course, neither, but a charismatic dictator whose success was dependent on a large element of fear and was only achievable because he wielded absolute power; the sort of person, in short, with whom you might think it inadvisable for politicians to share a platform, which tells you as much about the stupidity and vanity of politicians as it does about Clough.

Moreover, alleged financial irregularities at Nottingham Forest remain uninvestigated, and I notice a TV critic in one of the dailies took the programme to task for not delving more deeply into these matters. But that seems to me rather like having a go at apples for not being pears.

The programme was about football, and I thought the director Andy MacKenzie-Betty told his football story well. For viewers who did not live through the era, and even for some of us who did, the story of Clough's time at Derby and Forest is, if nothing else, a fascinating illustration of how radically our national game has changed, and in how short a time.

This week, Football Stories deals with the Charlton brothers, no particular friends of Clough, which brings to mind an old quote from Mao Zedong, with whom Cloughie has much in common, although I believe Mao was a better swimmer. "Stand by the riverbank long enough," said chairman Mao, "And eventually the bodies of your enemies will come floating by." Or, if not, you'll see them in television documentaries.

Finally, as you may know, this column is the official outlet for unlikely sightings of Chris Eubank, spotted on Friday morning on Kilroy, the subject of which was Poverty Ruined My Childhood. "What're you doing here?" asked Kilroy. "I suppose they kicked you out of Big Brother and you had nowhere else to go." Many a true word

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to football.editor@guardianunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Water cure
fields.standfirst: After an 11-hour flight and a night  in a hotel which smelt of bottled gas, Sue finds that a dinghy-ride through the whirlpools and rocks at the bottom of the spectacular Iguazu Falls is  just the thing to calm her nerves
fields.trailText: Week 22: New Zealand to Argentina After an 11-hour flight and a night in a hotel which smelt of bottled gas, Sue finds that a dinghy-ride through the whirlpools and rocks at the bottom of the spectacular Iguazu Falls is just the thing to calm her nerves
fields.body:
Hola from Buenos Aires!

A quick rundown of my last few days in New Zealand, which were spent driving back to Auckland via Taupo. Lucy and John put me up again on Saturday evening and took me to Cheltenham beach and on to Devenport for fish and chips. Thanks again to them.

By Sunday afternoon I was on the plane to Buenos Aires and due to arrive there at Sunday lunchtime. What a strange thing time is - I can't get my head around it at all. My body was also struggling with two Sundays and an 11-hour flight: I couldn't sleep on the plane and arrived at my chosen hotel via shuttle bus and taxi feeling very frazzled. The hotel was a ghastly dump, smelling of bottled gas and miles from the centre of the city. Beware website descriptions - for 'laundry' read large sink; for 'kitchen' read gas ring with no kettle, pans or crockery; for 'social area' read ancient settee in foyer; and for 'English spoken' read lie. I didn't have the energy to move hotels at that point, so I lugged all my bags up the umpteen flights of stairs, gathered what reserves I had and set out on the subte (underground) for the city centre.

As it was Sunday and Argentina is a good Catholic country, virtually everywhere was shut. However, I did manage to check out a couple of alternative accommodation possibilities and order a pizza: long live international food. I went back to the dump before it got too dark and collapsed into bed. 11 hours later I woke refreshed enough to claim my free McDonalds breakfast, and check out and move into a slightly less grotty hotel right in the centre.

The next couple of days were spent exploring Buenos Aires. I discovered that for some reason the whole city smells of bottled gas. I found a travel agent, Amichi, which had English-speaking reps, and booked a four-day trip to the Iguazu Falls - a must, according to Cheryl. The Plaza de Mayo was interesting: it's the equivalent of Speakers' Corner in Hyde Park, with lots of political banners and photos of what I presume are 'the missing', as well as lots of police. I also managed to buy a new spare pair of reading glasses - having already broken one pair, I was terrified of damaging the others and ending up stuck somewhere unable to read a thing.

I like Buenos Aires - it's a vibrant city, despite the narrow roads choked with traffic. The city is scruffy, the people smart. The Argentines seem to have an obsession with shiny shoes. Every street corner has a shoe-shine man, always with a customer, which thankfully means they don't feel the need to tout (unlike in Asia, where they try to shine your shoes even if you're wearing flip-flops). I'm a lover of cafés where I can sit with a coffee and people-watch, and there are enough in Buenos Aires to satisfy even me. They always provide a little biscuit or pastry too, which is nice.

My Spanish isn't really improving. I'm OK if I have time to prepare what I want to say, but unexpected encounters seem to drive the words out of my head. I've managed to get please, thankyou, sorry and toilet? off pat.

The trip to Iguazu was a bit hairy. The small local airport was packed, and nobody spoke English. By dint of a great deal of guesswork I did manage to get onto the plane and then the transfer bus, where lots of instructions and details of trips were given out - all in Spanish. I did eventually find a couple from York, travelling with Argentine friends, who promised to pass on anything important. The hotel was actually in Brazil and, topically, everyone had to get out at the border and walk through some antiseptic as a precaution against foot and mouth. A lady in thin sandals met with short shrift when she tried to walk round the edge. Although the trip was expensive (we were staying in a four-star hotel), I nevertheless decided to fork out a bit more to go to see The Spectacular, a show of music and dancing from Argentina, Brazil and Paraguay (the borders of all three countries meet here). It was a bit glitzy, but Bruce had a whale of a time when one of the Brazilian dancers took a shine to him (see photo).

The next morning we headed off to the Iguazu Falls. We visited the Argentinian side first, where 30 rivers meet and, over the space of 2,400m, plunge down 275 falls. It was an amazing sight - water crashing down into the rainforest for as far as the eye could see, falling so far and so fast that it sent up a huge spray. Every corner we turned during our walk revealing yet more impressive falls. I had four floppy discs for my camera with me, and soon filled the lot.

In the afternoon I paid out yet more money to go on the Great Adventure - a truck ride through the forest to the river and then a dinghy-ride to the falls. The first adventure came when the truck broke down and we had to walk through the last section of the forest to the river. Those who wanted them were issued with plastic bags to put over their shoes while they were walking through the red mud - quite a sight. Then we were packed into the dinghy for the mile-long ride through the rapids. This time the adrenalin really did flow as we sped past angry whirlpools and vicious rocks until we found ourselves in the middle of the seething cauldron at the base of one of the falls. From there we plunged on round a bend and virtually straight under another fall - this we did twice as we all demanded to go again. The thunderous roar of the falls, the drenching spray and the tossing boat made us all shout with exhilaration - it was fantastic.

The evening was spent drying out and agonising over which photos to delete to leave some space for the Brazilian side the next day.

I hadn't thought anything would be able to live up to the sights of the previous day - but I was wrong. At one point there was a walkway in front of a huge collection of falls. It was worth a second drenching to stand there and look at it in awe. I took a five-second video to try to give a better idea of the magnitude of the place, but even that didn't show the 180 degrees of solid falls behind me, where the spray was too intense to take pictures. The sun came out at this moment to produce a rainbow - magic (watch Sue's video).

By lunchtime all the other English speakers had left. Luckily Pedro, a young Argentine (who unfortunately didn't speak English either) appointed himself as my guide and minder. At the falls he was sent out to find me as the bus wanted to leave - how was I to know? We went on to see the 8km Itiapu dam which is the largest power station in the world, supplying most of Paraguay and Brazil's electricity. Impressive, but no match for nature's work down the road. Thanks for the tip Cheryl, it was a truly wondrous place.

I lazed about by the pool in the morning before flying back to Buenos Aires this afternoon. I'm writing my report now, a day late, as I refused to pay the hotel's exorbitant internet charge. I fly off to Santiago tomorrow, sad that I have barely glimpsed Argentina. As yet I have no idea how I'm going to spend these last five weeks travelling through Chile, Bolivia and Peru, but I'm sure I'll work it out somehow. I do know that my lack of Spanish is a definite drawback, although I was pleased with myself for managing to telephone to book a room in Santiago for Sunday night. I had an email from a Santiago resident but have somehow lost the address, which is a pity. So, I have survived and enjoyed my first week in South America - I wonder what the next one will bring.

webTitle: Roma throw it away to keep title race alive

fields.headline: Roma throw it away to keep title race alive
fields.trailText: After all the racism, the hooliganism, the fake passport and steroid scandals, Italy's attention was finally diverted back to the title race this weekend by biggest game of the season so far: Roma v Lazio.
fields.body:
After all the racism, the hooliganism, the fake passport and steroid scandals, Italy's attention was finally diverted back to the title race this weekend by biggest game of the season so far: Roma v Lazio.

And as clocks across Italy chimed 10pm last night, it looked like Roma were slowly and precisely tick-tocking their way to their second Rome derby win of the season and their first Scudetto since 1983.

Two-nil up against Lazio with just 12 minutes to play - and with the knowledge that second-placed Juventus had only drawn 1-1 at home to Lecce earlier in the day - it seemed inevitable that the Giallorossi were about to move eight points clear.

But once again this most intriguing of Serie A season's refused to end peacefully.

On 78 minutes, Pavel Nedved pulled it back to 2-1 with a drive home from the edge of the box. Then, as the match entered its 95th minute, Lazio substitute Lucas Martin Castroman hit a cannonball of a drive from 25 yards which flew into the bottom left-hand corner and sent the light-blue half of the Stadio Olimpico wild.

The Argentine midfielder celebrated his goal by lifting his shirt over his head to reveal a T-shirt bearing a photograph of a young man with long hair. "I want to dedicate this goal to my cousin Cristian, who died last October," Castroman explained later. "I promised myself I'd dedicate my first goal for Lazio to him."

The first half of the match was typical derby fare: frantic, bad-tempered and ugly. But three minutes into the second half Gabriel Batistuta nipped in front of Sinisa Mihajlovic to put Roma ahead. And six minutes later Cristiano Zanetti threaded a pass through to Marco Delvecchio who, at full stretch, stabbed a first-time volley past Angelo Peruzzi to make it 2-0.

But Roma were unable to hold on, much to the annoyance of Roma coach Fabio Capello. "We have a lot to regret after tonight," he admitted. "It's a pity. We could have wrapped up the championship but we didn't do it."

"My only complaint to my boys is that we conceded two identical goals, leaving an opponent free to shoot on both occasions. But these things happen.

"We could have killed off the match by scoring a third goal and if we had, I don't think Lazio would have come back," he added.

"Drawing a derby like this just seconds from the end leaves a bitter taste in the mouth but we have to bounce back and we will do - straight away."

Meanwhile, Lazio coach Dino Zoff was happy at his side's comeback. "I think we deserved the draw. Roma scored two great goals, but they didn't do much more than that during the second half. We had many chances in the final minutes.

"Of course, Roma maintained their lead, but now they know how hard they have to fight if they want the Scudetto," he added.

"That could have some consequences in their mind."

Juventus blow up at home - again

Juventus will certainly hope that Zoff's words prove prophetic. Next week they face Roma in the Stadio Delle Alpi in a match they need to win following their disappointing 1-1 draw against Lecce.

Throwing away points at home to relegation threatened sides is starting to become an unfortunate habit. At the start of the month, Juve drew 1-1 at home to Brescia after a 86th minute goal from Roberto Baggio broke their hearts.

Yesterday, it was one of their own players who broke their hearts. In the 86th minute, Fillippo Inzaghi blasted a penalty against the post, and in injury time he missed a one-on-one with the keeper and hit the woodwork again as Juve desperately sought a winner.

Earlier Croatian defender Igor Tudor put Juve ahead in the 40th minute, but Lecce equalised within seconds through Alessandro Conticchio, who planted a diving header past Edwin Van der Sar from 15 yards.

"It's not looking good," Juve manager Carlo Ancelotti said. "But we are not giving up. We have not yet surrendered. We're bitter about today's result but also confident we can bounce back next Sunday against Roma."

Juve fans aren't so sure. After the game they chanted insults at Ancelotti and called for Gianluca Vialli to replace him. "We have a dream in our hearts, Gianluca as coach," they chanted.

But the Italian newspapers preferred to blame Inzaghi. "Inzaghi betrays a bad Juventus," read the banner headline of the Gazzetta dello Sport.

Yesterday's results mean that Roma are still on course for the title. They lead Serie A by six points from Juventus and seven from Lazio with six games to play.

But the Giallorossi do have a more difficult run in. After visiting Turin next week their last three home games are against Atalanta, AC Milan and Parma - all of whom are chasing a Champions League berth. Juve have an easier run-in but face a testing visit to Fiorentina six days after they play Roma.

Lazio too insist they are still in the title race. "We cannot give up," said Castroman. "Seven points is a big gap, for sure, but we have to believe in ourselves, just as we believed we could fight back and draw against Roma."

Other business

In other Serie A matches this weekend, Parma stayed fourth as a late goal from Marco di Vaio gave them a 1-0 win away at Parma. AC Milan moved into fifth as an Andriy Shevchenko penalty helped them beat lowly Verona 1-0. Meanwhile, Atalanta fell to sixth after a 2-2 draw with Bologna.

But the game of the week was undoubtedly Perugia's 4-3 victory over bottom-placed Bari. The game looked over when Bari went 3-0 ahead in the 48th minute with goals from Giuseppe Mazzarelli, Michele Marcolini and Paolo Poggi.

But when South Korean forward Jung Kwan Ahn opened the scoring for Perugia in the 66th minute, Bari started to wilt. Substitute Anselmo Robbiati scored twice to make it 3-3 before Marco Materazzi scored the winner with an 82nd-minute penalty.

"At 3-1 we felt we had a chance of getting a draw," Perugia coach Serse Cosmi said. "The two goals we needed came quickly. We scored four times in quarter of an hour. It's a historic win."

Hooliganism: the problems continue

Sadly, Lazio's racist fans are at it again. During yesterday's derby they raised a banner aimed at Roma supporters which read: "Black squad, Jewish home end." Roma's Brazilian players Cafu and Aldair and French-born defender Johnathan Zebina were booed throughout the game.

There were also violent clashes between rival fans before the game, and a television journalist was stabbed twice in the thigh as he attempted to film the incidents. A police van was also set on fire and three fans were arrested.

There was no trouble inside the stadium but Lazio fans threw Molotov cocktails at police - who responded with tear gas - as they left the stadium shortly before the end of the match.

webTitle: Tories pledge to protect green belt

fields.headline: Tories pledge to protect green belt
fields.trailText: The Conservatives have attempted to make protecting the green belt from housebuilding a key election issue by promising to scrap national and regional housebuilding targets "within weeks" if they won the general election.
fields.body:
The Conservatives have attempted to make protecting the green belt from housebuilding a key election issue by promising to scrap national and regional housebuilding targets "within weeks" if they won the general election.

The Tories launched a "save our greenfields" battlebus tour in Hertfordshire to highlight what they claim are Labour's plans to concrete over Britain's countryside with unwanted development.

Shadow environment secretary Archie Norman also pledged to make it easier for councils to give more land green belt protection.

The Conservatives have campaigned against rural development through out this parliament, but this is first time it has pledged to scrap targets within weeks of the election.

Housing professionals claimed that abolition targets would give a charter to "not-in-my-backyard" protestors and increase rural homelessness.

Labour is likely to react by pointing to the Conservatives own poor record on protecting the countryside, not least from out-of-town supermarkets of the kind built by Mr Norman's previous employer, Asda.

Shadow minister for regeneration Tim Loughton spoke out on a visit to Stevenage in Hertfordshire, where a Liberal Democrat-Labour coalition is looking to construct 10,000 buildings on the county's green belt.

He said: "Across the country, Labour with their Lib Dem cronies, are planning to concrete over the countryside and bulldoze the green belt. John Prescott is issuing Soviet-style diktats to local councils forcing them to construct millions of buildings on greenfield land."

Mr Norman said: "I can pledge the next Conservative government will abolish these national and regional housebuilding targets within weeks of taking office. Conservatives will protect the green belt from further encroachment and make it easier for councils to designate more land with green belt protection."

Pressure on greenfield land has been particularly intense since government estimates, made during the Conservative administration, projected that 4.4m new households will form over the next 20 years. That figure has been revised down to 3.8m but government staticians have confirmed that demand for new homes will be acute because of greater longevity and higher divorce rates.

Sharon Hedges, policy officer at the south-east region of National Housing Federation, said: "Housebuilding targets, including targets for affordable housing, are an important tool in planning to meet housing need in a structured and appropriate way."

"Abolition would lead to a charter for 'nimbyism' and undoubtedly mean more people in local communities facing homelessness or inadequate housing."

She added: "Some managed release of greenfield sites is inevitable if we are to provide the homes that people need. Many rural communities are crying out for more affordable housing for local people.

"Quality design and landscaping can enhance the visual image. New homes with effective insulation, grey water recycling and other sustainable measures will contribute to the overall protection of the environment.

Nigel Kersey, senior policy officer at the Council Protection of Rural England, said the Tories campaign could "might go some way to high light the failures in the planning system".

He added: "House building rates should be based on the ability of the environment to accommodate new development and be informed by meaningful projections at the county level. Regional targets fail on both counts."

A spokesman for Mr Prescott said: "We will not weaken in any way our strict controls on development in the countryside. To suggest that the green belt is under threat is simply unfounded. It has actually been strengthened in this parliament by 30,000 hectares, or three times the size of Bristol."

webTitle: Guardian is most popular online paper

fields.headline: Guardian is most popular online paper
fields.trailText:
6.15pm: Guardian Unlimited has become the most popular newspaper on the internet, recording more than 2.4m users in March.
05.04.2001: Guardian Unlimited unveils first TV adverts
fields.body:
Guardian Unlimited has become the most popular newspaper on the internet, recording more than 2.4m users in March, according to new audited figures.

Page impressions were up 5m on February's figure of 25.5m to 30.2m.

This brought GU close to FT.com's latest page impression figures of 39m but beat its latest user figures of 1.7m.

Simon Waldman, GU's director of digital publishing, said: "This is a terrific achievement. We are the only publisher to regularly audit our traffic and user figures as it is hugely important to register the pattern of growth for both us and our advertisers."

GU has picked up 12 awards in the past year.

Its most recent accolade was the Newspaper award for best newspaper on the worldwide web, which GU won for the second year running.

Related story

webTitle: Barclaycard named as new Premier League sponsors

fields.headline: Barclaycard named as new Premier League sponsors
fields.trailText: Barclaycard have been unveiled as the new sponsors of the FA Premier League.
fields.body:
Barclaycard have been unveiled as the new sponsors of the FA Premier League.

The deal, worth £48m over three years, will see the league named the FA Barclaycard Premiership from next season. The decision followed a meeting today of the FA Premier League clubs, who unanimously agreed the new deal.

Current sponsors Carling, whose deal expires this season, paid £36m for their three-year sponsorship of the Premier League so the new deal represents a 33% increase.

The league's chief executive, Richard Scudamore, said: "This is an exceptionally good deal for both parties.

"This is a great opportunity for the league and Barclaycard to build on each other's strength and growing reputation throughout the world."

Barclaycard chief executive Bob Potts added: "The Premiership will be the platform to take our business into a league of its own. This is the kind of significant strategic investment which we have been looking to make for some time."

fields.headline: Barclaycard teams up with Premier League
fields.trailText:
6.30pm: Barclaycard has signed a £48m deal to become the new sponsor of the FA Premier League, writes Julia Day.
26.03.2001: Global companies eye Premier League
fields.body:
Barclaycard has signed a £48m deal to become the new sponsor of the FA Premier League.

The deal, worth £48m over three years, will result in the league being renamed the FA Barclaycard Premiership from next season.

The sponsorship was unanimously agreed by the FA Premier League clubs today.

The deal represents a 33% increase on the sponsorship's value.

Carling, whose sponsorship expires this season, paid £36m for its three-year association with the league.

The Premier League chief executive, Richard Scudamore, said: "This is an exceptionally good deal for both parties.

"It is a great opportunity for the league and Barclaycard to build on each other's strengths and growing reputations throughout the world."

The Barclaycard chief executive, Bob Potts, added: "The premiership will be the platform to take our business into a league of its own.

"This is the kind of significant strategic investment we have been looking to make for some time."

The Premier League clubs have also given the go-ahead for the FA Premier League and Barclaycard to link up with the British Tourist Authority to boost the number of visitors to Britain.

Chris Smith, the culture secretary, welcomed the move, saying: "Premier League football is watched by hundreds of millions of fans throughout the world.

"Harnessing this global reach for the benefit of Britain's tourist industry is a fantastic way of getting across the message that Britain is truly open for business.

"I hope to see this imaginative initiative turn viewers into visitors."
