webTitle: Police cannot win on May Day

fields.headline: Police cannot win on May Day
fields.standfirst:
No matter what happens during the May Day protests, the police will be lambasted from all sides, writes Alan Travis

Special report: May Day 2001
fields.trailText: No matter what happens during the May Day protests, the police will be lambasted from all sides, writes Alan Travis.
fields.body:
There is now an almost ritualistic element in the build-up to the May Day clashes between "anarchists" and police. The anarchist groups' refusal to share their planned routes and activities makes the police suspect they are intent on more than celebrating the right to peaceful protest.

The political and media speculation sparked by that secrecy and the scale of the police response required provides the anarchists with an annual public platform beyond the dreams of the 1990s poll tax protesters.

In 1999 the city of London police were heavily criticised when the Carnival Against Capitalism flared up, resulting in £2m of damage to shops and businesses. Last year the police took a more organised but less confrontational approach, and were again criticised when the 5,000-strong protest caused minor criminal damage in Parliament Square, the desecration of the Cenotaph and the destruction of a McDonald's restaurant.

This year police have stepped up their approach. Some 5,000 officers are reportedly ready to deal with the threat of an afternoon's 'free shopping' in Oxford Street.

Ken Livingstone has called on Londoners to boycott the May Day Monopoly actions, calling their chosen apparel of masks and padded boiler suits deliberately provocative. Toby Harris of the London police authority has underlined the new zero tolerance by warning of the use of rubber bullets "in extremis".

The police have sent out letters to businesses in the Oxford Street area containing such dire warnings that many have decided not to come into work tomorrow. The anarchists hide behind their website anonymity, threatening "the pigs" and urging their supporters to "mask up".

Each group, whether it is the Wombles, Reclaim the Streets or Class War, have lately secured more publicity than they muster in the other 11 months of the year put together.

Unsurprisingly few people want to go near such a polarised event. The police cannot win. If all goes peacefully tomorrow they will be accused of having over-reacted. If there is much violence, they will be criticised for intelligence failures. The nearness of the general election heightens the dilemma.

One radical American comedian suggested in the late 1960s that the annual battles between the Los Angeles police department and Californian students should be held in a baseball stadium in front of a paying audience, so that the whole thing could be self-financing.

Everyone has had their fun and the demo has already served its purpose. What actually happens tomorrow has almost become irrelevant in comparison with the pre-match hype.

Everyone has had their fun and the demo has already served its purpose. What actually happens tomorrow has almost become irrelevant in comparison with the pre-match hype. webTitle: Peers begin investigation into stem cell research

fields.headline: Peers begin investigation into stem cell research
fields.trailText: The newly appointed House of Lords' committee on stem cell research this afternoon began its investigation into one of the most contentious areas of scientific research, by visiting the Medical Research Council's clinical sciences centre in London.
fields.body:
The newly appointed House of Lords' committee on stem cell research this afternoon began its investigation into one of the most contentious areas of scientific research, by visiting the Medical Research Council's clinical sciences centre in London.

Stem cell research allows scientists to develop human tissues, with huge potential benefits for health: theoretically any tissue in the body could be augmented. For example, this could offer hope to people suffering debilitating diseases involving either their brain or their muscles.

But the research is an area of huge controversy, with protestors - including the Pope - alleging that man is playing God, particularly because some researchers use cells from human embryos and cadaveric fetal tissue.

At the beginning of the year, the Lords passed a bill allowing stem cell research to be carried out into two new areas, including serious diseases, but only on the proviso that a new committee be established to discuss the research.

Today's visit clinical sciences centre is supposed to help the committee understand exactly what the research involves and how it is carried.

The director of the centre, who is also the leading scientific expert for the committee, Professor Chris Higgins said, "Very few people actually use embryos.

"People do get worried about stem cell research, until you explain what it actually involves. You can actually match cells to a person, making treatment easier."

Theoretically, cells could be implanted into the heads of people with Parkinson's disease, offering a new and exciting treatment for the condition. But Professor Higgins emphasises that all these possibilities are a long way in the future.

The clerk of the select committee, Tony Rawsthorne, stressed that their examination of the implications of stem cell research had only just begun and that few responses to their questionnaire had been received. The committee is expected to finish their report by the end of the year.

fields.headline: Drug data shows promise
fields.trailText: Biotechnology company Antisoma is set to disclose encouraging data today on a breast cancer drug licensed from the Imperial Cancer Research Fund.
fields.body:
Biotechnology company Antisoma is set to disclose encouraging data today on a breast cancer drug licensed from the Imperial Cancer Research Fund.

The treatment, Therex, mimics the action of human antibodies in stimulating the body's defences against tumours. It revives the immune system in relapsed cancer patients, who often stop producing useful antibodies.

A study in the Netherlands has suggested that even at low levels, the drug can seek and destroy cancer cells. It appears to work better than human antibodies in patients still producing them.

The Dutch researchers were using blood samples from cancer patients. Antisoma completed a phase-one clinical trial of Therex at Guy's Hospital in London last year, showing that the product is safe and well tolerated.

Production of large quantities of the drug is underway, in preparation for phase-two trials next year. The trials are likely to involve several hundred volunteers.

Antisoma bought the rights to Therex from the Imperial Cancer Research Fund, which will get royalties on future sales and has a 5 per cent stake in the company.

The cancer charity also discovered Antisoma's lead product Theragyn, which is now in phase-three trials for ovarian cancer.

webTitle: Drug cost dithering 'lets MS get worse'

fields.headline: Drug cost dithering 'lets MS get worse'
fields.standfirst: Patients ailing beyond help while NHS bill for treatment is assessed, says Multiple Sclerosis Society
fields.trailText: Hundreds of people with multiple sclerosis are deteriorating past the point where they can be helped by the only drug neurologists believe can stall the disease, a patients' support group claimed yesterday.
fields.body:
Hundreds of people with multiple sclerosis are deteriorating past the point where they can be helped by beta interferon, the only drug neurologists believe can stall the disease, while a government institute drags its feet on whether the NHS can afford to pay for it, a patients' support group claimed yesterday.

MS patients have been waiting since August 1999 for a decision. "The whole way this has been handled has been dishonourable, disgraceful and disgusting," said Peter Cardy, chairman of the MS Society.

The national institute for clinical excellence (Nice) was established by the government to stamp out the "postcode lottery" in the NHS whereby one health authority will pay for a certain drug or treatment but another will not. Its remit is to appraise new drugs, treatments and guidelines, and to advise ministers on what the NHS could and should afford.

A significant number of new drugs have been appraised since Nice was set up in April 1999, including Relenza for flu, and various expensive cancer drugs. Drugs for motor neurone disease and Alzheimer's, both degenerative disorders like MS, have been approved even though, like beta interferon, they are said to give only marginal benefits.

Most appraisals take about a year, but MS sufferers have been waiting for a decision on the newer drug, glatiramer acetate (whose brand name is Capaxone), also for more than 20 months.

Part of the delay was caused by the appeal - by MS patient groups, neurologists, the Royal College of Nursing and drug manufacturers - against Nice's original decision to ban the drugs from the health service. The appeal was upheld and the appraisal committee looked again at the drugs.

A decision was expected last December, but Nice then decided to commission research into the cost to the health service. It has now said the decision will be made in July.

People with MS have been picketing Nice board meetings in protest at the delay, which Mr Cardy believes is unforgivable. "It has allowed hundreds of people to cease to be eligible for treatment, even if it finally recommends treatment."

Beta interferons have to be prescribed while the patient is still active. David Lloyd is a perfect candidate, but is 21st on his local drugs waiting list; like many health authorities East Lancashire capped the amount it was willing to spend on beta interferon, which costs about £10,000 per patient per year.

Dr Lloyd, who is 35, used to work for the authority and understands the predicament. "They must stay within budget. My beef isn't with the health authority, it's with the national institute taking so long." MS hit him suddenly around Christmas 1999.

"I had trouble asking for a 30ml syringe, then my hands started to go numb. Then it progressed. By the time they diagnosed it, it had affected most of my body - I couldn't put a drip in properly."

He worked at getting very fit, but the relapses set him back. "It's like someone has taken out the good battery and left you a half spent one," he said.

His neurologist believes he needs to have beta interferon soon. He is taking mitozantone, part of a cocktail of drugs used in leukaemia treatment that is quite toxic. But no one can take this for more than two years because it damages the heart. Dr Lloyd takes it every three months; it makes him vomit for several days before it works.

Mr Cardy believes that Nice is not taking fully into account the devastating nature of the disease, which in the worst cases can leave people totally disabled and others unaware of what is going on.

For Nice, the exercise is the hardest it has had to undertake. Beta interferon is considered to have only a modest benefit in slowing down the disease's progress, a fact that the institute must set against the cost to the NHS of a drug that many people could be on for years. The institute says it is trying to be fair to everyone and is participating in an economic modelling exercise.

Mr Cardy claims Nice is dragging its heels over cost alone. "Sir Michael Rawlins [chairman of Nice] has said it is the price that's too high. He has made it clear that he believes the MS societies should be lobbying companies to lower the price to about £3,000."

But the drug is widely available abroad. Dr Lloyd, for one, thinks that if the decision is an economic one, the government, and not the institute, should be making it.

fields.headline: Getting to the top of the class
fields.standfirst: If we want to be fair to children from working-class homes, those from the middle classes will have to move over and make room for them
fields.trailText: When it comes to social mobility, what goes up tries very hard not to come down.
fields.body:
When it comes to social mobility, what goes up tries very hard not to come down.

Middle-class parents pay for private schools; they move into the catchment areas of good state schools; they manipulate tax regimes to ensure that their children inherit property; they pull strings to get job interviews and network like mad. Policy-makers trying to do anything about these social facts face in-built resistance to change in the social structure. They run up against the Daily Mail's cry: it's only natural for parents to protect their own.

But not that natural, it turns out. Middle-class people do reproduce their success in their offspring as a general rule. To put the point formally, there is a strong association between class origins and class destinations. It is explained not just by access to schools and university but by the material advantages of a good background.

The proportion of middle-class men (the data are not too hot on women, because they relate to jobs and women arrived in the upper sections of the labour market only recently) who were socially "stable" did not change much during the 20th century. But this was not true of them all. Of the generation born in the first decade of the century, 39% stayed put in the social class of their fathers but 21% dropped down. Of the generation born in the middle of the last century and now nearing their 50th birthday, 35% have stayed in their father's social class but 13% fell down the ladder.

The chart shows that most working-class sons have working-class fathers; ditto sons of men in professional or managerial positions. But there is no perfect correlation between parents' position in the distribution of earnings and that of their children. There is a 40-60% probability that the middle classes will reproduce themselves.

All very interesting, a new report from the Cabinet Office's performance and innovation unit* says. But does it matter? The report will be circulated in Whitehall but it is not self-evident that even a government committed to "modernisation" could or should have a policy on mobility. A mobile society where winners took all would not do much for feelings of fraternity, as Tony Blair has recognised in recent speeches that have studiously avoided the term meritocracy.

No one knows how much mobility is needed for economic success. The US does well but, contrary to myth, is no more open a society than the UK in terms of social origins and destinations. Australia's economic record is patchy yet it is a more fluid society than the UK. We rank with France, Germany and the Netherlands in terms of the likelihood of children leaving the social class of their parents in order to move up (or down).

Thanks to work by sociologists at Nuffield College, Oxford - one of the most privileged academic environments in a university with an intake heavily biassed towards private schools - we know a lot about social mobility in the UK. Since 1945 ours has become a more middle-class society; the manual working class is a thing of the past in terms of social identification. Lots of people now do jobs in IT, call centres and the like. There is, as they say, more "room at the top", thanks to the expansion of white-collar and professional employment. Mobility has grown.

But not in relative terms. Class continues to matter in the sense that the odds of a working-class child ending up middle-class have not changed much over recent decades and may even have worsened. What has happened is that the classes out of which people are not moving have shrunk.

Will education continue to be the route to success that it has been for the postwar generations? Maybe the kind of jobs being created these days favour "middle-class" social skills. Increasingly it may not so much be education that counts as the unexaminable qualities associated with home background. Sociologists also note how middle-class families "hoard" opportunities by, for example, constructing barriers to entry to certain jobs - try becoming a QC without going to the right university then pupilling in the right chambers and getting the right kind of cases.

But mention the reform of the law and you are in the realm of political controversy. There is some evidence from Scandinavia that socially mobile societies are fairer in their distribution of income. Egalitarians therefore tend to be in favour of more ladders. Blairite rhetoric favours equalising the chances of individuals doing well in life which implies improving access to schools and - the reason Gordon Brown made such a fuss last year about Laura Spence's rejection - the University of Oxford.

Private schooling is not of itself a key to increasing mobility since rates of social movement are similar across countries where fee-paying schools play widely differing roles. But middle-class parents think a good school matters. That is why they colonise catchment areas of schools doing well in league tables.

Work for Demos by Ken Worpole showed how primary schools would have to be forced to take a mixed entry if the chance of a good start were to be made universally available - which could mean going back to the days of quotas for entry through ability bands. Imagine the furore. But an open society has to have losers. If the sons and daughters of the middle class do not vacate the top jobs and the number of desirable positions do not grow in number, how are the children of the lower social classes ever to get a look in?

*Social mobility, a discussion paper www.cabinet-office.

webTitle: Comment: The end for regional arts boards

fields.headline: Gerry's smash and grab
fields.standfirst: The replacement of regional arts boards with a national organisation is compellingly awful viewing
fields.trailText: The replacement of regional arts boards with a national organisation is compellingly awful viewing
fields.body:
Here's a strange little drama of how New Labour modernises government - and it's showing near you. Audiences so far have been modest, because the script is somewhat confusing, but it's worth persevering with: it's a classic farce rich in irony and paradox and by the end of the it you'll be rolling in the aisles.

The central character is complex: a charming, very successful businessman, with a ruthless record as corporate raider and a rags-to-riches background. The plot may seem a little obscure since it involves a small corner of government. But add in millions of unexpected extra dosh released by the Treasury, along with the corporate decision to take the public service ethos by the scruff of its neck, and Gerry's Smash and Grab is a tale for our times.

It opened in mid-March when Gerry Robinson (chairman of the Arts Council) launched a dawn raid on the England's 10 regional arts boards (RABs). He was freshly glowing from having wowed Gordon Brown (who plays a cameo role) with his Granada-Compass history of efficiency and cost-cutting contract catering to wrestle the biggest budget out of the Treasury in memory. A fat £100m was swilling about for the arts, and with the plaudits still ringing in his ears, Robinson pounced.

The action is pacy and full of surprises. Plans were drawn up in secret and sprung on astonished RABs, which were given six weeks to hand over all their staff contracts and assets to Gerry. The six weeks are up today and no one has handed over anything. Now there's a twist in the plot Gerry wasn't expecting: a debate in the Commons on Wednesday amid general uproar.

The script has been a virtually incomprehensible document, the Prospectus for Change, which is liberally sprinkled with keywords such as "modern" and "new". This is supposed to explain to the RABs' several hundred staff and thousands of artists whom they help what the purpose of the upheaval is all about. The idea is one national arts organisation with regional offices. A sweetener was added for the RABs: we may be abolishing you, but you'll get bigger budgets.

Confused by now as to what Gerry's up to? Well, you're in good company. Eight out of the 10 RABs are in a state of outraged rebellion. Instead of arts administrators getting on with their jobs, they're all in meetings trying to puzzle out what the prospectus means and what they should do about it.

Arts Council staff are zipping about the country try ing to explain the inexplicable prospectus to angry meetings of the arts community and the public. Gerry's apparatchiks are trying to pour oil on very troubled waters and, six weeks too late, they are lavishing soothing words about consultation and devolution on the ruffled regional sensitivities.

In the midst of this muddle there are three things on which the prospectus is clear. First, while it primly insists that this is not primarily a cost-cutting exercise, it admits that saving money will be one of the results. Second, it is honest about jobs: yes, there will be some job losses; yes, some could be compulsory redundancies; and yes, all redundancy agreements will have to be renegotiated.

Third and most importantly, whatever else this prospectus hopes to achieve, one thing is clear: it talks of a national "single voice" for the arts. It's the idea of Robinson with a loud-hailer that has really freaked out the RABs, who pride themselves on having built up distinctive and accountable regionalism. Local authorities are incensed at the high-handedness with which Robinson's plans sweep them aside.

This is the most contentious issue. Even Chris Smith at the Department of Culture, Media and Sport has made his nervousness clear in a conveniently leaked letter. The suspicion is that the Labour luvvies have nobbled Robinson, complaining of bureaucracy, and, as one northerner admitted, the Antony Gormleys and Anish Kapoors of this world would much prefer to deal straight with the bigwigs in London. Where the RABs play a crucial role is in building up and developing the work of local artists and communities who are unlikely to get to bend Robinson's ear.

It's the same hook New Labour gets caught on every time. All its rhetoric is to devolve, but its instincts are to centralise. After the Livingston/Morgan debacles in London and Wales, the talk is of having learnt lessons, but the Arts Council is flying in the face of this, defending its plans for this "single voice" on the grounds that artists should be able to expect consistency in arts policy across the country.

But is consistency such a prize that it's worth sacrificing local accountability and regional devolvement for it? The bitter irony is that New Labour is finishing off the work begun by the Tories in their mid-80s centralising spree when the power to appoint the RABs' chairs was shifted from the regions to the secretary of state.

Dawn raids may be good drama but they don't work in the public sector. The first sentence of the prospectus says that all the restructuring would be carried out swiftly while "consultation and implementation" would come in the second stage. Nothing now is going to happen swiftly, the sides are digging in for a long trench war. Meanwhile the trust between London and the regions (never high) has been spectacularly spent. This could end up a tragedy.

In the midst of this muddle there are three things on which the prospectus is clear. First, while it primly insists that this is not primarily a cost-cutting exercise, it admits that saving money will be one of the results. Second, it is honest about jobs: yes, there will be some job losses; yes, some could be compulsory redundancies; and yes, all redundancy agreements will have to be renegotiated. Third and most importantly, whatever else this prospectus hopes to achieve, one thing is clear: it talks of a national "single voice" for the arts. It's the idea of Robinson with a loud-hailer that has really freaked out the RABs, who pride themselves on having built up distinctive and accountable regionalism. Local authorities are incensed at the high-handedness with which Robinson's plans sweep them aside. This is the most contentious issue. Even Chris Smith at the Department of Culture, Media and Sport has made his nervousness clear in a conveniently leaked letter. The suspicion is that the Labour luvvies have nobbled Robinson, complaining of bureaucracy, and, as one northerner admitted, the Antony Gormleys and Anish Kapoors of this world would much prefer to deal straight with the bigwigs in London. Where the RABs play a crucial role is in building up and developing the work of local artists and communities who are unlikely to get to bend Robinson's ear. It's the same hook New Labour gets caught on every time. All its rhetoric is to devolve, but its instincts are to centralise. After the Livingston/Morgan debacles in London and Wales, the talk is of having learnt lessons, but the Arts Council is flying in the face of this, defending its plans for this "single voice" on the grounds that artists should be able to expect consistency in arts policy across the country. But is consistency such a prize that it's worth sacrificing local accountability and regional devolvement for it? The bitter irony is that New Labour is finishing off the work begun by the Tories in their mid-80s centralising spree when the power to appoint the RABs' chairs was shifted from the regions to the secretary of state. Dawn raids may be good drama but they don't work in the public sector. The first sentence of the prospectus says that all the restructuring would be carried out swiftly while "consultation and implementation" would come in the second stage. Nothing now is going to happen swiftly, the sides are digging in for a long trench war. Meanwhile the trust between London and the regions (never high) has been spectacularly spent. This could end up a tragedy. madeleine.bunting@theguardian.com

fields.headline: 'Language studies risk obscurity'
fields.trailText: The study of modern languages risks becoming either a rarefied study of obscurity or purely industry driven, according to detractors from either side of a debate about the future of languages in UK universities.
fields.body:
The study of modern languages risks becoming either a rarefied study of obscurity or purely industry driven, according to detractors from either side of a debate about the future of languages in UK universities.

The teaching of modern language courses for undergraduates has long been distanced from the leading research, according to practitioners.

"The problem is that people who become involved with research have very specialised areas of interest, but most people involved in teaching want to see them more involved with pedagogical research," said Elspeth Jones, secretary of the University Council of Modern Languages, vice chair of the standing conference of heads of modern languages in universities and director of the centre for language study at Leeds Metropolitan University.

But Michael Worton, vice-provost of University College London and Fielden professor of French language and literature, argues the real danger is that, as a result of fears over decreasing applications for undergraduate courses, language departments may be forced to give up their specialist studies of cultural, political and social linguistics.

"We should not become a glorified Berlitz. We have a real contribution to make to people's quality of life through research. It cannot just be about an undergraduate's employability," Professor Worton said.

Both sides of the debate might have some ground to concede: moving towards a greater skills emphasis in undergraduate teaching may not only be about employability, but about helping students in whatever they go on to do. And lecturers that are failing to keep up with advances in pedagogical research may find that, in the long run, they have made more work for themselves.

At least that's the unifying perspective of Mike Kelly, professor of French at Southampton University and director of the learning and teaching support network for language, linguistics and area studies.

He explained, "A lot of people are teaching in the same way they were taught. We're trying to address that. But also, at the moment most students are being taught only about, say, France and French. It's increasingly important that the skills they learn in relating to France are transferable, if they end up working in Japan. We need to develop programmes that take that into mind."

webTitle: World's first space holiday begins as Tito docks

fields.headline: World's first space holiday begins as Tito docks
fields.standfirst:
Special report: space exploration

Photo gallery: Dennis Tito's holiday snaps
fields.trailText: A Russian spacecraft carrying California millionaire Dennis Tito, the world's first space tourist, pulled up to the international space station today, within hours of space shuttle Endeavour's departure.
fields.body:
A Russian spacecraft carrying California millionaire Dennis Tito, the world's first space tourist, pulled up to the international space station today, within hours of space shuttle Endeavour's departure.

The Soyuz capsule docked just before 8am (GMT), ending a two-day journey that began in Kazakhstan. Nasa broadcast the 245 mile-high linkup, using the grey and grainy images provided by Russian mission control.

The Soyuz - Tito's taxi - made its slow approach with Russian cosmonaut Talgat Musabayev at the controls. A Russian flight controller asked how Mr Tito, the world's first space tourist, was doing. "He's doing fine," Mr Musabayev replied.

The Soyuz's arrival marked the beginning of six days of anxious monitoring by Nasa, who opposed Mr Tito's visit for months on safety grounds and capitulated just last week.

Alpha's three residents were under orders to conduct safety briefings and emergency drills as soon as the hatches opened. Nasa cleared the station crew's schedule for the rest of this week to allow time for "entertaining", as one Nasa manager described it over the weekend.

Mr Tito is paying as much as $20m (£14m) for this adventure of a lifetime. All of the money is going to Russian space officials; neither Nasa nor any of the other space station partners will get a cut.

Mr Tito, Mr Musabayev, his commander, and flight engineer Yuri Baturin were undoubtedly thrilled to reach space station Alpha, a palace compared with the cramped, spartan Soyuz. They have already accomplished their major objective: delivering a fresh Soyuz lifeboat to the station.

American astronauts Jim Voss and Susan Helms have said repeatedly that they would extend a warm welcome to whoever brings their new Soyuz. Russian cosmonaut Yuri Usachev, the station commander, has supported Mr Tito's flight all along.

The 60-year-old financier has strict limitations imposed on him by Nasa. He cannot enter the two US modules without an escort, which limits him to the two Russian-built compartments and his Soyuz.

If he breaks anything, he pays for it. If he is hurt or killed, he cannot sue Nasa. Neither can his family. Mr Tito agreed to these stipulations, in writing, before his launch.

Nasa cannot blame Mr Tito for the failed computer hard drives aboard the space station; they stopped working almost one week ago. The computer problems left the space station flying on autopilot for much of last week and almost delayed the Soyuz's arrival by one day.

By the time Endeavour pulled away on Sunday afternoon, all three command-and-control computers on the space station were working, but not all of them at 100%. Mission control in Houston scrambled to get the continuous TV link restored in time for Monday morning's Suyoz events.

Endeavour was about 80 miles away from the space station when the Soyuz docked, 14 hours after the shuttle parted.

Mr Tito, who worked as an aerospace engineer at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Pasadena, California during the 1960s, plans to focus on Earth observations and photography during his visit. He also plans some educational activities.

He and his Russian crewmates will depart on Saturday night aboard the Soyuz that has been docked to the space station for the past six months.

fields.headline: Electricity on paper
fields.trailText: Researchers from Brunel University's Department of Design have found a way to make paper circuit boards, replacing everything but the silicone chip.
fields.body:
Researchers from Brunel University's Department of Design have found a way to make paper circuit boards, replacing everything but the silicone chip.

A group of researchers at Brunel University is hoping to reduce the environmental impact of discarded electronic equipment by replacing conventional circuit boards with ones made of paper.

Three academics and three postgraduate students at Brunel's Department of Design have conducted a series of research projects on the paper circuit board. Their current project, funded by the Engineering and Physical Sciences Research Council (EPSRC) is concerned with how the components may be replaced, which if successful, would mean that all but the silicone chip could be replaced with paper.

Dr Peter Evans, who has worked on the various projects for some time, explained where the idea came from. "Our department has always had a strong reputation in environmental research, and it would have been the impulse to improve the environment which prompted the idea.

"Circuit boards are environmentally hazardous - the manufacturing of them is a messy and toxic process Ü and once produced, they are not safe to dispose of, even as landfill, unless they are treated. To get away from this would be of enormous benefit to the environment."

He went on: "Our group leader, Dr David Hansen, noticed that the little gold and silver metallic strips on greeting cards could conduct electricity. That particular way is unreliable and we quickly discarded it, but by then the idea for a paper circuit board was born."

Other attempts to reduce the environmental impact of circuit boards have relied on etching onto a surface. Brunel's model creates less waste than this method, as it uses the same process used to print magazines, and can be printed onto typewriter paper.

Circuits are, literally, printed onto paper using ordinary printing presses. The key to the process lies in the ink, a special patented formulation, which conducts electricity. The team has successfully incorporated paper circuit boards into a range of devices, from telephones to microprocessor-based products. Of particular interest are disposable devices, such as diagnostic kits used in medicine and industry.

As well as benefiting the environment, the new technique has the potential to slash the costs of producing circuit boards for many applications. The team are very excited by the potential of their innovation, and they are already seeing it make its way into industry. A company called RT Circuits has recently purchased licenses for the product from Brunel University.

fields.headline: Political scientists cite ESRC pressure
fields.trailText: The Economic and Social Research Council is trying to make political scientists into "ersatz civil servants" according to Professor Rod Rhodes, chair of the political studies association, by seeking research that is linked to current government policy.
fields.body:
The Economic and Social Research Council is trying to make political scientists into "ersatz civil servants" according to Professor Rod Rhodes, chair of the political studies association, by seeking research that is linked to current government policy.

The claim by the representative of over 1,200 university lecturers challenges the fundamentals of political research funding. According to Professor Rhodes, the ESRC is Ð perhaps inadvertently Ð pressuring professors to move away from qualitative long-term research and towards working in the short term to find policy implications.

"There is a recent trend around the notion of relevance. The ESRC looks over its shoulder too much at its paymasters, the government, and wants to inform its policy. It's skewing the system," Professor Rhodes.

Professor Rhodes felt the problem most acutely when studying the civil service. Government employees all agreed that his research did not need to be directly targeted towards government policy, but the ESRC continued to contact him asking about 'relevance'.

The ESRC does not agree that it is skewing the research agenda. A spokesperson said that, although much of their funding was organised through programmes and centres, a significant proportion is awarded through open competition for grants.

But other political scientists agree that the funding structure may have affected research, even if they would not go as far as Professor Rhodes does.

Professor Vernon Bogdanor from Oxford University said that, although the quality of research had not necessarily been affected, he believes that, over the last 10 years, researchers have been pushed into working in groups rather than following their individual interests.

Professor Rhodes believes that the ESRC attitude has to change. "It seems to me a recipe for disaster. It may sound old fashioned, but I believe the best way political scientists can change government policy is to do quality research."

webTitle: Research into higher education gets serious

fields.headline: Research into higher education gets serious
fields.trailText: The neglected elder sibling of pedagogical research Ð the study of higher education teaching Ð is finally getting serious.
fields.body:
The neglected elder sibling of pedagogical research Ð the study of higher education teaching Ð is finally getting serious.

Professor Noel Entwistle from Edinburgh University is taking 30 years of study about the primary factors that make a good teacher into 25 departments at Edinburgh, Coventry and Durham to look at what kind of improvements such an understanding can make to the way students learn.

A four-year grant just awarded by the Economic and Social Research Council is making the work by a team of nine researchers possible.

The group will first study lecturersÕ technique, suggest and discuss potential changes, and then study what impact those alterations make.

Professor EntwistleÕs main message is very simple: how lecturers teach makes an enormous difference to the performance of their students. At the most extreme, the method of evaluation used with students directly affects how they learn.

For example, multiple-choice exams can, if they are the only form of assessment, lead students to prioritise shallower fact-based learning over deeper reasoning.

Similarly, different approaches to everything from lecturing or marking through to behaviour make a huge difference to student progress.

"Many lecturers feel the research into student learning is generic and that it doesnÕt apply to them. In some ways, thatÕs true.

"By working with individual departments, weÕre hoping we develop ways in which the teaching and learning environment could be improved in ways that we havenÕt thought of yet," Professor Entwistle said.

The task that the Edinburgh team has undertaken is daunting, they are looking at 25 departments from various disciplines over nearly half a decade. Very few studies of higher education teaching have been undertaken on that scale in this country.

But, it might require exactly that kind of magnitude to improve our understanding and to make academics around the country take notice of advances in pedagogical research.

And Professor EntwistleÕs work is getting other researchers very excited. Professor Charles Desforges, director of the ESRCÕs teaching and learning research programme said, "his research is recognised as world class and he has built up a systematic picture of the drivers of quality teaching and learning."

webTitle: Questions raised over value of education research

fields.headline: Questions raised over value of education research
fields.trailText: Leading proponents of pedagogical research are questioning its value, particularly into areas outside of compulsory education. But the real question is how quickly it can improve.
fields.body:
Leading proponents of pedagogical research are questioning its value, particularly into areas outside of compulsory education. But the real question is how quickly it can improve.

"There is a general consensus that the quality of education research worldwide Ð not just in UK, but also in Europe and America Ð leaves a lot to be desired," said Professor Charles Desforges, director of the Economic and Social Research Council's teaching and learning research programme.

He believes there are three key reasons for this state of affairs. Education is extremely complex and bound up in individual relationships and in current public policies. But, the more significant problem is that there has not been enough funding and, when it has been there, it has been allocated incoherently.

One year, girls might do better than boys because of prioritisation, but after two or three years, he argues, funding moves on to a new issue.

While everyone agrees there has been some outstanding research carried out by some individuals, the question marks over particular areas and types of research have to be addressed by the profession.

"Some of the quality of research thatÕs been done hasnÕt been great. A lot has been small-scale and what I call Ôtrivial pursuitsÕ; not very significant," said Professor Michael Bassy, academic secretary of the British Educational Research Association.

But the greatest loser has been the study of teaching in the non-compulsory sectors, an area where there has been some fine research, but generally not on a large scale or across departments and disciplines.

There may be various reasons that research into higher education has not been prioritised in the past Ð partly because of funding realities Ð and there has always previously been more money available for the study of compulsory education.

Professor Desforges thinks that the more significant reason is that, until 20 years ago, universitiesÕ primary function was the generation of new knowledge through research, not teaching. It is only as teaching has become a higher priority that research into the area has been seen as worthwhile.

webTitle: Study reveals law can aid workers during restructuring

fields.headline: Study reveals law can aid workers during restructuring
fields.trailText: A new study of the shutdown at Rover's Longbridge car plant suggests the law can help workers during corporate restructuring, something that goes against the economists' theoretical and the public's intuitive perception.
fields.body:
A new study of the shutdown at Rover's Longbridge car plant suggests the law can help workers during corporate restructuring, something that goes against the economists' theoretical and the public's intuitive perception.

The work, which will be officially presented at a conference on May 19, was compiled by Cambridge University researchers Simon Deakin and John Armour.

Whether it is the shutdown at Rover's Longbridge car plant almost exactly a year ago, or Marks and Spencers' closure of French outlets, most economists assume that, at best, the law plays second fiddle to financial realities and, at worst, obstructs and aggravates events.

"The conventional view of economists is that the law operates like prices; certain laws can make a company more or less willing to take a decision. But, while theory is important, we didn't do armchair stuff. ItÍs labour intensive, but we interviewed all the participants, trying to understand the processes from their point of view," said Dr Deakin.

The two researchers found that the law played a much more dynamic role than cynics would expect, effectively supplying a platform for workers' objections.

It appears Ð though it has not been proven Ð that BMW broke the law by trying to sell the plant to the Alchemy consortium. That presumption was a key part of reopening the bidding and allowing the Phoenix consortium to enter the process.

Dr Deakin's point is that this is not just about pricing Ð the law can have an unpredictable impact on events that is much more complex than most current theories would suggest. Indeed, he believes that even more complex theories of business are required.

"There is an assumption that workers donÐt matter in restructuring, but the law actually subtly affects what happens," he said.

Although the results are clear, the public policy implications of the study are more vague, at least unless someone can prove how the relationship between law and business productivity works.

France and Germany have comparatively high productivity and rigorous labour laws, as Marks and Spencer's discovered. But it is uncertain whether the productivity allows the laws or the laws cause the productivity.

Without knowing which is the causal variable, only a very brave government would introduce stronger labour laws on the basis of Dr Deakin's research.

The work, which will be officially presented at a conference on May 19, was compiled by Cambridge University researchers Simon Deakin and John Armour. Whether it is the shutdown at Rover's Longbridge car plant almost exactly a year ago, or Marks and Spencers' closure of French outlets, most economists assume that, at best, the law plays second fiddle to financial realities and, at worst, obstructs and aggravates events. "The conventional view of economists is that the law operates like prices; certain laws can make a company more or less willing to take a decision. But, while theory is important, we didn't do armchair stuff. ItÍs labour intensive, but we interviewed all the participants, trying to understand the processes from their point of view," said Dr Deakin. The two researchers found that the law played a much more dynamic role than cynics would expect, effectively supplying a platform for workers' objections. It appears Ð though it has not been proven Ð that BMW broke the law by trying to sell the plant to the Alchemy consortium. That presumption was a key part of reopening the bidding and allowing the Phoenix consortium to enter the process. Dr Deakin's point is that this is not just about pricing Ð the law can have an unpredictable impact on events that is much more complex than most current theories would suggest. Indeed, he believes that even more complex theories of business are required. "There is an assumption that workers donÐt matter in restructuring, but the law actually subtly affects what happens," he said. Although the results are clear, the public policy implications of the study are more vague, at least unless someone can prove how the relationship between law and business productivity works. France and Germany have comparatively high productivity and rigorous labour laws, as Marks and Spencer's discovered. But it is uncertain whether the productivity allows the laws or the laws cause the productivity. Without knowing which is the causal variable, only a very brave government would introduce stronger labour laws on the basis of Dr Deakin's research.

fields.headline: Dorothee Metlitzki
fields.standfirst: Pioneering academic passionate about English and Arab cultures
fields.trailText: The professor emerita of English at Yale University, Dorothee Metlitzki, who has died aged 86, took an active role in the founding of the state of Israel.
fields.body:
The professor emerita of English at Yale University, Dorothee Metlitzki, who has died aged 86, was touched as a child by the Russian revolution, fled Lithuania for London as Hitler seized power in Germany, and took an active role in the founding of the state of Israel. She was an expert on Middle English, medieval Arabic language and literature, the Bible, and on the writer Herman Melville. Her definitive work on the intersection of Arabic and English culture in the Middle Ages, The Matter Of Araby In Medieval England, was published in 1976.

A master philologist, skilled in the history and structure of eight or so languages, she seemed to have all the major literatures at her fingertips and, science aside, there was hardly a subject on which she was not curious, well-informed, and able to speak about pointedly.

She was born in Koenigsburg, Germany, to a German mother and a Russian father, Israel Metlitzki. The family soon returned to Russia, to Yekaterinburg near the Ural mountains, where Israel was active in international trade. After the Bolshevik revolution of 1917, he was imprisoned as a capitalist, and his wife and two young children embarked on a two-year flight that eventually brought them, in 1920, to the Baltic port city of Memel, in Lithuania. There, Israel, a social democrat who had been freed from prison by his own employees, joined them.

Dorothee was educated at the gymnasium in Memel, then, when Hitler came to power in 1933, she went to England and enrolled at London University. She graduated seven years later with a BA and two master's degrees, one in medieval English under RW Chambers, and one in classical Arabic under Sir Hamilton Gibb, where one of her classmates was Abba Eban, who later became the first foreign minister of Israel.

She became active in London with the Zionist movement, working with Eban and the future Israeli prime minister, Moshe Sharett. She went to Jerusalem shortly before the war, and spent the next 15 years there and in Cairo and Tel Aviv.

A co-founder of the English department at the Hebrew University of Jerusalem - and of an Arab women's self-help organisation - after the establishment of the state of Israel in 1948, Dorothee was an informal, travelling ambassador for the country, speaking of the nation's ideals. She visited the United States in 1951, and returned three years later to enroll in the new American studies PhD programme at Yale.

In 1957, she completed her doctorate, on Melville's use of Near Eastern material; it was published in 1961 as Melville's Orienda. From then until 1966, she taught in the English department of the University of California at Berkeley, becoming, in 1964, an associate professor - and only the second woman to be given tenure in that department.

Dorothee then returned to Yale, where, from 1976 until her retirement in 1984, she was professor of English. She continued to teach and counsel undergraduates until 1998.

She had a deep love for Piers Plowman, on which she was writing when she died. She complained that for all his greatness as a philologist, Chambers had been too silent about its poetry and moral intensity, and one sensed that she felt called to make up for that by the substance and passion of her own reading.

Passion was certainly Dorothee's mark; it found expression both in her teaching and conversation, and in the warmth of her friendship. She was the most extraordinary person I have ever known. She was also a revered teacher and friend, with a stock of information and ideas not only on literature and the arts but on philosophy, on religion, and on all the important intellectual currents and major political events of the 20th century.

She was reticent about the details of her rich life, but one always sensed that her thought carried the weight not just of her deep and wide reading but of a life intensely lived. She went on teaching until the day she died.

She married the Cairo university Arabist Paul Kraus in 1943, but he died shortly afterwards. She then married the Egyptologist Bernhard Grdseloff, who died in 1950. A third marriage, to the Assyriologist Jacob Finkelstein in 1964, ended in divorce in 1972. She is survived by the daughter of her second marriage, Ruth Grdseloff.

Dorothee Metlitzki, academic, born July 27 1914; died April 14 2001

fields.headline: John Sutherland
fields.standfirst: Blubbing in public - it has always been part a good politician's repertoire. But has the cry-baby card had its day?
fields.trailText: Blubbing in public - it has always been part a good politician's repertoire. But has the cry-baby card had its day?
fields.body:
It has been a memorable fortnight for the hero's snuffle. First came Commander Scott D Waddle blubbing all over talk-TV about accidentally killing those Japanese trawlermen. But spill no tears for submariner Waddle. He will get an honourable discharge, full pension, and has some really great job opportunities lined up. Honourable?

A couple of days later, ex-senator Bob Kerrey, holder of the Congressional Medal of Honour, confesses "his previously undisclosed role in the killing of more than a dozen Vietnamese civilians". He claims his squad only fired after being fired on, but according to another account (disputed by Kerrey) the victims, including women and children, were massacred in cold blood after being taken prisoner. Honour?

All choked up and "close to tears" (of course), Kerrey stated: "I was so ashamed, I wanted to die." Fact is, he wants to live and be president in 2005. His staff got early wind that the story was about to break in the New York Times and on CBS's Sixty Minutes. They got the Kerrey remorse-retaliation in early.

It looks like Kerrey, too, will get off the hook. He may not now get the presidency but chances are he won't do time in the stockade, like Lieutenant William Calley, who was court martialled after the My Lai massacre in Vietnam. The message? You can kill Asians, without penalty, if you express public enough grief after the event.

When and how to blub in public is now as much a part of the American politician's repertoire as what tie to wear and at what stage in your career to let the grey flecks show. It is a big change in political culture. Poor Edmund Muskie washed himself right out of the 1972 presidential race when Nixon's dirty tricks men provoked him to on-camera tears. Gutless Ed, the electorate thought.

The master-weeper, the man who raised public blubbing to an art-form, is, of course, Slick Willie. Famously, he was caught on camera in 1996 laughing at the funeral of his friend Ron Brown (whom he was accused, by the vast right-wing conspiracy, of having assassinated). When he saw the lens, Clinton instantly changed his face to a mask of lachrymose anguish.

Clinton turned on the waterworks in Ireland, in Vietnam (whole buckets of tears - enough to drown any allegation of draft dodging), and in the Balkans. When he made his "that woman" declaration about Monica Lewinsky, his eyes were visibly "moist". He suffered.

The tears of presidential contrition were probably more real than those of compassion. But who knows? Clinton trained himself to cry on cue for the same reason that ambitious politicians learn to press the flesh, kiss babies, and smirk at idiot voters. It goes with the job.

Whether or not to weep is, however, problematic for republicans such as Bush. He can, when the occasion calls for it, pipe his eye in public with the best of them. When, in 1996, those Texas A&M students were crushed by collapsing logs from their campus bonfire, Governor Bush spilled what looked like an unforced tear (just one) on camera.

But in the past few months, crying has become a hot-button political issue. The "feminisation" of American manhood is now seen by republicans as something peculiarly and insidiously "liberal". It is associated in the hard conservative mind with those other "bleeding-heart" abominations: the "culture of apology" and "reparation" for the "crime" of antebellum slavery.

"I don't feel your damn pain" is the message currently emanating from 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue. Not being a cry baby has been strong for Bush. Hanging tough, walking tall - that's what the new guys are about. Did Colin Powell cry after Desert Storm? Did he hell.

The 43rd president has been conspicuously dry-eyed under pressure. At some point there will be another Columbine slaughter, Challenger disaster, or Oklahoma bombing. It will be interesting to see if Bush weeps. I doubt he will. Not even one tear. Now he's got the White House, he can be an uncompassionate conservative again.

And what of Bill's good friend, Tony? The prime minister swings both ways. He maintained a "British" stiffness of upper lip at Dunblane, Omagh, and even at Diana's funeral, when all around him were crying fit to bust. Composure became the PM, one felt. But Blair got all choked up and "close to tears" when he squared Euan's Leicester Square frolic with the nation. And he gushed, in true Clinton style, in Kosovo. The advice for Blair's second term? Lose the Kleenex, Tony. Crying is for losers.

fields.headline: Washington dream may come true
fields.standfirst: Special report: globalisation
fields.trailText: The World Bank's offices in Washington loom over Pennsylvania Avenue like a glass ocean liner. Inside the vast superstructure, the first thing you notice is the national flags of the countries that make up the Bank's membership. The second is a notice emblazoned on the wall reading: "Our dream is a world free of poverty."
fields.body:
The World Bank's offices in Washington loom over Pennsylvania Avenue like a glass ocean liner. Inside the vast superstructure, the first thing you notice is the national flags of the countries that make up the Bank's membership. The second is a notice emblazoned on the wall reading: "Our dream is a world free of poverty."

To which the snap response is: dream on. As the Bank is honest enough to admit, there is a very long way to go before global poverty is eradicated. The litany of horrific statistics is well known: 20% of the world's 6bn people live on less than a dollar a day, almost half on less than $2 a day; 10m children under five die each year from preventable diseases; half a million mothers die in childbirth from complications that could have been prevented with access to proper care; 113m children never go to school.

That is the magnitude of the problem. Nicholas Stern, the Bank's chief economist, calls them sobering figures and he is absolutely right. Stern also believes there is reason for hope, and he is right about that as well. "If developing countries, donor countries, and international organisations can work together with urgency, hundreds of millions of people will then have the opportunities to escape severe deprivation."

Inevitably, this will be a slow process, and the frustrations will be many. The reality is that the sort of changes demanded by campaign groups requirepolicy shifts by the rich and powerful countries that together make the big decisions affecting the global economy. This does not happen overnight but takes time and patience.

New sensitivity

The encouraging news is that progress is being made. The international organisations, the politicians and the campaigners in non-governmental organisations now all agree about what they should be aiming to achieve: hitting the development goals set by the United Nations in the mid-90s. Both the Bank and the International Monetary Fund have changed over the past 10 years, in part because their previous strategies did not work, but also because the governments of the countries that control the institutions have responded to public pressure for change.

The communiqué released by the leading industrial nations on Saturday committed the G7 to work on a health initiative to tackle tuberculosis, malaria and HIV/Aids, and to ensure that the debts of the poor countries are sustainable. There is a sensitivity to global issues in the developed world that was not evident at international meetings even four or five years ago, with this mood reflected in the commitment to the UN development goals.

Achieving these targets would involve halving the number of people living in poverty, cutting infant mortality by two-thirds and putting every child in school. Enshrining the development goals as central to the work of the Bank and the Fund is a big step forward, and its significance should not be underestimated.

While there is plenty of unanimity about ends, there is less of a consensus when it comes to means. In theory, it looks so simple. Those countries that have made the most rapid progress towards eliminating poverty in recent decades have also been those that have enjoyed the most rapid growth.

The number of people living on less than a dollar a day in China has fallen from 92m in 1990 to 54m in 1998, and is expected to fall to 9m by 2015. Why? Because per capita incomes are rising at 6-7% a year. In sub-Saharan Africa, where real incomes fell in 1997-98 and 1998-99, according to the Bank's data, the trend is in the opposite direction. Faster growth creates extra resources that can be spent on social and transport infrastructure, which in turn helps attract foreign capital, making the growth process self-reinforcing.

The advantage that China has is its size. With a population of 1.3bn, it is a potential market no global business can ignore, and is comfortably the biggest recipient of foreign direct investment among developing countries. Sub-Saharan Africa has none of China's advantages. Many of its countries are too poor to create the pool of savings necessary to finance investment, and foreign direct investment is hard to attract.

Debt relief is one way of providing poor countries with extra resources to kick-start growth. Money saved can be recycled into spending on health and education, which are now seen as the building blocks of development.

The Bank and the Fund believe that they have almost reached the end of the road with debt relief, and that the next step is for poor countries to improve the quality of their governance and liberalise their markets. Trade openness is seen as crucial if real incomes are to grow fast enough to reduce poverty levels. Poor countries should reduce their tariffs, rich countries should dismantle their protectionist regimes. The G7 is concerned that a new round of trade liberalisation talks is launched in Qatar later this year, something that is looking increasingly unlikely given divisions among the rich countries and opposition from developing countries.

The argument in favour of a round is that without one there will be a further retreat from multi-lateralism into regionalism and protectionism. This is certainly a risk, and there are those - such as international development secretary Clare Short - who believe that the way forward should be for the developing countries to agree to talks being started while retaining the right not to sign up to an inadequate deal.

Supply-side rigidities

Organisations such as the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development (Unctad) believe, however, that poor countries should not sign up to fresh talks until some outstanding issues from the last round - market access, the new regimes on intellectual property rights and investment measures - have been cleared up.

Unctad's annual report last week noted that because of supply-side rigidities "African LDCs [less developed countries] that rely on exports of only one or two primary commodities cannot take full advantage of global expansion by increasing their export volumes, while they often bear the full brunt of commodity price declines".

James Wolfensohn, World Bank president, said last week debt relief was not a silver bullet that would solve all the problems of poor countries. The same applies to trade. Historically, it is completely untrue that liberalising trade provided the engine for economic development. It was not true of the United States, which industrialised behind massive tariff barriers erected in the 19th century to keep out competition from more efficient British firms. Nor was it true of Japan or the Asian tigers in the decades after the second world war. Nor is it true of China today.

The economist Dani Rodrik says: "Countries that have achieved long-term economic growth have usually combined the opportunities offered by world markets with a growth strategy that mobilises the capabilities of domestic institutions." In other words, it may be that strong economies lead to trade, rather than the other way round.

Those campaigning for a better deal for developing countries see trade as one of the big issues for the coming years. There are three others.

The first is the need to keep up the fight on debt, where recent efforts meant discussion by the Bank and Fund yesterday about topping up - in exceptional circumstances - the financial help for those poor countries that find the repayments unsustainable even after debt relief. Debt relief has become a war of attrition, but there is more that can be achieved if the pressure is maintained.

The second area is aid, where the fine words of rich countries have not been matched by the delivery of extra development assistance. Britain, which has moved up from fifth to fourth in the league table of donors, is an honourable exception, progressing towards the UN's target of 0.7% of GNP, in contrast to retreats elsewhere.

Finally, there is the still fragile state of the global economy. Even here there has been some progress, with recognition by the Fund that short-term controls on capital are a legitimate tool to handle financial crises.

Much remains to be done. But the foundations for real progress have been laid. Now it is time to build on them.

Debt relief has become a war of attrition, but there is more that can be achieved if the pressure is maintained. The second area is aid, where the fine words of rich countries have not been matched by the delivery of extra development assistance. Britain, which has moved up from fifth to fourth in the league table of donors, is an honourable exception, progressing towards the UN's target of 0.7% of GNP, in contrast to retreats elsewhere. Finally, there is the still fragile state of the global economy. Even here there has been some progress, with recognition by the Fund that short-term controls on capital are a legitimate tool to handle financial crises. Much remains to be done. But the foundations for real progress have been laid. Now it is time to build on them. larry.elliott@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Grisly secrets of the 'civilising' Romans
fields.standfirst: British research shows they were headhunters
fields.trailText: British research shows they were headhunters.
fields.body:
Imperial Romans practised human sacrifices and head-hunting in ancient Britain while hiding behind the facade of civilising the natives, according to new research.

Dismembered bodies found in British sites show that the colonisers secretly flouted their own laws by killing humans to appease the gods. Babies, prisoners and elderly women were slaughtered in superstitious rituals which, until now, have been blamed on Celtic druids.

Human remains thought to be from the iron age have been redated to the second century AD, suggesting the image of rational Romans is a myth.

"We are getting some surprises. Killing people for religious reasons was supposed to have been banned by Emperor Augustus," said Alison Taylor, of the Institute of Field Archaeologists.

Historians have long accepted the official Roman version that the empire banished barbaric customs with a severe but enlightened rule of law.

But British bogs have yielded at least 10 bodies from the Roman period which were bludgeoned, garrotted, slashed across the throat and beheaded. The victims were mostly well nourished and some showed signs of struggle. Heads were placed at the feet, between the legs or upside down above the neck.

"It is a fairly consistent pattern. The practice went on for a long time and in a systematic way," Mrs Taylor said.

A lead tablet from a Roman temple at Brandon, Suffolk, was inscribed: "He is sacrificed to the lord Neptune with hazel."

Skulls excavated from the Walbrook, a dried-up stream near the Thames, show that at least six victims were decapitated and their heads left as votive offerings.

Bones have been discovered in ditches near temples and at the bottom of ritual wells. A shrine in Cambridge also contained the remains of babies and dogs.

Parents who could not afford to raise a child could legally kill a newborn, usually by exposure, but the temple discoveries suggest that some were killed as sacrifices.

Unlike the Celts, who practised a form of nature worship, the Romans had a pantheon of gods. At times of stress, such as war or disease, it was common to placate them with animal sacrifices.

The human victims, who were likely to be considered dispensable, would have included criminals, prisoners of war, elderly women and infants.

Romans believed the future could be divined in death throes. "The more painful, graphic and lingering the death the easier it would be to see the future," Mrs Taylor said.

The British School at Rome is planning to publish her research, along with other papers presented at a conference last month called Roman Bodies.

It has also emerged that the Roman army under Emperor Trajan developed a fetish for head-hunting: a custom supposedly restricted to barbarians. Nic Fields, a historian at the University of Edinburgh, said Romans were titillated and horrified by stories about the Gauls' atrocities, but absorbed their habits.

"The idea was to take the enemy's strength, please your warrior gods and flaunt battlefield prowess," he said.

A relief in Trajan's column, erected in Rome in the second century AD to commemorate the emperor's campaigns in Romania, shows a head swinging from the teeth of a soldier hacking at his next victim. Another relief on the Arch of Constantine shows Trajan accepting a head offered by one of his bodyguards.

Revered by many historians as perhaps the best emperor, he is also shown on a coin standing on the head of a defeated opponent.

"Rome was supposed to have stamped out this sort of thing, but here we have a barbarian custom celebrated in officially commissioned monuments and coins," Dr Fields said.

The soldiers depicted in the reliefs appear to be dismounted cavalrymen and therefore probably mercenaries, but there is evidence that legionaries too were head-hunters.

webTitle: Drugs fund set up for poorest nations

fields.headline: Drugs fund set up for poorest nations
fields.standfirst:
Special report: debt relief
Special report: Aids
fields.trailText: Leaders of the richest nations yesterday agreed to bankroll a multibillion dollar fund for new drugs and vaccines against HIV/Aids, tuberculosis and malaria in some of the poorest countries.
fields.byline: Jane Martinson  and  Larry Elliott  in Washington
fields.body:
Leaders of the richest nations yesterday agreed to bankroll a multibillion dollar fund for new drugs and vaccines against HIV/Aids, tuberculosis and malaria in some of the poorest countries.

The fund, worth an estimated $3bn-$4bn (£2bn-£2.7bn), will pay for drugs and treatments that already exist as well as for research into new vaccines.

Debt campaigners have argued that the richest countries, the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund have failed to help poor countries increasingly crippled by the spread of such diseases.

Yesterday's agreement was designed to show that the developed world is taking the health crisis seriously.

There was a heavy police presence outside as politicians and diplomats met in Washington, amid anti-globalisation demonstrations.

Against the furore over high prices charged by pharmaceutical companies for drugs to treat HIV/Aids and other deadly viruses, the fund will offer an incentive to the companies to carry out research and development work for poor consumers.

The US is understood to have earmarked $1bn for the fund, although officials still have to convince some members of the Bush administration that the infrastructure needed to spend the money is in place.

Campaign groups welcomed the fund yesterday but warned that more should be done to provide debt relief for poor countries struggling to pay for healthcare.

Two leading IMF committees agreed to consider additional debt relief for countries in exceptional circumstances. This could be a step towards allowing the cost of dealing with epidemics to be set against debt repayments. Sub-Saharan Africa pays $13.5bn in debt repayments each year.

Adrian Lovett, of the campaign group Drop the Debt, said: "Creditors have today admitted they will have to take further action on debt because of emergencies like Aids. The cat is now out of the bag."

Kofi Annan, the UN secretary-general, has said that between $7bn and $10bn is needed to pay for treatment in developing countries.

The World Bank, which met alongside the IMF at the weekend, expects to take charge of distributing the money to drugs companies and poor nations.

James Wolfensohn, the bank's president, has said the need to tackle health problems in developing countries is a priority for his organisation.

Nicholas Stern, its chief economist, said rich countries had to lower trade barriers and increase aid if the goal of reducing by half the number of people living in extreme poverty was to be met by 2015.

The bank defines extreme poverty as living on less than $1 a day. Of the world's 6bn people, 1.2bn fall into this category.

fields.headline: Henrik Larsson: the 50-goal man
fields.trailText: If there was an award for the British game's bargain buy of the past decade, Henrik Larsson would surely be the leading contender.
fields.body:
If there was an award for the British game's bargain buy of the past decade, Henrik Larsson would surely be the leading contender.

The 29-year-old Swedish international has been the key player in Martin O'Neill's transformation of Celtic from also-rans into champions. His efforts, as both goal scorer and maker, were recognised on Sunday when he was named as Scotland's player of the season.

He has been a prolific scorer since he arrived at Celtic from Feyenoord in 1997 for £650,000, hitting 117 goals in 156 appearances. His form has if anything improved since he swapped his dreadlocks for a shaven-headed look: on Sunday he reached a half-century of goals for Celtic this season with their third in the 3-0 win over Rangers, scored with typical panache from an almost impossible angle.

With three Premier League games left as well as the Scottish Cup final against Hibernian, he will surely break Willie McFadyen's Scottish record of 52 goals in 34 games for Motherwell in 1931-32, having already passed Charlie Nicholas's post-war record of 48. With 34 goals in the top flight, he needs one more to equal Brian McClair's milestone of 35 league goals in a season.

Europe's golden boot appears a mere formality with his nearest rival Malega Kezman of PSV Eindhoven more than 10 goals behind.

It is the second time in his three and half years at Parkhead that Larsson's goals have helped Celtic break Rangers' monopoly of the Scottish title deeds.

In 1998 his tally of 16 was crucial in Celtic winning their first championship for a decade under Wim Jansen. Despite a change of coach, with Josef Venglos replacing Jansen, Larsson continued in prolific form the next season with 29 goals in all competitions.

Only injury stemmed the flow when in October 1999 he broke a leg in a Uefa Cup tie in Lyon and as a result did not don a Celtic shirt in anger for almost six months. But fears that Larsson would never be the same again proved groundless and he achieved his aim of playing for Sweden at Euro 2000.

Despite all his success this season, Larsson remains an unassuming character. As for the records? "I don't really care about them," he says. "For me it's no problem whether I break them or not."

fields.headline: Auditors savage Harlow council
fields.trailText: In one of their most damning local government inspection reports to date, auditors today savaged an Essex council for providing poor quality services while charging some of the highest costs in the country.
fields.body:
In one of their most damning local government inspection reports to date, auditors today savaged an Essex council for providing poor quality services while charging some of the highest costs in the country.

Best value inspectors have told Labour-run Harlow district council, recently described as "the next Hackney," to examine whether its middle managers are up to the job of turning the authority round.

They call on the council to privatise a swathe of its core services, with street care, waste management and building repairs all mooted as candidates.

The inspectors also question whether the council has the commitment and capacity to push through radical changes.

Paul Kirby, central regional director for the Best Value Inspection Service (BVIS), said: "Harlow council has been providing poor services to local people. They have been paying too much for poor services, which have been getting worse.

"Harlow is the most costly council, per head, of any district in the country, with one of the worst performances across the full range of its services."

But Harlow has fought back, accusing the inspection team of lacking objectivity and making unfounded claims about the council's performance.

The Labour administration's leader, Alan Jones, said sweeping statements had been made about the authority's performance without comprehensive evidence to back them up.

He also claimed that the BVIS call for privatisation flew in the face of best value, because the regime demands that services should undergo a thorough review process before any decision is made about their future.

Mr Jones also rejected the claim that his council's services were still deteriorating: "There is very little evidence to substantiate this - and we can provide significant evidence that we are getting better."

The BVIS says Harlow needs to develop a strategy for improving its performance, as well as putting together a clear financial plan.

The report also slates Harlow for being overly bureaucratic. Rubbish collectors could be called out several times to tackle the same pile of dumped trash, say the inspectors, because the council only allows its staff to pick up pieces of refuse that a resident has specifically complained about. If any extra refuse has been added, it must be collected later.

Today's findings echo the scathing comments auditors made about Harlow in an initial presentation of their findings made to the council earlier in the year, and leaked to SocietyGuardian.co.uk.

Speaking shortly after that presentation, shadow local government minister Nigel Waterson said: "They're in a real state. I'd say they're well on their way to becoming the next Hackney."
