webTitle: Ealing turns out first film for 40 years

fields.headline: Ealing turns out first film for 40 years
fields.standfirst: Plus: grave matters for Hopkins in Prague; Courtney Love to play serial killer; Hollywood goes into hibernation as strikes approach
fields.trailText: Plus: grave matters for Hopkins in Prague; Courtney Love to play serial killer; Hollywood goes into hibernation as strikes approach
fields.body:
 The classic Ealing comedy name is to be revived, with Colin Firth starring in the first film made there for 40 years. A new production of Oscar Wilde's The Importance of Being Ernest will be the first film to be released under the west London studio's banner since 1957. Rupert Everett, Judi Dench and Reese Witherspoon are also among the stars of the $15m [£10m] movie, which has already begun shooting. In the 40s and 50s, Ealing became a byword for a typically English style of comedy, with the likes of Passport to Pimlico and Kind Hearts and Coronets. The new movie is due be released next year.

 Anthony Hopkins has upset locals in Prague by filming a high speed chase around the city's largest cemetery for his new movie, Black Sheep. Hopkins also upset locals by parking his trailer in the crematorium. Local resident Jan Stolzar told Ananova: "It may be a comedy but none of us are laughing. We want to be able to visit the cemetery in peace and quiet, not have it turned into Disneyland." Hopkins plays a CIA agent in the film, which also stars comedian Chris Rock.

 Courtney Love is to play a serial killer in the screen adaptation of the novel 24 Hours, to be directed by Luis Mandoki. Other actors set to star are Stuart Townsend, Charlize Theron and Kevin Bacon. Love said of the film: "I like this part, and it's a really fertile creative environment with a director who is really spiritual and deep and good with actors so I'm excited." Filming began in Canada last week, forcing Love to take a break from recording with her new, all-girl punk band BAS***D.

 Hollywood film and TV production has ground to a halt as talks continue to prevent planned strikes by writers and actors. The contract between studios and the 11,500-member Writers Guild of America is due to expire on May 2 and union members will walk out if there is no agreement by then. Studios have been rushing through television shows and wrapping up movies in an attempt to lessen the impact of any industrial action. "We've been unbelievably busy," says Dan Schultz, vice president for operations for 20th Century Props. Even if strikes can be avoided, studios plan to wind down operations this summer.

webTitle: Formula 1: Car fails Finn 40 seconds from victory

fields.headline: Car fails Hakkinen 40 seconds from victory
fields.standfirst: Finn breaks down on the last lap to gift Schumacher his third win
fields.trailText: What should have been the 19th victory of Mika Hakkinen's formula one career dramatically turned into the 47th of Michael Schumacher's when the Ferrari driver emerged victorious from the battle of the walking wounded in the Spanish grand prix here yesterday.
fields.body:
What should have been the 19th victory of Mika Hakkinen's formula one career dramatically turned into the 47th of Michael Schumacher's when the Ferrari driver emerged victorious from the battle of the walking wounded in the Spanish grand prix here yesterday.

As Hakkinen's McLaren-Mercedes rolled to a standstill enveloped spectacularly in smoke and flame after a clutch failure less than half a mile from the finishing line, Schumacher's Ferrari, hobbled by severe tyre vibrations, surged past to take the chequered flag.

"I have to say I feel very sorry for Mika," said Schumacher, who now leads the championship by eight points from David Coulthard, who finished fifth after a fraught and dramatic afternoon.

"I think we had both done a very good race, very entertaining up to the last pit stop. Then he jumped me because he did a better last section and I was a bit in traffic and having a bit of a problem on top of that.

"Seeing him retiring on the last lap, with five corners or whatever to go before the finish, was shocking. It's not the way you like to win a race, honestly. It's happened to me and now it has happened to Mika, but that's the way it goes sometimes."

Into second and third places came the former Indianapolis 500 winners Juan Pablo Montoya and Jacques Villeneuve, in Williams-BMW and BAR-Honda respectively, with Jarno Trulli bringing his Jordan-Honda home fourth ahead of Coulthard's McLaren-Mercedes.

The race turned out to be a damage-limitation exercise for the Scot after he stalled his McLaren just before accelerating away on the parade lap. At a stroke he traded a strong third-place qualifying position for a lowly place at the back of the grid, the rules barring anybody who fails to get away before the parade lap from regaining his original starting position.

Things went from bad to worse when he knocked his car's nose section off against the back of Enrique Bernoldi's Arrows and had to come in for a replacement to be fitted at the end of the opening lap. He restarted last, but plugged away to wind up an eventual fifth, increasing his championship tally by two points.

Hakkinen had been 40 seconds ahead of his Ferrari rival, and on course to take his first win since last September's Belgian grand prix, when a misfiring engine alerted his pit crew to potential problems a couple of laps from the finish.

The clutch had started to slip, allowing the Mercedes engine to "flutter" against its electronic rev-limiter, and the Finn was keeping his fingers crossed that it would last those final 2.9 miles.

Yet with two corners to go, belching smoke, the clutch finally flew apart and Hakkinen's gallant race was run. Schumacher, unable to believe his luck, limped by to score his third win from five races this year.

Montoya's second place meant his first visit to the victory podium in only his fifth formula one race. On a day when his team-mate, the San Marino grand prix winner Ralf Schumacher, spun off the road, the Colombian driver saved the day for the BMW-Williams team with a strong showing.

Similarly Villeneuve posted his first podium finish for the BAR team only 8.8sec behind the Williams. Neither of the former Indycar drivers used all the permissible electronic aids during the course of the race in the interests of mechanical reliability. Their conservatism certainly paid off.

Eddie Irvine had another disappointment when his Jaguar R2 succumbed to engine failure with 17 laps to go, possibly with his first championship points on the horizon.

After battling gamely with Olivier Panis's BAR-Honda in the opening stages, Irvine was warned over the radio that he had an oil leak with about 25 laps to go.

Rather than retire the car, the team instructed him to press on with their fingers crossed. Their audacity was not to be rewarded. "I used less [engine] revs in the hope that the oil problem would go away," said Irvine, "but it was no surprise when it stopped. A shame, because the car was pretty good."

His retirement rounded off a troubled day for Jaguar as their new recruit Pedro de la Rosa spun off early on after colliding with Heinz-Harald Frentzen's Jordan which also went no further.

The afternoon ended with Hakkinen being given a lift back to the pits on the sidepod of Coulthard's sister car. The Scot later reported that the Finn was leaning into the cockpit, fiddling with the buttons on the centre of the steering wheel.

"I thought, if he activates the launch control mechanism, this is going to be a lot of fun for both of us," said Coulthard later. After a day like that, it was reassuring that the two McLaren drivers retained their sense of humour.

It's happened to me and now it has happened to Mika, but that's the way it goes sometimes." Into second and third places came the former Indianapolis 500 winners Juan Pablo Montoya and Jacques Villeneuve, in Williams-BMW and BAR-Honda respectively, with Jarno Trulli bringing his Jordan-Honda home fourth ahead of Coulthard's McLaren-Mercedes. The race turned out to be a damage-limitation exercise for the Scot after he stalled his McLaren just before accelerating away on the parade lap. At a stroke he traded a strong third-place qualifying position for a lowly place at the back of the grid, the rules barring anybody who fails to get away before the parade lap from regaining his original starting position. Things went from bad to worse when he knocked his car's nose section off against the back of Enrique Bernoldi's Arrows and had to come in for a replacement to be fitted at the end of the opening lap. He restarted last, but plugged away to wind up an eventual fifth, increasing his championship tally by two points. Hakkinen had been 40 seconds ahead of his Ferrari rival, and on course to take his first win since last September's Belgian grand prix, when a misfiring engine alerted his pit crew to potential problems a couple of laps from the finish. The clutch had started to slip, allowing the Mercedes engine to "flutter" against its electronic rev-limiter, and the Finn was keeping his fingers crossed that it would last those final 2.9 miles. Yet with two corners to go, belching smoke, the clutch finally flew apart and Hakkinen's gallant race was run. Schumacher, unable to believe his luck, limped by to score his third win from five races this year. Montoya's second place meant his first visit to the victory podium in only his fifth formula one race. On a day when his team-mate, the San Marino grand prix winner Ralf Schumacher, spun off the road, the Colombian driver saved the day for the BMW-Williams team with a strong showing. Similarly Villeneuve posted his first podium finish for the BAR team only 8.8sec behind the Williams. Neither of the former Indycar drivers used all the permissible electronic aids during the course of the race in the interests of mechanical reliability. Their conservatism certainly paid off. Eddie Irvine had another disappointment when his Jaguar R2 succumbed to engine failure with 17 laps to go, possibly with his first championship points on the horizon. After battling gamely with Olivier Panis's BAR-Honda in the opening stages, Irvine was warned over the radio that he had an oil leak with about 25 laps to go. Rather than retire the car, the team instructed him to press on with their fingers crossed. Their audacity was not to be rewarded. "I used less [engine] revs in the hope that the oil problem would go away," said Irvine, "but it was no surprise when it stopped. A shame, because the car was pretty good." His retirement rounded off a troubled day for Jaguar as their new recruit Pedro de la Rosa spun off early on after colliding with Heinz-Harald Frentzen's Jordan which also went no further. The afternoon ended with Hakkinen being given a lift back to the pits on the sidepod of Coulthard's sister car. The Scot later reported that the Finn was leaning into the cockpit, fiddling with the buttons on the centre of the steering wheel. "I thought, if he activates the launch control mechanism, this is going to be a lot of fun for both of us," said Coulthard later. After a day like that, it was reassuring that the two McLaren drivers retained their sense of humour.

fields.headline: Tibetan leader at crossroads
fields.standfirst: The 15-year-old Karmapa has broken his silence to talk of his escape from China and hopes of travelling to his sect's monastery in India, writes Luke Harding
fields.trailText: The 15-year-old Karmapa has broken his silence to talk of his escape from China and hopes of travelling to his sect's monastery in India, writes Luke Harding.
fields.body:
What next for His Holiness Gyalwa Karmapa, Ogyen Trinley Dorje? The 15-year-old Karmapa, one of Tibetan Buddhism's most important leaders, broke his silence over the weekend for the first time since his dramatic escape from China 16 months ago.

At a press conference in the north Indian hill station of Dharamsala, the Karmapa revealed how he had jumped off the roof of his monastery near Lhasa, driven across western Tibet through the dead of night, and crossed the border three days later into Nepal.

The Chinese government had attempted to use him to woo support inside Tibet away from the Dalai Lama, he admitted. He had no plans to return to Tibet - unless, of course, the Dalai Lama was invited back as well.

Since fleeing China in December 1999, the Karmapa, who is head of Tibetan Buddhism's powerful Kayug sect, has been virtually imprisoned in Gyuto monastery, a previously empty and rather peeling building in the foothills of the snow-covered Himalayas.

Two months ago the Indian government finally granted him political asylum. The move allowed him to go on a pilgrimage within India to some of Buddhism's most sacred sites.

It also enabled him to explain for the first time the real motives behind his extraordinary escape. The unanswered question now, is what will the Indian government do next?

In his press conference, the Karmapa complained that he had been unable to travel to his sect's principal monastery, Rumtek, in the tiny mountain state of Sikkim. The previous Karmapa, who died in 1981, established the monastery after himself fleeing Tibet 40 years ago (at the same time as the Dalai Lama).

"Almost all Kagyu lamas consider it extremely important that I go to my main seat at Rumtek. They have made repeated requests that I be able to do so," the Karmapa announced three days ago. The fact that he had been granted asylum, but so far prevented from going to Rumtek, was "confusing", he added.

Sceptical officials in New Delhi, meanwhile, are now said to be busy analysing the Karmapa's comments. There appears to be a lingering suspicion in political circles that the Karmapa is not quite what he seems.

The Indian government appears unconvinced by the apparent ease with which the Karmapa managed to slip across the border with Nepal - and, perhaps, still suspects the Chinese of helping him. The main problem, though, is the vexed status of Sikkim.

Until 1975 this remote and spectacular Himalayan kingdom, with its unique flora and fauna, was independent, albeit under a treaty which allowed the Indian government to control Sikkim's foreign affairs and defence.

However, following a period of political crisis, India somewhat ruthlessly annexed the kingdom. Sikkim duly became India's 22nd state. The Chinese government, meanwhile, which itself invaded Sikkim's much larger Buddhist neighbour Tibet in 1949, has never recognised India's claim on Sikkim.

By allowing the Karmapa to take up residence in Sikkim, so the argument goes, New Delhi will further offend the Chinese, for whom the Karmapa's flight was a profound and avoidable humiliation.

But one suspects the Indian government is also reluctant to provoke political tension in the region. Not everyone welcomed India's annexation of Sikkim in 1975, and much of the state's unique Buddhist culture has now been subsumed by immigration from the rest of India.

The claim that the Karmapa is a Chinese stooge, though, strikes me as unreasonable and ill-founded. Having conducted the first face-to-face interview with him on Saturday, there seems little doubt of his sincerity, his resentment at Beijing's interference in his activities, and his desire to fulfil the role destiny has carved out for him.

Until the Indian government makes up its mind, he remains confined in the fourth floor of Gyuto monastery, with only his sister, who fled Tibet with him, and a pet Pekinese dog for company.

Indian intelligence agents and security guards live downstairs. Their ostensible function is to protect the Karmapa. But there is no doubt they are also there to keep an eye on him.

It would be nice if New Delhi gave this serious and exceptionally gifted 15-year-old the benefit of the doubt, and allowed him to take up residence at Rumtek monastery in the coming months.

webTitle: Call to give disabled real job opportunities

fields.headline: Call to give disabled real job opportunities
fields.standfirst: A change of strategy within the government means councils are dropping schemes to create jobs for people with disabilities. That's OK say campaigners, as long as employers accommodate people of all abilities
fields.trailText: A change of strategy within the government means councils are dropping schemes to create jobs for people with disabilities. That's OK say campaigners, as long as employers accommodate people of all abilities.
fields.body:
Paternalistic work environments should be consigned to history, according to disability rights campaigners.

In tune with the times, the government has been responding with new measures aimed at putting disabled workers alongside other able-bodied workers in the community. But there are fears that these may mean that some disabled people employed by local authorities will be in danger of losing their jobs. Under new regulations, councils are no longer required to help fund sheltered workplaces.

From this month on, individual authorities are no longer required to pay 25% towards the cost of sheltered workplaces. At a time when many local authority social services departments are under pressure to make savings to deal with overspends, there are growing concerns that one casualty may be the jobs that are currently offered to disabled workers.

At Gloucestershire county council, the social services department needs to make savings of £6.5m out of a budget of £88.5m. One option is to make around 50 disabled people, who are employed at the council's industrial units, redundant. The units, Gloucester Industrial Services (GIS), employ more than 200 people working on reconditioning wheelchairs and making double-glazed windows.

"The government is not placing the same conditions on us to joint-fund sheltered workshops as it did in the past," says Mark Branton, assistant director of social services.

"It is placing targets on us that are about moving disabled people into real employment in the private sector, as opposed to real employment within the units. The impact of that is that there isn't the same requirement for us to be providing subsidised employment."

And, he points out: "That means that we have to consider whether we should keep a sheltered industrial unit, when most of the government's strategy, in terms of the welfare to work programme, is finding work for disabled people in the community. It is not about running sheltered workshops ourselves, and many local authorities no longer run them at all. It is about using that resource occasionally as a way of providing rehabilitation to people."

Although major providers of employment for disabled people - including Remploy, which currently has over 10,000 disabled employees - agree that the aim should be to see as many disabled people as possible working in the community, they stress that what is needed is more options.

"Although the long-term aim should be to get as many disabled people into the community as possible, there is a need for a range of employment, because we have to recognise that the needs of disabled people are different. At present, not all employers are geared to providing the level of support that some disabled workers need," says Ray Fletcher, director of personnel at Remploy.

The charities Scope and Mencap also emphasise that, while supporting disabled people's right to acceptance in the workplace is vital, flexibility in what is offered is just as important.

Mike Stubley has first hand knowledge of working in a sheltered workplace. He works at GIS as a production superintendent and is disabled himself.

He agrees that the broad intention behind the government's strategy for the disabled is correct but argues that the reality for many disabled people is that the kind of sheltered workplace offered at GIS is likely to prove most successful for some disabled people.

"Unfortunately, not everyone is capable of working in open employment. The experience of many of us who work in sheltered employment with disabled people with different levels of disability is that we know that, for many, especially some of the older people, a sheltered workplace is a good environment for them to work in. It is important to see people as individuals and cater for them appropriately. In an ideal world, there would be adequate support and flexibility in all open employment - but this is not an ideal world," he said.

Sarah Everett, branch secretary of public sector union Unison in Gloucester, said the union would fight any attempt at making workers at GIS redundant and that one way of doing so may be to invoke the new human rights legislation. A decision from the local authority is expected next month.

fields.headline: The return of revolution
fields.standfirst:
Adam Fox welcomes a reprint of Christopher Hill's classic, Puritanism and Revolution.
Win a copy
fields.trailText: Adam Fox welcomes a reprint of Christopher Hill's classic, Puritanism and Revolution.
fields.body:
Christopher Hill will be 90 in February and some of the essays in this famous volume, first published in 1958, were written 60 years ago.

Inevitably, therefore, one or two have a slightly dated feel, such as the introductory conspectus 'Recent Interpretations of the Civil War' which, as he concedes in a new preface, are no longer quite so recent.

In more important senses, however, these studies remain as vital, provocative and inspiring today as they were to their original readers. Indeed, in some ways, developments in the study of seventeenth-century English history since their first appearance make yet another reprinting eminently justifiable.

For these 14 papers consistently emphasise, from their diverse perspectives, three crucial points which have tended to be lost sight of in recent years and all of which are well worth reminding a new generation of students.

The first is that one cannot hope to understand the momentous events of this period without a holistic and integrated sense of factors so often now abstracted and treated in isolation. As Hill reminds, and demonstrates, 'the connections of religion, science, politics, and economics are infinite and infinitely subtle'.

The proliferation of sub-disciplines within an increasingly specialised historical profession has often militated against a recognition of the interdependence and contingent status of historical causes and effects without which any analysis of change on this scale must be partial.

The second is to stress what a profound effect the 1640s and '50s had on the nature of English society. The reason that the second half of the seventeenth century looks so different from the first in so many respects - the plurality of political and religious ideas, the departures in scientific, historical and legal thought, the changing nature of economic thinking and practice, the developments in language and literature, the altered cultural ambience - is a legacy, on one level or another, to the revolutionary events of these decades. The consequences were by no means as thorough-going as contemporary radicals (or Hill himself) would have liked, but the Restoration of Charles II did not return England to the world of his father.

Hill's discussion of the 'Agrarian Legislation of the Revolution', which did so much to hasten the establishment of full market relations between landlord and tenant, emphasises this in one context; his analysis of Clarendon's writings, with their powerful sense of the momentous changes which he had witnessed at first hand, or of Thomas Hobbes' 'Revolution in Political Thought', highlights it in others.

The third point is the location of events in mid seventeenth-century England within the wider international context which they must be understood. 'The English Revolution and the Brotherhood of Man' demonstrates that the tumults taking place in these islands were both influenced by and, in turn, contributed to a European-wide process of religious war and political crisis.

As Hill shows, James Harrington's Oceana conceived of England's troubles in these terms. It was strongly influenced by the Venetian republicanism which its author so admired and it was, in due course, to have an important influence on the revolutionaries of America and France in the eighteenth century.

For these three points of emphasis, which yet remain insufficiently heeded, Puritanism and Revolution is still essential reading for all students of the period. That it represents the work of one of the twentieth century's greatest historians writing at the height of his powers, it is well worth the attention of everyone else.

fields.headline: Chesterfield bought by fans
fields.trailText: Chesterfield supporters have bought their problem hit club for just £6,240.
fields.body:
Chesterfield supporters have bought their problem hit club for just £6,240.

Former owner Andy Cooke, of the UK Sports Group, sold his 78% stake in the club to Chesterfield Football Supporters Society earlier today.

The sum was raised by 1,000 fans at the group's first meeting, which was held last Wednesday.

Chesterfield chief executive John Green applauded the fans' takeover, which echoes supporter-backed schemes at Bournemouth and Lincoln.

He said: "I think it's a superb move for the club.

"It's something I have mooted. I felt that the way football's going, it was a natural progression that supporters would be more involved in the running of the club.

"I'm extremely happy. The battle for Saltergate is still not done and dusted, but I feel that today's move is a pivotal move for Chesterfield.

"If we get a positive result tomorrow when the club's nine-point penalty is in danger of being increased, the season could have turned itself round inside 48 hours."

A statement on behalf of Cooke and the fans' group said: "At no stage during the launch meeting was it envisaged that, just five days later, the Society would be able to formally announce it had purchased a 78% stakeholding in Chesterfield Football Club.

"Darren Brown [the former chairman] was unable to secure borrowing and Andrew Cooke offered to take over UK Sports Group in the hope they could secure financial backing.

"Unfortunately, Andrew Cooke has been unable to do so - and is therefore willing to allow the supporters to take over the club."

The press release revealed Brown planned a groundshare with local rivals Mansfield, if he had been able to regain control of the club.

The statement continued: "Notwithstanding his apparent inability to raise money for Chesterfield, Brown has been keen to take back the shares. However, his stated intention was to place to club in administrative receivership, close Saltergate and be left sharing the ground of Mansfield for at least three years.

"Andrew Cooke did not feel this was in the best interests of the club and the town - and has therefore chosen to ensure the club is in the hands of its supporters, who thank Mr Cooke for giving them the opportunity of owning and running the club.

"The society recognises the immediate problems that surround the club.

"Player wages are overdue, there is a winding up order on May 10 and 24 hours after that there is a High Court hearing due where Norton Lea [the chairman before Brown] could possibly reclaim the shareholding from our new organisation. Plus there are many creditors, for both large and small amounts."

fields.headline: Hague finally gets it right
fields.standfirst: It took him a while - but William Hague has finally answered critics who have accused the Conservative party of being racist, writes Michael White, the Guardian's political editor
fields.trailText: It took him a while but William Hague has finally answered critics who have accused the Conservative party of being racist, writes Michael White, the Guardian's political editor
fields.body:
He took his time about it, but when he emerged from Tory HQ at 3.15pm today William Hague finally got it right. He announced that he had told John Townend to apologise for his inflammatory remarks on race and to promise not to do it again.

As a result the MP for Yorkshire East will be allowed to keep his party card and the whip at Westminster. The Tories are not racist, Mr Hague said with emphasis and - for the first time in this affair - some conviction.

It should be enough to persuade the black Birmingham barrister, Lord John Taylor, to withdraw three days of heavy hints that he is poised to do a runner - and quit the Conservatives for the multicultural embrace of New Labour.

But for many of us old lags Mr Hagues reluctance to discipline his 66-year-old colleague for his intemperate remarks about national identity, immigration and mongrel races recalls a similar incident - and a different response.

When Enoch Powell made his Rivers of blood speech at Wolverhampton in April 1968 some shadow cabinet collegues, including Margaret Thatcher, urged their party leader, Edward Heath, to wait and see if the controversy took off.

Heath thought otherwise and sacked Powell even as the Powellite surge swept through suburb and factory alike. Many thought he would regret it and be replaced by the mesmerising prophet of racial disharmony and unreconstructed British identity.

They were wrong: against odds as grim as Mr Hague faces on June 7 Heath beat Labours Harold Wilson in 1970. Powell had to wait until 1974 when he played the Europe card with greater success before he could gleefully hum a Te Deum as the Tories lost. But he lost too and never held office again.

Mr Townend is a Powellite, but not a Powell. He never rose higher than chairman of the rightwing backbench pressure group, the 92 group. But for the timing of his remarks and - until he was told to shut up on Sunday - his persistence - his views might have retired quietly with him.

So why did Mr Hague not swat him aside immediately ? After all, he took the Tory whip away from another MP poised to leave the Commons, Charles Wardle, on the (disputed) grounds that the MP had threatened to back an independent Tory candidate in Bexhill and Battle.

The contrast was a painful one and doomed Mr Hagues defence of his inaction in the weeks since Mr Townends. What was good enough for Mr Wardle (actually it was an injustice) was surely good enough for Mr Townend!

No one at Westminster seriously regards the Tory leader as a racist. He is the wrong age, class and educational profile. From the start he made clear that he did not agree with Mr Townends tone or content.

It is possible, but only just, to claim that his hesitation was prompted by decent instincts, by a broad church tolerance, a desire not to make a mountain out of an ancient East Yorkshire molehill.

But it is also possible to argue that party HQ hoped to exploit the ambiguity inherent in Mr Hagues very public dither. The moderates would be assuaged by his evident distaste for the Bridlington wine merchants language, the not-so-covert racists pleased by loud tabloid defence of the MP.

Thanks to the awkward Wardle precedent it was never likely to work and rendered Mr Hagues hopes of peeling minority votes off Labour pretty minimal. The moment Lord Taylor started to cause trouble the prospect collapsed to less than zero. He dare not lose a black barrister , pin-striped suits and all, to Labour. By comparison Shaun Woodwards defection would have looked a plus with hindsight.

In the event the Tories gained nothing in the polls, contrary to what some party officials had hoped. Nor has the asylum controversy done them much good. It will be harder to play it in a loose way now. Attacks on New Labour must be focused on the competence - or lack - of its vetting and admission policies.

Whether or not Lord Taylor signs up to the letter of support from minority candidates which Hague aides are organising (he surely will?) the incident has damaged Mr Hague by making him look weak as a leader - something he has fought fiercely to avoid with his tough guy talk.

Did Labour orchestrate Lord Taylors public dither? The peer was vague about it yesterday. Many MPs said Yes. It had the hallmark of a Millbank or Downing St job. The timing - and the choice of language - point that way too.

A bit of a phoney controversy to have dominated the media for five days, even by the phoney war standards of the postponed pre-campaign. There will be plenty more of this sort of stuff over the next six weeks.

webTitle: Statements from John Townend and Willam Hague in full

fields.headline: Statements from John Townend and Willam Hague in full
fields.standfirst: Special report: Racism in the UK
fields.trailText:
Statement in full from John Townend, Conservative MP for Yorkshire East:

I entirely accept that racism has no place in the Conservative party and am very sorry that ill-chosen words by me may have given a different impression.
fields.body:
Statement in full from John Townend, Conservative MP for Yorkshire East:
I entirely accept that racism has no place in the Conservative party and am very sorry that ill-chosen words by me may have given a different impression.

Accordingly, I withdraw the recent words which I have issued on the subject of race, apologise for the embarrassment which they have caused the Conservative Party, regret any offence which I have caused to others and undertake not to repeat them under any circumstances.

Statement in full from William Hague:

In politics, issues blow up unexpectedly, but they do give you a chance to say who you are as a party.

I want to say two things today:

We mean business about being an inclusive party that has no truck with racism, and we mean business about being a disciplined party determined to win the election.

Britain is made up of many ethnic communities. Conservatives believe that we are richer and stronger for it.

I want people from all communities to feel at home in the Conservative Party, which means that racism can never be at home in the Conservative Party.

I will not be driven by Labour's politically correct agenda that does not want to address their chaotic asylum policies, but nor will I allow John Townend's offensive remarks to be mistaken for those of the Conservative Party.

Today I spoke to John Townend and told him that unless he was prepared to apologise for his ill-chosen words, withdraw them, undertake not to repeat them and accept that racism has no place in the Conservative party, then he could not remain a member of the Conservative party. He has today signed a statement to that effect.

So we mean business about being an inclusive party that has no truck with racism.

But we also mean business about being a disciplined party determined to win the election.

And I cannot allow people in receipt of the Conservative whip in the House of Lords to agonise publicly about whether they support the party.

A number of highly talented prospective parliamentary candidates and Members of the European Parliament from ethnic minority communities are today writing an open letter calling on people of all communities to support the Conservative party in the forthcoming election.

Lord Taylor is being asked to add his name to this letter and I hope that he will be able to do so.

fields.headline: Race row Tory apologises
fields.standfirst: Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: The rightwing backbench MP John Townend has signed a statement undertaking not to repeat his comments on race, William Hague announced today.
fields.body:
The rightwing backbench MP John Townend has signed a statement undertaking not to repeat his comments on race, William Hague announced today.

The Conservative leader had threatened the MP for Yorkshire East with expulsion from the party unless he signed a statement apologising for "his ill-chosen words", withdrawing them, undertaking not to repeat them and accepting that racism has no place in the Conservative party. Mr Townend had signed a statement to that effect, Mr Hague said.

The black Conservative peer Lord Taylor of Warwick - who had urged Mr Hague to expel Mr Townend from the Conservatives - was being asked to add his name to an open letter written by senior Tories from the ethnic minorities expressing support for the party, Mr Hague added.

Earlier today the Conservative party vice-chairman, Steven Norris, joined other senior Tories in questioning Mr Hague's handling of the Townend affair, which has prompted criticism of the Conservative leader by the party's leading black and Asian peers.

Mr Norris revealed that he had expressed concern to Mr Ancram over the handling of Mr Townend's comments about immigration and those of Tory fellow-MP Christopher Gill, who compared asylum seekers to "rats in a bucket".

Mr Norris told the Evening Standard: "I made my feelings known.

"I certainly accept that it is William Hague's decision over how to exercise discipline in the party, and I accept the decision. That does not mean I welcome it," he said.

His comments come in the wake of criticism of Mr Hague by the party's leading black and Asian peers.

This morning the party's senior Asian peer, Baroness Flather, said that the Conservative leader should have thrown Mr Townend out of the party for suggesting that immigration was making Britons a "mongrel race". She said Mr Hague's failure to do so showed he was "weak".

Lord Taylor widened his attack on Mr Hague by suggesting that other senior Tories shared his anger over Mr Hague's failure to expel Mr Townend.

He told Sky News: "It is not just me. There are several others in the Conservative party who are very angry about this situation.

"Yes, it involves race, but it also involves leadership, ethical leadership.

"William Hague wants to bury the race issue. He can't do. It will keep coming back time and time again and will end up burying him if he doesn't deal with it."

Lord Taylor denied he had been "in talks" with Labour over a possible defection, but admitted that he had spoken to the party in the past.

Earlier he had warned that he might quit the party if Mr Townend were not disciplined.

Mr Hague had tried to end the race row engulfing the Tories by warning the Yorkshire East MP - who is retiring at the election - that he faced expulsion if he repeated his comments.

Writing in the Times, Lord Taylor said: "If John Townend is still in the party at the start of the election, my position may well be untenable."

He said he was looking for "certain signals" before deciding whether to quit the party he has repeatedly said he wants to stay in and reform.

Lord Taylor was today due to appear before the Opposition Chief Whip in the Lords, Lord Henley, to explain his comments about Mr Hague. But party chairman Michael Ancram today stressed that there was no question of Lord Taylor having the party whip withdrawn.

Mr Ancram said on BBC Radio 4's Today that Mr Hague had made it plain that he utterly rejected Mr Townend's comments. He told Today: "When he first made them, William Hague made it quite clear that the remarks he made were unacceptable and he repudiated them entirely. It was when he repeated them that we had to consider what further action should be taken.

"What William Hague has now done is he has shown he is not prepared to allow this to continue any further."

Lord Taylor told the programme that Mr Ancram's comments were "indefensible". "It is inconsistent, it is indefensible," he said.

Asked if he had had talks with other parties about defecting, Lord Taylor said: "I have always regarded my fight as within the Conservative party. I want to make it more inclusive, I want to encourage ethnic minorities to join the party, more women candidates, younger people.

"I really do want to stay - if I can - within the Conservative party. But if the whip is taken away from me - and I have been summoned to see the chief whip to account for my remarks - there is not a lot I can do about that."

webTitle: Ultimatum for Hague in race row

fields.headline: Ultimatum for Hague in race row
fields.standfirst: Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: William Hague's efforts to quell the race row within the Tory party were on the brink of collapse last night after the party's   most prominent black member, Lord Taylor, said he might have to quit if the backbench MP John Townend was not   driven out for racism.
fields.body:
William Hague's efforts to quell the race row within the Tory party were on the brink of collapse last night after the party's most prominent black member, Lord Taylor, said he might have to quit if the backbench MP John Townend was not driven out for racism.

Lord Taylor said the party was a broad church, but could not accommodate both him and Mr Townend.

Earlier, Mr Hague had acted to reassert his authority and multicultural credentials by giving Mr Townend a final warning that he would be expelled if he made any further racist remarks. Mr Hague had previously resisted calls to withdraw the whip from Mr Townend as gesture politics. But Mr Townend was not asked to withdraw his previous remarks, including a claim that British multiculturalism was turning the nation into a mongrel race.

Lord Taylor responded by describing Mr Hague's ultimatum as "pathetic and typical of weak leadership".

He said: "On at least three separate occasions Mr Townend has uttered racist remarks and William Hague has done nothing. What this decision amounts to is an acknowledgement that the party has a racist MP, but that he can remain a Conservative MP as long as he keeps his mouth shut. William Hague can make all the clever speeches he wants to about race relations, but people will not forget that he refused to act against a racist MP in his own party." Lord Taylor also upped the stakes by implying that Mr Hague should not simply withdraw the whip from Mr Townend but expel him from the party.

Earlier Lord Taylor had warned that he was staying in the party "for the sake of democracy, not out of any great love for the Tory party. I am not looking to jump ship. If they pushed me I would have no choice".

His remarks set alarm bells ringing in Conservative Central Office that Labour might be about to stage one of its dramatic pre-election defections.

Mr Hague had also been under private pressure from members of the shadow cabinet, including warnings that his inaction on the matter appeared tantamount to a covert endorsement of Mr Townend.

Following talks with the Conservative chief whip, James Arbuthnot, the party chairman, Michael Ancram, and some shadow cabinet members, Mr Hague ordered a final warning for Mr Townend.

Mr Arbuthnot spoke to Mr Townend twice yesterday and a party official said it was hoped that the MP would remain silent. In an initial sign that the belated warning shot may have worked, Mr Townend last night refused to comment on his exchanges. The clampdown came only 24 hours after it seemed that Lord Taylor, rather than Mr Townend, would be disciplined.

Following a coruscating attack on Friday on Mr Hague's "misguided advisers", and the racism within the party, Lord Taylor received an email ordering him to report to Lord Henley, the Conservative chief whip in the Lords, today. The email told him to stop attacking Mr Hague and suggested that "he should instead urge all black people to vote Tory".

Lord Taylor was later assured at the weekend that he would not be disciplined. However, the meeting will go ahead today.

Mr Hague has been resisting pressure to withdraw the whip from Mr Townend, an influential Eurosceptic figure in the party, saying it would amount to "gesture" politics since Mr Townend will be standing down as an MP at the election.

But this position was badly undermined by the sudden withdrawal of the whip three weeks ago from Charles Wardle, the Tory MP for Bexhill who is also retiring at the election. Mr Wardle insists that he was misquoted when it was reported that he might support an independent candidate in his constituency.

A final warning before expulsion, rather than withdrawing the whip from Mr Townend, was a much more draconian measure, Central Office claimed. The MP will not be asked to withdraw or apologise for his remarks.

Conservative officials admitted that Mr Hague had been infuriated that his goodwill multicultural visit to Yorkshire last Thursday had been over-shadowed by Mr Townend's press release complaining that Britain was turning into a mongrel race. The MP also claimed to have massive support inside the party, adding that his views on asylum were similar to Mr Hague's.

fields.standfirst: | Discrimination | The Concordat: CRS Career Management| Help | Your future| Understand your prospects | Publish| Bring in research funding | Keeping records| Networking | Training| Updating your CV | Promotion| When to leave | At the end of a contract| Contract extension | Web resources|
fields.trailText: In the second part of his guide to contract research employment, Alan Williams examines more ways of making the experience work for you
fields.body:
Discrimination
One major consequence of the almost complete reliance on fixed-term contracts for research is the scope for discrimination, either direct or indirect. In principle, direct discrimination during an appointment should not be possible, although procedures may not be so rigorous. For example, there is often scope for job specifications to be written to match the required individual.

Sadly, prejudices still remain within higher education. Women researchers working in a shared office have been assumed by visitors to be secretarial staff for their male colleagues, especially when answering the phone.

While fixed-term contracts are in such widespread use, there is very little that can be done about stopping this "passive" discrimination.

Of course, you should check the obvious: ensure that you are on the appropriate pay scale and point, that you get considered for promotion, and that you have appropriate parity with all colleagues (with issues such as authorship).

Many women also prefer to put off starting a family until they are in a more secure position. However, you should bear in mind that some people continue to work on successive contracts as CRS for 10-20 years or longer.

CRS should have parity in maternity benefits with established staff. So ensure that you can take maternity leave. Unscrupulous managers may use the vulnerability of your fixed-term position to persuade you against taking the length of maternity leave you wish to. Ignorant managers may simply get it wrong. If you are denied access, or feel pressurised into comprising, then contact your union.

To ensure that you are considered for future appointments, you should also state clearly, and early on, that you intend to return to work if that is what you want, as it may be assumed that this will not be the case.

The Concordat: CRS career management
The Concordat is an agreement made in 1997 concerning improvements to the working conditions, career structure and management for CRS. It is the result of discussions between the Committee of Vice-Chancellors and Principals (CVCP), the Standing Conference of Principals (SCOP), the Committee of Scottish Higher Education Principals (COSHEP), the research councils, and the British Academy. Unions were not part of the agreement.

The Research Careers Initiative (RCI) is the national committee set up to monitor the implementation of the Concordat. Its first report in 1998 contained about 30 recommendations that need to be followed through at a local level.

The aims of the Concordat are rather restricted, starting from the principle that contract researchers will be on fixed-term contracts for a limited time, and that an established career in academia or, exclusively, academic research, is realistic only for a minority. Essentially it merely encourages institutions to manage CRS better.

However, does it represent a small step in the right direction, since it recognises some of the problems of CRS. For example, it requires that institutions make provision for the full salary costs of named researchers, including scope for promotion.

So you should find out what the Concordat is all about. Has your institution actively been implementing the Concordat and RCI recommendations? Has it appointed an RCI coordinator and who are they? National agreements are one thing - local implementation is another matter.

Help
Do not assume that your personal development and role are only your problem, or just yours and your manager's. If you need to know how to go about something, keep asking for guidance. They are paying you, so they should use you effectively. Apply for internal funds for attending conferences and training activities. The worst thing that can happen is if they say no, but they will know you are keen.

Ask for regular appraisals. These are important to fall back on to demonstrate that your performance was satisfactory throughout your contract in case it is ever questioned at a later date. You can also use them to discuss issues such as promotion with your manager.

Your future
As a CRS member, the chances of getting a career in research are largely out of your control. Initially, you are reliant on grant holders and other more senior people to keep you employed. Then you become more dependent on your own skills for obtaining funding, but at no point do you really become any more secure. The longer you are employed in an institution, the more likely you are to be able to be successful in negotiating your own terms, including getting your name on papers, working part-time or other arrangements. There are several steps you can take to improve your prospects.

Understand your prospects
Contract research itself does not really amount to a career - the closest you get will be a string of contracts, possibly in different institutions or groups, covering a number of years. In fact, the policies of some research councils are designed to actively discourage researchers from being employed in such a way, with the aim of making sure they leave academia unless they get a lecturing post. Meanwhile, universities will wish to keep you, so long as the funding is there.

Make sure that the work you are going to do will be likely to result in the kinds of things that might provide you with future prospects of work: publications, conference appearances and relevant skills. If you want to move to a lecturing job, get some teaching experience.

Unfortunately, doing contract research often does not necessarily increase your attractiveness as far as future employees outside academia are concerned.

Raise the question of what is likely to happen to you at the end of your contract during your interview and at regular intervals throughout your contract. This way, you can keep track of any changes (for example to funding) that might affect your situation at the end of your contract.

Publish
You cannot have a successful academic research career without publications, so you should aim to write lots of papers and get them published in high-quality journals or conferences. Ensure that you are at least co-author on the papers concerning your research. Try to find some way of doing a single-author paper, perhaps on some "extra" research.

Bring in research funding
Regrettably, the opportunities for applying for research funds are not the same for contract staff as for tenured staff. CRS are often forbidden from submitting applications in their own right due to the rules of either the funding body or the institution. For example, the EPSRC forbids grant holders from paying their own salary out of grants, yet the ESRC allows it - make sure you know the rules of your funders.

Most of the research councils operate fellowship schemes, although usually for only a very limited number of researchers, so start applying for these as soon as you can.

Make absolutely certain that any research proposal you write - or collaborate in the writing of - will, at the very least, guarantee you employment on the project should the application be successful (it has been known for researchers to successfully raise funds only to find themselves unemployed). So ensure that you are a named researcher on the grant, and check that the requested salary will be sufficient to pay you.

Even if you cannot submit your own proposals, you can at least try to do some of the spade work, digging out grant opportunities and learning how the systems work. Help your manager to write proposals to keep the cash flow coming and keep yourself in a job. It is never too early to start investigating this.

Keeping records
It is worth keeping your own work diary, recording meetings, hours worked on particular activities, training, along with notes of your contribution to your research work. You never know when this might come in useful.

Networking
The chances are that you will find your next contract by virtue of your own efforts. A key factor is your network of contacts. Use every opportunity you get (such as conferences, workshops, contacts with industry) to extend that network. Know your rights and responsibilities.

Make yourself an indispensable insider if you can - look for ways to collaborate with others and ask about the big picture of where you fit in and what the likely future is. It is not always easy, especially for women, but make them feel bad about the prospect of losing you.

Contact established names in your discipline, and (hopefully) impress them. It seems that academia depends more often on who you know than anything else.

Don't forget the internet as a means of networking. Valuable international contacts can be gained from joining and contributing to email discussion lists in your research domain.

Training
Be aware that contract research is probably not going to be your gateway to a long-term career in academia. Get the most out of it while you can, but try to make sure you are training yourself for a future job outside.

Take every opportunity to get more training - not only training suitable for your current position, but also general skills that can help your career progression. You will be under a lot of pressure to concentrate on project work, but remember that your salary stops when the project finishes. If anyone tries to block you getting training, then contact your union.

Updating your CV
Be constantly on the look-out for ways to enhance it, both for academic and outside credibility. Responsibilities, local involvement, teaching, computing skills, a strong contact network and work abroad can all help.

Promotion
Like any other member of staff, CRS are eligible for promotion. In some cases, this is not taken into account early enough by project managers, and appropriately experienced CRS are taken on to projects where no allowance has been made to pay the extra cost of promotion. In the worst cases, CRS may even have to take pay cuts, work without receiving increments or have the project shortened because they were engaged to work on under-funded projects. This is particularly a danger when contracts are extended via follow-on projects.

The Concordat even advises institutions and funders to build in costs of promotion where there is a possibility of requiring them during the lifetime of a grant. The promotion would then be made in accordance with the policies and procedures of the employing institution.

So, if you consider that you will be eligible for promotion within a project then, before it starts, check that this will in principle be possible and has been budgeted for. When you determine that your responsibilities warrant promotion, you should get support from your project manager and apply to your institution in the usual way.

When to leave
By keeping yourself informed about the prospects of continued funding on your project, you will hopefully be able to judge whether there is likely to be future employment for you. You should therefore look at alternatives months ahead of the end of your present contract. Keep your CV up to date and regularly send it to prospective employers (you may even discover a job you prefer).

If you get an offer that you wish to accept, there is little point in staying to the bitter end of a contract that may not be renewed, especially if you are not entitled to redundancy pay. Dole gaps in your CV will do you no favours.

At the end of a contract
The period around the end of each contract can be messy and very stressful. Redundancy itself can cause many practical, financial and psychological problems to you. However, you may also be kept in a state of uncertainty about your future, depending on the success of a research project announcement.

If your contract is not going to be renewed, then your employer is required to follow a redundancy procedure in order to dismiss you fairly.

 Is it really a redundancy? Can the redundancy be avoided by re-deployment elsewhere in the university? The redundancy should be far more pro-active than pointing you to the list of vacancies, and may involve retraining or utilising a bridging fund to cover short funding gaps.

 Mitigation: Your prospects may be improved via training or by receiving career guidance. At the very least, the university should offer you continued use of facilities such as the library, internet and email. One concrete way of mitigating the effects of any redundancy is to offer redundancy pay.

If the university does not invoke a suitable redundancy procedure (which would clearly need to start several months before the end of your contract) then, apart from adversely affecting your prospects, your dismissal could be unfair.

And do not forget to provide your department with a forwarding address for post.

Contract extension
In many cases, your contract may be extended or renewed when you start work on a new research project. Sometimes funding is only secured right at the last minute, perhaps even with a gap between projects.

You should make sure that you have backup plans in place so that you have alternatives in case last-minute funding applications fail. However, you should know when to leave. You may be better off taking other employment opportunities, even if this means leaving the project before the end, rather than facing the uncertainty of funding applications.

If there are gaps between projects, the university should provide bridging funding, so that disruption to your work is kept to a minimum instead of obliging you to consider unpaid work.

When considering an extension, ensure that you will continue under the same terms and conditions as before. In particular, check that you will be placed on the same or higher point on the pay scale. If a project proposal has been made with you in mind, then appropriate allowance in salary should have been made to support you, in accordance with recommendations in the Concordat.

As far as the university is concerned, you employment ends on the end date of your contract. Notwithstanding what any individual member of staff might say, any promised extension is pie in the sky until you get a new contract in your hand. Treat verbal promises made by individuals with great caution - they may mean little to the personnel department. As with your initial contract, you should have a written contract extension before this further period of work begins.

Two national email discussion groups are relevant to CRS. Both are "open" - anyone can join and postings are not moderated:
 FTCS Mailing List: aimed at all academic and related staff on fixed term contracts. To join the list send a message to majordomo@leeds.ac.uk and put in the message body: subscribe ftcs You can ignore the "subject" line. A related FAQ list is available.
 CRS: This list is for discussion of all issues relating to the employment and career management of contract researchers. This is for sharing experiences, and exchanging information and responses to Concordat. There is an accompanying comprehensive index of CRS-related issues maintained by Clare Davies.

We will not attempt to reproduce a comprehensive list of links to resources relevant to CRS. These already exist and some of the best starting points are:
 Clare Davies' CRS resources pages
 The Association of University Teachers CRS pages.
 Colin Bryson's pages focusing on research and detailed policy developments for fixed term staff.
 Science's next wave: US online journal with items of interest to academic researchers.
 The Association of Researchers in Medicine and Science (ARMS), which was founded in 1978 with the aim of promoting a higher degree of professional competence in research within academic and allied institutions in the UK. In particular, it aims to establish a satisfactory career structure for researchers in medicine and science.

webTitle: Dreams of a tobacco ad-free world shattered

fields.headline: Dreams of a tobacco ad-free world shattered
fields.standfirst: Hopes that this week's anti-tobacco treaty would ban tobacco advertising worldwide have been dashed
fields.trailText: Hopes that this week's anti-tobacco treaty would ban tobacco advertising worldwide have been dashed, writes Julia Day.
fields.body:
The World Health Organisation has long been committed to a total ban on tobacco advertising. But by the end of this week its dream of a tobacco ad-free world may be in tatters.

The anti-tobacco lobby has accused WHO of selling out to the tobacco industry and compromising its aims.

In Geneva this week the first worldwide anti-tobacco treaty is being thrashed out by government representatives

At preliminary meetings last October, 25 countries agreed to an outright ban on tobacco advertising.

But the draft treaty, written by Brazilian diplomat Celso Amorim, takes a much softer line on advertising than was expected.

It would commit governments to ban "all forms of direct and indirect tobacco advertising, promotion and sponsorship targeted at persons under the age of 18".

This means advertising targeted at over-18s will still be acceptable.

The advertising provisions were criticised as "useless, unenforceable and misguided" by the anti-tobacco pressure group, Action on Smoking and Health.

ASH director Clive Bates said: "We expect the US to oppose any serious advertising restrictions, we expect the EU to be weak on smuggling and we expect Japan to try and block consumer protection measures like a ban on misleading 'light' branding.

"By the time they've watered down the text to their liking there may not be much left."

The treaty is scheduled to come in to force in 2003.

According to the Institute of Development Studies, 4m people a year die from smoking, a figure that will rise to 10m a year by 2020.

The report says efforts to control the resulting spread of smoking are undermined by the deluge of marketing, advertising and sponsorship.

But the WHO treaty is the last in a long line of laws that have failed to implement a total tobacco advertising ban.

Last year the European Union received a setback in its efforts to ban tobacco promotion by a European Court decision and has since adopted a more liberal approach.

The UK's Tobacco Advertising & Promotion Bill, a Labour manifesto pledge, is currently being debated in the Lords.

It proposes a ban on tobacco advertising except at point of sale, but could still be diluted as tobacco companies push hard for exemptions for direct marketing.

The tobacco industry is determined to continue retain the right to send smokers direct mail, an exercise it spends £50m a year on in the UK.

Useful link

ASH website

webTitle: Haaland plays down feud with Keane

fields.headline: Haaland plays down feud with Keane
fields.trailText: Alfie Haaland has tried to play down his long-running feud with Roy Keane which resurfaced during the Manchester derby when the United captain was sent off for a dreadful tackle on the City player.
fields.body:
Alfie Haaland has tried to play down his long-running feud with Roy Keane which resurfaced during the Manchester derby when the United captain was sent off for a dreadful tackle on the City player.

Haaland was reported as saying that Keane was "not mentally right" and added: "I really dislike United and I can't stand their players." But now Haaland says he does not hold a grudge against Keane and does not hate United's players.

After Keane had received his marching orders, he taunted the prone Haaland, apparently referring to an incident four years ago when he injured his cruciate ligaments trying to foul Haaland, who was then a Leeds player.

Gordon Taylor, the chief executive of the Professional Footballers' Association, welcomed Haaland's conciliatory line. "We just hope that the matter has been sorted out and that there won't be any such problems in the future," said Taylor.

"We don't want to see this because it can cause problems and build up grudges before games and set the wrong tone for games. If needs be we will do our best to make sure this does not happen again and that they bury the hatchet."

Meanwhile, Haaland is to have a cartilage operation in the summer. He was substituted during the 1-0 win over West Ham but City's manager Joe Royle is hopeful he will be fit for next Monday's match against Ipswich at Portman Road, which his side need to win to maintain their slim chance of Premiership survival.

webTitle: Canadian opposition leader has his day

fields.headline: Canadian opposition leader has his day
fields.standfirst: The formerly promising Stockwell Day has proved to be a gaffe-prone liability for his recently relaunched party, writes Anne McIlroy
fields.trailText: The formerly promising Stockwell Day has proved to be a gaffe-prone liability for his recently relaunched party, writes Anne McIlroy.
fields.body:
It has been a little over six months since Stockwell Day zoomed onto the political scene in Canada, driving a personal water craft to his first press conference after being elected to parliament, attired in a body-hugging wetsuit and no shoes.

He had just bumped off Preston Manning to take over the leadership of the Canadian Alliance, formerly known as the Reform party but renamed as part of an effort to become more than a west Canada-based, rightwing protest party. Mr Day, the new leader of the official opposition, had energy, a sunny smile, and great biceps. The governing Liberals, who are led by the 67-year-old prime minister, Jean Chretien, were nervous. As it turns out, they had no reason to be.

Six months ago Mr Day was touted as the man who would cost the Liberals their parliamentary majority. Today, he is a figure of fun, or, worse in politics, pity. Last week he barely faced down an open revolt, with party stalwarts openly demanding his resignation. Requests for him to step down streamed in from party members in the west. Senior staff resigned. A tearful Mr Day pleaded for his job at a meeting with mutinous MPs.

Unlike most palace coups, there is no obvious successor waiting in the wings, although Mr Manning could conceivably come back as an interim leader. "People have just lost confidence in his leadership," said MP Val Meredith, who supported Mr Day in his leadership race against Mr Manning.

How could it go so wrong, so fast? Political commentators have blamed his pride, his lack of depth, his lack of experience, his lack of smarts. The series of frequent gaffes began in the snap autumn federal election that Mr Day had dared Mr Chretien to call. When he failed to make a breakthrough in eastern Canada, Mr Day said his mistake had been to listen to his advisers rather than his own instincts.

Those instincts, it was revealed after the election, cost taxpayers in his home province of Alberta more than £300,000 in legal fees. When Mr Day was the province's treasurer, he publicly questioned whether a lawyer in his home town who defended an accused paedophile was condoning that kind of criminal behavior. The lawyer sued him, and the public paid for Mr Day's out-of-court settlement and legal costs. At first, a defiant Mr Day claimed he had been right, although eventually he was forced to apologise.

When the Globe and Mail, a national newspaper, reported that Mr Day had hired a private detective to dig up dirt on the Liberals, he confirmed he had met with the man. The next day, he said he had not. His explanation? Mr Day said when he first read the story in the Globe, he assumed it was accurate. But when he checked his schedule he found otherwise.

That schedule may soon be much less busy. Mr Day, a former Alberta treasurer, cannot go back into politics in his home province, where polls show he is the most unpopular of all federal leaders. He does not have a formal education, but could return to auctioneering or interior decorating. At best he can probably hang on to his job as leader for a year.

But his nickname, used by Liberals and Canadian Alliance members alike, is Dead Man Walking.

webTitle: Europe irresolute over Israeli trade fraud

fields.headline: Europe irresolute over Israeli trade fraud
fields.standfirst: Israel has been flouting an EU trade agreement at the expense of Palestinian finances for the past six years. But, asks Brian Whitaker, does Europe have the nerve to take punitive action?
fields.trailText: Israel has been flouting an EU trade agreement at the expense of Palestinian finances for the past six years. But, asks Brian Whitaker, does Europe have the nerve to take punitive action?
fields.body:
There is no conduct quite so unbecoming as the betrayal of a friend. Israel professes to be a friend of Europe and yet, in its dealings with Europe, Israel has cheated and lied and abused the trust that was placed in its officials. It has done this cynically and systematically - and has been found out. The question now is what Europe is going to do about it.

In 1995 Israel and Europe signed an agreement "to establish lasting relations, based on reciprocity and partnership". On the first page, both sides declared a commitment to "the common values that they share" and "the observance of human rights and democracy".

Among other things, Europe promised Israel cooperation in a wide range of fields, including culture and science - an important morale-booster for any country which has been ostracised by its neighbours.

But the biggest prize for Israel was trade: it would be allowed to export its own goods to Europe either duty-free or at reduced rates. Today, that trade accounts for one third of Israel's worldwide exports.

This was not merely a goodwill gesture by Europe. The agreement (and another one signed later with the Palestinians) was meant to reward Israel for its participation in the Oslo peace process, and to encourage further progress in the negotiations. Indeed, several European countries waited for signs of further progress before ratifying the agreement.

The agreement was based (misguidedly, as it turned out) on mutual trust. This meant that Israeli customs officials were expected to certify - truthfully - that the goods exported to Europe had in fact been produced in Israel.

But no sooner had the ink dried on Shimon Peres's signature than Israel began to cheat. To imagine that this was due to a few bent officials in the customs department would be a mistake: cheating was built into the system and it was carried out with the blessing of the Israeli government.

The cheating took three forms, which I outlined in an article last week (Europe colludes in Israeli trade scams). One was to re-label produce from other countries as Israeli.

Another was to pretend that products from illegal Israeli settlements had originated within Israel's internationally-recognised boundaries. The third was to frustrate the Palestinians' efforts to trade directly with Europe and instead force them to send their produce via Israel under an Israeli label. Because of this, money which by rights should have gone to Palestinians went to Israelis and, in the case of imports, the Palestinian Authority was deprived of much-needed tax revenue.

In 1997, as a result of complaints, the European commission sent a delegation to Israel to find out why Brazilian orange juice arriving in Europe had been certified as Israeli in order to qualify for preferential rates.

The problem, the delegation concluded, went way beyond orange juice: Israeli customs officials simply could not be trusted. The problem was so serious, their report said, that "the validity of ALL preferential certificates issued by Israel, for ALL products", was in doubt.

The commission then issued a warning to European companies which trade with Israel, pointing out that they could be liable to backdated import duties if the certificates proved to be invalid.

In the meantime, the commission announced it would take steps to verify the "ample evidence" of Israeli violations of the agreement, and added that "should these violations ... be confirmed they should be brought to an end." Instead, they continued. Last year, after months of hesitation, the process of returning suspect certificates to Israel for verification finally got under way.

Britain has so far returned certificates for Ahava cosmetics, dates, carpets from Barkan (a West Bank settlement), wines, brandy and liqueurs, pencils, plastic household items, key blanks and locks, electrical items, and bath and skincare products. The commission has also alerted British customs to watch out for biscuits and Soda Stream drinks makers. Other countries have taken similar action, but the products have continued to enter Europe at preferential rates.

The procedure laid down in the agreement for challenging the validity of certificates is to seek verification, though nobody is in any real doubt that the products have come from illegal settlements and that their documentation has been falsified. They are listed as settlement products on rival Israeli websites which urge people either to boycott them or to make a point of buying them.

Under the rules, once Europe asks for verification, Israel is allowed 10 months to provide evidence of the real origin of a product. The deadline on some products has already expired; on others it will expire between now and the end of September. So far as is known, Israel has not replied.

In the absence of confirmatory evidence from Israel within the 10-month deadline, customs authorities throughout Europe can refuse preferential treatment for the product concerned, and claim backdated duties at the full rate.

Israel, in turn, is obliged under the agreement to take punitive action against anyone who has been involved in falsifying documents. In the coming weeks, European leaders will decide whether to continue with this leisurely, piecemeal approach or whether to take tougher action.

Ending preferential treatment for settlement products would certainly be progress, but it barely scratches the surface. It does not address the European commission's most serious complaint: that all certificates issued by Israel, for all products, are suspect.

To re-establish trust, Israel will have carry out a thorough overhaul of the way it does business with Europe. On past form, that is unlikely to happen unless Europe threatens to terminate the agreement.

Given that Israel has shown such persistent bad faith - in contrast to the spirit of "reciprocity and partnership" on which the agreement is based - there are reasonable grounds for termination.

The unfair practices employed against Palestinian trade with Europe are further evidence of Israel's lack of commitment to a genuine partnership.

Finally, one might ask whether the agreement has served its aim of promoting peace. By helping to keep the settlements in business it may well have prolonged the conflict. And while the peace process is on hold, might it not make sense to put the Euro-Israeli agreement on hold too?

France has already said it wants tough action. But any decision would have to be unanimous - and Britain and Germany are resisting. Last January, Britain's foreign secretary, Robin Cook, was asked in a letter if he would consider suspending the agreement on the grounds that Israel had infringed a clause dealing with human rights.

In response, Mr Cook pointed out another clause that says: "Nothing in this agreement shall prevent a party from taking any measures...which it considers essential to its own security".

Mr Cook, who used to pride himself on Britain's "ethical" foreign policy, commented: "Any EU moves towards suspension of the agreement on human rights grounds would involve lengthy and difficult negotiations with Israel on the relative weight to be attached to these two articles. These negotiations would leave little room for anything else in the EU-Israel relationship."

So perhaps Ariel Sharon need not worry after all. For Europeans, arguing with the Israelis is far too tiresome.

fields.headline: Anti-tobacco treaty rejects advertising ban
fields.trailText:
1.30pm: Anti-smoking campaigners are furious that the world's first anti-tobacco treaty will not include a ban on advertising. By Julia Day.

Special report: tobacco advertising
fields.body:
Anti-smoking campaigners have reacted furiously to the news that the world's first anti-tobacco treaty will almost certainly not include a total ban on tobacco advertising.

Government representatives are in Geneva this week to draft the treaty at a tobacco convention sponsored by the World Health Organisation.

It is believed UN staff have already rejected an outright ban on tobacco advertising in favour of restrictions on cigarette advertising to under-18s.

But the anti-tobacco lobby claims the move was made to appease the US contingent, which claims a ban would be in breach of laws on freedom of speech.

The UK anti-tobacco pressure group, Action on Smoking and Health, said the convention was in the pocket of the tobacco industry and had sold out to vested interests.

US President Bush's administration has strong links with the industry and the Japanese government owns Japan Tobacco International.

ASH said the draft treaty included "useless, unenforceable and misguided provisions on tobacco advertising".

"It is impossible to define advertising targeted at under-18s," said the group in a statement.

"All advertising reaches under-18s even if it is targeted at older age groups, and it is, in any case, important to remove all advertising for its impact on adult smokers - many of whom are struggling to break their addiction to nicotine.

"The chair's text has the US and hence the tobacco industry's fingerprints all over it."
