fields.headline: Living on the edge
fields.trailText: An estimated 2m to 3m people dont have access to financial services as a result of having a poor credit rating or simply because of where they live.
fields.body:
An estimated 2m to 3m people dont have access to financial services as a result of having a poor credit rating or simply because of where they live.

The problem has been compounded recently with banks closing many of their smaller branches which has left some of the most deprived communities without banking facilities.

The government has helped attack the problem head on recently, when it ordered the high street banks to offer basic accounts to the financially excluded.

This has resulted in a variety of new offers from NatWest, Co-operative, Yorkshire, Lloyds TSB and Barclays amongst others.

Basic bank accounts are fee-free and provide day-to-day banking services but dont allow customers to go into debt  overdrafts are not allowed, although some banks will offer a £10 buffer zone. You can set up direct debits and standing orders, and a card is provided for cash machines. Some go further and offer a debit-type card allowing you to buy goods in shops provided you have the funds.

The accounts can usually be opened regardless of your credit rating, though people who have been declared bankrupt will in many cases still be blacklisted.

Banks will make little, if any, money from basic accounts, as customers wont be paying overdraft charges and many will not be depositing large sums. So they probably wont advertise the accounts, leaving it up to you to ask individual banks if they offer them.

When you go to open a basic account, you will need some form of identification. Passports and driving licenses are the norm, but banks such as Lloyds TSB will accept pension books, recognised ID cards with a photo and signature and the new orange disabled drivers passes which also carry a photo.

webTitle: The essential guide to contract research

fields.headline: The essential guide to contract research
fields.standfirst: Introduction | Doing your own research | Joining a union | Understanding your position | Hours | Authorship | Understanding your contract rights| Employment rights | Finance and pensions| Joining a pension scheme | Isolation|
fields.trailText: There are pitfalls as well as benefits to working as a contract researcher, as Alan Williams explains in the first of this two-part feature.
fields.body:
Introduction
Most research in universities is carried out by contract research staff (CRS), who are on fixed-term contracts and often funded by external research contracts, where each contract is directly linked to a particular piece of funding for a specific research project.

This guide is aimed at those who are considering contract research and those who have just started as CRS. It gives tips from other contract researchers indicating what you should think about before deciding to do contract research, how to get the most out of it, and how to avoid some of the problems caused by the nature of contract research.

You will find that, in some items below, there is a lot of detail. You may not necessarily wish to take all of it into account in the excitement of looking for and getting a new job. However, this will be a good resource once you are there.

Of course, no guide will ever be a substitute for getting detailed personal advice on your particular situation from your union - the CRS experience varies enormously, even within the same department, and it is therefore impossible to cover all circumstances.

However, it is important to emphasise that, despite all of these problems, academic research is often extremely rewarding. It is a great opportunity to pursue something which you are passionately interested in, offering a lot of flexibility, working with supportive colleagues in a stimulating environment, with the chance to make world-shattering discoveries Ü at the cutting edge of knowledge.

On the other hand, the very use of fixed-term contracts is often the cause of many of the difficulties highlighted below. Higher education unions argue that they are also extremely inefficient and do not enable institutions and researchers to pursue their work in the most productive way.

For example, the Association of University Teachers (AUT) is campaigning against the casualisation of academic staff and for the vast majority to be employed on a long-term basis.

You may agree with this (and wish to participate in union campaigns against casualisation), but here we will only look at getting the most out of the current situation, one where almost all researchers in universities are employed on fixed-term contracts.

Doing your own research
There are a lot of advantages to being a member of CRS. Hours are generally more flexible than in many jobs (but you need to check) and, in the right research group, you can enjoy your work. You may also be somewhat more protected in terms of the teaching and administration that you can be required to undertake (but you will need to find out what your position would actually be).

Find out what being CRS really involves and understand what you would be getting into Ü make use of national CRS networks or look at research into CRS issues (for example Colin Bryson's research) Do you actually want to do it? Does it fit in with your career plans? One reason CRS run into trouble is because they are not clear what they may be expected to do.

 The research group: If you decide CRS is for you, then go and meet the people that you would be working with, or who are in the same unit/department. Is it friendly and does it provide a good working atmosphere, or is it likely that you will be working in a small room isolated from everyone else? Will you have your own office or laboratory space? Will appropriate equipment be available and supported (or will you end up as the lab technician?).

 The institution: This is a bit wider than the immediate research group but just as important Ü after all, the institution is your employer. Not all institutions treat CRS in the same way. Find out if it has a code of practice for employing CRS, to implement the Concordat. This should cover project management, maternity leave/pay (check carefully any qualification conditions), and provision for support at the end of a project, including bridging and redundancy.

Will you get redundancy pay and does the institution operate a meaningful redeployment scheme? Do CRS have parity with established lecturing staff with respect to their terms and conditions? Will you be treated as a member of staff (as you should be), or essentially as a student? Do you have equal access to the library (you should do)? Are relocation expenses paid (they should be)?

Will the institution charge you fees if you wish to take a further degree? Then check if the code is actually implemented. The two important principles are that it is the university that is your employer (not the research funder or your project manager) and that you are a full member of staff (rather than a glorified student).

 The research funder: Contract research is paid for from a variety of sources, including the government-funded research councils, various charities, the European Union and commercial enterprises.

All have their own interests and requirements. You should check what the particular rules attached to your funding would be - will they restrict you? For example, will you be able to spend a proportion of your time on work not directly related to the project (training, teaching, your own research)?

Are there any restrictions on publication or ownership of the work? Is the funder committed for the full duration of the project or is there a possibility they will stop the funding, perhaps because they are not satisfied with interim results? Does the funder allow CRS to apply for research grants in their own name?

As part of their mission, the main research councils are required to provide trained researchers. As well as funding postgraduate students, some interpret this as requiring a continuous flow of CRS, and so their policies are designed to discourage CRS from staying in universities for more than a couple of contracts.

By arming yourself with this information before you begin, you will go a long way to saving yourself from some nasty surprises or disappointments later on.

Joining a union
Fixed-term contracts themselves are the cause of many of the problems described here. Contract researchers are more vulnerable than any other staff group to being unfairly treated/dismissed, and missing out on legal entitlements.

You may find it difficult to stand up for yourself unless you know that your situation is wrong and that there are people to support you. Reliable information and advice may not be available. You will not have a very loud voice on your own.

It is therefore essential that you join a union. You may not want to get actively involved, but think of it as insurance. Only a union can help effectively if anything bad happens to you, but like any insurance it can only help if you have been a member for some time prior to a crisis.

You may see your current job as a short-term thing that will end soon anyway, so why bother joining? But there may be problems within your first contract. This may well be extended, sometimes several times, so unless you join at the start there is a danger you will be without insurance for a long time.

Also, only the unions can have any hope of influencing your pay and conditions, and then only if they're seen to represent enough of you.

You may also wish to become active in the union in order to fight against casualisation and the second-class academic citizenship of CRS.

The Association of University Teachers (AUT) has a CRS committee which initiates and co-ordinates campaigns, responds to national developments and liaises between CRS members and national AUT. The National Association of Teachers in Further and Higher Education (NATFHE) represents academic staff (more in post-1992 universities) and is also committed to reducing casualisation. The Manufacturing, Science and Finance Union (MSF) opposes short-term contracts amongst scientific workers and promotes greater participation by women in science, engineering and technology.

Understanding your position
Before accepting a job you should find out specifically what will be expected of you.

Will you be required to undertake any teaching, supervision or administration? Again, if you know about this beforehand, you can take appropriate action if you are not happy.

Do not let managers offload inappropriate tasks onto you, such as arbitrary teaching or administrative duties - any teaching should have been agreed with you at the start and, in general, would be related to your research. You are there to do research - and a little teaching if that's what you want - so do not get distracted.

This is particularly true if your post is being funded by a research council or a commercial enterprise that has asked for a particular piece of work. Questions will be asked if the work is not completed (and you may get the blame, even if it's not your fault).

However, check that you will have the opportunity for personal development via training, or even having some proportion of your time so that you can pursue your own non-project research.

If you are sharing your time between more than one project, or if you are to be employed part time, check that it is clear how much time you will be expected to allocate to a particular project. There is always the danger that the sum of the parts will be greater than the whole.

It is useful to see the proposal for the project that you are working on. This will probably lay down quite clearly what is expected of you.

Hours
One of the perceived benefits of academic research is that you have very flexible hours and are free to work when you wish (as long as you get the job done). Many contracts do not specify hours, saying you will be expected to work "reasonable hours".

However, you should check if there are times when you will be expected or required to work Ê for example, will you be required to work weekends? If there are, you may be happy to accept them (if they are reasonable), but at least it will be far easier to walk away or to negotiate if you are not happy. It is one thing voluntarily working certain hours, but may well be a problem for you if you have to do it.

Also check that your department's position on working from home fits in with your own wishes, working style and circumstances. Some departments forbid working from home, whereas other departments are happy for employees to work from home on a regular basis.

Authorship
When you accept, but before the project starts, get a written agreement from your project team members about authorship of papers:

 Under what circumstances will someone appear as an author?
 How will the order of authors be determined?

That way, the principles are laid down and you know where you stand.

Although different disciplines have their own conventions, in general, if you contribute directly (by writing) or indirectly (for example, by producing results) to a paper, then you should be included as an author.

A related and particular thorny topic concerns the inclusion in the author list of one's manager/project supervisor, even if they have made little or any contribution.

Understanding your contract rights
You should be issued with a written contract before you begin work.

Read it carefully before you accept and make sure that you understand what it is saying (seek advice from your union if you are not certain). If it refers to other documents, get hold of them and make sure you know what they say.

 Duration: The contract should normally last as long as the project - check that there are no probationary periods or other reviews that you did not expect.
 Conditions: Check that these match what you had been informed - it is not reasonable for the contract to introduce conditions you were not already aware of. Again, ask advice from your union if you are unsure before you sign. Equally, you should question anything that you think is missing - it is dangerous to rely on verbal agreements.
 Watch your pay: Get hold of the local pay scales and descriptions of the grading levels. Check where you are on them and whether it is where you should be, given your age, role and qualifications.

If the annual salary stated on your pay slip does not match any current scale point, you may have missed out on recent national pay rises. When offered a research post, always check that annual increments will be applied (to move you up the pay scale step-by-step): this doesn't always happen.

Also, try to find out what your colleagues are earning, especially if you are a woman or a member of an ethnic minority. You could be a victim of unjustified, systematic, thoughtless discrimination.

Employment rights
Find out what your employment rights are so that you will be in a position to determine whether they are being honoured.

They cover important things such as maternity, pension, sick leave, pay scales, redundancy/dismissal, holiday, hours, or disability. If you will be working part-time, ensure that you have the same (pro-rata) conditions as your full-time colleagues.

The area is far too big to list in detail, but clearly, your union will be able to assist you. Your CRS colleagues will also be able to help, both within your institution and outside. However it is always worth confirming any information because they may equally be misinformed.

Equally, do not rely on what your manager or personnel office tells you Ü always double check.

It is best to resolve problems as soon as you start and to ensure that your contract makes all of the conditions of your employment clear. Verbal agreements and reassurances are not often much use later on.

Do not let your employer get away with things just because you do not know any different - be sure to complain if they try.

Finance and pensions
Some long-term CRS have put off getting a mortgage for many years due to job insecurity, fear of unemployment or the need to move to the other end of the country to get a job in their field. In fact, much of the academic system seems to assume that people can move around at will, often for the dubious benefit of getting a short contract somewhere else.

However, due to family circumstances you may wish to settle in one area and commit to home ownership. In many cases your contract will be extended (many mortgage lenders recognise this and are more prepared to offer a loan to CRS), making this possible. You should ensure that you know when to leave well in advance of the end of your contract.

Joining a pension scheme
Just as you may think it's not worth bothering joining a union because you are only on a short-term contract, you may also think that there's no point in joining a pension scheme. But, as before, this contract may be the first of many and, before you know it you'll have missed out on many years of pensionable service.

So, join a pension scheme as soon as you start. The Universities Superannuation Scheme (USS) operates within pre-1992 universities and the Teachers' Pension Scheme (TPS) within post-1992 universities.

This is a common situation, especially for individual researchers. Even if you join a research team, you may end up with a very restricted view of your unit or institution as a whole. You may not really be considered a member of the department (for example you may not be 'expected' to attend departmental meetings), so you have to try hard to get involved.

In many departments, you may find you are pushing at open doors, although sadly, in others you may still find yourself excluded from departmental meetings because of the nature of your contract.

This is obviously important if situations develop in your research environment which need changing Ü here you can also seek the support of the FTCS mailing list, because part of the solution is often the knowledge that you are not alone.

webTitle: Rugby league: Pitiful final could only be plot to keep union away

fields.headline: Pitiful final could only be plot to keep union away
fields.trailText: As a keen conspiracy theorist, I should like to think this drab, disappointing cup final was part of a cunning plot to discourage rugby union from poaching any more league stars.
fields.body:
As a keen conspiracy theorist, I should like to think this drab, disappointing cup final was part of a cunning plot to discourage rugby union from poaching any more league stars. What other reason could there be for saving the worst final in living memory for the Challenge Cup's one and only visit to the headquarters of the 15-a-side game?

Certainly England's manager Clive Woodward and the other union types in the crowd must have seen little - apart from St Helens' outstanding scrum-half Sean Long - to make them want to rush on to the pitch at the end brandishing chequebooks, assuming they had managed to stay awake that long.

On the other hand, maybe it was the kind of match only a coach could love. St Helens, playing against type, put in an impressive defensive performance to frustrate Bradford in the first half, snatched a couple of close-range tries and then successfully closed up the game, denying the Bulls a way back. Thoroughly professional and efficient - and admirable from a coach's point of view - but not at all like the swashbuckling Saints we have come to know and love.

Bradford were frankly a shambles, careless in defence and without any coherent attacking strategy other than relying on flashes of individual brilliance from one or other of the Paul brothers to get them out of trouble.

The irony was that all the criticisms that lovers of union traditionally like to hurl at league - that the game is sterile and formulaic: four or five drives followed by a kick and chase, with little scope for improvisation - seemed suddenly validated.

Maybe it was the curse of the BBC, which is having some rotten luck at present. First Lennox Lewis, now this. It must feel like the Coventry City of sports broadcasting.

After some of the spectacular matches in Sky's Super League this season, many of them featuring one or other of these teams, our senior broadcaster was entitled to expect something more compelling than this mistake-ridden war of attrition. As indeed we all did.

Before kick-off, league followers were bullish about storming union head office, joking about being disinfected at the turnstiles - "nothing to do with foot and mouth, old boy, just a precaution" - and about the electronic scoreboard advertising tours round Twickenham "including" (gasp!) "the England changing room". Boy did they have the wrong crowd.

So confident was the great northern game of producing something really special that the A list had been invited. Not only Tony Blair, attending his first rugby league cup final and roundly booed (the most popular peacetime prime minister maybe, but to this crowd he was just another posh guy in a suit), but also Hear'Say who, despite the rather worrying apostrophe, turned out to be real troupers, coping with the heavy showers far better than Bradford.

Such a pity, then, for those of us still fighting the class war, that the match turned out to be more Darius than Myleene (my 10-year-old daughter assures me these references are valid).

fields.headline: AOL eyes NTL for European push
fields.trailText: 10am: US media giant AOL Time Warner has chosen cable operator NTL as a partner in its bid to boost European revenues, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
The US media giant, AOL Time Warner, has chosen cable operator NTL as a partner in its bid to boost European revenues.

The world's largest media company is seeking a broadband distribution deal across the Atlantic and has made NTL its main target.

NTL, which dominates the cable market in the UK and Ireland with 8m subscribers, today stressed the talks were in their early stages.

"We are talking to a broad range of companies about a range of agreements," said an NTL spokesperson.

"While it is true that we are in the early stages of talks with AOL, apart from an outline terms sheet nothing has been agreed."

While AOL Time Warner has an extensive cable network in the US, it lacks a similar operation in Europe, and needs a broadband deal to get the most from its TV, music, film and internet services.

The surprise move follows a dramatic week for NTL, in which it raised an extra £388m in financing but was tipped to run out of money by the end of June by the HSBC investment bank.

Despite its pre-eminent position in the UK market, the company's £10bn debt burden remain a source of concern for investors, who want to see a more tangible return from its "triple play" offer, in which telecoms, internet and TV services are bundled into one package.

NTL insiders have privately scorned the HSBC report, saying its capital expenditure will fall from £1.9bn to £1bn by next year.

But AOL Timer Warner is expected to team up with other European cable services, as NTL only has 500,000 subscribers outside the UK and Ireland.

Steve Case, the chairman of the £72bn media group, last month said the company will raise its international revenues from 17% to 50% of the total over the next 10 years.

fields.headline: BBC woos 'Viagra generation'
fields.trailText:
12.15pm: BBC2 is hoping to win back older viewers with tales of divorce, unhappiness and midlife crisis, writes Lisa O'Carroll.

30.04.2001: Vaughan signs up with BBC

30.04.2001: C4 unveils rival to Room 101

30.04.2001: BBC admits talent failure

30.04.2001: Wogan loses TV contract

30.04.2001: Channel 4 struggles to replace Breakfast
fields.body:
BBC2 is to launch a concerted effort to win back the "Viagra generation" of viewers in their 40s and 50s with tales of divorce, unhappiness and midlife crisis, the new watchwords of entertainment.

The station's controller, Jane Root, says the older generation has been ignored for far too long as TV broadcasters everywhere became obsessed with reaching trendy 16 to 34-year-olds.

Now, as part of a strategy approved by the BBC director general, Greg Dyke, BBC2 will phase in a new breed of mainstream adult entertainment shows with esoteric and laddish entertainment for the nightclub generation removed from the schedule.

Programmes such as Robot Wars and DJ Trevor Nelson's Urban Choice will be shifted to the digital channel, BBC Choice, and replaced with "big, brave shows" with wider appeal.

"Shows like Trevor Nelson's basically said to viewers 'piss off if you're over 30' and that is all going to disappear from BBC2," said Ms Root.

"We will get out of the 16 to 34-year-old market that other channels go for. There are a lot of sophisticated viewers out there in their 40s and 50s who can really enjoy the programmes coming up."

To kickstart the initiative, the station has commissioned three new comedies including Manchild, starring Nigel Havers as a divorcee in his 50s who has found his second youth.

He wears leathers, drives a Harley Davidson and is obsessed with impotence.

"He is a 50-something man who is really enjoying himself but is actually having a midlife crisis," said Ms Root. "The Harley Davidson is something a lot of viewers will identify with - the motorbikes are apparently huge sellers to men in their 50s."

The show has been dubbed "Sex And The City for the Viagra generation" by BBC executives.

It also stars Anthony Head, the librarian from Buffy the Vampire Slayer, and Ray Burdis.

Another series, Mr Charity, stars Stephen Tompkinson as a corrupt charity worker not averse to pilfering funds.

Ms Root said she cast Tompkinson, who made his name in mainstream dramas such as Ballykissangel, as part of her bid to provide the viewer with the "unexpected".

She added: "Nigel Havers has never been on BBC2 and Stephen Tompkinson has never done anything like this. These are shows that are inclusive but still inspiring."

Ms Root has also signed up Steve Coogan for an extended special of the award winning comedy, Marion and Geoff.

Coogan, best known as spoof presenter Alan Partridge, runs Baby Cow, the production company that makes the series. For the first time viewers will get to see both Marion and Geoff, who will be played by Coogan.

There will also be a new series of Happiness starring Paul Whitehouse as a 40-something in a midlife crisis.

Shows aimed at the younger generation will still appear on BBC2 but in the long term will be moved to BBC Choice, the digital channel which will relaunch next year as BBC3.

fields.headline: BT wins trademark battle with Yellphone.com
fields.trailText: 4pm: Phone giant BT has won a battle against a start-up mobile phone ringtones business, reports Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Telecoms giant BT has won a battle against a start-up mobile phone ringtones business.

BT's directories division, Yell, has ordered Yellphone.com to shut down after a two-month legal wrangle in which Yellphone.com put up a fight to save its brand name.

Yell said the company's name was a trademark infringement and demanded it cease trading immediately.

Yellphone.com today threw in the towel in a bid to avoid a lengthy and expensive court case. Instead, it will relaunch as SplashMobile.com at the end of this week at a cost of £10,000.

A statement on Yellphone.com's site said: "Due to temporary difficulties, this site is currently unavailable. We apologise for the inconvenience. Please check back soon."

A spokeswoman for Yellphone.com said it would have "loved to have stood up to BT", adding: "Unfortunately the legal system in this country dictates that costs have to be put up in advance, to the tune of hundreds of thousands of pounds, making it impossible for small business to fight big business."

David Warburton, the managing director of Yellphone, said: "Naturally we are devastated that BT should bring this action against us.

"Yellphone.com is a model of successful small business enterprise and by bringing our business to its knees in this way, BT demonstrates a pointless level of contempt and corporate arrogance which belies belief."

Launched in February, Yellphone.com claims to have signed up more than 20,000 users and supplies ringtones and logos to websites for the BBC, Emap and Carlton.

BT today confirmed it is looking to sell Yell.

fields.headline: Kelly locks horns with Radio 1 duo at Sonys
fields.trailText:
3.45pm: Henry Kelly will tonight go head-to-head with dance DJs the Dreem Teem and rap expert Tim Westwood at the Sony Radio Awards.

Comment: radio ghosts step out of shadows
fields.body:
Smooth talking Henry Kelly will tonight go head-to-head with cutting edge dance DJs the Dreem Teem and rap expert Tim Westwood at the Sony Radio Awards.

The Classic FM DJ and Going For Gold TV show presenter is up against the Radio 1 stars for the music broadcaster of the year title at the Sony awards ceremony, which takes place tonight at the Grosvenor House Hotel in London.

Competing for the national station of the year award are Radio 2, Radio 3 and TalkSport, the one-time chat station that was relaunched as a sports service last year.

Radio 2 took the title two years ago and has fought hard to shake off its image as a station for older listeners by recruiting broadcasters such as Jonathan Ross.

Similarly, Radio 3 has expanded its interests by bringing in regular world music slots, taking the emphasis away from pure classical music.

It was nominated last year but lost out to its rival, Classic FM, so its inclusion in the shortlist for 2001 will be a seen as major achievement.

Kelly, the Dreem Teem and Westwood will face Radio 2's Stuart Maconie and Radio 3's Late Junction presenter, Verity Sharp, in the music broadcaster category.

Radio 2's Terry Wogan will face last year's winner, Bam Bam from Kiss 100, for the prize for best music breakfast show.

Other nominees for the title include shows on 96.9 Viking FM, Classic FM and 100.7 Heart FM.

Despite retaining a strong audience, Radio 1's replacement for Zoe Ball, Sara Cox, is not on the shortlist.

Radio 1's Mark Radcliffe is up for two awards for his show. The afternoon programme is up for the best daily music programme award, with other nominees including Radio 2's Johnnie Walker Drivetime show.

Radcliffe is also up for the entertainment award, on a shortlist which also includes Radio 2's Jonathan Ross - the winner of a Sony last year for the now defunct music presentation category.

Veteran broadcaster John Peel is up for the best speech broadcaster title for his Radio 4 programme, Home Truths.

Indeed, Radio 4 heads the field with 27 nominations, taking four out of five places in some categories.

A judging panel of more than 100, including radio industry figures and anti-drugs coordinator Keith Hellawell, Olympic gold-winning rower Matthew Pinsent and record producer Arthur Baker, chose the nominees.

Tim Blackmore, chairman of the Sony Radio Academy Awards committee, said: "This years nominations reflect the sheer diversity and strength of radio programming in the UK. The 2001 awards look set to be a truly compelling event."

fields.headline: Clooney to return as Batman
fields.trailText: The director of the new Batman film has confirmed that George Clooney will reprise his role as the Caped Crusader for a second time, despite the fact that the actor's original turn as the superhero was a box office flop.
fields.body:
The director of the new Batman film has confirmed that George Clooney is to reprise his role as the Caped Crusader for a second time, despite the fact that the actor's original turn as the superhero was a box office flop.

Darren Aronofsky, who previously directed the controversial Pi and the award-winning Requiem For A Dream, has said that the former ER star would return to the role in Batman: Year One. He told reporters: "George Clooney is going to be back as Batman in the movie. There are no major casting changes".

If rumours are to be believed, Clooney could be reprising the role under duress. An industry insider claimed that the actor had been contracted to do two Batman films, but was unhappy about returning to the role after Batman and Robin received dire reviews and failed to set the box office alight in 1997.

However a reported $15m pay packet and the chance to work with the feted Aronofsky may have gone some way to changing Clooney's mind.

Batman: Year One is one of two Batman films currently in production. Whereas the Aronofsky project will be a prequel to the previous Batman films, the animated Batman Beyond will see a retired Bruce Wayne handing the Caped Crusader mantle over to a younger man.

Both films are due to be released in 2002.

webTitle: Blair outs himself as a spectacle wearer

fields.headline: Blair outs himself as a spectacle wearer
fields.trailText: The prime minister showed today that he is not as image conscious as some critics think - by unveiling himself as a spectacle wearer to an audience of journalists.
fields.body:
The prime minister showed today that he is not as image conscious as some critics think - by unveiling himself as a spectacle wearer to an audience of journalists.

Speaking at the London Press Club awards lunch in London today, Mr Blair said: "I have an important announcement to make to you. This is something I have been struggling with for a very long time."

He then retrieved the black rimmed spectacles from his breast pocket and put them on before adding: "You may have noticed recently at prime minister's question time I have had some problem referring to my brief."

Mr Blair has worn glasses in private for some time but rarely allowed himself to be photographed wearing them and has never delivered a set piece speech wearing them before.

"Matters came to a head a couple of weeks ago in Devon when I was addressing a teacher's conference and had said that social exclusion, drugs and crime - and I was supposed to say teenagers and I said teachers - and I have decided it's time to come out," he said.

With a smile on his face he continued, "Some things in life you have to accept. It gives a whole new meaning to the phrase a vision for Britain."

And Mr Blair also joked: "I see journalists in an entirely different light as well."

Ask Aristotle
Tony Blair

Special report
The Labour party

webTitle: Newsplayer signs camcorder deal with JVC

fields.headline: Newsplayer signs camcorder deal with JVC
fields.trailText: 3pm: Online archive firm Newsplayer has signed a deal with electronics group JVC, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Online archive firm Newsplayer has taken a major step towards profitability by signing a deal with electronics group JVC.

The JVC Miniature camcorder will go on sale next month with a free subscription to Newsplayer's newsreel database.

Paul Duffen, the chief executive of the group, said the agreement will earn Newsplayer a minimum of £600,000 over the next two years.

The camcorder will be launched in the UK at first, but it is expected to go on sale in the US and other countries later on in the year.

"If we get a decent percentage of JVC's global customer base, it could make us up to £3m a year," said Mr Duffen.

He stressed that more deals were in the pipeline for the new media outfit, which expects to become profitable by the middle of next year.

"This is the start of generating our revenues from as many different outlets as possible. We will be coming to market with more deals," he added.

The JVC product will also go on sale with a home editing system, allowing customers to combine home video footage with clips from Newsplayer's 1,000-hour archive.

Newsplayer has displayed its knack for innovative deals before after it teamed up with broadcaster David Frost to sell hundreds of his interviews with the rich and famous over the net.

The group revealed a loss of £2.6m in its maiden results at the beginning of the year, and it is waiting for high-speed internet access to take root in the UK before the revenues start to flow in.

In the meantime, Newsplayer has signed agreements with Microsoft, Yahoo! and BT in a bid to offset any problems with accessing its newsreel archive.

webTitle: BBC business editor in row over Bland appointment

fields.headline: BBC business editor in row over Bland appointment
fields.trailText: 2.45pm: The BBC's business editor, Jeff Randall, has denied suggestions that he was given last week's story about Sir Christopher Bland, reports Jason Deans.
fields.body:
The BBC's business editor, Jeff Randall, has reacted furiously to suggestions that he was given his story last week about the chairman of the BBC, Sir Christopher Bland, joining BT.

A BBC press officer reportedly said Mr Randall had reported the story only after it had been announced to the stock exchange - by which time it was public knowledge.

But Mr Randall told MediaGuardian.co.uk: "It was a bloody scoop. I behaved like a journalist would and broke the story. I'm not a part of the BBC apparatus."

He was not willing to enter into a discussion about the BBC's publicity machine, beyond saying "she [the press officer] got it wrong".

"I've been in this business too long to start to worry about the media critics," said Mr Randall. "But what bothers me is that people think I was given this story by the BBC.

This is the first high-profile clash of interest between Mr Randall and his bosses.

An avowed free market supporter with a track record as one of Britain's best-known business journalists, Mr Randall has expressed his dislike of the BBC's corporate culture in newspaper articles.

Meanwhile, the BBC appeared to have backtracked on its earlier claim that the release had been issued to the stock exchange first.

"Jeff Randall broke the story, as a good journalist would expect to," said a BBC spokeswoman. "But he did not get it from the BBC."

Mr Randall was first with the news that Sir Christopher was quitting the BBC to become BT chairman last Thursday morning, with a report on the BBC Radio 4 Today programme at around 7.08am, according to the spokeswoman.

BT's official announcement to the stock exchange about the appointment followed at 7.36am.

At around that time, Sir Christopher was already being interviewed live on the Today programme as a follow-up to Mr Randall's earlier report.

The spokeswoman also dismissed a diary story in this morning's Mirror claiming Mr Randall had got into a row with the BBC corporate press office over whether or not he broke the story as "not true".

This is not the first time BBC journalists have found themselves at odds with the BBC's publicity machine.

When the appointment of Greg Dyke as director general was announced, BBC correspondents were unable to get the appointment confirmed, leading the news to be broken on other news services first.

fields.headline: Gnash promotion for PR pair
fields.trailText: 2.45pm: PR consultancy Gnash Communications has promoted Rebecca Oatley and Nancy Prendergast to joint managing directors, writes Julia Day.
fields.body:
The PR consultancy, Gnash Communications, has promoted Rebecca Oatley and Nancy Prendergast to joint managing directors.

Ms Oatley and Ms Prendergast will be responsible for the development of Gnash's corporate, consumer and business to business operations.

The pair, who were previously account directors at the agency, will also take on additional responsibilities for the day-to-day management and continued growth of the business.

The founder of Gnash, Narda Shirley, moves from managing director to chief executive and will concentrate on the strategic direction and development of the agency.

"Our challenge this year is to continue to migrate our success and experience of building cornerstone new economy brands into effective communications campaigns for established brands," said Ms Shirley.

"Nancy and Rebecca have complementary skills that give the business a strong and balanced management platform from which to continue to grow."

The company recently appointed a number of people to handle business administration, notably Paul Billings as head of finance and operations. Mr Billings was formerly the finance director at internal communications specialist Smythe Dorward Lambert.

Gnash concentrates on new media clients including Lastminute.com and Hoover's Online.

fields.headline: La sécurité alimentaire en question
fields.standfirst: Following the various food crises (mad cow disease, foot-and-mouth disease, etc), do French people still trust what they eat? Apparently, they are not turning vegetarian, but they are cautious.
fields.trailText: Following the various food crises (mad cow disease, foot-and-mouth disease, etc), do French people still trust what they eat? Apparently, they are not turning vegetarian, but they are cautious.
fields.body:
La sécurité alimentaire a été récemment mise à mal par le fromage à la listéria, le poulet à la dioxine, les rillettes pas très fraîches, les poissons mazoutés par l'Erika, la crise de la vache folle, l'épizootie de fièvre aphteuse et le développement des OGM (organismes génétiquement modifiés). La confiance des Français quant au contenu de leur assiette bat de l'aile. Ils ne savent plus à quel saint se vouer pour se nourrir sainement.

Nous avons demandé à trois jeunes français si ces différentes crises alimentaires avaient modifié leurs habitudes : sont-ils devenus végétariens ou encore anorexiques ? Voici ce qu'ils nous ont confié :

Faites-vous encore confiance au contenu de votre assiette ?

Josselin, 17 ans, lycéen : Oui, je mange toujours de la viande rouge et des rillettes. Les contrôles sanitaires sont tellement stricts et nombreux avant qu'un produit ne soit introduit sur le marché qu'on peut avoir confiance. De toute façon, on n'a pas le choix, alors mieux vaut ne pas trop y penser.

Amélie, 18 ans, lycéenne : Je suis à cheval sur la fraîcheur des aliments, mais rien ne sert d'être obnubilé par le contenu de son assiette, sinon, tu ne vis plus. La viande rouge et moi, ça fait deux, alors la crise de la vache folle ne m'a pas touchée.

Maloya, 19 ans, étudiante en ethnologie : Quand la crise de la vache folle était à son comble, j'ai mangé du cheval, c'est délicieux. Maintenant, je recommence un peu à manger du buf. On flippe parce que, chaque jour, on nous parle de problèmes alimentaires, mais avant, il y en avait autant. Seulement, on n'en faisait pas un drame. C'est pas la petite bête qui va manger la grosse, si ? Qui plus est, on n'a pas d'autre choix que de manger ce qui est vendu dans les supermarchés, alors, il faut faire avecÉ

Pourquoi en est-on arrivé là ?

Josselin : À cause du progrès et du fric. Pour être compétitif, il faut avoir les prix les plus bas possibles, donc, on sacrifie la qualité : donner des farines animales au bétail revenait moins cher que de leur donner des produits frais et naturels.

Amélie : C'est la crise de la productivité. Les animaux sont dopés pour être abattus et vendus plus vite.

Maloya : En raison de la productivité. Il faut faire du pognon, à tout prix. On privilégie les marges, au détriment de la qualité. Le grand gagnant : la grande distribution. Ceux qui sont lésés : les producteurs, qui vendent à des prix dérisoires, et les consommateurs, qui paient le prix fort pour des produits de mauvaise qualité.

Les aliments d'aujourd'hui sont-ils de meilleure qualité qu'il y a 20 ou 30 ans ?

Josselin : Avant, la production était naturelle, sans engrais, pesticides ni conservateurs. On ne mangeait pas de fraises ou de tomates en hiver, mais au moins, elles poussaient naturellement. Les OGM n'existaient pas encore !

Amélie : Il y a 20 ans, il y avait moins de produits sur le marché, mais ils étaient plus sains, moins industrialisés.

Maloya : Ils sont de moindre qualité car la production est industrielle. On utilise des produits chimiques pour que les aliments soient plus appétissants et se conservent plus longtemps. Les animaux sont gavés, pour être prêts à consommer en moins d'un mois. Le poulet n'a plus un goût de poulet, et les fruits et légumes n'ont plus de goût du tout.

Josselin : J'ose même pas y penser ! Peut-être que, comme dans les films de science-fiction, on prendra une gélule, et on sera rassasié. Quel cauchemar !

Amélie : Pour bien se nourrir, il faudra acheter des produits biologiques, donc plus chers. Ceux qui auront les moyens se nourriront bien, mais les autres continueront à manger de la merde !

Maloya : Soit des produits du terroir, naturels et bio, pour les riches, soit des plats préparés et/ou surgelés (pizzas, quiches, etc.), pour les moins riches ! En tout cas, la bonne bouffe (française) a encore de beaux jours devant elle. Les gens aiment manger de bonnes choses, et ça ne changera pas de sitôt.

il ne faut pas en faire un drame : there's no need to dramatize

gaver : to force-feed (poultry)

webTitle: Protesters meet Maff over lorry leak fears

fields.headline: Protesters meet Maff over lorry leak fears
fields.standfirst:
• Protesters to meet Maff officials over lorry leak scandal
• Farmers offered free holidays to relieve stress
• Tests give five more people the all clear

Special report: Foot and mouth
fields.trailText:
• Protesters to meet Maff officials over lorry leak scandal
• Farmers offered free holidays to relieve stress
• Tests give five more people the all clear
fields.body:
Protesters who halted deliveries of animal carcasses to a disposal site were today meeting Ministry of Agriculture officials to discuss safeguards.

The lorries carrying animal carcasses to a burial site at Widdrington, Northumberland were halted at the weekend after fluid leaked onto a road, Maff said.

Further deliveries were suspended until today's meeting between the protesters and Maff officials.

"This is a serious and highly regrettable situation. The seals are checked before the lorries begin their journey to Widdrington. The leakage is largely disinfectant fluid," a Maff statement read.

Meanwhile, farming communities in one of the worst affected foot and mouth areas are being offered free holidays to help ease the pressure and isolation they face.

The rest and recuperation scheme will enable around 250 Cumbrian families to "take a valuable break from it" in the county during a time of increased financial hardship and stress.

The scheme has been set up by the Hadfield Trust and funded by £52,000 raised from public donations and matched by the government through a scheme run by the countryside agency.

Margaret Clark, a countryside agency director, said: "People living in those parts of the country which have been worst hit by foot and mouth desperately need some kind of respite from their daily worries.

"Over the next few weeks we expect to be providing around £5m of match-funding across England as part of this measure to help alleviate the problems caused by this dreadful disease," she said.

Fears that humans had become infected with foot and mouth diminished after medical tests gave a further five people the all clear.

The results follow eight announced before the weekend - including that of slaughterman Paul Stamper.

The Public Health Laboratory Service said tests on all 13 people suspected to have contracted the disease had proved negative, while two more people were awaiting test results.

Meanwhile, the agriculture minister, Nick Brown, has pledged to fight for sweeping changes in British agriculture, but he stressed change would take time.

His comments came as the Ministry of Defence rejected reports that it was linked with the start of the disease.

It confirmed at the weekend that the Army's Whitburn training camp near Sunderland supplied waste food to the Northumberland pig farm at the centre of the foot and mouth outbreak.

But it said all food provided by caterers at the camp conformed to British and European rules that ban imports from areas hit by the disease.

fields.headline: Bleak future for Business 2.0 staff
fields.trailText:
12.30pm: Few of the staff on the defunct title, Business 2.0, can expect to find new jobs at Future Network, writes Jessica Hodgson.
27.04.2001: Future closes European editions of Business 2.0
19.03.2001: Future slides into the red
fields.body:
Few of the staff on Business 2.0, the "new economy" magazine Future Network is closing, can expect to find new jobs at the company.

Ray Philpott, the managing editor of Business 2.0, said staff were "pissed off and depressed" at the way Future had handled the closure. He thought it "unlikely" staff would be relocated within the company.

"There were a number of things we'd put in place at the beginning of this month for this edition and we'd been working like dogs to turn it around," he said.

"Future faffed around for months and didn't tell us what was going on."

At least four of the 10 staff based in Business 2.0's London office had recently relocated there from Bath, Mr Philpott added.

Last week, Future announced it could no longer afford to continue to publish the magazine in Europe, although it has not ruled out finding a buyer for the US edition.

Meanwhile, Red Herring, the last "new economy" magazine left standing following the demise of Business 2.0 and the Industry Standard, is reported to be looking for a buyer.

AOL Time Warner, Ziff Davis and Pearson have been listed as potential suitors.

fields.headline: Sophie Wessex dot.com firm shelved
fields.trailText: 1.30pm: An internet company backed by Sophie Wessex has hit the rocks, reports Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
An internet company backed by Sophie Wessex has hit the rocks just weeks after she was forced to resign as chairman of her PR company, R-JH.

The internet management consortium, 5at6.com, has been forced to shelve plans to launch a number of websites for the well-heeled because of a lack of funding.

Tim Oldfield, a co-founder of the company, said the team had been disbanded and that 5at6.com was now a "shell company" without enough capital to launch any businesses.

Ms Wessex, who has a 10% stake in the company, was to have provided her PR expertise to the proposed websites.

Fellow investors had hoped Ms Wessex's involvement would give the project the upmarket image it needed.

But recent accusations that she tried to use her royal connections to win business for her PR agency have damaged her reputation.

The news of Sophie Wessex's dot.com adventure broke in May last year when it was announced the consortium would be launching five websites by the end of the year.

The first, ladsaway.com, was to have been a great outdoors travel site aimed at grown-up Harry Potters, followed shortly after by girlsaway.com, a "deluxe" travel site for women, with which Ms Wessex was supposed to be heavily involved.

The third was 360me.com, a "personal information database" that would stretch to match-making, recruitment and wedding lists. Neither of these websites got off the ground.

Mr Oldfield now works for the internet venture capitalist, CMGI, but maintains that Ladsaway could still launch if "someone came along with some money".

fields.headline: BBC1 gets its fingers burnt
fields.trailText: 1.45pm TV overnights: EastEnder Steve McFadden's role as a cuckolded fire fighter in BBC1 drama Murder in Mind failed to catch viewers' imagination last night, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Steve McFadden's first role outside EastEnders for many years, as a cuckolded fire fighter seeking revenge in BBC1 drama Murder in Mind, failed to catch viewers' imagination last night.

The drama proved less popular than ITV's long-established fire service drama, London's Burning, drawing nearly 2m fewer viewers.

Murder in Mind attracted 6.4m viewers and a 27% audience share; while London's Burning pulled in 8.2m and a 34% share, according to unofficial overnights.

Both dramas were on between 9pm and 10pm last night.

ITV's Richard Wilson sitcom vehicle, High Stakes, failed to convince on its second outing between 10pm and 10.30pm last night, losing out to BBC1's news in the ratings.

The sitcom about investment banking had just 5.2m viewers and a 26% audience share.

The BBC1 news attracted 6.6m between 10pm and 10.15pm.

Jon Ronson's new Channel 4 documentary series, conspiracy theorists' delight Secret Rulers of the World, aired between 9pm and 10pm.

The documentary, which follows Mr Ronson as he examines the conspiracy theories expounded by various fringe political groups, had 2m viewers and an 8% audience share.

It lost out to BBC2's World Championship snooker coverage from Sheffield, which had 2.2m and a 9% share.

On Saturday night Get Real With Casualty, a documentary in which Casualty stars met their real-life counterparts at the Royal London Hospital A&E department, was on between 9.05pm and 9.55pm.

It drew 6.6m and a 30% audience share.

The ITV opposition, a Midsomer Murders detective drama repeat, broadcast between 9.10pm and 11.10pm.

The John Nettles drama had 6.3m overall, but rose to 7.1m when it went head to head with Get Real With Casualty.

Channel 4's decision to repeat its Top Ten: Boy Bands show, which was presented by the late Paula Yates, between 9.05pm and 10.35pm on Saturday proved a success.

The cheesy pop-fest had 2.8m viewers and a 13% audience share; beating BBC2's World Championship snooker, which drew only 1.7m.

Friday night saw the return of Jack Dee's Happy Hour for a second BBC1 run between 10.35pm and 11.05pm.

It drew 3.2m viewers - one in five of the available audience at that time.

But Jack Dee's Happy Hour lost out to ITV documentary Child Stars, a look at early exposure to fame featuring contributors including Charlotte Church, Aled Jones, Petula Clark and Bonnie Langford, between 10pm and 11pm.

Child Stars had 5.8m and a 31% share.

webTitle: Radio ghosts step out of shadows

fields.headline: Radio ghosts step out of shadows
fields.standfirst:
Northern editor Martin Wainwright was a judge in this year's Sony Radio Academy Awards. Here he celebrates producers; the unsung heroes of the medium

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Northern editor Martin Wainwright was a judge in this year's Sony Radio Academy Awards. Here he celebrates producers; the unsung heroes of the medium.
fields.body:
When the stars of radio step up to receive their Sony awards tonight, many will be accompanied by a ghost: invisible to the general public but known to everyone in the trade. These phantoms form a fascinating but largely unstudied type: the power-behind-the-throne, the grey eminence. They intrigue human nature but perversely never get their due.

The protoplasm swirling about in the Sony's empty spaces is that of a particularly intelligent, interesting and powerful group of people: the speech-radio producers. Stoutly shouldering books of research, they pore over digital editing screens until their eyeballs spin. Juggling expense claims and directories of contact numbers, they send juicy ideas and information to big-name presenters, who then appear to have had these revelations themselves.

Proving the point is easy. Try these two hypothetical questions from your local pub quiz. What do John Humphrys, Jenni Murray and Sara Cox do? Easy-peasy. But how about Sera Lefroy-Owen, Zillah Watson and Arlene Gregorius?

The latter group are taken at random from the producer bylines in the current Radio Times, a literally minuscule sample made even smaller by the fact that their Radio 1, 2, 3 and Five Live colleagues are hardly ever listed at all. The only weighting to the sample is a preference for memorable names: such as Piers Plowright or Gillian Hush. This is the best chance of public recognition for those few who are heard, but not seen.

Does it matter? Probably not to most of the victims themselves, who have the additional qualities of the Roman; they tend to be virtuous stoics whose Reithian reward is the knowledge they have done their best and brought out the best in others.

They don't all want their name in lights. Indeed some find it counter-productive. Unlike their celebrity colleagues, for whom the limelight is their business, many producers have a wealth of diverse extracurricular hobbies. One BBC producer sails luxury yachts for rich clients in the summer. Another producer is also a geologist and author of the definitive doctoral thesis on mudslides in Kuala Lumpur.

But it cannot be good for the rest of us to have a completely misleading view that the individual presenters dominate a creative process whose very essence is a partnership. As if the reign of William and Mary was just William, or the jokes of Morecambe and Wise were entirely Wise?

Isn't this exactly the spin which suggests that only a hospital consultant can make you get better, or that a single, partisan MP really is a loving mother or father to all 50,000 voters in their constituency? Isn't it one of the tightest brakes on a real, participative democracy which taps the resources to be found in everyone?

Rather grand conclusions to draw from the exclusion from gongs of a few, well-paid media folk, maybe. But from such small injustices, much bigger flaws really do arise.

One of the problems of the BBC in recent years has been the sidelining and second-guessing of producers, whose views have been dismissed by either the budget brigade or the wodge of new commissioning editors beamed in from Planet Birt.

And it works the other way. Although modesty is becoming, it is famously dangerous when influential people develop a liking for working behind the scenes or in the dark. How do we react to names like Machiavelli and Metternich (or more prosaically, Ingham and Campbell)? That's right: boo hiss.

Which is why the Sony speech broadcaster judging panel this year has decided to do something about it. Chaired by Caroline Millington, former BBC controller of radio, a plea has been entered for a speech broadcast producer award in 2002.

The letter containing the request to the Radio Academy underlines the enormous input of producers, and the way that so many outstanding programmes have rested on their hidden shoulders. And goodness, isn't that producer-shaped, ghostly space even more embarrassing when there are already awards for interactive programmes, short-form radio and the digital terrestrial station of the year?

With 29 categories already, they may need to lay on an extra course and even more drinks at the Grosvenor House ceremony in 2002, to give the producers their due. But they would also be striking a small blow for the unacknowledged everywhere, who could do with a golden bauble to bang on the negotiating table.

The protoplasm swirling about in the Sony's empty spaces is that of a particularly intelligent, interesting and powerful group of people: the speech-radio producers. Stoutly shouldering books of research, they pore over digital editing screens until their eyeballs spin. webTitle: Jailed mothers test baby age limit

fields.headline: Jailed mothers test baby age limit
fields.trailText: Two women prisoners who are threatened with having their toddlers taken from them and put into care will ask the high court today to rule that the Home Office's upper age limit of 18 months for babies in prison is unlawful.
fields.body:
Two women prisoners who are threatened with having their toddlers taken from them and put into care will ask the high court today to rule that the Home Office's upper age limit of 18 months for babies in prison is unlawful.

The case, brought under the Human Rights Act, is the first challenge to the rule, though lawyers have been anticipating such a claim since the act came into force last October.

The case is seen as so important that it was rescheduled from later this week to Monday and Tuesday, so that the lord chief justice, England's most senior judge, could hear it. The two women will seek a confidentiality order before the hearing begins today, and their lawyers were reluctant yesterday to give many details of their personal circumstances.

The two children are believed to have already passed the 18-month age limit and will have to go to foster parents soon unless the court intervenes. One of the women is serving a five-year sentence and her earliest date of release is just over a year away. The other has been jailed for eight years and faces deportation at the end of her sentence.

In family court cases, judges take account of the serious risk of permanent psychological harm to young children in removing them from their mother. The women's lawyers will argue that the prison service ignores this in operating its upper age limit.

"The blanket policy means there could be grave injustices to individual children," said Harriet Wistrich of the London law firm Thanki Novy Taube, which acts for one of the women.

"There seems to be a conflict between the basic principle that the court should always act in the best interests of the child and these cases where there is a blanket policy which could be totally against the best interests of these children."

Richard Gordon, the women's QC, will argue that there is no objective justification for the rule. He will contend that it breaches article eight of the European convention on human rights, the right to respect for private and family life, and article 14, the ban on discrimination, because it discriminates between the children of prisoners and those of others.

Lawyers for the Home Office are expected to argue that the 18-month limit should remain pending further research.

There are only 72 places in prison mother and baby units, though more than 1,000 women prisoners at any one time have children under five. The Home Office is considering proposals for increasing the number of mother and baby units, and for special units to accommodate children up to the age of four with their mothers.

A report last year from the Council of Europe's social, health and family affairs committee concluded that prisons were not an appropriate environment for children, often causing long-term developmental retardation. "Yet, if babies and children are forcibly separated from their mothers they suffer permanent emotional and social damage," it said.

The report recommended that prison should be a last resort for mothers of young children, and should be used only for those women convicted of the most serious offences who represent a danger to the community.

They should be housed in small secure and semi-secure units with social services support, and access to the outside world under supervision.

In Germany and Spain, mothers are allowed to have their children with them in prison until the age of six, in the Netherlands until four in one prison, and until three in Portugal and Switzerland. One German jail has an open unit outside the prison walls in which each mother has her own apartment.

fields.headline: Celebs 'forfeit right to privacy'
fields.standfirst:
Read the report: BSC website
Talk about it
fields.trailText:
10.45am: Most people believe politicians, celebrities and criminals have forfeited their right to privacy according to research out today, reports Jessica Hodgson.
Talk about it
fields.body:
Most people believe that politicians, celebrities and criminals have forfeited their right to privacy.

Research published today by the Broadcasting Standards Commission shows the public believes celebrities should accept that all aspects of their lives may be made public.

Only criminals were judged more harshly, with most people saying they should have no rights to privacy at all.

Politicians were a little more controversial, with older "traditional" people feeling their lives should be subject to the same degree of scrutiny as celebrities, but younger "modern" groups believing their private lives should be kept private.

But respondents said private citizens should have an absolute right to privacy unless they chose to waive their rights.

The report, Reflecting Community Values: Public Attitudes to Broadcasting Regulation, was based on a series of focus groups.

It included questions about the rights of people volunteering to be in fly-on-the-wall documentaries, which showed most respondents believing they also had forfeited their rights to privacy.

All focus group respondents felt, however, that "private citizens" had an absolute right to privacy.

But nearly 30% of respondents felt that by choosing to appear on television, members of the public had forfeit that right.

The report revealed that older respondents were more inclined to feel that the private lives of individuals should be kept private, even when there was a public interest justification.

More than half of the over-55s questioned felt there was never a public interest justification for intrusion into private lives.

The report showed that 41% of people felt that television should show more respect for the intelligence of viewers.

webTitle: Bayern pumped up for the Real deal

fields.headline: Bayern pumped up for the Real deal
fields.trailText: Bayern Munich received a major boost before the first leg of their European Cup semi-final against Real Madrid in the Spanish capital tomorrow when they drew level with Schalke 04 at the top of the Bundesliga.
fields.body:
Bayern Munich received a major boost before the first leg of their European Cup semi-final against Real Madrid in the Spanish capital tomorrow when they drew level with Schalke 04 at the top of the Bundesliga.

The German champions defeated Freiburg 1-0 on Saturday to go second on goal difference with 56 points. Shalke meanwhile could only manage a 1-1 draw against bottom side Vfl Bochum

Bayern's goalkeeper Oliver Khan stepped up the psychological pressure on Schalke when he predicted: "If we win in Leverkusen this Saturday we will win the championship."

"Everybody can see Schalke are nervous," he added. "Two weeks ago, I said that we can benefit from every mistake they will make, and now we have started benefiting."

Bayern were made to work for victory by their mid-table opponents. Freiburg dominated the first-half but Bayern's Carsten Jancker went closest with a header that hit a post. It took a stunning free-kick from Mehmet Scholl in the 65th minute to break the deadlock.

Schalke suffered an early shock when the Bochum midfielder Paul Freier opened the scoring after 21 minutes when he latched on to a poor back pass from Jiri Nemec. Bochum held on to their lead until the 70th minute, when Schalke equalised through the Belgian international striker Emile Mpenza from Tomasz Waldoch's fine pass.

The substitute Marinus Bester secured Hamburg SV's place in the Bundesliga for next season when his late header earned a 2-1 win over Hansa Rostock 2-1 that lifted his side six points clear of the relegation zone with three matches left.

In France, Nantes moved closer to the title with a 1-0 victory at Troyes thanks to a 56th-minute goal from Frederic da Rocha, who fired home from 12 yards after the home side had failed to clear a corner.

Eric Carriere, the midfielder who has played a key role in Nantes's championship challenge, has been named France's player of the year by his fellow professionals. The 27-year-old playmaker joined the club from amateurs FC Muret in 1995. The Lyon striker Sidney Govou, who scored two stunning goals in a home victory over Bayern Munich in the second phase of the Champions League, was named young player of the year.

PSV Eindhoven would have wrapped up the Dutch title at the weekend had they beaten Willem II Tilburg on Saturday. But they were held 1-1 and could not take full advantage of the 1-0 defeat of their nearest challengers Feyenoord at Roda JC on Sunday.

An injury-time winner by the Brazilian striker Jesus Pena kept Porto's title hopes alive in Portugal as they defeated Braga 3-2 on Sunday to keep up pressure on their local rivals Boavista who won 2-1 at Alverca on Saturday.

Benfica's general director Antonio Simoes is in Argentina looking for new players - and not a moment too soon judging by Sunday's 3-0 defeat by Sprting in the Lisbon derby. The visitors never recovered after conceding an early goal to the Argentine striker Alberto Acosta. Pedro Barbosa increased the lead in the 21st minute and Paulo Bento added the third after half-time.

fields.headline: Springer to host Channel 5 election coverage
fields.trailText:
1pm: Jerry Springer, the king of trash television, is to be the face of Channel 5's election coverage, writes Lisa O'Carroll.

30.04.2001: BBC2 woos 'Viagra generation'
30.04.2001: Vaughan signs for Beeb

30.04.2001: C4 unveils rival to Room 101

30.04.2001: BBC admits talent failure

30.04.2001: Wogan loses TV contract

30.04.2001: Channel 4 struggles to replace Breakfast
fields.body:
Jerry Springer, the king of trash television, is to be the face of Channel 5's election coverage.

Executives at the station say they will approach the prime minister, Tony Blair, and the leaders of the two other main parties asking for face-to-face interviews with controversial chat show host.

Mr Springer, who has made millions out of the outrageous confessions of his guests, has been lined up to present a series of shows for Channel 5.

He will fly over to London this weekend and for the Bank Holiday weekend at the end of May to film a British version of his US chat show and a documentary about the election "from an outsider's point of view".

But Channel 5 bosses are determined to get him in the studio with the party leaders and are optimistic the prime minister will be sympathetic to their request.

Four years ago Tony Blair agreed to a similar appearance with the station's former news star, Kirsty Young.

"This will be really big box office for us," said a Channel 5 spokesman. "Jerry Springer in combat with Tony Blair and William Hague would be a much bigger crowd puller than the Dimblebys or even Jeremy Paxman."

Springer's special relationship with the broadcaster has surprised many, particularly since the station's budget cannot accommodate the huge fees US stars command.

However, the Chicago-based presenter is the perfect match for Channel 5 because it will allow him to indulge in what he knows best - controversy.

"He felt he was on a leash at ITV and he wants to be more outrageous," said Alan Nixon, the head of entertainment at Channel 5.

Mr Springer, who was born in Hampstead in London, had decided he would spend six months of the year in the UK even though it will mean a punishing schedule involving three days a week in Chicago and four days a week in London.

Among the shows lined up for him include Greed, a £1m prize gameshow.

One fanciful idea dreamed up by TV executives is a celebrity version of his chat show featuring live confrontations between warring couples such as Patsy Kensit and Liam Gallagher.

For the full story and expert comment by pregnant health minister Yvette Cooper, log on to:

http://www.societytheguardian.com/health/

Tony Blair has sanctioned the preferential allocation of lottery funding to ethnic minority projects.

http://www.societytheguardian.com/lottery

The pro-hunting Countryside Alliance funded an attempted infiltration of theRSPCA, leaked documents reveal.

http://www.societytheguardian.com/voluntary/

Hundreds of people with multiple sclerosis are deteriorating past the point where they can be helped by the only drug neurologists believe can stall the disease, a patients' support group claims.

http://www.societytheguardian.com/health/

http://www.societytheguardian.com/regeneration/

webTitle: The issue explained: a European superstate

fields.headline: European superstate
fields.standfirst:
Germany's chancellor, Gerhard Schröder, has upset Eurosceptics with a blueprint for greater political integration. Derek Brown explains

European integration
fields.trailText: Germany's chancellor, Gerhard Schröder, has upset Eurosceptics with a blueprint for greater political integration. We explain why.
fields.body:
What does Schröder want?
He proposes a radical overhaul of European Union structures, with the European commission becoming a central government for the 15 member states. Schröder says this arrangement would make the EU more democratic.

Would we get to elect the commission?
No. That is the greatest flaw in the Schröder plan. But he does at least suggest that the elected chamber of the European parliament should have the final say on the EU budget.

Does the commission already govern Europe?
No. That is the fallacy being peddled by Europhobes. The commission has two roles: to come up with new policy ideas, and to administer existing Euro-legislation.

Where does power lie in Europe?
In the national capitals, as it always has. Member state governments exercise that power through the council of ministers with each state effectively able to veto proposals they really hate.

Does Schröder want to do away with the council of ministers?
In its present cumbersome form, yes. He wants it to become the second chamber of parliament, which would safeguard national sovereignty and protect the interests of member states.

Will the Schröder plan lead to a United States of Europe?
Hardly. For one thing, it is only a discussion document before his Social Democrats, and has not been approved by the party - let alone the German parliament. Even if he gets national backing, Schröder can hardly expect the other governments to fall in line. And even if they did endorse the plan, or something similar to it, it would take decades to implement.

What is in it for Germany?In the short term (there are national elections next year) Schröder wants to project himself as a visionary leader. In the longer term, he genuinely wants Germany to take a leading role in a new, more closely united Europe, as befits the biggest member state and by far the biggest contributor to EU funds.

Who will oppose the Schröder plan?
The British will, in their long tradition of distrust of Europe and all its works. With the election expected in June, Tony Blair has already appealed to the government of Belgium - currently holding the presidency of the council of ministers - to tone down its integrationist rhetoric. British government ministers are horrified that the Schröder plan is due to be discussed by the chancellor's party on the very day next month that Tony Blair visits Berlin.

Who else opposes the proposals?
The French will froth with fury over the proposal to give budgetary powers to the European parliament, for MEPs would love to scrap the common agricultural policy which is a sacred cow in France.

What do the Eurosceptics say?
They can barely contain their indignation, or conceal their delight that the spectre of a superstate could haunt the election campaign. Francis Maude, the shadow foreign secretary, says that an EU government "will damage our economy and our democracy".

webTitle: New head of PR for Seat UK

fields.headline: New head of PR for Seat UK
fields.trailText:
12.30pm: Seat UK has appointed Juliet Edwards as its new head of public relations, reports Julia Day.
Useful link: Seat UK website
fields.body:
Seat UK has appointed Juliet Edwards as its new head of public relations.

Ms Edwards will head up the new four-strong PR team at Seat's headquarters in Milton Keynes from May 1.

She has worked within the Volkswagen Group since 1987, most recently on the Skoda brand where she held the position of press relations manager.

Seat has also launched its revamped online press office.

Ms Edwards's appointment comes after Seat promoted its regional brand manager, Mark McKenna, to head its marketing operation.

Mr McKenna took over from the head of marketing, Gary Savage, who has moved to head of sales and operations at the Volkswagen-owned subsidiary.

fields.headline: Bright Station rescue plan fails to impress
fields.trailText: 12.15pm: The future of internet technology company Bright Station is hanging in the balance, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
The future of the internet technology company, Bright Station, is hanging in the balance after the stock market hammered a last-ditch rescue plan.

Shares in the struggling group fell 17% this morning to 17p, as investors scorned the announcement of a £25m cash injection from the investment bank, Credit Suisse First Boston.

The convertible bond deal will only go through if the company's market value stays above £30m. Today's share tumble puts Bright Station's value at £29m.

Bright Station, which bought the technology assets of online retailer boo.com last year, has been forced to go cap in hand to investors, with just £7.4m left in the bank.

Sources close to the company stressed it was looking at other options, but admitted that today's market reaction underlined the difficulty of its task.

"The board recognises there is a fair chance the plan will not work in the current market conditions. There is a very urgent need for additional cash, so it is a question of ruling nothing in and ruling nothing out," said the source.

Dan Wagner, chief executive of the group, has agreed to bail out from Bright Station if a restructuring deal goes through. He has expressed an interest in buying most of its subsidiaries.

If the rescue plan goesahead, Bright Station will be renamed after its SmartLogik knowledge management subsidiary, which would be its only remaining asset.

Mr Wagner has long complained that the group's assets have been undervalued by a sceptical stock market. He believes that SmartLogik could be as successful as technology giant Autonomy.
