webTitle: Cameron to be king of the cosmos?

fields.headline: Cameron to be king of the cosmos?
fields.standfirst: Plus: P.Diddy to score Ferrara prequel; Everett lords it up in South Kensington; Van Damme reverts to habit in The Monk; treat on the web for web fans
fields.trailText: Plus: P.Diddy to score Ferrara prequel; Everett lords it up in South Kensington; Van Damme reverts to habit in The Monk; treat on the web for web fans
fields.body:
 Titanic director James Cameron's dream to be the first member of the entertainment industry in space has moved one step closer to reality, following American multi-millionaire Denis Tito's trip into space over the weekend. The Oscar winner is now keen to restart talks with both the Russians and Nasa and hopes to ride a Russian Soyuz rocket to the International Space Station to film in space. "I think we need to keep the dream of exploration alive," Cameron told the New York Post. "If people realised how important the space station is as a stepping stone to the stars and the thing that excites the human heart, they would get behind it more."

 Sean "P.Diddy" Combs is to write his first Hollywood soundtrack, according to Ananova. The music will feature in The Last Crew, starring rapper turned actor Mark Wahlberg and The Sopranos actress Drea de Matteo. The film's producer, Barry Amato, is also keen for Combs to appear in the film, which is a prequel to Abel Ferrara's 1990 cult classic King of New York.

 Rupert Everett is in final negotiations to star in the Italian-language film South Kensington, according to Variety. Everett, who speaks fluent Italian, will play a British aristocrat in dire financial straits who rents rooms in his lordly residence to two Italians, resulting in a series of comic twists. Directed by Italian Carlo Vanzina, the $7m picture is set to start shooting in London in July.

 Jean-Claude Van Damme has signed up to star in the independent kung fu film The Monk for director Ringo Lam, according to Variety. Set to begin production on November 1, the $25m project centres on a Shaolin monk who journeys to America in search of his father and instead finds himself in a battle with an evil crime lord. The production will shoot in China, Bulgaria and New York.

 The Ain't It Cool website has got some exclusive pictures on the set of the new Spider-Man film, starring Tobey Maguire.

webTitle: Drug cost dithering 'lets MS get worse'

fields.headline: Drug cost dithering 'lets MS get worse'
fields.standfirst: Patients ailing beyond help while NHS bill for treatment is assessed, says Multiple Sclerosis Society
fields.trailText: Hundreds of people with multiple sclerosis are deteriorating past the point where they can be helped by the only drug neurologists believe can stall the disease, a patients' support group claimed yesterday.
fields.body:
Hundreds of people with multiple sclerosis are deteriorating past the point where they can be helped by beta interferon, the only drug neurologists believe can stall the disease, while a government institute drags its feet on whether the NHS can afford to pay for it, a patients' support group claimed yesterday.

MS patients have been waiting since August 1999 for a decision. "The whole way this has been handled has been dishonourable, disgraceful and disgusting," said Peter Cardy, chairman of the MS Society.

The national institute for clinical excellence (Nice) was established by the government to stamp out the "postcode lottery" in the NHS whereby one health authority will pay for a certain drug or treatment but another will not. Its remit is to appraise new drugs, treatments and guidelines, and to advise ministers on what the NHS could and should afford.

A significant number of new drugs have been appraised since Nice was set up in April 1999, including Relenza for flu, and various expensive cancer drugs. Drugs for motor neurone disease and Alzheimer's, both degenerative disorders like MS, have been approved even though, like beta interferon, they are said to give only marginal benefits.

Most appraisals take about a year, but MS sufferers have been waiting for a decision on the newer drug, glatiramer acetate (whose brand name is Capaxone), also for more than 20 months.

Part of the delay was caused by the appeal - by MS patient groups, neurologists, the Royal College of Nursing and drug manufacturers - against Nice's original decision to ban the drugs from the health service. The appeal was upheld and the appraisal committee looked again at the drugs.

A decision was expected last December, but Nice then decided to commission research into the cost to the health service. It has now said the decision will be made in July.

People with MS have been picketing Nice board meetings in protest at the delay, which Mr Cardy believes is unforgivable. "It has allowed hundreds of people to cease to be eligible for treatment, even if it finally recommends treatment."

Beta interferons have to be prescribed while the patient is still active. David Lloyd is a perfect candidate, but is 21st on his local drugs waiting list; like many health authorities East Lancashire capped the amount it was willing to spend on beta interferon, which costs about £10,000 per patient per year.

Dr Lloyd, who is 35, used to work for the authority and understands the predicament. "They must stay within budget. My beef isn't with the health authority, it's with the national institute taking so long." MS hit him suddenly around Christmas 1999.

"I had trouble asking for a 30ml syringe, then my hands started to go numb. Then it progressed. By the time they diagnosed it, it had affected most of my body - I couldn't put a drip in properly."

He worked at getting very fit, but the relapses set him back. "It's like someone has taken out the good battery and left you a half spent one," he said.

His neurologist believes he needs to have beta interferon soon. He is taking mitozantone, part of a cocktail of drugs used in leukaemia treatment that is quite toxic. But no one can take this for more than two years because it damages the heart. Dr Lloyd takes it every three months; it makes him vomit for several days before it works.

Mr Cardy believes that Nice is not taking fully into account the devastating nature of the disease, which in the worst cases can leave people totally disabled and others unaware of what is going on.

For Nice, the exercise is the hardest it has had to undertake. Beta interferon is considered to have only a modest benefit in slowing down the disease's progress, a fact that the institute must set against the cost to the NHS of a drug that many people could be on for years. The institute says it is trying to be fair to everyone and is participating in an economic modelling exercise.

Mr Cardy claims Nice is dragging its heels over cost alone. "Sir Michael Rawlins [chairman of Nice] has said it is the price that's too high. He has made it clear that he believes the MS societies should be lobbying companies to lower the price to about £3,000."

But the drug is widely available abroad. Dr Lloyd, for one, thinks that if the decision is an economic one, the government, and not the institute, should be making it.

webTitle: PM sanctions lottery boost for minorities

fields.headline: PM sanctions lottery boost for minorities
fields.standfirst: Special report: the lottery
fields.trailText: Tony Blair has sanctioned the preferential allocation of millions of pounds to ethnic minority projects bidding for lottery funds. The money will go towards a programme to end the social exclusion and deprivation of black communities.
fields.body:
Tony Blair has sanctioned the preferential allocation of millions of pounds to ethnic minority projects bidding for lottery funds. The money will go towards a programme to end the social exclusion and deprivation of black communities.

The groups likely to benefit from the switch in policy include an arts and music centre named after the late campaigning Labour MP Bernie Grant; a training centre for black architects named after the murdered teenager Stephen Lawrence; and a family project in one of the most deprived inner city areas in Leicester, in the constituency of Keith Vaz, the Foreign Office minister. The successful bids will be announced in the next two months.

The prime minister approved switching £20m of lottery money from the Lottery's New Opportunities Fund to the millennium commission, in order to fund big projects led by black and Asian groups. The move followed a Whitehall analysis which showed that only 2.3% of lottery money went to ethnic minority groups, although these groups make up 6% of the population.

Ministers have also invoked, for the first time, "positive discrimination" clauses in the 1998 Lottery Act, allowing the millennium commission to solicit applications from black projects, and to give them £623,000 of lottery funds with which to draw up their bids.

Until the law changed, the commission, and other lottery boards, was unable to solicit bids. It was also unable to give any lottery money to organisa tions to help them draw up the time-consuming and detailed proposals required to satisfy the funding criteria.

Details of the prime minister's initiative came to light in a confidential memorandum sent to Mr Blair by Chris Smith, the culture secretary, last April.

The memo sought Mr Blair's approval for special measures because,it said: "It has proved more difficult to support capital projects addressing ethnic minorities.

"Despite many government initiatives, the Afro-Caribbean community still faces significant deprivation and social exclusion which the lottery could, and should, do something to address. Particularly important would be some landmark projects to which these and other communities could look as a beacon of black aspiration and achievements."

Mr Smith went on to say that both he, as chairman of the millennium commission, and Mo Mowlam, the Cabinet Office minister who sits on the body, believed the commission was "uniquely well placed" to use the positive discrimination powers to help black groups.

Mike O'Connor, the commission's director, confirmed that, following Mr Smith's plea to the prime minister, the go-ahead had been given for the initiative, which has now attracted applications totalling almost double the amount of money available.

He said: "Because we have put our head above the parapet in funding ethnic minority groups, I expect we will face criticism since we won't able to grant all the applications."

fields.headline: Stallone's Driven burns past Bridget
fields.trailText: Bridget Jones's Diary has been knocked off the top of the US box office charts by Sylvester Stallone's new racing car thriller, Driven
fields.body:
Bridget Jones's Diary has been knocked off the top of the US box office charts by Sylvester Stallone's new racing car thriller, Driven.

Despite receiving a panning from critics, the film, which was written by and co-starred Stallone, made $13.1m [£9m] over its opening weekend.

It is Stallone's first box office success in a decade and tells the story of two gung-ho race drivers who vie for the Championship Auto Racing Team crown. Dan Fellman, president of distribution at Warner Bros, said that Stallone was "thrilled" with the film's debut.

Bridget Jones, which dropped down to the number two position, has still taken a healthy $36.2m since its Stateside release three weeks ago.

Meanwhile the long-delayed Warren Beatty-Goldie Hawn marital infidelity comedy Town & Country which reportedly cost upward of $90m to make, opened at number seven, taking a disappointing $3.1m. The film, which also stars Diane Keaton, took three years to make and had its release date changed 13 times as it underwent re-shoots and rewrites that doubled its initial budget.

fields.headline: Cash in the community
fields.standfirst: Special report: the lottery
fields.trailText: Ethnic minority groups applying for lottery funding
fields.body:
Groups applying for money include:

 The Asha Centre, Harrow, north-west London. It wants £10m for a centre and garden on a 10 acre site.

 The Peepul Centre, Leicester, is seeking £7m for a centre in one of the most deprived areas. It plans to run multilingual business conferences, day care facilities, a gym and a cybercafe. The millennium commission has given it £181,222 to draw up its application.

 The Bernie Grant Centre in Tottenham, north London. It is seeking £6m to convert Tottenham old town hall into a black music and arts centre. The millennium commission gave it £250,000 to draw up an application. It is being developed by Sharon Lawrence, widow of the Labour MP Bernie Grant.

 The Stephen Lawrence Technocentre in Deptford Creek, south London. It is seeking £3.9m for a technical centre to train architects and designers. It received £150,000 to draw up an application. It is backed by the veteran film producer Lord Puttnam, the designer Sir Terence Conran and TV mogul Lord Alli.

fields.headline: In favour of motherhood
fields.standfirst: Six months pregnant herself, the public health minister looks forward to a big boost in maternity services
fields.trailText: Two years ago, having just given birth to my first child at 5am, an unexpected acceleration in labour meant that I missed out on the epidural I wanted, and I was feeling pretty sore about it in more ways than one. But uppermost in my mind, with my newborn and husband crashed out asleep together in the armchair, was a craving for a cup of tea and a bacon sandwich.
fields.body:
Two years ago, having just given birth to my first child at 5am, an unexpected acceleration in labour meant that I missed out on the epidural I wanted, and I was feeling pretty sore about it in more ways than one. But uppermost in my mind, with my newborn and husband crashed out asleep together in the armchair, was a craving for a cup of tea and a bacon sandwich.

Sadly, at that hour, no one was taking orders for a fry-up. If asked for a personal recommendation on how to modernise maternity services, "bacon and anaesthetists" would have been my reply.

Bacon aside, the care from staff at Pontefract hospital was excellent. According to an audit commission survey a few years ago, most women say that they are pleased with the care they receive. The trouble is that there are wide variations in maternity services across the country. These limit rather than extend the choices offered to women and their partners at a critical time in their lives.

Perhaps most important of all, those variations often reflect deep-rooted inequalities. The founding principles of the NHS are that healthcare should be free at the point of use, based on need, not ability to pay. That means ensuring that those in greatest need do not have least access to health services. Nowhere is this more important than at the very beginning of a child's life.

So as part of a plan to tackle child poverty and give every child the best start, Alan Milburn, the health secretary, will set out this week a major programme of modernisation in our maternity services. That means investment in facilities and recruitment, improvements to screening and the beginnings of a major scheme of national standards in maternity and children's health. We need such new standards to ensure proper safety and high-quality care in every area.

Now in the sixth month of my second pregnancy, I know from personal experience that different places can have very different approaches. The consequence of travelling each week between Westminster and my constituency is signing up for maternity care at both ends of the country. After all, it's hard to predict where I will be when labour starts. All mothers know that drawing up birth plans can prove pointless when labour takes a different course. Discussing epidurals with two sets of midwives proved doubly redundant but provided an interesting insight into the variations that exist.

Different units offer different tests at different points in pregnancy. In fact if you switch hospitals at the right point, you can probably clock up six different tests for Down's syndrome (scans, double and triple tests galore) and each will give you a slightly different result.

One of the first areas in which we are introducing national standards involves the screening and counselling support to be offered for certain tests in pregnancy and newborns so that parents have a proper, informed choice about which tests they want. Work is under way too on clinical standards around the management of labour, particularly when problems arise, including induction, fetal monitoring and Caesareans.

Second, as investment in the NHS grows, we need to address the backlog in underinvestment that can have a huge impact on family experience. Staff are often working extremely hard, but having to contend with outdated, rundown facilities. Some units offer home-from-home comforts, perhaps with separate midwife-led facilities. Others have cramped labour wards that look more like Victorian operating theatres.

In Pontefract there were TVs in individual rooms on the labour ward, in theory to provide distraction during a long labour. In practice I suspect they found more enthusiasm among partners, bored with helping with breathing. Either way, modern maternity services need modern facilities too.

Increasing staffing levels is vital. Recruitment pressures in some areas make it difficult to provide the one-to-one care in established labour that women want. The Pontefract area operates team midwifery, which meant we saw the same familiar faces before, during and after the birth. In other areas hard-working health service staff have developed different innovative models to provide continuity of care and support. In part it means proper staffing, but it can also mean new ways of working.

As new investment and improvements take place it is essential that they support choices for parents. The choice whether to have a home birth varies dramatically across the country. Personally I am too risk-averse, and pain-averse, to dream of a home birth myself. The idea of all that trauma in my kitchen or bedroom is enough to put me off ever going into the rooms again. But wherever it is clinically appropriate, these are choices the NHS should, where possible, support.

So mothers and mothers-to-be will be asked their views on improving maternity services across the country. And for the first time in any government review of this kind, we will explicitly seek the views of fathers too. Already the royal colleges representing midwives, obstetricians, paediatricians and anaesthetists have joined the government and parent groups in a joint maternity working group.

But in the end, the real challenge is to improve the choices and support avail able for those whose voices are least often heard, yet who may need support most. As one midwife told me, the expectant mothers she worried about most were often least likely to make it to appointments.

Certainly for those on low incomes facing a long bus ride with toddlers in tow, a trip to an antenatal appointment can be a daunting experience. As my own second bump gets bigger and bulkier, wrestling with an errant pushchair, an excitable toddler and the London-to-Yorkshire train each week is ordeal enough. It is only a matter of time before we sail past our Wakefield stop because a coincidence of tantrums and twinges make it physically impossible to get everything off in time.

So improving access to maternity services is not just about what happens in hospital, or the care the NHS provides. Already Sure Start programmes are providing toddler-friendly mini-buses to healthcare appointments, or taking the midwives out into family homes. After the baby is born, extending care and support is just as vital - whether it be help for women who want to breastfeed, identifying post-natal depression or just making sure that there is someone to talk to in those difficult early months.

It isn't hard to be passionate about improving maternity services and children's health when your own little one is on the way. But if we are to deliver major improvements in children's health across the board, we need to build on progress in all these areas. Only that way can we ensure that every child gets the very best start in life.

The author is public health minister and MP for Pontefract and Castleford.

webTitle: Amazing opportunity! Read on to find out...

fields.headline: Amazing opportunity! Read on to find out...
fields.trailText: Someone called Jo Eardmore sent me an email labelled "interesting" the other day. I don't know Jo, but he or she could have been a contact or someone who was, indeed, interesting. Instead, Jo offered me the chance to become financially independent in a few years. I had been spammed.
fields.body:
Someone called Jo Eardmore sent me an email labelled "interesting" the other day. I don't know Jo, but he or she could have been a contact or someone who was, indeed, interesting. Instead, Jo offered me the chance to become financially independent in a few years. I had been spammed.

Call it inertia, but I've grown used to arriving home to listen, on my answer-machine, to time-share salesmen offering me a trip to Disney. I also quickly delete those emails offering an "Aaamazingly huge" opportunity, or the ones from African businessmen asking for the use of my bank account for a guaranteed fee.

Most people learn to live with the junk which fills their email and voicemail boxes every day. Even though I was annoyed at being duped by Jo, I couldn't be bothered enough to take a note of his or her Altavista email account or send a stinging message back. That could change, however, if the egregious Jo found my cell-phone number.

Cell-phones in the US - or at least in the connection desert that is New York city - have many drawbacks. One of these is that users are charged when they are called as well as when they do the calling.

This actually makes it illegal for someone to send unsolicited commercial email, or spam, to a mobile phone in the US under a provision in the Telephone Consumer Protection Act designed to save consumers money. However, a very murky legal area means that there is no prohibition on sending a short text message to the same device. And almost all of the cell-phones sold in the US are provided with a text-messaging capacity. Consumers only pay when they respond to a message on most services.

Armed only with telephone numbers and the name of the local provider - both easy to find out - spammers can send out one message that will beep simultaneously on thousands of mobile devices. Bad news if all the owners are at the same tennis match.

Rodney Joffe was at a performance of Riverdance when he received what he took to be an urgent message. The Arizona-based entrepreneur had remembered to turn off his telephone function but not his text messaging service. When it rang during the show, he jumped in embarrassment. After reading his message, however, he thought the caller must have dialled a wrong number. It read: "To Carla - mortgage rates cut - still interested?"

But when the same company called his cell-phone a month or so later, using a different message, Joffe realised that he had been spammed. Unlike most of us, Joffe, the former chief technology officer of an internet access company, did something about it.

After turning to the web, he found more than 170,000 people who, he claims, have all been targeted by the same company, a local mortgage provider. Joffe has now launched what is believed to be the first lawsuit against a company for wireless spam in the US.

Privacy advocates in the US, who have long battled against some of the weakest legislation in the world, believe that consumer outrage against wireless spam could prove to be the last straw. They also hope that an early response could stop a fledgling industry in its tracks. "It's really important to make a stand early on," says Joffe. "By the time we realised what was going on with email spam it was too late."

He faces an uphill struggle, largely because advertisers have only just started to wake up to the potential for short-text messaging in the US. In an interview with National Public Radio, Gerald Youhanaie, the president of the mortgage company that targeted Joffe, was completely unabashed by the protest. He called text-messaging "a unique medium to inform people that mortgage rates were on the decline". Then he added: "We felt it was very cost-effective."

A wireless advertising company called SkyGo says the potential market for commercial email over wireless phones is so huge that few companies will ignore it. The company paid 1,000 people to take part in a four-month trial of spammed phones and, perhaps unsurprisingly, reported back that they were happy to receive the messages. The study did find that consumers preferred to choose when to see the ads, however.

Jason Catlett, the president of Junkbusters.com, a privacy campaign group, hopes that the growing furore over relatively rare wireless spam could help prompt tighter legislation against wired and telephone spam. He appeared before the US Congress last week and argued that a proposed bill that would allow consumers to opt out of receiving spam needs to be made far tougher.

Until there is more political support for his position, however, I'm keeping my cell-phone number to myself.

webTitle: Who wants to own a million-hits-a-day website?

fields.headline: Who wants to own a million-hits-a-day website?
fields.standfirst: ITV.com has been given the green light, but will rivalry between Carlton and Granada sink it?
fields.trailText: ITV.com has been given the green light, but will rivalry between Carlton and Granada sink it?
fields.body:
It's been a long time coming and it's still not quite all there, but so far it's got a tentative thumbs up from an industry not ordinarily noted for eulogies. itv.com looks like finally happening this year as part of ITV's effort to get its house in order. A rumoured investment of £15m in a website for the ITV network makes perfect sense, and puts to shame other media companies that are getting twitchy about the internet. Top 10 status shouldn't be that difficult to achieve, and, with ITV's sales clout, it might actually make some of that elusive internet cash.

At this stage, plans are still very sketchy. Everyone is waiting for new ITV boss Stuart Prebble to sit down and thrash out the company's internet strategy with ITV henchmen and the heads of interactive departments at Carlton and Granada, the dominant ITV shareholders. While it may not be Prebble's top priority, itv.com is still important.

Senior executives at Granada Broadband and Carlton Interactive are expecting a summons from ITV network centre in Grays Inn Road this week to determine itv.com's structure, and define how the centralised operation should be run.

So far it seems that itv.com will make very little difference to their operations, despite a leaked memo from Gerry Murphy, the chief executive of Carlton, suggesting that downsizing may occur. But, says Justin Judd, controller of online at Granada Broadband, it's not a matter of merging internet operations, it's more about pooling resources. "We'll still look after all our own resources, such as Wellbeing, SwapitShop and the Liverpool and Arsenal websites, but our content will now be pulled into a much bigger portal."

Likewise, Carlton will hold onto its internet assets, which include Jamba, Popcorn, Taste and Carlton.com, and feed them into itv.com. Production and development will still be handled by Carlton and Granada's individual teams, while a new "leaner and meaner commissioning body" will sit in network centre, pulling it all together.

Some preparations are going on behind the scenes: no surprise as the idea for itv.com has been touted since before Carlton chairman Michael Green first revealed it in June last year. One snag, however, was always ownership of the domain name itv.com. It was owned by one Nick Rosen of the Online Research Agency, who registered it in 1994 thinking it would make a good name for an interactive TV (iTV) website. After lengthy negotiations, Rosen caved in and sold it for a reported £100,000 at the beginning of April - just in time for ITV to start singing and dancing about ITV Digital.

What is important about the proposals for itv.com is that finally the two former adversaries have seemingly buried the hatchet and have laid to rest the ridiculous notion of trying to plug their own corporate brands as entertainment portals. What Carlton was trying to achieve with Carlton.com has baffled many internet pundits - Carlton is a brand that means absolutely nothing to that part of the population not served by its TV franchise.

That said, Carlton did at least make an effort early in the web game. It developed three strong specialist websites which gave the impression it had a good web strategy, until it seemed to stall 18 months ago. Success wasn't just born out of luck, though. Carlton brought in Carol Dukes, one of the internet's cleverest operators, who quickly pulled together some of the best talent in the industry. She is now founding CEO of Thinknatural.com.

Granada, on the other hand, took a long time getting to where it is now. Its big internet adventure so far has been G-Wizz, an expensive drain on resources (around £9m was spent) which taught execs that internet branding was not about having a snazzy name. With G-Wizz finally exterminated, Granada has been able to get back to focusing on what it's good at: content. Having brought in two former Granada TV producers (Judd and Simon Shaps) last year, it has had to work out just what it can do with its programmes on the web.

Since joining Granada Broadband, Judd has been working on a number of programme sites and initiatives, namely the Popstars website, chat and SMS strands, and redefining flagship brands such as Coronation Street, This Morning and Emmerdale. In addition, Granada Broadband has invested in the cross-media Wellbeing venture with Boots and kids exchange site Swapitshop. They will all now be rolled into itv.com along with Carlton's web properties.

To move forward, itv.com needs a managing director and the sooner the better, according to John Hardie, ITV's marketing and commercial director, who wants to see the project accelerate ahead. "The MD could be found internally or externally - there's no shortage of people around with the right experience. Once we get the right group of people together and find the right person to run it, it's full steam ahead."

It's going to be quite a challenge. While unquestionably it will be a big, well-paid and high-profile job, that person will have to be skilled in the art of tricky negotiations. Even if everything at ITV now looks rosy, there is a certain amount of baggage that might make it frustrating at times.

The history of Carlton and Granada fighting their own corners at the network is well-documented, which is why the companies' internet strategies have never been comfortable bedfellows. In a perverse way, their inertia has worked in their favour in that they haven't (aside from G-Wizz) rushed in and wasted tons of cash on foolish ideas.

Conrad Roeber, a partner at Spectrum Strategy Consultants, thinks itv.com should be trying to punch at an even higher weight, not just settle for top 10 status. "They wouldn't accept that position for their TV channel," he says. Roeber suggests itv.com should look even further afield than just entertainment, and start thinking about their respective 20% stakes in ITN.

"They haven't yet been able to incorporate ITN.co.uk within the proposed portal, which is a pity, given the importance of online news to the BBC," says Roeber. "Clearly, this is due to the independence of ITN from the ITV shareholders, but it would make perfect sense for these two to form a strategic alliance in the online environment, and it is a pity that this has not been identified as one of ITV's ambitions."

The network's ambitions for itv.com have also so far failed to include two smaller cogs in the ITV machine - Scottish Media Group and Ulster, who between them own the remaining 8% of the network. Including these assets in itv.com would bring Virginradio.co.uk, a ready-made network of classified sites, and an Irish internet service provider from Ulster TV, to the table. The sum of the parts has enormous potential, and should start to make competitors such as Sky.com, BBC.co.uk and Channel4.com reassess their tactics.

Andy Anson, head of strategic planning at Channel 4, is concerned that if itv.com works then it could be "quite scary" for other players such as himself. webTitle: Brown rejects infected foreign meat claim

fields.headline: Brown rejects infected foreign meat claim
fields.standfirst: Special report: foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: The agriculture minister, Nick Brown, moved swiftly yesterday to dismiss claims that the foot and mouth virus had been brought to Britain in infected meat imported by the army from South America.
fields.body:
The agriculture minister, Nick Brown, moved swiftly yesterday to dismiss claims that the foot and mouth virus had been brought to Britain in infected meat imported by the army from South America.

As he spoke, the Ministry of Defence confirmed that the army had supplied waste food to the Northumberland pig farm where the outbreak is believed to have begun, but said any suggestion of a link between the swill and foot and mouth was "completely unjustified".

Mr Brown said it was "completely wrong" to suggest the army was to blame.

"I don't think there is anything in that at all," he told BBC1's On the Record. "Apart from anything else, the virus strain that is present in regions of South America is a different strain. I do not think that the army's arrangements are the cause of this disease outbreak."

Some meat used at a training camp at Whitburn, near Sunderland, may have been imported by the army from Brazil and Uruguay, where a strain of the disease is endemic. But in a statement the MoD said it took supplies only from regions clear of infection.

"Until recently small amounts of food waste from Whitburn training camp were disposed of via a local firm who hold the appropriate licence for swill collection and processing," the statement said.

"The firm collects from a number of non-army sites around the north-east. All food that is imported for use by the army for consumption complies with all relevant UK and EU regulations. With respect to foot and mouth, this means only importing from areas that are certified free of the disease."

Swill from the camp was collected, treated and fed to pigs at Bobby and Ronnie Waugh's farm in Heddon-on-the-Wall in Northumberland. Bobby Waugh confirmed that he collected waste from the camp 10 times a year and had last collected a load of wet food slops in December, two months before the disease was identified at the farm.

The army's link with the farm follows earlier suggestions by a Ministry of Agriculture official that suspect meat used in Chinese takeaways and restaurants could have found its way into the swill fed to the Waughs' pigs.

Stuart Renton, who works at a foot and mouth control centre in Newcastle, said he and other vets were certain the disease had taken hold before it reached Heddon-on-the-Wall. "Long-standing foot and mouth lesions are being found in sheep nationally, indicating the disease was probably present before the initial outbreak in Heddon," he said. "We are still getting pockets of infection in sheep which cannot be traced back to Heddon."

Dr Renton also said that he and some colleagues had serious doubts about the government's culling policies.

"From day one, Maff has been terribly under-resourced to cope. I knew when I took on a case in February that we were on the edge of a disaster and it's been playing catch-up ever since."

Bobby Waugh said yesterday: "Once again there is evidence to show my farm is not to blame for the foot and mouth disease. I am now waiting for the government to admit they got it wrong and clear my name."

webTitle: Comment: Backroom deals for BBC regulation

fields.headline: There's only one good name in the hat for BBC chairman
fields.standfirst: Does it matter if a mate of New Labour is chairman? Hardly at all
fields.trailText: Name games are jolly games, of course they are. Who's up, who's down, who's a "people's peer" or the next boss of BT? But don't let such games get in the way. Always watch for the hard issue amid the soft speculation. Watch, especially, what happens to the BBC.
fields.body:
Name games are jolly games, of course they are. Who's up, who's down, who's a "people's peer" or the next boss of BT? But don't let such games get in the way. Always watch for the hard issue amid the soft speculation. Watch, especially, what happens to the BBC.

At first sight - fuelled by malign coincidence - this is merely another soapy, back-scratching saga. Sir Christopher Bland exits right just as Lord Stevenson, centre-left, bobs in with his first 15 appointed (and self-promoted) wearers of the ermine. Ever-decreasing circles. Could Lord Stevenson himself be the next to chair the BBC governors? And how about Elspeth (three times a Lady) Howe, who used to prescribe broadcasting standards for all until HMG cancelled her last quango? What goes around comes around for the great and good.

Let's get serious, though - as serious as the problems facing the corporation. There is, as always, a clock ticking towards charter-renewal time in 2006 (and ticking towards another general election time, too). That's the licence fee, which means the future of everything, up for grabs. Swamp politics. Meanwhile, the whole structure of broadcasting will have changed. Never forget last winter's communications white paper, with all the regulators rolled into one dodgy giant called Ofcom.

Those who govern the BBC wriggled half-free from Ofcom's prospective embrace. They'll remain seemingly as heretofore, sitting round the big table in Broadcasting House, debating, taking decisions, their legal remit in place. But compromise is also the mother of enfeeblement. If you, the viewer, want to complain and get no joy from the Beeb, then there's a right to patrol on to Ofcom and its "contents board": this train won't terminate in Langham Place any longer.

And where does logic draw a broader line? Most of the fulminations since the white paper was published have concentrated on this BBC anomaly. Gerald Kaufman and his media select committee think it's ridiculous to set up a supreme, joined-up regulator whose brief for upholding standards or competition or technological common sense runs out at Regent Street. Any supposed deal here surely won't hold through a couple of years of charter-renewal manipulation. Worse still, Chris Smith shows every sign of thinking that putting the governors on drip feed gives him the right to drip the culture secretary's own views down the pipe.

Be clear, then. This is already a far more serious game; in play and rolling on. And it has to be set against an equally serious internal management problem. Simply, does the ancestral carve-up between full-time director general and part-time governors still work? You'd hardly think so after the fiasco of John Birt's reforms (warmly backed by Bland et al ) and their subsequent junking by Greg Dyke (warmly backed by Bland et al ).

The grand old Duke of York never had it so ridiculous. If the governors - appointed by HMG on our behalf - are there to provide bridges of consistency and accountability in the public interest, then there appeared to be very little of all that on offer. The governors, in defensive mode, were there to sanctify what the DG wanted; the Bland leading the blind.

The inescapable fact is that the traditional division of powers doesn't work any more. If the BBC is to have a board of governors, they need to be as professional and committed as the board Sir Christopher will need to rescue BT. They can't be alternates on Lord Stevenson's list. And whoever takes the chair will have to burn much midnight oil.

This isn't the genteel monopoly of yesteryear. This is now a big player - prospectively Britain's biggest player - in an intensely competitive global market. It uses our licence money to parade into digital or bestride the internet - and, in so doing, inevitably conditions what Britain's private players can do in turn. That doesn't make it bad: just the contrary. But it does - pounding on towards a £3bn annual spend - make it vastly relevant.

Think of that and you see the oddness of Greg Dyke's position. He is responsible for the gold standard, the programmes the corporation puts out, but he is also responsible for hotel bills and free croissants. He is an editor and an accountant and his own managing director: an impossibly stretched job that is bound to come apart at the seams - and made more impossible because of the Beeb's penchant for always buying in its stars from outside so that home-grown talent gets the message and pushes off.

It's no accident that one of the most interesting BBC times came when Michael Checkland was DG (managing away) and John Birt his deputy, doing the programmes. A natural division, which crumbled as an omnipotent Lord Birt got bitten by McKinsey's.

So names are not the only part of this game. You need architects and the builders to follow a plan. But who (the real curse of the modern BBC) is strong enough to be head architect? Not our nervy, meddling politicians. Not the current, amateur governors. Not a director general (and allies) who can't extend his sway to the people who are supposed to call him to account. Sir Christopher Bland could have done it, in concert with Dyke, but he's seen a different, fatter challenge floating by and jumped ship two crucial years early, any legacy left in the lurch.

Plain questions, plain conclusions. Do we want the essence of what the BBC offers to survive much beyond the middle of the decade? If we do, then the corporation will need a tougher, more driving management, led by a tighter, more professional board. There's no point in keeping the current crew if Ofcom is going to duplicate their standards role (unless you want to make them a kind of Langham magistrates court).

Does it matter if a mate of New Labour chairs the governors? Hardly at all. Conservative governments have been putting in their mates - remember Charlie Hill? - since the BBC began; the whole edifice is a pantheon of mateyness. I'd rather have a Tony crony who knows about the digital revolution than a tame all-purpose hack who starts from square one. And I'd desperately want someone with a direct line to Downing Street when things get rough.

What about other jobs on other boards? Who cares? Charlie Hill ran Laporte Industries and the Beeb out of his two, well-stuffed back pockets. The imperatives are time and energy, commitment and clout. The job isn't staggering on between charter crises but, for the first time, creating a powerhouse that can make its own case - an enterprise shaping its own future.

Continuity? That comes naturally, as it happens, because - out of all the names in the game - only one fits. Gavyn Davies, a uniquely qualified deputy chairman. Why is anyone who really cares about the BBC waiting?

fields.headline: Sheringham wins PFA award
fields.trailText: Manchester United striker Teddy Sheringham was named Footballer of the Year by his fellow professionals at a PFA dinner in London last night. United team-mate Roy Keane came second in the poll and Arsenal striker Thierry Henry was third.
fields.body:
Manchester United striker Teddy Sheringham was named Footballer of the Year by his fellow professionals at a PFA dinner in London last night. United team-mate Roy Keane came second in the poll and Arsenal striker Thierry Henry was third.

Liverpool midfielder Steven Gerrard claimed the Young Player of the Year award, with Joe Cole runner-up and Wes Brown third.

Sheringham, who received his award from Sir Steve Redgrave at the Grosvenor House Hotel in London, described the award as the "biggest personal award you can get in the game".

He said: "I first came to this dinner at 17 or 18 when I'd just started playing for Millwall and you think one day you are going to be up there.

"I'm here now and it's a great honour to be recognised by your fellow professionals," he added. "It's a great list of previous winners and it's one of those things you will look back on in years to come.

"It's the biggest personal award you can get in the game and it's something that you really cherish."

The former Tottenham, Nottingham Forest and Millwall forward maintains the recent tradition of players claiming the two most prestigious domestic player of the year awards, following Keane's double 12 months ago and David Ginola's PFA and football writers' accolades the year before.

Sheringham's 21 goals - all but six have come in the league - helped Sir Alex Ferguson's men to the Premiership title in record time.

Joining Sheringham and Keane in the PFA team of the year from the Old Trafford ranks were Brown, Fabien Barthez, Jaap Stam and Ryan Giggs.

However, there was no place for England captain David Beckham in the XI selected by his fellow professionals, with Gerrard and Patrick Vieira of Arsenal completing the midfield quartet.

Gerrard, who was handed his young players' trophy by England manager Sven-Goran Eriksson, said: "I was in contention for the award last year and I really wanted to win it this year. I'm pleased that I have because it was a very good shortlist and there are some very good young players around."

Taylor added: "I think he has had an outstanding season. I am sure every England supporter will keep their fingers crossed he remains injury-free."

PFA representative teams as picked by the players from each relevant division:

Premiership: Barthez (Man Utd), Carr (Tottenham), Silvinho (Arsenal), Stam (Man Utd), Brown (Man Utd), Keane (Man Utd), Giggs (Man Utd), Gerrard (Liverpool), Vieira (Arsenal), Henry (Arsenal), Sheringham (Man Utd).

First Division: Taylor (Fulham), Finnan (Fulham), Grainger (Birmingham), Coleman (Fulham), Berg (Blackburn), Clark (Fulham), Dunn (Blackburn), Duff (Blackburn), Davis (Fulham), Saha (Fulham), Jansen (Blackburn).

fields.bodyText: Manchester United striker Teddy Sheringham was named Footballer of the Year by his fellow professionals at a PFA dinner in London last night. United team-mate Roy Keane came second in the poll and Arsenal striker Thierry Henry was third. Liverpool midfielder Steven Gerrard claimed the Young Player of the Year award, with Joe Cole runner-up and Wes Brown third. Sheringham, who received his award from Sir Steve Redgrave at the Grosvenor House Hotel in London, described the award as the "biggest personal award you can get in the game". He said: "I first came to this dinner at 17 or 18 when I'd just started playing for Millwall and you think one day you are going to be up there. "I'm here now and it's a great honour to be recognised by your fellow professionals," he added. "It's a great list of previous winners and it's one of those things you will look back on in years to come. "It's the biggest personal award you can get in the game and it's something that you really cherish." The former Tottenham, Nottingham Forest and Millwall forward maintains the recent tradition of players claiming the two most prestigious domestic player of the year awards, following Keane's double 12 months ago and David Ginola's PFA and football writers' accolades the year before. Sheringham's 21 goals - all but six have come in the league - helped Sir Alex Ferguson's men to the Premiership title in record time. Joining Sheringham and Keane in the PFA team of the year from the Old Trafford ranks were Brown, Fabien Barthez, Jaap Stam and Ryan Giggs. However, there was no place for England captain David Beckham in the XI selected by his fellow professionals, with Gerrard and Patrick Vieira of Arsenal completing the midfield quartet. Gerrard, who was handed his young players' trophy by England manager Sven-Goran Eriksson, said: "I was in contention for the award last year and I really wanted to win it this year. I'm pleased that I have because it was a very good shortlist and there are some very good young players around." Taylor added: "I think he has had an outstanding season. webTitle: Douglas and Zeta-Jones team up for illusionist pic

fields.headline: Douglas and Zeta-Jones team up for illusionist pic
fields.trailText: Loved-up Hollywood couple Michael Douglas and Catherine Zeta-Jones are set to work together again and will employ other members of the Douglas clan on the new project
fields.body:
Loved-up Hollywood couple Michael Douglas and Catherine Zeta-Jones are set to work together again and will employ other members of the Douglas clan on the new project.

According to Variety, the couple, who appeared together in Steven Soderbergh's Traffic, have signed up to appear in Smoke and Mirrors, the tale of the 19th-century French illusionist Robert Houdin.

The pair are evidently determined to keep it in the family. Michael's brother, Joel, and Kevin Brodie, the brother of Joel's fiance, will be joint producers on the film and Catherine's brother, David Jones, has joined the project as co-producer.

It is also rumoured that Kirk Douglas will make a cameo appearance, playing a sultan.

Little else is known about the project and no casting details have been announced. The producers are reported to be scouting for locations in Morocco, Tunisia and Israel.

webTitle: PM sanctions lottery boost for minorities

fields.headline: PM sanctions lottery boost for minorities
fields.trailText: Tony Blair has sanctioned the preferential allocation of millions of pounds to ethnic minority projects bidding for lottery funds. The money will go towards a programme to end the social exclusion and deprivation of black communities.
fields.body:
Tony Blair has sanctioned the preferential allocation of millions of pounds to ethnic minority projects bidding for lottery funds. The money will go towards a programme to end the social exclusion and deprivation of black communities.

The groups likely to benefit from the switch in policy include an arts and music centre named after the late campaigning Labour MP Bernie Grant; a training centre for black architects named after the murdered teenager Stephen Lawrence; and a family project in one of the most deprived inner city areas in Leicester, in the constituency of Keith Vaz, the Foreign Office minister. The successful bids will be announced in the next two months.

The prime minister approved switching £20m of lottery money from the Lottery's New Opportunities Fund to the millennium commission, in order to fund big projects led by black and Asian groups. The move followed a Whitehall analysis which showed that only 2.3% of lottery money went to ethnic minority groups, although these groups make up 6% of the population.

Ministers have also invoked, for the first time, "positive discrimination" clauses in the 1998 Lottery Act, allowing the millennium commission to solicit applications from black projects, and to give them £623,000 of lottery funds with which to draw up their bids.

Until the law changed, the commission, and other lottery boards, was unable to solicit bids. It was also unable to give any lottery money to organisa tions to help them draw up the time-consuming and detailed proposals required to satisfy the funding criteria.

Details of the prime minister's initiative came to light in a confidential memorandum sent to Mr Blair by Chris Smith, the culture secretary, last April.

The memo sought Mr Blair's approval for special measures because,it said: "It has proved more difficult to support capital projects addressing ethnic minorities.

"Despite many government initiatives, the Afro-Caribbean community still faces significant deprivation and social exclusion which the lottery could, and should, do something to address. Particularly important would be some landmark projects to which these and other communities could look as a beacon of black aspiration and achievements."

Mr Smith went on to say that both he, as chairman of the millennium commission, and Mo Mowlam, the Cabinet Office minister who sits on the body, believed the commission was "uniquely well placed" to use the positive discrimination powers to help black groups.

Mike O'Connor, the commission's director, confirmed that, following Mr Smith's plea to the prime minister, the go-ahead had been given for the initiative, which has now attracted applications totalling almost double the amount of money available.

He said: "Because we have put our head above the parapet in funding ethnic minority groups, I expect we will face criticism since we won't able to grant all the applications."

fields.headline: Bland leaves before a flop
fields.standfirst: Christopher Bland's stint at the BBC has been widely praised, but under his chairmanship the broadcaster has missed some crucial tricks, says  Maggie Brown
fields.trailText: Christopher Bland's stint at the BBC has been widely praised, but under his chairmanship the broadcaster has missed some crucial tricks, says Maggie Brown.
fields.body:
The news of Sir Christopher Bland's post-election departure to BT first surfaced within the BBC last Monday when the corporation secretary was informed. So market-sensitive was the appointment that, as word of it spread by Wednesday night to about 100 shell-shocked people, the normally leaky BBC successfully kept it secret.

During Wednesday, as the governors prepared for their dinner ahead of the regular monthly meeting, members of the BBC's consultative councils - which offer feedback about its services - gathered from around the UK at Broadcasting House. All were unaware of the imminent news.

An executive who attended says: "Sir Christopher was anxious to introduce them to his relatively new vice-chairman, Gavyn Davies. He was saying, 'You need to know this man.' I thought it was like he was introducing his eventual successor. But none of us knew it might be so soon."

There is now concern that the move has happened too fast for Davies to stand a realistic chance of succeeding, despite being seen as the most distinguished of the potential candidates. The Goldman Sachs economist and multi-millionaire was only drafted in as vice-chairman in January, and has hardly begun the task of distancing himself from the taint of being a "Labour luvvie".

"It's two years too soon. He's still pretty green about what the BBC is about. But if Davies really wanted it, I'm sure he could go for it," says a key BBC insider, with (perhaps) more hope than realism.

Davies's claim is based on the 1999 panel report he produced into the future funding of the BBC. While it was critical of the broadcaster's commercial and self-help ventures (selling off a 49% stake in BBC Worldwide, he counselled), it also backed public service broadcasting as a crucial force for good. He informed the government that the BBC should be funded sufficiently to remain an unfettered public service broadcaster operating across a rapidly developing marketplace. That paved the way to the current generous licence fee settlement, rising 1.5% annually above inflation to 2006.

Although the initial coverage of Bland's departure has tended to praise his five-year chairmanship and his role as a "safe pair of hands", the truth is more mixed. There is much unfinished business. One current conundrum is what the BBC should say in its annual report, being finalised for publication in July. It will provide a judgment on Bland's record and Dyke's first stab at re-energising BBC1.

At best, the governors can argue that the foundations are at last in place for a revival through a diversion of funds into drama, entertainment and sport, while the move of news to 10pm has led to an increase in audiences.

Overall, BBC Television will argue that its audience share has remained remarkably robust, helped by the strong showing of BBC2 and the surprise success of The Weakest Link. Recently, Alan Yentob triumphantly faxed the front page of the New York Post, devoted to the US version, to the chairman.

Yet the chairman's abrasiveness has gone down badly with many in government, and Bland has missed some crucial tricks. The BBC remains in limbo over its raft of new digital TV and radio services, while commercial pressure over its sprawl onto the internet is intense. BBC Worldwide's strategy remains fundamentally unsettled, making it a business staffed by jumpy executives. The board of governors are having great difficulty working out what to do with it.

Further, the communications legislation, creating Ofcom, currently leaves the BBC and its governors as a separate entity. It seems like a Pyrrhic victory, with opponents winning the argument. This issue is bound to be revisited after the election.

And Bland also presided over the great Birtist coup of 1996, splitting the production and broadcast arms of the corporation - a move later judged to have landed the BBC in its current creative mess. In short, Bland is leaving before the problem-solving Dyke's "One BBC" mission either proves itself, or flops.

fields.headline: To bear witness
fields.standfirst: Marie Colvin was determined to reveal the human tragedy of war. She nearly died doing so. But, as the world remembers more than 50 journalists killed last year, she tells  Roy Greenslade  why she will be back
fields.trailText: Marie Colvin was determined to reveal the human tragedy of war. She nearly died doing so. But, as the world remembers more than 50 journalists killed last year, she tells Roy Greenslade why she will be back.
fields.body:
As the Sunday Times's brave war correspondent, Marie Colvin, rests before undergoing a delicate operation to save the sight of her left eye, it is sobering to reflect that this week also marks World Press Freedom Day.

It was inaugurated by the United Nations 10 years ago as a way of highlighting the risks taken by journalists struggling to exercise their freedom to tell the truth. Last year alone, more than 50 were killed across the globe and Colvin could so easily have added to the grim statistics recorded by the World Association of Newspapers (WAN).

She was, as she is the first to admit, lucky. Lucky to have survived so many conflicts. Lucky not to have died at the hands of Sri Lankan troops two weeks ago. Lucky to be able to fly away from so many countries which deny indigenous journalists the freedom to report.

Many of the people on WAN's list were murdered by enemies within their own countries, with Colombia and Russia having by far the worst body count. Colvin's case is somewhat different. She runs toward the sound of gunfire, putting her life on the line time after time in order, as she says with such sincerity it sounds nothing like a sanctimonious boast, "to bear witness."

Her trip to the Tamil enclave in the north of Sri Lanka in defiance of a government ban on visits by journalists was a classic example of her work. She aimed to speak to the Tamil Tigers' leadership to assess their political stance in the light of Norwegian-sponsored peace negotiations. But she also wanted to report on the humanitarian crisis in an area where 500,000 people - "civilians, all of them", she stresses - are living in cities turned to rubble, where aid agencies are barred from offering help, food and fuel are scarce and medicine is non-existent. It is a tribute to the Sunday Times, and a measure of its confidence in Colvin, that its editor John Witherow and foreign editor Sean Ryan backed her desire to go.

The conflict between the Singhalese and Tamils, in which 63,000 people have died since 1983, is one of the most under-reported of wars. No foreign reporter has managed to enter Tamil-held territory since the blockade began in 1995.

That Colvin got in was a testament to her determination and fitness: she walked 30 miles through jungle with her Tamil guides to slip past government lines. Ten days later, while trying to do the reverse journey, she ran into a government unit and, in the melee, got separated from the Tamil escort as she crawled into undergrowth.

"I was terrified," she admits, "more frightened than I've ever been before. This was a take-no-prisoners army. When I realised I was hit I didn't have any profound thoughts. I just kept thinking it was taking me an awfully long time to die." She then stood up and shouted "journalist, journalist", quickly realising that the troops she was facing were also "scared, hysterical and hyped-up".

Bleeding from injuries caused by grenade shrapnel to her left eye and chest, she was roughed up during her interrogation before receiving medical help, eventually reaching hospital in Colombo. From there, she was flown to New York via London, where her former husband, Daily Telegraph foreign correspondent Patrick Bishop, jumped aboard.

He was at her bedside when doctors confirmed what she had learned in Colombo: since the shrapnel entered the centre of her left eye, she will almost certainly be left, at best, with only peripheral vision. "I won't be blind-sided. It's not so bad," she says almost casually from the comfort of her mother's house in Long Island.

Colvin was born and raised in New York, and studied marine biology at Yale before switching to major in English literature while working on the university's paper and becoming hooked on journalism.

After a year on a trade paper, she was hired by the international news agency UPI, working in New York and Washington before heading up the Paris bureau - "a grand name for a one-woman band", she recalls - which included covering the Middle East. While there, she acted as a stringer for the Sunday Times and in 1986, when the paper lost its renowned middle east correspondent David Blundy to the Sunday Telegraph, Colvin took his job. She acknowledges the black irony that a couple of years later Blundy was killed by crossfire in San Salvador.

Colvin made a success of that post, reporting well from Libya - where she got to know Colonel Gadafy, though not as well as he would have liked - and from the Lebanon. It was her reporting from Beirut which led her inevitably down the path of becoming a war correspondent.

Since then she has covered conflicts in the Balkans, Chechnya and, memorably, East Timor, where she famously helped to save the lives of 1,500 women and children besieged in a compound by Indonesian troops. She refused to leave them, waving goodbye to 22 journalist colleagues to stay on with an unarmed UN force and help highlight their plight by reporting to the world, in her paper and on global TV. The publicity was rewarded when they were evacuated to safety after four tense days.

This is the essence of Colvin's approach to reporting. She isn't interested in the politics, the strategy, the weaponry, only the effects on the people she regards as innocents. "These are people who have no voice," she says. "I feel I have a moral responsibility towards them, that it would be cowardly to ignore them. If journalists have a chance to save their lives, they should do so."

People, clearly, have not forgotten Colvin's courage. At the end of her Sunday Times report about her Sri Lankan experience, she wrote: "What I want most, as soon as I get out of hospital, is a vodka martini and a cigarette." Later that week, having moved briefly to New York's St Regis hotel, she was woken by a room service waiter bearing a tray with a huge bottle of vodka and all the necessary ingredients for her drink of choice. She says: "It had been fixed, God knows how, by the East Timor crowd, the people in the compound."

It is the only moment I detect any emotion in Colvin's voice. After a moment she tells me that although she has stared death in the face it won't stop her returning to the front line if the occasion demands.

That's why Thursday, World Press Freedom Day, is so important. It reminds us that journalism, proper journalism, Colvin's journalism, is still worth fighting for, even in a country where celebrity trivia dominates too many news pages.

fields.headline: Dinosaurs and digital don't mix
fields.trailText: The hills were alive with media metaphors last week, when ONdigital, the baffling digital terrestrial broadcaster, shed its unique brand and became ITV Digital, while its chief executive, Stuart Prebble, was elevated to chief executive of the whole of ITV.
fields.body:
The hills were alive with media metaphors last week, when ONdigital, the baffling digital terrestrial broadcaster, shed its unique brand and became ITV Digital, while its chief executive, Stuart Prebble, was elevated to chief executive of the whole of ITV.

"This is the biggest shifting of goalposts since they shut down Wembley Stadium," barked one media wag on the rebranding exercise, while a more catty executive was unflattering about the appointment of a new ITV CEO, chortling: "Stuart Prebble is to the future of television what Sir Christopher Bland is to the future of telecommunications."

The sudden demise of the ONdigital brand comes as no surprise to anyone. A quick glance in the rearview mirror on the information superhighway revealed that it was struggling to sell a technology that the audience did not understand, or want in sufficient numbers.

The creation of the typographically unsatisfactory digital terrestrial package was a product of the unhappy circumstances that prevented it from being able to say exactly what it was. As the digital offering of ITV's key players Carlton and Granada, internal politics meant it was unable to use the ITV brand. But as they are now effectively ITV's only players, they can do what they like with the brand.

Only Prebble's elevation came as a surprise. When handed the ONdigital job two years ago, the general opinion was that he was was a safe pair of Granada hands from a bygone era of broadcasting. Now he is in charge of the whole shooting match.

But returning to the mountain of metaphors, is the ONdigital's rebranding merely a case of putting lipstick on a dinosaur? One can only assume that the sensible shifting to ITV Digital marks the beginning of a more profound and timely discussion about its position as a platform rather than a programme provider. We have, since the advent of multi-channel television, had more platforms than Noddy Holder. First there was cable, but not so that anyone other than a tree surgeon would notice, then there was BSB and Sky, which cleverly spotted that there was only enough room in the market for one player and became BSkyB.

Then after a hiatus of 10 years we had Sky Digital, ONdigital and limping along in third, digital cable. ONdigital's insistence that there was a market in the middle of middle England for those who were a) dish phobic and b) only wanted 30 channels rather than 300 now looks daft. With its own figures around 1m and Barb's March total for ONdigital viewers at 700,000, it is clear that demand for an analogue offering at a digital price is still limited.

The problem has always been that though people who buy into multi-channel TV may watch only 10 channels, unless they have the full 300 they feel under-equipped.

Break-even has been pushed back once again, and is now stuck at an unimpressive target of 1.7m subscribers within the next two years. With a churn rate (polite parlance for "cancel my subscription") of 22% compared to Sky Digital's 9.8% one can imagine a situation where ITV Digital will have to run at full speed just to stand still.

What we do know is that ITV has already committed to running its services on digital satellite, but whether it allows Sky subscribers the full smorgasbord of its digital delights has yet to be decided.

One hopes that this is the beginning of a strategy that abandons the notion of holding viewers to ransom with premium content (in ONdigital's case, Champions League fixtures) to get them to take on a platform the market is clearly moving against.

But beyond that, the episode raises serious questions about the direction of a single ITV under a Granada ownership. While Charles Allen's transformation from catering king to media mogul has been widely welcomed, his two key TV staff - Granada chief executive Steve Morrison and Stuart Prebble - are not exactly new bloods. This might not be a problem, but the fractious City contingent is keen on rating media companies on strategic strength and management depth. Therefore it might be a little dismayed that the "dream team" is so doggedly old ITV.

Much of inspired media management is about implementing the bleeding obvious as rapidly as possible, and it has taken ONdigital three years to get to the point of rebranding itself in an inviting way. If it takes ITV Digital another three years to realise that it is going to lose a multi-channel war with Sky, then it will need something more than a name change to revitalise its prospects.

fields.headline: And then there was one
fields.trailText: 11.30am: Ajaz Ahmed and Rob Wilmot, half of the founding "Freeserve Four", are to leave the company. By Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Two of the founder members of internet company Freeserve are to leave the company.

Ajaz Ahmed and Rob Wilmot, half of the "Freeserve Four", said today they were setting up their own business to develop internet projects.

The term "Freeserve Four" was coined by the former general manager, Mark Danby - himself one of the four - who recently left to manage a Royal Bank of Scotland investment fund.

The only remaining founder is John Pluthero, now by far the best known. But in the early days of the company Mr Danby and Mr Ahmed were the highest profile, with Mr Pluthero taking a back seat.

As the company grew and became more corporate, the founders were pushed into roles further away from the centre of Freeserve's decision-making process, with Mr Ahmed becoming business development director and Mr Wilmot director of research and development.

The two are thought to have become increasingly frustrated with their roles at Freeserve.

Mr Ahmed, the Dixons shop manager who came up with the idea for Freeserve and took it to Dixons bosses, was last year told he was no longer allowed to be a spokesman for the company and had to refer all press calls.

"With Wanadoo, Freeserve has entered an exciting new phase of its development, and Rob and I are both proud of the role we have played in its rapid progress, from start-up to becoming part of one of Europe's leading online media & service groups," said Mr Ahmed.

Freeserve said it will not be replacing Mr Ahmed and Mr Wilmot.

fields.standfirst: Today's rumours just can't work out why the Daily Express suddenly has so many celebrity photos in it
fields.trailText: Roy Keane could be on his way to Celtic in the summer in a £15m deal, reports the Mirror. The Manchester United captain was spotted at Ibrox yesterday watching his childhood heroes turn Rangers over 3-0, "fuelling speculation" of a move. Martin O'Neill has asked to be kept informed of Keane's increasingly uneasy relationship with the English champions.
fields.body:
Roy Keane could be on his way to Celtic in the summer in a £15m deal, reports the Mirror. The Manchester United captain was spotted at Ibrox yesterday watching his childhood heroes turn Rangers over 3-0, "fuelling speculation" of a move. Martin O'Neill has asked to be kept informed of Keane's increasingly uneasy relationship with the English champions.

Not that Manchester United are letting go easily. They're planning to offer Keane an £18m deal to tie him to Old Trafford for the rest of his career, according to the Sun.

Gareth Southgate's desire to leave Aston Villa may be sated by a £5m transfer to Fulham.

Birmingham will offer Darren Purse a new contract in the hope of warding off interest from Arsenal, who are preparing a £5m bid.

West Ham manager Harry Redknapp will allow Paolo Di Canio to leave Upton Park if he gets a £5m offer in the close season, according to the Mirror.

fields.headline: Big Ron's chalkboard
fields.trailText: The goal Gary McAllister scored to seal Liverpool's 2-0 win at Coventry on Saturday was a classic example of why I believe teams should defend direct free-kicks with a man on the line.
fields.body:
The goal Gary McAllister scored to seal Liverpool's 2-0 win at Coventry on Saturday was a classic example of why I believe teams should defend direct free-kicks with a man on the line.

If there is nobody protecting the post behind the wall, the goalkeeper will inevitably shift his weight on to his right foot because he realises there's a big gap on that side and knows most free-kick takers will look to curl the ball over the wall into the vacant space.

Coventry's Chris Kirkland did precisely that on Saturday making it more difficult for him to adjust and save McAllister's free-kick into the opposite corner. Obviously he can't stand in a more central position because that would leave him no sighting of the ball behind the wall.

If Coventry had put Barry Quinn on the line I don't think McAllister would have scored. In my last 10 years in management I never conceded a goal direct from a free-kick with a man on the post.

The advantage is that the keeper doesn't have to worry too much about anything that's curling that way and can initially concentrate on the other side. Free-kick takers tend to curl the ball rather than rocket it over the wall, so a tall player on the line can deal with it using his head.

I know people will argue there are down sides. Having a man on the line allows opponents to push up, knowing they can't be offside, and they may even try to stand directly in front of the keeper. But I feel it is best to eliminate the first problem first and then deal with the second.

To combat the possible difficulties, I asked the man on the line to creep back rather than rushing back in an obvious way.

When someone stood in front of the keeper I would tell a defender to mark in front of him so the free-kick taker can't just flip the ball on to his head.

The defender is then favourite to head away, and that 10-year run without conceding from free-kicks shows the idea must be worthwhile.

webTitle: Foot and mouth in the media

fields.headline: Day 70: foot and mouth in the media
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk keeps you informed with a daily briefing on the press coverage of foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText:
Day 70: With the crisis now in its 70th day, foot and mouth fatigue is setting in among journalists on the nationals.
Special report: foot and mouth in the media
fields.body:
With the crisis now in its 70th day, foot and mouth fatigue is setting in among journalists on the nationals. This, combined with the Tory race row, Nelson Mandela's appearance in Trafalgar Square and the expected confession from Martin McGuiness of his role in Bloody Sunday, pushed foot and mouth off the front pages of all the national papers.

The Independent
The paper continues its investigations into the source of the virus. It carries the first interview with a Maff vet, who voices his belief the disease was present in sheep before it broke out officially at a pig farm at Heddon-on-the-Wall in Northumberland.

The Daily Telegraph
The Telegraph continues to claim to be the voice of the countryside, focusing on the impact of the crisis on country people by publishing the diary of a farmer's wife. Sally Leaney voices her concerns about the government's plan to shift the emphasis for farmers away from the role of "food producer" and towards "keeper of the countryside". She claims the strategy is unrealistic.

The Wall Street Journal Europe
The paper investigates the related issue of mad cow disease. A front page story reports on a patents row that has broken out following the discovery of a "breakthrough" in identifying the disease.

The Sun
The paper counters the Mirror's Phoenix the calf PR victory. The Sun supplies cake and champagne to the owners of Porky, the 18-stone Vietnamese pot-bellied pig that was saved from the slaughterhouse the 11th hour. Surprisingly, all the tabloids missed a golden opportunity to use a picture of the former "sex bomb", Brigitte Bardot, whose actions were instrumental in saving Porky.

webTitle: Lee to star in new C4 show

fields.headline: Lee stars in C4's answer to Room 101
fields.trailText: 11am: Iain Lee, former host of the Eleven O'Clock Show, which spawned Ali G, is being lined up for his own series. By Lisa O'Carroll.
fields.body:
Iain Lee, former host of the Eleven O'Clock Show - the programme that spawned spoof interviewer Ali G - is being lined up for his own series.

The First TV Show is being billed as Channel 4's answer to Paul Merton's BBC2 hit, Room 101.

Guests will be asked to talk about the first milestones in their lives, such as their first crush, their first kiss, and their first record.

Sacha Baron-Cohen, the performer behind Ali G, is also poised for a comeback with a cast of new characters including a spoof camp German TV host.

He will not be back on British TV screens for some time, however, as he is concentrating on his Ali G movie.

The third star of the Eleven O'Clock Show, Daisy Donovan, famous for duping politicians into answering outrageous questions about sex and drugs, is also getting a new series - a panel show with the working title Daisy Daisy.

The programme has been likened to Small Talk, the TV show presented by Ronnie Corbett in which competitors were asked to guess pre-recorded answers given by children.

fields.headline: Britons are dunces on Europe
fields.standfirst:
Britons face a referendum on the euro after the election, but they know less about the single currency than the citizens of any other EU member state, writes Ian Black

Special report: European integration
Special report: economic and monetary union
fields.trailText: In the latest Eurobarometer poll Britain comes bottom of the class in virtually every single category of knowledge about, attachment to and trust in Europe.
fields.body:
In the latest Eurobarometer poll Britain comes bottom of the class in virtually every single category of knowledge about, attachment to and trust in Europe.

It is also the country where people are least proud of being European and where the loss of national identity is a prime fear. Others worry more about drugs, crime, unemployment and adapting to the euro.

The average number of Britons expressing trust in all EU institutions was just 17%, lower than the EU average and even the next lowest, sceptical Sweden (35%).

Britons know less than anyone else about the EU while displaying a curiously paradoxical view: although concerned about the "power of Brussels" they also dismiss the importance of European institutions.

Only 35% of Britons thought EU bodies important, while 70% of Swedes did. And Britons do want to know more, but there is less support than in any other country for teaching children about the EU.

Support for the single currency is another EU low of 21%. But it is the ignorance about it that is probably the most worrying for the government: 73% of Britons have received no information about the single currency at all. In Denmark, which rejected the euro in last autumn's referendum, 100% had received information.

Fifty-seven per cent of Britons expressed little or no interest in the euro. Britons are also the least likely to have even heard of the European Central Bank in Frankfurt.
