fields.headline: Rich EU citizens oppose enlargement
fields.standfirst:
Poll shows people fear cost of bringing in outside states will weigh down Europe

Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: More than a third of European Union citizens oppose the forthcoming enlargement of the union. Half the Frenchmen and Austrians and 43% of Germans are against it in principle, according to a poll by Eurobarometer, an arm of the European Commission.
fields.body:
More than a third of European Union citizens oppose the forthcoming enlargement of the union. Half the Frenchmen and Austrians and 43% of Germans are against it in principle, according to a poll by Eurobarometer, an arm of the European Commission.

The figures paint a picture of apathy and hostility to the EU's single most important current challenge at a time when the 15 member states are haggling over the terms, dates, and money involved.

Candidate countries are already complaining of slow-moving negotiations, shifting goalposts and tough conditions, and the findings will increase the resentment in Warsaw, Budapest and elsewhere, and boost the fear of a backlash against Brussels.

Eurobarometer's biennial attitude survey finds that only 34% of those questioned favour giving the 13 applicant countries membership, compared to 38% a year ago. Only 26% see enlargement as a priority.

Poland, Hungary, the Czech Republic, Estonia, Slovenia, Cyprus and Malta are the leading candidates. Bulgaria, Romania, Slovakia, Latvia and Lithuania are moving more slowly towards meeting the tough political, economic and legal criteria. Turkey has yet to start talks.

EU enlargement is lauded as a means of eradicating cold war divisions and creating the world's biggest single market, with half a billion consumers. Opposition to it is based on self-interest, Eurobarometer shows: half the EU's citizens believe that enlargement will cost their own country more money, and 40% that it will increase unemployment rates.

Spain, which always fights doggedly for the funds it receives from the EU, has just signalled an attempt to keep them at their current level, despite the candidate countries' expectation that they too will be financially supported.

Extending the common agricultural policy, which accounts for almost half the £54bn budget, is a huge difficulty. Fear of being swamped by cheap labour from the east is cited as the reason why Austrians and Germans oppose the admission of neighbouring Poland and the Czech Republic in 2004 or 2005.

This month the commission proposed that the free movement of labour from new members to existing ones should be restricted for up to seven years after they join, reflecting the position of the German chancellor, Gerhard Schröder.

Analysts point out, however, that migratory flows are likely to be limited, as they were when Spain and Portugal joined in 1986.

The French, though geographically far from the borders of the eastern applicants, are the most opposed to enlargement: only 22% support it. In Sweden, the most enthusiastic, 51% are in favour. Ominously, 60% of Frenchmen oppose membership for Slovenia, the former Yugoslav republic, which is probably closest to fulfilling the membership conditions.

Hubert Védrine, the French foreign minister, plans to visit all the candidates in the coming months to answer those who blame Paris for failing to make progress during its EU presidency last year.

Sweden, the current president, is pushing hard for progress to be made by the time the Gothenburg summit is held in June. Britons are keenest on membership for English-speaking Cyprus and Malta. But Tony Blair, who describes himself as an "unashamed champion" of enlargement, should note that only 31% of Britons back the process, 36% are against, and 33% "don't know".'

The countries EU citizens would most like to join are wealthy Switzerland and Norway, neither of which has applied. Opposition is strongest in the case of Turkey (48%), the only applicant not to have begun talks, and Romania, 45%.

Support is even lower for membership for Yugoslavia, Bosnia, Croatia and Macedonia, which are not candidates, though the last two have special "association agreements" with Brussels.

In other areas the survey shows that EU citizens' greatest fear is the loss of jobs to countries with lower production costs.

Eight months before the 12 eurozone countries change over to euro notes and coins, 58% fear the loss of their national currency. Eurobarometer shows that Italians are the most enthusiastic supporters of EU decision-making and Britain and Sweden the least.

Seventy-three per cent of citizens favour a common defence policy. Belgians are the keenest (84%). The majority of Finns and Danes are opposed, but a surprising 51% of Britons are in favour.

This month the commission proposed that the free movement of labour from new members to existing ones should be restricted for up to seven years after they join, reflecting the position of the German chancellor, Gerhard Schröder. Analysts point out, however, that migratory flows are likely to be limited, as they were when Spain and Portugal joined in 1986. The French, though geographically far from the borders of the eastern applicants, are the most opposed to enlargement: only 22% support it. In Sweden, the most enthusiastic, 51% are in favour. Ominously, 60% of Frenchmen oppose membership for Slovenia, the former Yugoslav republic, which is probably closest to fulfilling the membership conditions. Hubert Védrine, the French foreign minister, plans to visit all the candidates in the coming months to answer those who blame Paris for failing to make progress during its EU presidency last year. Sweden, the current president, is pushing hard for progress to be made by the time the Gothenburg summit is held in June. Britons are keenest on membership for English-speaking Cyprus and Malta. fields.headline: Will gas become another Railtrack?
fields.standfirst: Labour crisis and doubts about maintenance have cast a cloud over an industry once seen as a privatisation success story
fields.trailText: Labour crisis and doubts about maintenance have cast a cloud over an industry once seen as a privatisation success story.
fields.body:
Just before Christmas 1999, Andrew and Janette Findlay and their two children, Stacey, 13, and Daryl, 11, were killed when their new bungalow in Larkhall, Lanarkshire, was blown to pieces by a huge gas explosion.

The metal gas main near their house had corroded, causing a leak. A spark from a light being switched on or the boiler starting probably caused the blast.

When engineers dug up the pipe they reportedly found 19 holes in it. The old system of "trigger surveys", to check on mains after snaps of cold weather, had been abandoned by Transco, the privatised monopoly responsible for the gas pipe network. New safety procedures, approved by the health and safety executive (HSE), had been introduced instead.

A Transco employee has also said that the company did not have proper records. Engineers called to the area thought new plastic mains had been laid when in fact the old ductile iron mains which suffer from corrosion and can fail suddenly were still in place.

In October last year there were more angry relatives and neighbours demanding answers. An elderly couple, William and Mary Bailey, died from burns after a gas explosion ripped through their home in Dundee. Transco had been called to the area four times in the previous 18 months to investigate suspected leaks.

In September the HSE passed a report on its Larkhall investigation to the Crown Office, which is expected to decide shortly whether charges should be brought against Transco for culpable homicide or criminal negligence. If it decides not to prosecute there will be a fatal accident inquiry.

In Scotland, Larkhall and Dundee are known as the gas industry's Hatfield. South of the border the full implications have yet to sink in. But with other parallels with Railtrack emerging, alarm bells are ringing. Transco says it has fulfilledits safety obligations. It has been considered a well run company, but the question that won't go away is: how do you ensure the safety of an essential service when the owner of the assets is a privatised monopoly with a duty to maximise profits?

The much-hyped privatisation of the British Gas Corporation took place in 1986, and was an early Thatcher triumph, with thousands of people rushing to buy shares. In 1996 Britain became the first country in the world to deregulate its energy market when it began to open up the supply of gas to competition.

Offshore producers take gas, mostly from the North sea, and land it around the coast. More than 50 shippers and suppliers now compete to sell it to domestic and commercial customers.

In 1997 British Gas was split up. A new company, Centrica, now handles accounts and billing, although it still trades under the name British Gas. BG plc was left with offshore exploration and Transco, the privatised monopoly which operates and maintains the pipe network transporting gas from the coast to the meter, and runs the 24 hour gas emergency service.

Last year Transco was hived off into the Lattice group. The Lattice group has been under pressure, with share prices falling, and has built up huge debts trying to move into telecoms. Transco's debt book is the largest of any British utility after BT.

Transco is restructuring again, splitting its assets (the pipes) from its operations (maintenance and emergency work). These will be further divided into up to 20 units and could be sold off. Industry insiders fear this will "create another Railtrack".

Deregulation was meant to cut gas bills and, at first sight, five years on it has. Although only 6m out of 20m customers have changed their suppliers, British Gas estimates domestic users have seen their total bills reduced by around £1bn a year.

The figures suggest a business success too. British Gas profits in 1985 immediately before privatisation were £712m, and soared to £1.06bn in 1987. Transco, whose transportation costs account for 40% of domestic gas bills, reported an operating profit pre-deregulation in 1995 of £780m, and a post-deregulation peak in 1998 of £1.22bn.

The picture this year is more troubling. As a privatised monopoly Transco is regulated by Ofgem (the office of gas and electricity markets), which sets price controls. But Ofgem cannot make Transco invest, and Transco underspent on capital expenditure by 23% in 1997 and by 19% in 1998. Now Transco has said it will need to increase spending on mains replacement work by more than 50% over the next three years. To do so it wants to set higher prices.

Ofgem has seen its role as a driver of competition. In theory greater competition forces down prices while giving incentives to maintain standards. But utility experts fear there is an inherent conflict. The danger is that if prices are set a company could increase shareholder value only by outwitting the regulator on its costs or spending less later. Only now, five years after deregulation, is Ofgem proposing to introduce medium and long term performance reports to check trends on leakage, pipework replacement and forecasts on future capacity.

As with other utilities, the constant hiving off of companies enables the group to realise shareholder value. Bits of the company that are most profitable can be sold off. Foreign utility giants would be keen to get their hands on the assets. They can get a guaranteed return, and if they chose not to invest but just to fix problems then sell on in time, who is to catch up with them?

The constant restructuring presents particular difficulties to the safety regulator, the HSE. A spokesman said: "Every time I blink, something seems to have changed its logo, but whatever happens somebody somewhere will end up with the responsibilities that used to be Transco's."

Transco has pleaded for a different approach. "Economic regulation has been dominant," it says in submissions to Ofgem. "Structural changes to promote competition have been encouraged, so far with little consideration of the potential trade-offs against operational integrity and safety. In future a different view may be appropriate, which broadens the focus to a wider definition of customer value - a balance of economic efficiency, reliability, safety and environmental benefits."

Meanwhile, wholesale gas prices have doubled this year. Much of this has been blamed on rising oil prices but other factors are at work. Shippers say a new auction system set up by Ofgem and operated by Transco is inflating prices.

Mergers of major producers have created a concentration of power offshore and the European commission is investigating allegations that producers have manipulated prices. A new pipe between Norfolk and Zeebrugge in Belgium connects Britain to the European gas network. Companies using the pipe vote on the day which way gas should flow. In January, when demand in the UK was high, they voted to export to Europe. UK prices rose by 42%. The Energy Intensive Users Group estimates the recent price rise has cost schools, local authorities, the NHS and commercial users £1bn. And this month suppliers increased domestic gas prices between 5% and 7%.

Related stories
'It takes a bang for people to sit up and listen'

fields.headline: Two tribes go to war
fields.standfirst: The protesters at tomorrow's May Day demos will fall into two distinct - and none too friendly - camps. But how to tell the spikies and the fluffies apart?  Oliver Burkeman offers a guide
fields.trailText: The spikies Manifesto
fields.body:
The spikies Manifesto

Capitalism perpetrates violence, so violence against property and persons is perfectly justifiable in the cause of anti-capitalism. A few more festivals of broken glass in central London and the entire capitalist machine will grind swiftly to a halt, to be replaced with, um, can we get back to you on that one?

How to spot them

Balaclavas to prevent identification by the police - a cunning distraction, say the fluffies, many of whom reckon they are state-planted agents provocateur in any case.

Favoured tactics

Gutting the Gap, smashing Starbucks, mangling McDonald's. "Their aim is violence against police officers," said one police officer; nevertheless, they are arguably less confusing to the police since they presumably have some ringleaders (Osama bin Laden? Phil Mitchell?) - unlike the fluffies.

Classic campaign

The Battle of Seattle, when a mob of violent protesters looted shops and clashed with riot police.

Key accessory

The brick.

Historical antecedents

Violent ideologues from crusaders to Eta.

Names they go by

Anarchist Federation, Urban Alliance.

Spikies on fluffies

"Sad to see the idiots . . . standing in front of the lines of tooled-up riot cops shouting 'No, no, don't throw things, we're here to party' - a 1997 leaflet released by the spiky-led "Hungry Brigade".

Embarrassing media figurehead

Matthew MacDonald, an Eton schoolboy whose efforts to bring down the Establishment from the inside were cut swiftly short when he was arrested for hurling a chair through the window of a central London branch of the multinational McDonald's.

The fluffies

Manifesto

You can't fight violence with violence: non-violent direct action is the only way to confront an inherently violent economic system.

How to spot them

Unmasked faces, whistles on ribbons, bright costumes, distressing facial hair.

Favoured tactics

Guerrilla gardening, street parties; fire-breathing, marching into police lines with battering rams made of foam - a particular favourite of the White Overall Movement Building Liberation Through Effective Struggle, or Wombles. Also: spending too much valuable anti-capitalist campaigning time coming up with comedy acronyms.

Classic campaign

Operation Dessert Storm, deploying custard pies in the service of anarchy. "What better way to draw attention to the often faceless leaders of the corporate world, shameful 'jour nalists', dodgy politicians and anyone who deserves a full face of dissent? The 'global movement' is often misrepresented in the mainstream media. You can't misrepresent a face full of cream."

Key accessory

Penny whistle.

Historical antecedents

Non-violent direct action from Mahatma Gandhi to the hippies to Ya Basta!, the Italian non-violent support group for the Zapatistas who pioneered the dastardly "foam battering ram" method.

Names they go by

Reclaim the Streets, Mayday Collective.

Spikies on fluffies

"The fluffy-spiky debate has become a cliche, and is filed under The Great Unmentionables, along with Swampy - [but] if we use violence, we give the vested interests something more interesting to talk about. They get away with carrying on, and usually with a lot more support" - fluffy campaigner.

Embarrassing media figurehead

Swampy, the tree-dwelling hero of Newbury bypass action.

Related article
Organised chaos

fields.headline: Kubrick's strange afterlife
fields.standfirst: Steven Spielberg's new film A.I. has been shrouded in secrecy, but someone is leaving a bizarre trail of mysterious clues on the internet. Stanley Kubrick is just one suspect, says Paul Trueman
fields.trailText: Steven Spielberg's new film A.I. has been shrouded in secrecy, but someone is leaving a bizarre trail of mysterious clues on the internet. Stanley Kubrick is just one suspect, says Paul Trueman
fields.body:
April 10 saw the second teaser trailer for the film A.I. go up on the official site (http://aimovie.warnerbros.com/). A.I. (Artificial Intelligence) is the film that Stanley Kubrick was to make after Eyes Wide Shut, but when the auteur died in 1999, Steven Spielberg took over the reins. Other than casting details, the production has been shrouded in secrecy.

The internet-only trailer is a suitably oblique introduction to the themes of the film - there is no mention of plot or characters, no cheesy "starring Academy Award nominee Haley Joel Osment" voiceover, just a series of beautiful frosted images. Or so it was thought. Later the same day, someone calling themself "ClaviusBase" emailed film journalist Harry Knowles at http://www.aintitcoolnews.com. The email pointed out that something very strange was going on with the trailer, something that had never been attempted before - the filmmakers had placed two coded messages at the end of it.

ClaviusBase had noticed that on the credits at its end, Jeanine Salla is listed as a "Sentient Machine Therapist" alongside the usual names of producers and writers. "Type her name in the Google.com search engine and see what sites pop up," Knowles was told in the email. Salla, it turns out, has her own home page, http://www.jeaninesalla.com, where she talks about her work with artificial intelligence, and her friendship with someone called Evan Chan. There's only one problem - the life she describes is set a few centuries in the future and wholly fictional.

The trailer's second clue came in the form of the notches in the type that spells out "Summer 2001" in the promo's last frame. If you count the notches on each letter you get a series of numbers, 5033215122 - a US phone number. Ring it (adding the US code 001) and you hear a decidedly creepy answer machine message that talks of "a forest that teems with life... full of grass and trees, and databanks and drowned apartment buildings filled with fish", and it points you to the Salla website, seemingly the start of the "game".

Salla's site mentions that her friend Evan Chan has recently died in an accident on his "intelligent" yacht Cloudmaker, and there is a link to his site (http://www.familychan.org). And so it begins, leading you through dozens and dozens of sites, all different, all superbly designed, all completely fake - but none of them so much as mentions the film A.I. or even acknowledges a world outside the 22nd century, other than to refer to "the warming" that took place 100 years earlier, drowning millions.

Intrigued? Thousands of internet- users and film fans were, and the hunt was immediately on to discover what the hell was going on. How and why had Spielberg, the undisputed king of mainstream cinema, created this huge, bizarre fake world to accompany his latest film, without anyone finding out? What would be the response from Dreamworks and the film's distributor Warner Bros? "It's a complete blackout," Knowles told me in an email. "Both Warner and Dreamworks are saying, 'No comment'... It's the smartest thing they could say." I rang McDonald & Rutter, the PR agency handling A.I. in the UK. After saying they needed to check the official line, I received a call firmly telling me "No comment".

Faced with this silence, the internet community has mobilised to solve the mystery. Websites and chat forums following the trail have sprung up overnight, and are obviously being dissected with glee by whoever is behind it. One such fan site, http://www.for-evan.com, has even been referred to in a new entry on Salla's site - the ultimate accolade. "The Trail" website (http://www-stu.cai.cam.ac.uk/~dyh21/trail/trail.html) is one of the most popular, receiving thousands of hits a day, and is run by six "Cloudmakers" (the name of Evan's boat - pay attention at the back), all under the age of 25, from the UK and the US. There is discussion day and night of "the trail" on the site's chat groups, and a guide through the labyrinth of sites in case you get "lost" while playing the game.

"What I find admirable is that this campaign has been conducted in a remarkably advertising-free manner," says Dan Hon, Cloudmaker and final year law student at Cambridge. "There are no references, as such, to the film, and no messages being pushed down our throats to say, 'Hey, go watch this new Spielberg movie that's coming out.'" So do the Cloudmakers and their users - the campaign's target audience - think it will work in getting people to see the film?

"The game appears to be appealing only to a small section of the demographic," reckons Dan's brother Adrian. "However, I think we have to bear in mind that most people playing the game right now are early adopters. Perhaps when news becomes more widespread, we'll be seeing a greater variety of people getting involved."

Who wants to be a bean-counter worrying about cost-effectiveness when faced with a campaign so wonderfully off-beam? Hollywood. "This is a campaign that other studios are watching like a hawk," says Knowles. "I've talked with a couple of other heads of internet PR for a pair of studios and both of them are absolutely in love with the campaign, and dying to find out who is behind it." Such is the seeming reality of the world created by the promo that plenty of trail-followers have suggested the guiding hand of Kubrick - that the pre-production work he left behind for A.I. may have detailed such a campaign.

There is also the matter of the initial email to Knowles's site sent by ClaviusBase, which began the whole thing - and was presumably leaked on purpose. Clavius Base, as Kubrick fans will know, was the moon base in 2001, from where the black monolith sent the first signal to Jupiter. Kubrick was famous for his instinctive ability to market a film, and he would almost certainly have left behind plenty of ideas for A.I. Such were the gaps between the legendary director's films that we never got the chance to see what he might have done with the internet at his disposal. Until now, perhaps.

"However, I think we have to bear in mind that most people playing the game right now are early adopters. Perhaps when news becomes more widespread, we'll be seeing a greater variety of people getting involved." Who wants to be a bean-counter worrying about cost-effectiveness when faced with a campaign so wonderfully off-beam? Hollywood. "This is a campaign that other studios are watching like a hawk," says Knowles. "I've talked with a couple of other heads of internet PR for a pair of studios and both of them are absolutely in love with the campaign, and dying to find out who is behind it." Such is the seeming reality of the world created by the promo that plenty of trail-followers have suggested the guiding hand of Kubrick - that the pre-production work he left behind for A.I. may have detailed such a campaign. There is also the matter of the initial email to Knowles's site sent by ClaviusBase, which began the whole thing - and was presumably leaked on purpose. Clavius Base, as Kubrick fans will know, was the moon base in 2001, from where the black monolith sent the first signal to Jupiter. Kubrick was famous for his instinctive ability to market a film, and he would almost certainly have left behind plenty of ideas for A.I. Such were the gaps between the legendary director's films that we never got the chance to see what he might have done with the internet at his disposal. Until now, perhaps.

fields.headline: Australia ignores global warming threat
fields.standfirst: Despite its reliance on tourism and agriculture, Australia is one of the world's worst polluters and supported the US dismantling of Kyoto, writes Patrick Barkham
fields.trailText: Despite its reliance on tourism and agriculture, Australia is one of the world's worst polluters and supported the US dismantling of Kyoto, writes Patrick Barkham.
fields.body:
Australia's economy depends on the health of its large agricultural industry, which in turn is precariously reliant on the country's hostile, semi-arid climate not serving up droughts and floods.

It boasts the largest living organism in the world, the Great Barrier Reef, which brings the country $A1bn (£360m) a year from tourism, and which will die if sea temperatures rise by a couple of degrees. The reef is already "bleaching", turning white and dying, in several spots.

So the fact that Australia is the highest per capita emitter of greenhouse gases in the world appears particularly reckless, as does the Australian government's tacit support for George Bush's dismantling of the Kyoto treaty on global warming.

Agriculture minister Warren Truss crowed that the US had "done the world a favour" when it signalled that it would not sign the Kyoto treaty. The official government line on Kyoto has painted itself in softer, more pragmatic hues. The minister for the environment, Robert Hill, said that he would prefer the US to support Kyoto, but has made it clear that Australia will not back a treaty the Americans do not sign up to.

"I don't think you can have a consensus agreement to address global warming if you're not including the party that makes up 25% of global emissions," Mr Hill said in a meeting in New York last week, where he was hailed as virtually America's only remaining ally in the world on the issue.

Australia is waiting for the US government to finish its review of climate change policy - due in about five weeks - before it commits itself more clearly to the anti-Kyoto camp. But in reality, it is far closer to the US position than it is in understanding the outraged sentiments of most European ministers. The Australian government shares Bush's scepticism about the science of global warming, his suspicion of the treaty's adverse effect on industry, and desire to bind developing countries to any emission control agreement as well.

In the short term at least, the Australian government probably believes it has nothing to lose. If a form of Kyoto goes ahead it is sitting pretty. It got one of the best deals out of the original Kyoto treaty, which allowed it to increase its emissions by 8% from 1990 levels by 2008-2012 (although figures released earlier this month revealed that Australia's greenhouse gas emissions were 17.4% above 1990 levels in 1999). An entirely new international agreement on climate change, which enjoyed US support, would in all probability be more generous in its permission for Australia to carry on polluting.

In the long term Australia might have rather more to lose. As well as devastating the nation's agricultural sector - much of it currently farming on fairly marginal arid land - much native flora and fauna will disappear as the world warms up.

Last week, a study found that Australia's alpine region is threatened by global warming, with the treeline at Victoria's Mount Hotham moving 40m further uphill in the past 25 years.

The signs of Australia's careless attitude towards its greenhouse gas emissions are everywhere. Land-clearing, which leads to the mass burning of "waste" vegetation and the wood-chipping of logs for fires - remarkably classed as renewable energy in recent government legislation - continues at unsustainable levels.

Australia is the sixth highest clearer of native forest in the world. Only developing countries, such as Brazil, are ahead. States with anti-clearing legislation, such as New South Wales, have yet to seriously crack down on illegal felling.

Despite the huge capacity for the development of solar and wind energy offered by its climate, the country continues to lean on traditional sources of energy, such as coal. It has a passion for large, petrol-guzzling cars and cheap fuel matched only by America.

The chairman of the UN's climate change panel has appealed to Australia to bring the US back to the negotiating table. But it appears to be wishful thinking to hope that a future accord on global warming can be forged by the US's traditional allies, also including Canada and Japan, by bridging the gap between Europe and America.

Gareth Walton, Greenpeace Australia's climate change spokesperson, has criticised the disingenuity of Australian politicians, who style themselves as the pragmatic "good guys" with the ear of the US on Kyoto.

Australia's rhetorical stance is softer simply because they are smaller country. "They know full well that the US is not going to come on board," Mr Walton said. And the Australian government doesn't appear that bothered if they don't.

webTitle: BBC admits failure to nurture talent

fields.headline: BBC admits failure to nurture talent
fields.trailText: 10.30am: The BBC admits it must do more to nurture home-grown talent as it revealed a £10m scramble to hire outside stars, writes Lisa O'Carroll.
fields.body:
The BBC has conceded it must do more to nurture home-grown talent as it revealed a £10m scramble to hire on-screen stars from outside.

The corporation even "thanked" Channel 4 for developing stars such as the Big Breakfast's Johnny Vaughan and camp chat show host Graham Norton to enable it refresh the look of its TV schedules.

"Developing our own talent... is something that has been lacking in the last few years," said Rob Warr, the BBC's head of talent.

In an admission that the BBC had concentrated far too long on stars such as Terry Wogan and Noel Edmonds, Mr Warr said the corporation had to do more for younger viewers in order to sustain the argument for the licence fee.

"We cannot have a licence fee that appeals just to people over 35," he said.

"The licence fee argument won't work if we don't bring in younger audiences. We will simply die. This is about survival and renewal."

Mr Warr said attracting younger viewers was "an issue" for the BBC but that it was confident that "as an organisation we are doing more to bring talent through".

Talent the BBC has successfully nurtured includes Angus Deayton, Paul Merton, stars of Have I Got News for You, and impressionist Alistair McGowan, famous for his sketches on David and Victoria Beckham.

But this weekend the corporation revealed it had spent between £3m and £5m on signing Vaughan. It was claimed the BBC had also offered a £6m golden handcuffs deal to Graham Norton.

"Channel 4 have done a very good job developing Johnny Vaughan and Graham Norton and we have to thank them for that," Mr Warr said.

The BBC has let big on-screen stars such as Ross Kemp slip through their fingers in the past amid and are now determined to guard against defections.

Last night, however, it appeared that its approach can still be muddled and off-putting. Graham Norton told MediaGuardian that he never knew who he was dealing with.

"There was Lorraine Heggessey, Danielle Lux, Alan Yentob, Jane Root. It seemed to be the deal that was the story rather than what you are doing as part of the deal," he said.

Norton, who has decided to stay with Channel 4 until 2004, said he was also apprehensive about signing for the BBC because he would have had to tone down his So Graham Norton show, which is notorious for its innuendo.

"At the BBC I would have had more memos about the show," he joked.

"That is the thing with the BBC, that people have a right to be annoyed about what they see because it's their licence fee money," he added.

webTitle: Pubs could open round the clock under licensing reforms

fields.headline: Pubs could open round the clock under licensing reforms
fields.trailText: Pubs are to be allowed to stay open round the clock under plans for a radical overhaul of licensing laws expected to be announced by the Home Office on Wednesday.
fields.body:
Pubs are to be allowed to stay open round the clock under plans for a radical overhaul of licensing laws expected to be announced by the Home Office on Wednesday.

Sunday licensing laws in shops and supermarkets will also be scrapped and residents will have a right to appeal against late licences in their locality. Restrictions on children's access to pubs will be eased, although publicans will be able to apply for licences to exclude them.

Closing times will be staggered to ease pressure on police resources. The government predicts that most pubs will close between 11pm and 3am.

Ministers have been looking at the reform for years and believe liberalisation could end the scourge of binge drinking, especially at weekends. Home Office research shows alcohol-related crime soars between 11pm and 1 am.

The reform was outlined in a white paper which suggested: "Longer hours generally should promote a more gradual drift from licensed premises as customers make for home."

It applies to England and Wales and is broadly popular with publicans and younger people. But the Conservatives yesterday condemned the timing of the announcement as a pre-election bribe. Ministers will defend the liberalisation by pointing out that the police have been given new powers, including on-the-spot fines, and new rights to close "irresponsible" pubs.

Under the proposals a new split licensing system would require landlords and their premises to get separate permits. A three-strikes-and-you're-out policy would prevent landlords who have lost licenses setting up elsewhere.

The broad reform would bring Britain closer into line with continental Europe and could help boost the ailing tourist industry, but some club owners may worry that the traditional rush to clubs after pubs close will evaporate. The call for reform under this government started with the Better Regulation Task Force, chaired by Lord Haskins.

The task force declared Britain's 19th century laws confusing, inconsistent and too rigid. Lord Haskins insisted that "There is no evidence that longer opening hours increases hooliganism - by reverse, it reduces it. People drinking up very rapidly in the last half hour before closing time is a much greater problem than if they have leisure to make their own decisions."

At present, the 160,000 licensed premises in England and Wales apply to licensing magistrates. In future, licensing authorities will provide a personal alcohol licence.

The white paper called for a new offence of buying alcohol on behalf of a person under 18 and another new offence of knowingly permitting a sale to a person under 18 years

The Association of Chief Police Officers said the move would help the police control troublemakers.

webTitle: AOL eyes NTL for European push

fields.headline: AOL eyes NTL for European push
fields.trailText: 10am: US media giant AOL Time Warner has chosen cable operator NTL as a partner in its bid to boost European revenues, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
The US media giant, AOL Time Warner, has chosen cable operator NTL as a partner in its bid to boost European revenues.

The world's largest media company is seeking a broadband distribution deal across the Atlantic and has made NTL its main target.

NTL, which dominates the cable market in the UK and Ireland with 8m subscribers, today stressed the talks were in their early stages.

"We are talking to a broad range of companies about a range of agreements," said an NTL spokesperson.

"While it is true that we are in the early stages of talks with AOL, apart from an outline terms sheet nothing has been agreed."

While AOL Time Warner has an extensive cable network in the US, it lacks a similar operation in Europe, and needs a broadband deal to get the most from its TV, music, film and internet services.

The surprise move follows a dramatic week for NTL, in which it raised an extra £388m in financing but was tipped to run out of money by the end of June by the HSBC investment bank.

Despite its pre-eminent position in the UK market, the company's £10bn debt burden remain a source of concern for investors, who want to see a more tangible return from its "triple play" offer, in which telecoms, internet and TV services are bundled into one package.

NTL insiders have privately scorned the HSBC report, saying its capital expenditure will fall from £1.9bn to £1bn by next year.

But AOL Timer Warner is expected to team up with other European cable services, as NTL only has 500,000 subscribers outside the UK and Ireland.

Steve Case, the chairman of the £72bn media group, last month said the company will raise its international revenues from 17% to 50% of the total over the next 10 years.

fields.headline: C4 struggles to get replacement Breakfast
fields.trailText:
10am: Channel 4 admits it is struggling to come up with a replacement for the Big Breakfast, writes Lisa O'Carroll.

25.04.2001: D-day for Big Breakfast
fields.body:
Channel 4 executives have admitted they are struggling to come up with a replacement for the Big Breakfast.

They admit the show is no longer up to scratch but say there is still nothing better to replace it with.

"What do we replace it with? Three hours of live television every morning is the most difficult thing in the business to get right," said one senior executive.

"We don't know what is going to happen yet, but we can't replace it with cartoons."

One idea was to replace it with T4, the hit Sunday morning show anchored by Dermot O'Leary, but that appears unlikely.

"T4 is just smoke and mirrors," the executive said.

The beleaguered show has plunged in the ratings and is expected to be cancelled in June, when Channel 4 is contractually obliged to tell producers Planet 24 whether it will renew the £60m a year contract.

The terms of the contract means the show will continue until the end of the year, raising fears that it could become a lame-duck programme.

webTitle: Football tycoon joins and funds anti-EU party

fields.headline: Football tycoon joins and funds anti-EU party
fields.standfirst: Full coverage of Election 2001
fields.trailText: Sir Jack Hayward, the millionaire owner of Wolverhampton Wanderers football club, has joined the UK Independence party, donating a five figure sum which will help the party field nearly 500 candidates at the coming general election.
fields.body:
Sir Jack Hayward, the millionaire owner of Wolverhampton Wanderers football club, has joined the UK Independence party, donating a five figure sum which will help the party field nearly 500 candidates at the coming general election.

The number of candidates is nearly 100 more than the party had initially forecast. The news will put extra pressure on the Conservative candidates in marginal seats to harden their Eurosceptic views.

Nigel Farage, the UKIP leader and MEP, said yesterday: "With a month to go we are on course to spend £1m at the general election which for little old us is not bad going."

Sir "Union Jack" Hayward, whose wealth comes from a string of business interests in the Bahamas, joined the UKIP a week ago. He has already handed the cheque to Mr Farage. Details of the amount will not be released to the electoral commission until July, but Mr Farage said it was a healthy five figure sum.

Sir Jack kept the Liberal party afloat financially in the 70s, but said yesterday he fully supported the UKIP's aims of keeping sterling as a matter of constitutional principle, not to be ruled from Brussels and to be independent from Europe.

Sir Jack is one of a group of businessmen now funding the UKIP. Mr Farage disclosed yesterday that Bruce Robertson, the owner of Trago Mills, a supermarket chain in the south-west with an annual turnover of more than £100m, had also donated a five figure cheque. Cornwall is a relative UKIP stronghold and Mr Robertson's intervention will make the outcome of some key marginals in the region even more difficult to predict.

Mr Farage said the party was also receiving funding from John Langham, the Dorset based head of Langham Industries. Funding is also coming from Harris paint brushes.

In recent weeks, Mr Farage has been able to confirm the support of two peers - the Duke of Somerset and Viscount Exmouth - as well as the former Tory whip in the Commons Roger Knapman. Mr Knapman is to fight the seat of North Devon.

Andrew Spence, one of the leaders of last year's fuel protest, is taking on Tony Blair in his Sedgefield seat.

Although the UKIP insists its polling shows that it gains a majority of its support from outside the Tory party, it is the Conservatives who fear most that the UKIP will prevent them from winning some key marginals.

In Dorset South the combined vote of the Referendum party, then led by Jimmy Goldsmith, and the UKIP reduced the Tory majority to 77.

Mr Farage said: "The Conservatives can call us a rabble, but they are absolutely terrified of us. They know their candidates will be under pressure to harden their policy towards one of withdrawal [from the EU]."

fields.headline: Interview:  Kate Hoey
fields.standfirst: Jim White questions the Minister for Sport on the Wembley stadium debacle, spitting footballers, obsessive media, the upcoming election and her days as a revolting student
fields.trailText: Jim White questions the Minister for Sport on the Wembley stadium debacle, spitting footballers, obsessive media, the upcoming election and her days as a revolting student.
fields.body:
The first thing Kate Hoey would like to point out, as she comes to meet me herself in the reception of the department of culture, media and sport rather than sending a minion, is that she is the Minister for Sport, not the Minister for Football. As she leads the way past the modernist art works that pepper the walls of the department - given its split brief, you half expect to see a rugby boot dissected by Damien Hurst sitting in a tank of formaldehyde on a window ledge - she says it exasperates her that every time she makes a speech detailing government funding policy for the grass roots of sport, or conducts an interview about the new strategy for physical education in primary schools, she happens to make some throwaway, 10-second observation about football and that is what makes the headlines.

"Honestly," she says, which is always an awkward word for a politician, "I think the obsession our media has with football is dangerous, I really do. And I love the game, I'm an Arsenal fan."

Thus the first impression you get of Hoey is that she can get an awful lot said in a short walk from reception. Still, it would be a shame to disabuse her about the average journalist, so here, in short order are the passing thoughts of the sports minister on our national game, all of them buried deep within a wide-ranging interview. First of all she thinks it's unnecessary for footballers to spit all the time. After all, rugby players don't and they don't choke on accumulated gob. She believes footballers, even if they don't wish to be, are role models to young children and really ought to bear that in mind before they start arguing with referees or fighting on the pitch. She also reckons there is merit in the idea of safe terracing at football grounds, even if her immediate boss, Chris Smith, will have none of it. Oh, and though the Chelsea chairman has consistently implied she did, she denies she ever briefed the press against Ken Bates over the Wembley debacle. "No I didn't," she says. "One thing about the press, I'm always amazed how much they know without me having to go to the bother of briefing them." Which, as a politician's answer, is hard to fault.

Indeed as a passionate enthusiast for both politics and sport, Hoey could be said to have arrived at her spiritual home. A graduate in PE with a radical political outlook (not many Ulster unionists got involved in the International Marxist Group in the sixties) even when she was manning the barricades as a revolting student, sport meant everything to her. Later, after she switched from IMG to Labour, she worked for Arsenal, Chelsea and Spurs as an education officer. One of her pupils was David Rocastle, which was why she is that rarity among her peers, someone who was genuinely moved when she was obliged recently to give the standard New Labour sound bite about the death of a prominent figure. When she fought a by-election in Vauxhall, she enlisted the help of local lad Michael Thomas, the then championship-winning Arsenal player, in her successful campaign. And her first big parliamentary speech was one which exposed corruption in football, the start of a crusade in which she did not flinch from naming names. As the misogynistic vitriol came back from certain quarters in response, you couldn't help thinking that if those were the people she had upset, her heart must be in the right place.

In July 1999 she took over from Tony Banks the government office she always wanted. She had arrived. And, judging by the over-flowing bookshelves in that office, she has been frantically busy ever since, putting herself about the sporting world. There are presentational golf balls and rugby balls and judo kits. There are shields and trophies and certificates. There are photographs with her shaking the hands of the great, the good and Harry Kewell. She has so much stuff, she can pass some of it on. Since politicians are obliged to list gifts they receive from the members of the public lest they be accused of taking secret bribes, I should reveal that the gift this member of the public received from a politician was the cuddly toy emblem of the English Netball Association she had been presented with at a recent international.

That she was there to receive it at all, is typical. The minister believes it is important symbolically for her to be seen at events like this, at netball, badminton and judo. It is vital, she says, that the huge spread of sport we enjoy in this country is maintained to give the young as wide a choice as possible in which to express themselves, to steer them away from a life of sloth, crime and expanding waistlines. In short, this is not an office in which the essential moral, physical and spiritual value of sport is remotely in doubt. That is the purpose of her ministry, she says: to ensure access to sport for all. It is as important that children in Hackney learn to swim as it is that England (and Scotland) qualify for Japan and Korea in 2002. Which places the present incumbent of the office a philosophical mile from her predecessor. For Banks there seemed a different point to the job entirely.

"Yes, Tony got completely involved in the World Cup bid and saw it as his major role as sports minister to deliver it," she says.

And deliver it he did. Unfortunately it was for Germany. But then the obsession with 2006 appeared such a transparently party political one, few outside No 10 can have been too dismayed to see it falter. The idea was that the feelgood factor of hosting the world football championships would translate itself into the votes which would secure a third term for the Blair government. They might think they are, but New Labour are by no means the first to believe there is a link between national sporting and political success. Harold Wilson spotted it, John Major pumped money into Manchester hoping the Olympics would go there in 2000, the first face French people saw on television after their team had won the World Cup was Jacques Chirac's, keen that glory should be reflected in his vote. So, now that the World Cup has gone west, is Tony Blair on the phone demanding his sports minister come up with something else to win him the election?

"I think it's probably a bit late for this election, isn't it?" she says. "Look, the Prime Minister understands the genuine importance of sport to the country, but he realises it is about long-term investment. He took great interest in the sports strategy, and I think his support has helped us deliver real extra money including - and this is something the press never seems interested in because it's boringly good news - giving community sports groups charitable status which is going to make an enormous difference."

Then again, even if he wanted it, the chances of us landing a big sporting event at the moment are about as high as Halifax Town's of winning the Premiership. Although the words piss up and brewery weren't actually used, the recent commons select committee on sport could not have been more direct about the shambles of Wembley, 2006 and the national athletics stadium at Pickett's Lock. So what is going on in sport? It can't be funding, not with the bloated resources of the lottery to hand. Presumably the minister must be dismayed that while her colleagues down the corridor in the arts seem able to boast wonderful lottery projects - the Tate Modern, the Walsall art gallery, the new Sadlers Wells - sport is so abject? "Well of course the lottery is producing brilliant sporting projects which are making a huge difference to daily lives at a grass roots level but generate zero publicity," she says.

Maybe, but surely she must look at the sad hulk of Wembley and shiver with embarrassment. "Wembley is a private sector project," she says. "The lottery money was used to buy the stadium, after that it's been led by football. We as government want to see a successful Wembley, but it's up to football. Ken Bates was leading the stadium team, we weren't represented. He took the decision when to go to the City. All the discussion about athletics being in it made no difference to the planning permission being delayed. When you talk to people about it now, it seems Mr Bates simply didn't keep the rest of the board informed. Most of them didn't know what was going on, so when he said everything's fine, it'll happen, they believed him. It wasn't until Adam Crozier got involved that he discovered things were not as they seemed. I had no personal involvement at all. Let me make this quite clear, Wembley is not a government project. It was and is a football project."

And she says this with such a tone of regret in her voice, you wonder if the Minister for Sport wouldn't mind, after all, being the Minister for Football.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to football.editor@guardianunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: The survivor
fields.standfirst:
Gerry Adams is one of the most prominent political figures of our time, yet the man behind the beard and spectacles remains an enigma. What did he actually do in the years before he swapped his Armalite for a negotiating suit? And will he ever be able to tell the truth about his past?

Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Gerry Adams is one of the most prominent political figures of our time, yet the man behind the beard and spectacles remains an enigma. What did he actually do in the years before he swapped his Armalite for a negotiating suit? And will he ever be able to tell the truth about his past?
fields.body:
The skinny-arsed security man is padding up and down, up and down, the reception of Sinn Fein headquarters. He stares out of the window on to the Falls Road, fag pinched between thumb and forefinger, smoking arm behind back.

He looks like a man who has seen a lot. The air is thick with the smell of bacon. We're waiting for the president of Sinn Fein. Sinead on reception watches the people passing on the streets on the CCTV.

There is no sign of Adams. The security man keeps padding up and down the reception.

The windows are reinforced. You would break your fingers before you could put a fist through one of them.

Sinn Fein, the political arm of the IRA - as it used to be called - is such a complex organisation. With the IRA no longer active, Sinn Fein now has to accommodate both the politicians and the hard men under one umbrella. Often, they are one and the same.

I go to the toilet.

In the loo, there is a sign: "Important notice: If you sprinkle, while you tinkle, be a sweetie, wipe the seatie."

Finally, we are ushered up to see the man himself. These are tricky times for Adams.

On the one hand, he seems to have more "establishment" support than ever before. On the other, some of his own supporters are wondering what it is they have laid their weapons down for exactly. The Good Friday agreement looks more precarious than ever.

The Real IRA is back in bloody business and David Trimble, Adams's partner in peace, looks increasingly vulnerable to those who believe he has also given too much for too little.

Gerry Adams, MP for West Belfast, looks like a bear trapped in a politician's suit. Big body, big hair, coffee liqueur of a voice. Scary-cuddly, like a bear. He shakes my hand, and crushes it.

He says he is optimistic that Sinn Fein will gain an extra seat in the general election. But isn't he worried about anti-agreement unionists gaining ground too?

"I'm refusing to be pessimistic about this. I think the majority of unionists will respond positively, given positive leadership. But there has been an absence of consistent support for the agreement.

"I think it's a mistake for people to continue to look at it in terms of unionism and nationalism. I think the agreement carved out a new majority, not unionist or nationalist. Without reneging on republicanism, we have to find accommodation with our opponents. If the agreement collapses, it will be proof that unionism isn't up to the challenge of finding accommodation with its neighbours. But I refuse to give you a line saying the agreement could collapse. Of course it could. Many republicans argue it isn't delivering now. But if it collapses on Monday, on Tuesday we have to put it together again. We have to have a long-term strategic view of this. We need to look at this 10 years up the road."

Sinn Fein has predicted that in 10 years there could be a Catholic majority in Northern Ireland. The census is expected to show that already 46% of Northern Ireland is Catholic. I suggest that perhaps republicans could just wait till there's a natural majority and then hold a referendum. Adams laughs at the idea.

"Outbreeding unionists may be an enjoyable pastime for those who have the energy, but it hardly amounts to a political strategy. We can't give up on the task of winning unionists over."

What about the Real IRA? Does it pose a real threat to peace?

"Yes.Yes and no. Yes in so far as they appear to have some capacity to carry out operations. No in that they have no possibility of having popular support. Or no possibility of succeeding because they don't have a strategy."

The door opens and a head pops round.

"All right?"says the disembodied head.

"All right, minister," Adams says with a smile.

The visitor is Martin McGuinness.

"I should have said, 'Yes, minister'," grins Adams.

Both McGuinness and Adams still take boyish pleasure at his new status as education minister in the Stormont Assembly.

While McGuinness is generally acknowledged as having been the commander of the IRA's Derry Brigade during the bloody events of 1972, Adams's paramilitary background remains more opaque.

According to British Army intelligence reports, at 23 he was the commanding officer of the IRA Second Battalion in Belfast. Adams was interned in Long Kesh twice for suspected terrorist activity.

He has always denied his alleged links to the Bloody Friday bombing campaign of July 1972. Again, in 1972, he was the youngest of a group of men flown secretly to Britain to negotiate with the then home secretary Willie Whitelaw. Until seven years ago the British were not even allowed to hear Adams's voice on television or radio - his words had to be mouthed by an actor.

Both Adams and McGuinness are still believed to be on the army council, the governing body of the IRA.

'Ach, that's rubbish," he says.

Adams has never talked about his IRA involvement for pragmatic reasons - IRA membership remains a criminal offence. But his involvement in the IRA is the one thing most of us want to know about. Not just enemies, but also friends and sympathisers. Not simply to call him to account, but out of sheer curiosity. We talk about the truth and reconciliation process in South Africa.

Adams has visited the country many times, and sees it as a model for Northern Ireland. He calls Nelson Mandela one of his heroes.

I ask him when he will be able to do what so many former terrorists have done in South Africa - come clean about his past. Will he ever admit that he carried bombs or killed in the name of his cause? "Well, you'd be asking to make something up if you're asking me to give you that story."

But wouldn't he like to be able to say he did this or he did that for the IRA, and this is why? Sometimes, you feel, you're better off talking in euphemisms to Adams.

"Well, I haven't even contemplated any of that. My position has been very, very clear in all of these matters. It is obviously part of the reclamation, or the reownership, or the reconquest of our people to tell their story. When I wrote Before The Dawn I made it quite clear that there are lots of people involved in my life who I can't talk about simply because I'd put them at risk. At some point it may be possible to lift the lid on different aspects of this, but it isn't something I'm concerned or worried about."

Adams is 52. He doesn't talk about his family in interviews.

He has been married to Colette McArdle for 30 years, and they have one son, a teacher and gaelic footballer. Adams has spent most of his married life away from his family, moving from safehouse to safehouse.

He has a 16-month-old granddaughter, and it has been suggested that he has softened since becoming a grandfather.

Would he be happy for her to grow up involved in the struggle? "It's hard to think of a 16-month child being anything other than a delight to be around. I've not thought about it," he says, unconvincingly.

He still seems to be thinking about lifting the lid.

"There is a need for processes of truth, there is no doubt of that. I think the worst kind of grief is unacknowledged grief. There is a very long wound in the nationalist community because of the number of people who have been killed by British soldiers."

But he says Northern Ireland is a long way away from a formal truth and reconciliation process.

"If the truth and reconciliation process had happened in South Africa before the settlement, there might not have been a settlement because it's so traumatic. It happened after the settlement, and was part of developing a process of closure, and a new beginning."

There is still too much unfinished business in the north, Adams says.

Anyway, he adds, forgiveness cannot simply be a political construct, it has to be on a personal basis.

"If I didn't forgive the people who took me into the barracks and beat me unconscious over a period of days during the period when the British state was indicted for inhuman and degrading treatment in 1971-72, or even the guys who shot me, if you don't forgive them, you end up with unnecessary baggage. I have no wish to carry that baggage. These people did what they thought was right. Or maybe they didn't think about it at all. Maybe they did it instinctively, as happens sometimes when people lose control, when there's a particular regime in place."

He was shot five times. I ask him where the wounds are. He points to his upper chest, neck and shoulders. Can I see them?

"No," he says, with his coffee-liqueur laugh.

"You'll want to stick your fingers in them."

It is a typical Adams response: allusive, biblical, multi-layered. He should have gone to university, but chose to work in a bar instead - more politically grounded, he thought.

Adams has written poems, short stories and his autobiography. He says, casually, that he would rather write than be a politician. He would really like to give up politics?

"Yes." When? "Now. But I realise I can't do it." Really, truly? "I would. I genuinely would. I'd prefer that I wasn't involved in political struggle. I can think of numerous things that I could do with my life, and I enjoy life hugely. Even a year off would be something, but somebody has to do it. If I wasn't doing it, somebody else would be."

He stresses and re-stresses there is nothing unusual about him.

Whenever anyone enters the office, as they often do, he tells me how much longer than him they spent in jail.

In one of his earliest interviews, Adams said that he reckoned he had a 90% chance of being killed.

Did he expect to be alive now? "At this moment?" He smiles.

"After the coffee?" He laughs. Shakes like a bear.

"To tell you the truth, I'm not fixated by this question of death, or its proximity.

There are obviously dangers in what you do, but somebody has to do it," he says yet again.

He's seen so much death, he's been responsible for so much death: why should his life be sacrosanct? Surely he must have felt isolated, seeing so many people die around him?

"I've never felt isolated. I've felt alone, I've felt depressed, I've felt cheesed off, the same as anybody would, but I've never felt isolated. Never. Never ."

A few minutes later he, typically, returns to an earlier point. There is something so dogged, so obdurate, about Adams.

"Now going right back to your question about depression you are victim to the ordinary depressions, insecurities and doubts you get as a human being. When was I depressed? When my mother died. I was depressed when many good friends were killed. I was depressed in prison."

He talks about some of the deaths that have affected him most - his mum, his two nephews killed in a car crash, his friend Cleeky Clarke, who recently died of cancer.

He seems to find these deaths more unbearable than those of comrades killed by the British Army - at least they died for a cause. Cleeky Clarke was his minder in latter years, and much more. They were mates in Long Kesh, Cleeky always getting him into trouble with "his harebrained ideas to escape or some other completely imbecilic notion".

Why was escaping a harebrained notion?

"Because I was the world's worst would-be escaper. I actually ended up in prison for trying to escape. I was interned without trial, tried to escape twice, and was caught twice."

The talk turns to Tony Blair.

Does he consider the prime minister a moral man? "Depends whose advice he's taking." He stops himself.

"That's probably an impertinent thing to say, an imprudent thing to say in terms of this peace process.

Yes, I think this British government is different from previous British governments but, and I've told Tony Blair this, the question of a British policy in Ireland will be the most difficult issue he faces as prime minister. The foot and mouth thing is a big issue, the euro is a big issue, but the question of Ireland will continue to dog the relationship between these two islands unless Mr Blair is prepared to rise to the challenge."

I ask him whether there is a unionist he admires.

"Well, I do think David Trimble is very good at what he does.

I mean, David Trimble, from a unionist perspective, has been able to get a British government to pander to his every whim by working on the inside of the agreement to actually prevent the implementation of that agreement.

Maybe I give him too much credit, but I do think he's a skilled politician."

So Sinn Fein would be happy to see the embattled Trimble fall? No, he says, the party's position is clear - it needs a unionist party to work with in order to implement the Good Friday agreement, and it has given Trimble as much support as possible.

Adams has talked so much about his capacity for forgiveness. Does he feel he has anything to be forgiven for?

"I don't think we would be at the point we are now if we had not come through the conflict, and if there had not been an armed struggle as part of all of that. Now I wish that it was different. I actually wonder at different times why it was not possible to get to this point before we got to it."

Does he still go to confession? "Yes," he says.

Has he confessed to the really nasty things he has done in the past? He doesn't answer, but I suppose it is a vague question.

Have you ever put a gun to anyone's head? "No."

He always thought that was something for others to do? "No, it never entered into the possibilities."

I remind him of a short story he once wrote in which a young gunman, sweating and palpitating before the moment of action, wonders whether it is more noble to be shot than to do the shooting. I say it sounded like a personal dilemma.

Adams seems annoyed.

"Well, I think it's interesting that, seven years into an IRA cessation, and we're talking about all of that. But there you are If you start to explore the use of violence, I think there's a tremendous amount of hypocrisy in it.

I mean, Martin Luther King described violence as the language of the unheard."

He embarks on one of those elaborate sentences he excels in.

"So if you find people in a partitioned Ireland - who are not treated as badly as people in South Africa, not as badly as the Jewish people were, not as badly as the Palestinian people - resort to armed action, whether that is right or wrong is something else, then you find the establishment which has built itself out of violence, depicts these people as terrorists."

He says all wars are dirty wars, and make no mistake: this has been a war.

"You know there's the age-old argument about Washington - terrorist or patriot? And Mandela. There's a slogan that says the victor writes the history."

And, of course, he eventually returns to the original question.

"Let me come back to the confession thing. You tell sins in confession."

Silence.

Pardon, I say.

"You tell sins or what you think are sins in confession."

And another silence. I look him in the eye. He looks me in the eye. I want to look away or blink, but feel that I cannot. We are eyeballing each other.

I want to ask him what he means, but I know it is the most eloquent and honest answer he could give.

It is a stand off. Eventually, he laughs.

"We're going to look at each other a long time," he says.

fields.headline: In favour of motherhood
fields.standfirst: Six months pregnant herself, the public health minister looks forward to a big boost in maternity services
fields.trailText: Two years ago, having just given birth to my first child at 5am, an unexpected acceleration in labour meant that I missed out on the epidural I wanted, and I was feeling pretty sore about it in more ways than one. But uppermost in my mind, with my newborn and husband crashed out asleep together in the armchair, was a craving for a cup of tea and a bacon sandwich.
fields.body:
Two years ago, having just given birth to my first child at 5am, an unexpected acceleration in labour meant that I missed out on the epidural I wanted, and I was feeling pretty sore about it in more ways than one. But uppermost in my mind, with my newborn and husband crashed out asleep together in the armchair, was a craving for a cup of tea and a bacon sandwich.

Sadly, at that hour, no one was taking orders for a fry-up. If asked for a personal recommendation on how to modernise maternity services, "bacon and anaesthetists" would have been my reply.

Bacon aside, the care from staff at Pontefract hospital was excellent. According to an audit commission survey a few years ago, most women say that they are pleased with the care they receive. The trouble is that there are wide variations in maternity services across the country. These limit rather than extend the choices offered to women and their partners at a critical time in their lives.

Perhaps most important of all, those variations often reflect deep-rooted inequalities. The founding principles of the NHS are that healthcare should be free at the point of use, based on need, not ability to pay. That means ensuring that those in greatest need do not have least access to health services. Nowhere is this more important than at the very beginning of a child's life.

So as part of a plan to tackle child poverty and give every child the best start, Alan Milburn, the health secretary, will set out this week a major programme of modernisation in our maternity services. That means investment in facilities and recruitment, improvements to screening and the beginnings of a major scheme of national standards in maternity and children's health. We need such new standards to ensure proper safety and high-quality care in every area.

Now in the sixth month of my second pregnancy, I know from personal experience that different places can have very different approaches. The consequence of travelling each week between Westminster and my constituency is signing up for maternity care at both ends of the country. After all, it's hard to predict where I will be when labour starts. All mothers know that drawing up birth plans can prove pointless when labour takes a different course. Discussing epidurals with two sets of midwives proved doubly redundant but provided an interesting insight into the variations that exist.

Different units offer different tests at different points in pregnancy. In fact if you switch hospitals at the right point, you can probably clock up six different tests for Down's syndrome (scans, double and triple tests galore) and each will give you a slightly different result.

One of the first areas in which we are introducing national standards involves the screening and counselling support to be offered for certain tests in pregnancy and newborns so that parents have a proper, informed choice about which tests they want. Work is under way too on clinical standards around the management of labour, particularly when problems arise, including induction, fetal monitoring and Caesareans.

Second, as investment in the NHS grows, we need to address the backlog in underinvestment that can have a huge impact on family experience. Staff are often working extremely hard, but having to contend with outdated, rundown facilities. Some units offer home-from-home comforts, perhaps with separate midwife-led facilities. Others have cramped labour wards that look more like Victorian operating theatres.

In Pontefract there were TVs in individual rooms on the labour ward, in theory to provide distraction during a long labour. In practice I suspect they found more enthusiasm among partners, bored with helping with breathing. Either way, modern maternity services need modern facilities too.

Increasing staffing levels is vital. Recruitment pressures in some areas make it difficult to provide the one-to-one care in established labour that women want. The Pontefract area operates team midwifery, which meant we saw the same familiar faces before, during and after the birth. In other areas hard-working health service staff have developed different innovative models to provide continuity of care and support. In part it means proper staffing, but it can also mean new ways of working.

As new investment and improvements take place it is essential that they support choices for parents. The choice whether to have a home birth varies dramatically across the country. Personally I am too risk-averse, and pain-averse, to dream of a home birth myself. The idea of all that trauma in my kitchen or bedroom is enough to put me off ever going into the rooms again. But wherever it is clinically appropriate, these are choices the NHS should, where possible, support.

So mothers and mothers-to-be will be asked their views on improving maternity services across the country. And for the first time in any government review of this kind, we will explicitly seek the views of fathers too. Already the royal colleges representing midwives, obstetricians, paediatricians and anaesthetists have joined the government and parent groups in a joint maternity working group.

But in the end, the real challenge is to improve the choices and support avail able for those whose voices are least often heard, yet who may need support most. As one midwife told me, the expectant mothers she worried about most were often least likely to make it to appointments.

Certainly for those on low incomes facing a long bus ride with toddlers in tow, a trip to an antenatal appointment can be a daunting experience. As my own second bump gets bigger and bulkier, wrestling with an errant pushchair, an excitable toddler and the London-to-Yorkshire train each week is ordeal enough. It is only a matter of time before we sail past our Wakefield stop because a coincidence of tantrums and twinges make it physically impossible to get everything off in time.

So improving access to maternity services is not just about what happens in hospital, or the care the NHS provides. Already Sure Start programmes are providing toddler-friendly mini-buses to healthcare appointments, or taking the midwives out into family homes. After the baby is born, extending care and support is just as vital - whether it be help for women who want to breastfeed, identifying post-natal depression or just making sure that there is someone to talk to in those difficult early months.

It isn't hard to be passionate about improving maternity services and children's health when your own little one is on the way. But if we are to deliver major improvements in children's health across the board, we need to build on progress in all these areas. Only that way can we ensure that every child gets the very best start in life.

The author is public health minister and MP for Pontefract and Castleford.

fields.headline: Hairdressers of the world unite
fields.standfirst: Insensitive to deride them when the deputy PM is married to one
fields.trailText: Insensitive to deride them when the deputy PM is married to one.
fields.body:
To paraphrase Harold Macmillan, these days I am not much in the company of hairdressers. To be honest, I never was. But, 50 years ago, the estrangement did not result from any lack of enthusiasm. In those days, I regarded hairdressers (of the female variety) as creatures of desire second only in attraction to the lady assistants in the Boots cosmetics department.

My motives in attempting to arrange a rendezvous have changed, but if there are a couple of crimpers (of either sex) who would like a free acclimatisation tour of the House of Lords, I would be happy to make the arrangement. It might even be possible for them to meet Lord Stevenson of Coddenham, the chairman of the appointment committee who judged that they would not be "comfortable" in such noble company and elevated surroundings.

No doubt, if such a meeting were arranged, the visiting hairdressers would be too polite to offer Lord Stevenson their opinion of his judgment that their whole profession does not include one suitable candidate for elevation to the House of Lords. So here is mine. Lord Stevenson is an ass. No doubt, whatever he does for a living, he does very well. But his television appearances during the day on which the new peers' names were announced exuded all the silliness that comes from a misplaced sense of superiority.

Defending his choice, he told the world that he had ruled out potential peers with "less obvious highfalutin" achievement. What sort of a man is it who equates highfalutin with merit? Perhaps the answer is the sort of man who is so insensitive that he derides hairdressers without (on a charitable interpretation) remembering that the deputy prime minister is married to one. Lord Stevenson would be well advised to keep away from Kingston upon Hull.

However, he comes only second in the competition for prize chump of the Lords appointments commission. The first prize goes to whichever member of the Downing Street press office had the idea of telling the press that the prime minister was to create "people's peers".

Once again, the desire to manipulate the news has turned what might have been a minor success into a major fiasco. For, within the absurd context of an unelected upper house, the independent appointment of distinguished cross-benchers is not a bad idea. It has been made to look ridiculous by a single soundbite that - whatever its attraction to the media - had nothing to do with the policy.

Apologists for a House of Lords that is untainted with democracy always argue that appointments (in one form or another) are the only way to recruit men and women of distinction but no firm politi cal allegiance. Until now, such persons have been the beneficiaries of the prime ministers' patronage. Creating a commission to free the new nobility from the taint of cronyism was a tiny step towards more transparent government. But it had nothing to do with people's peers.

If we are to have an unelected House of Lords, Herman Ouseley, Claus Moser, Susan Greenfield and David Hannay are the sort of people who should be sitting on the red leather. On their arrival they will immensely improve the quality of the place. But this morning, they must be seething with irritation at the farce that has been made of their appointment. They are condemned forever to be names on the "Hairdressers List". The controversy surrounding their elevation will be a feature of their obituaries.

It could have been all so different. If the soundbite had reflected the policy, some genuine people's peers could have been appointed. Long ago, during a television interview after I had announced the creation of a prices watchdog I was asked if it would include an "ordinary housewife", the only possible answer was "yes". So we had to find one. Thousands of hopefuls applied, the civil service cursed and I interviewed a shortlist of three. The successful candidate - after recovering from the shock of discovering that her daily allowance was more than she received for a month of part-time work - was a triumph.

The importance of our "ordinary housewife" was that she was different from the merchant banker and company chairman who sat round the same table. A dozen people's peers with similar qualities could set the House of Lords alight. And they could be found. Last week alone I met a Kent comprehensive headmaster, a hospital registrar, a vicar, a publican and a barber who, given the chance, would do the job admirably.

The barber - who would be reluctant to call himself a hairdresser - wondered why the distinguished dozen were so anxious to wear ermine. Unable to provide a convincing answer, I told him to change the subject. So he explained to me why a Keynsian chancellor would exploit a possible economic showdown to increase public expenditure without risking higher inflation.

Roy Hattersley is a member of the House of Lords
