fields.headline: McGuinness to admit IRA role
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Northern Ireland
Special report: the Bloody Sunday inquiry
fields.trailText: Martin McGuinness, Ulster's education minister, is publicly to admit his role in the Provisional IRA in evidence to   the Bloody Sunday tribunal. It is thought he will say he was the group's number two in Derry when troops shot dead 14   Catholics in 1972.
fields.body:
Martin McGuinness, Ulster's education minister, is publicly to admit his role in the Provisional IRA in evidence to the Bloody Sunday tribunal. It is thought he will say he was the group's number two in Derry when troops shot dead 14 Catholics in 1972.

Mr McGuinness, who became MP for Mid-Ulster in 1997, has never formally acknowledged his paramilitary background.

But he has now decided to tell the Saville inquiry that he was asked by his commanding officer to order IRA members not to fire on soldiers so that the demonstration would pass off peacefully.

He will rubbish a claim, from a military intelligence agent known as Infliction, that he precipitated the mayhem by firing the first shot in the Bogside on January 30,1972.

But he is expected to disclose that two IRA units, with four men in each, were armed and told to stay in the Creggan and Brandywell areas of the city, well away from the march, in case of an incursion of troops.

Mr McGuinness will also say that all other IRA weapons were secured in an arms hide that day and members told they could attend the civil rights protest in a private capacity or stay at home. He will claim he was at the march, unarmed, from start to finish.

Lawyers for the soldiers have alleged at the tribunal that there were hidden casualties who may well have included IRA gunmen, and have criticised the Provisionals for the "wall of secrecy" surrounding its activities on Bloody Sunday.

webTitle: Wogan loses TV contract but stays at Radio 2

fields.headline: Wogan loses TV contract but stays at Radio 2
fields.trailText: The BBC has decided not to renew the television contract of Terry Wogan, who has been a broadcaster for more than 40 years. By MB>Matt Wells.
fields.body:
As BBC TV signs up Johnny Vaughan to net a new generation of viewers, it is letting go a star whose appeal is somewhat less youthful.

The corporation has decided not to renew the television contract of Terry Wogan, who has been a broadcaster for more than 40 years. From now on, Wogan's deal will cover only his Radio 2 show.

He has criticised BBC bosses in the past, saying they squandered his talent, and that he was not used enough on television. It seems, however, that BBC executives feel Wogan's appeal lies more with his traditional fan base on his Radio 2 breakfast show, which still performs strongly.

Rob Warr, the BBC's head of talent management, said at the Golden Rose television festival in Montreux that Wogan, 62, would still do "specials" for the BBC such as the Eurovision Song Contest and Children in Need. But his exclusive contract, thought to be worth about £500,000 a year, will cover radio only.

The BBC's decision means that Wogan could be signed up by other television broadcasters. His old BBC1 chatshow, Wogan, has been criticised for being anodyne but was popular with viewers.

webTitle: Vaughan joins BBC in big money move

fields.headline: Vaughan joins BBC in big money move
fields.standfirst: Former Big Breakfast presenter to front US-style satirical talk show
fields.trailText: The spiralling cost of top TV talent was starkly illustrated yesterday when the BBC announced it had signed Johnny Vaughan on a multimillion pound contract to front a US-style nightly chat show.
fields.body:
The spiralling cost of top TV talent was starkly illustrated yesterday when the BBC announced it had signed Johnny Vaughan on a multimillion pound contract to front a US-style nightly chat show.

BBC executives defended the deal with the former Big Breakfast presenter, understood to be between £3m and £5m over two years, saying it had to maintain top stars to justify the licence fee.

But Vaughan's style is edgy and irreverent, and it is far from clear whether he will command universal appeal.

Admitting Vaughan was a risk, Rob Warr, the corporation's head of talent management, said the BBC had to keep bringing in new viewers. "The licence-fee argument won't work unless we bring in younger audiences," he said.

It is clear that the BBC under Greg Dyke is prepared to splash out: Graham Norton said at the weekend that he had turned down a reported £6m from the BBC, preferring to stay with Channel 4. The former footballer Ian Wright has signed to the BBC on a £1m deal over two years.

As part of the deal, Vaughan will present a post-watershed talk show on BBC1, which will run three or four nights a week. It is likely to be a topical, slightly satirical show reflecting on the day's events.

A comedy series, titled Orrible and starring Vaughan, will start on BBC2 in September. He is writing a drama, and will host shows for the entertainment network BBC Choice.

Vaughan, speaking at the Golden Rose television festival in Montreux, Switzerland, said he was delighted with his BBC deal. "Sometimes it feels like the right time to move on, and I had been at Channel 4 for nine years. It's a lovely deal and I'm very pleased with it."

His talk show is the BBC's first attempt to create a regular, live weekday entertainment programme since the demise of Wogan.

Norton's show will continue on Channel 4 after the star agreed a two-year extension to his deal. He will be tied exclusively to Channel 4 until 2004, in a deal worth less than the BBC's proposal. Norton said the corporation's plans for him were too vague.

ITV is also building up new stars for young audiences. It announced at the weekend that the Brookside actress and star of Celebrity Big Brother, Claire Sweeney, will host a new version of Don't Try This At Home, a Saturday night primetime show featuring daredevil stunts which had been hosted by Davina McCall.

Bob Massie, head of entertainment at LWT, which is making Challenge of a Lifetime, the new Sweeney show for ITV, said the actor had potential to become a new "face" for prime time entertainment shows on the channel.

 The presenter Jamie Theakston is to do his Channel 4 show, The Priory, under hypnosis.

Paul McKenna, who has treated many celebrities for phobias and used to have his own ITV hypnosis series, will put Theakston into a trance two hours before Tuesday's show. Lawyers scrutinised the plans - believed to be the first time a broadcaster has been under such a spell on a British show - to make sure they clear TV guidelines.

Although Theakston will appear normal, he will be instructed to react to a number of buzz-words which will affect the way he behaves.

fields.headline: Berlusconi taunts 'Lenin' editor
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The media empire of Silvio Berlusconi has hit back at criticism in the Economist by accusing its editor of resembling Lenin. By Rory Carroll.
fields.body:
The media empire of Silvio Berlusconi, Italy's opposition leader, has hit back at criticism in the Economist by accusing its editor of resembling Lenin.

Il Giornale, a national daily owned by the centre-right leader's family, said at the weekend that Bill Emmott, who has a goatee and a bald patch, belonged to a "lefty" conspiracy that wanted to derail Mr Berlusconi's expected victory in the May 13 general election. The paper added that the British weekly was meddling in Italian democracy.

A photograph of Mr Emmott holding a copy of his magazine was captioned to say that he "vaguely resembled" Lenin.

His three television channels joined Il Giornale in accusing the foreign press of siding with the government.

The magazine's latest cover story has ignited a furore by declaring Mr Berlusconi, 64, unfit for office due to his past business dealings and the conflict of interest between his political ambitions and his ownership of media companies.

Mr Berlusconi's holding company, Fininvest, said on Friday it would sue the Economist for libel for detailing his alleged money laundering, bribery, tax evasion and mafia links.

The ruling centre-left coalition, trailing in opinion polls, was euphoric about the criticisms, but Mr Berlusconi's coalition, which held power briefly in 1994, is still expected to win a majority.

webTitle: Pop star photos put NoW on mat again

fields.headline: Pop star photos put NoW on mat again
fields.trailText: Pop singer Noel Sullivan of Hear'Say has complained to the press complaints commission about pictures in the News of the World. By Matt Wells.
fields.body:
The News of the World is again being forced to justify its blatant intrusions into the personal lives of public and private figures in the pursuit of circulation-boosting stories.

A friend of the pop singer Noel Sullivan, of the band Hear'Say, has complained to the press complaints commission about pictures which showed the pair embracing.

The paper's editor, Rebekah Wade, will have to explain why she allowed an ordinary person to be subjected to the glare of publicity in the pursuit of increasingly salacious stories about Sullivan.

Sullivan's friend, 24, whose name and place of work were printed by the NoW, is understood to believe that publication of the pictures was a clear breach of his privacy. He has never courted publicity, and the pictures date from before Sullivan became famous.

Less than a month ago the commission ruled that the paper had intruded on the privacy of stars from the ITV soap Emmerdale by covertly filming their Christmas party, even though no story appeared.

Since the "fake sheikh" affair involving the Countess of Wessex, the NoW's methods have been under scrutiny. Yesterday it backed away from another clash with the commission by not printing pictures of Prince William on holiday.

The feature on Sullivan - headlined, Queer'Say? No, it's just Noel having a bit of fun - is understood to have caused the star and his friend great offence. They were shown together at a nightclub in Ibiza, where the singer worked before his pop career took off with the ITV series Popstars.

Sullivan, 20, has never discussed his private life, and has made it plain to the NoW that he does not intend to. Outside promotional events, he has avoided exploiting his celebrity.

webTitle: BBC unveils South East Today team

fields.headline: BBC unveils South East Today team
fields.trailText:
8.30am: The BBC has announced the presenting line-up for its new regional news programme, South East Today. By Ashley Davies.

Special report: the BBC
fields.body:
The BBC has announced the presenting line-up for its new regional news programme, South East Today.

Laurie Meyer, a veteran BBC reporter who has worked in the past decade on Around Westminster, BBC Breakfast News and the Six O'Clock News, cut his teeth on BBC Radio One's Newsbeat in the 1970s.

The new bulletin covers the Kent and East Sussex regions, and will launch in mid-June.

Mr Meyer will present the 6.30pm evening news and lunchtime programmes, John Young will front the late evening bulletin at 10.25, while Ceri Thompson will host the early morning round-up on the BBC's Breakfast programme.

South-East Today is the product of a shake-up of the BBC's broadcast news programme in the region instituted last year by the BBC's then head of nations and regions, Mark Thompson.

The revamp lead to the rebranding of the BBC's London radio service, GLR, as BBC London Live, a move that was widely condemned.

MediaGuardian.co.uk special report

fields.headline: ITV's peace broker
fields.standfirst: From trucking to television - Gerry Murphy's move to head up Carlton was greeted with bemusement eight months ago. Can he deliver the goods in media? asks  David Teather
fields.trailText: From trucking to television - Gerry Murphy's move to head up Carlton was greeted with bemusement eight months ago. Can he deliver the goods in media? asks David Teather.
fields.body:
Gerry Murphy, the chief executive of Carlton Communications, is doing his best to insist he is a big fan of Crossroads, the company's flagship soap.

When does he get time to watch it? "It's on in the staff cafe at lunchtimes," he says. So who is his favourite character? A pause. "The young chap who showed up on a motorbike in the very first episode. There's this wonderful scene where a young guy on a motorbike put-put-puts into the car park - the bright young thing in the cast." The answer reminds me of English lit students asked to pick a passage from a novel in a seminar. You could always tell who hadn't read the book because they would plump for something from the opening chapter.

When Murphy took the chief executive's job at Carlton last summer, the common, sniffy, question was "Gerry who?" The genial Irishman had little, well no, experience in media and his immediate background had been running the logistics (that's trucking) group National Freight Consortium (NFC).

Eight months later he openly admits he is in no position to make editorial judgments but he has, in a relatively short period, built up a body of corporate work with which to answer the critics, culminating in last week's announcement that Carlton and Granada would work together in digital and online under a single ITV brand.

In February last year, while at NFC, Murphy had played a part in a merger with rival logistics business Ocean, a deal well liked by the City. He cleared the path for his opposite number at Ocean to take the top job and found himself praised for his self-effacement by former NFC chairman and outgoing BBC chief, Sir Christopher Bland. "Ego trips can get in the way of these kind of mergers. It's a tribute to Gerry that this didn't happen," he said at the time.

His departure from NFC, £1.5m the richer, led to a phone call from Carlton chairman Michael Green asking if he would be prepared to join the company if the merger with United fell apart. His predecessor, Steven Cain, had already gone in anticipation of losing his job in the deal.

Murphy joined Carlton in the wake of the aborted merger with Lord Hollick's United News & Media. The merger would have helped the company leapfrog Granada to become the prime force in ITV, but it was blocked, Granada stepped in and Carlton's hopes were dashed. Murphy, 44, had to pick up the pieces. Virtually on his first day he had to play a part in deciding whether Carlton should pursue HTV, which Granada had to sell for regulatory reasons. Then came his first set of negotiations with Steve Morrison, his opposite number at Granada. "A very deep-end experience," Murphy recalls. "The conclusion we came to was that the strategy of three into two was right for ITV and we would be one of those two. We started to negotiate with HTV almost on the first day of my job."

Murphy has gone on to play a significant role in the reshaping of the business. Technicolor was sold for £1.4bn, a far better price than many had believed Carlton would get in the current economic climate.

Many have regarded Murphy's depth of experience in running companies as an important foil to what can euphemistically be described as Green's big personality. Murphy played a significant role in turning around the fortunes of NFC and Green has pretty much left him alone at Carlton, according to insiders. Tellingly, on the day of last week's announcement of the restructuring of ITV, Green left Murphy to face the press as he flew to New York for a meeting.

Murphy describes his relationship with Green as "good". Has he lost his temper with him yet? "We have our moments," he replies. "We're very different and come from very different places every which way, but I think that's what makes it work. You don't work with challenging, demanding, stimulating people without the occasional moment but it's healthy, lively, robust and it's fun.

"There are many misconceptions about Michael. One is that he is a bully and domineering. Well ,he hasn't been. Two, that he is very involved in the day-to-day business. He's not. Three is that he interferes. Actually he doesn't."

Green returns the compliments. "A good relationship between a chairman and a chief executive is vital," he says. "I like working with Gerry because he gets to the point quickly and he makes it fun." Insiders say that with Murphy's arrival they have seen Green relax about the day-to-day business for the first time. According to one ITV source Murphy is "very pragmatic, someone who listens and is without ego, which is probably because he doesn't come from this industry."

The restructuring of ITV will see Carlton and Granada's joint pay television business renamed ITV Digital to exploit the stronger brand. The two companies also announced the launch of website itv.com and ITV Sport, a premium sports channel, the first of many digital channels in the pipelines. ONdigital boss Stuart Prebble was named as ITV chief executive, a post which had lain vacant for the past 15 months. The plan is the closest they are likely to get to a single ITV company for many years to come.

Murphy suggests it was helpful in developing a better relationship between Carlton and Granada that both companies had relatively new chief executives - Steve Morrison took over at Granada when it demerged from the hospitality group last year.

"We're actually pretty complementary," he says. "I'm new to TV, but have been a chief executive for 10 years. Steve has spent his life in TV but is a new chief executive. There are things we can learn from each other. If we'd both been doing our jobs for 10 years I expect it would have been tougher, because that's life. But he and I get on well together."

Morrison says both he and Murphy "came to it with the same attitudes of clearing out the baggage" of old rivalries. "Gerry is very straightforward and very good to deal with," he says.

Few observers doubt the logic of the two companies working more closely together, or of exploiting the ITV brand. But the shares of both fell on the day, principally because of concerns about the future of ONdigital. As long as the markets were going in the right direction investors were happy enough, but in the present climate the amount of cash being soaked up by the business has caused increasing concern. ONdigital has now retrenched and is aiming for a more modest 1.7m customers by 2003/4 against 2m by the end of 2002. From the £300m it said would be invested at launch, the sum spiralled to £1.2bn which it last week cut back to £1.1bn in a nod to shareholders.

Murphy thinks much of the criticism has been unjustified. "I can appreciate the miracle of achieving a subscriber base of 1m in two years from a standing start. Logistically that is nothing short of extraordinary. I don't see ONdigital as a failure. The reason the cash consumption has been higher than originally expected was that the business model changed with Sky's launch of free set-top boxes which changed the rules. The rapid growth of the digital TV market has been significantly fuelled by equipment giveaways. But there are two sides to this. One, we have the highest digital penetration in Europe. Two, it's cost us a lot of money to get there, and it's cost Sky more." Prebble's promotion he says is an endorsement of their belief in the platform. "He has done a phenomenal job in the face of the most aggressive competitor on the planet.

The bigger story here may take some time to be properly understood. We have combined the most powerful information and marketing medium in the UK, ITV, with new digital channels, with a new internet proposition and with a pay platform. And that is unique. Given the power of that brand and the sheer visibility of ITV - 90% of all people in the UK watch ITV every week - that is an extraordinary presence. We can do most of the things that a single ITV can do by constructive cooperation, which is why we put in place the measures we did. Full merger of the ITV businesses is, I expect, a long way off."

The other thing spoiling Murphy's party is the decline of the advertising market which has affected ITV more acutely than any other media outlet. The decline in advertising this year and digital doubts have dragged Carlton's share price down from a high of 865p to 417p on Friday. Murphy, though, is sanguine. "It's a great irony. The thing that matters most in our business is ratings, and as an investor and manager the thing that gives me most pleasure is when ITV delivers enormous audiences, which it has done so far this year. Revenues will go up and down, but as long as we keep delivering good audiences our business is in good shape. We were first into the softening economy and we'll be first out."

As for his credentials to work in the media, a press cutting culled from the FT in 1995 shows the world of trucks was no less suspicious when he arrived there. It's a comfort to know that snobbery is not confined to luvvies. "When Gerry Murphy, chief executive of Greencore, the Irish food group, was appointed as the new chief executive of NFC on Wednesday, the reaction from most of the transport and logistics group's shareholders was 'Gerry who?'" it reads. "His selection, with no experience of the logistics industry was something of a gamble."

fields.headline: My media
fields.standfirst: Richard Branson
fields.trailText: Richard Branson
fields.body:
Newspapers: I read the Times, the Sun, the Independent and the Guardian, but am not a great fan of the Daily Mail. I enjoy Sunday Business, which gets exclusive stories which would normally go to the Sunday Times.

Magazines: I'm not a great magazine reader but I'll look at the Economist, Time and Newsweek if I'm on a plane or something.

Television: I love Discovery Channel, Have I Got News for You? and Question Time. I've probably seen most episodes of Friends with my children - and I even appeared in it once.

Books: I'm reading Anthony Sampson's biography of Nelson Mandela, who I am meeting in South Africa this week. I'd like to finish it before meeting the man. The book is superb and takes a dispassionate look at his life. I'm also waiting to read Captain Correlli's Mandolin before seeing the film.

Radio: Still enjoy Chris Evans. We know each other, and I've watched him over the years go from being outrageous to being very entertaining. I've got to the age when I tune in to Radio 4 more than Virgin, and my kids like Radio 1, which is very disloyal of them, so we always have a battle over that.

Films: Traffic was slightly disappointing after such a big build up, but I enjoyed Enemy at the Gates. My all-time favourite is an old gangster film called Borsolino.

Adverts: The new Mercedes advert, with all the faces saying how they appreciate their lives, is excellent. The ones that get on my nerves completely are the American-style ads for compensation, which ask if you've fallen off a ladder recently. It's ghastly, and done so badly.

New Media: I'm not enormously technical; in fact, I'm terrified of computers, having once wiped out all my work. I write every conversation that I have down in my old-fashioned notebooks and that's the way I manage to get everything done in the day.

Richard Branson announced Virgin Mobile's sponsorship of the Sun cartoon strip, Warbury Town, last week.

fields.headline: Impure genius
fields.standfirst: His Guinness Surfer ad is one of a clutch of commercials which any director would kill to have on their CV. But Jonathan Glazer tells  James Hamilton  that despite it all he's in the wrong business - and it makes him angry
fields.trailText: His Guinness Surfer ad is one of a clutch of commercials which any director would kill to have on their CV. But Jonathan Glazer tells James Hamilton that despite it all he's in the wrong business - and it makes him angry.
fields.body:
Maybe it's the fact that his beloved Arsenal's Champions League bid fizzled out like a Junior Disprin the night before, but Jonathan Glazer is in a contemplative mood when we meet. His main concern isn't the football, though. It's his new commercial for Guinness - Dream Club - and whether or not the advert is leaving audiences a little bewildered. Could this just be that sense of deflation you get when you finish a job?

"It's a particularly flat feeling because I don't think I nailed it," says Glazer. "I don't think it doesn't work, but I think there's a certain thing I wanted out of it that I don't think I achieved."

With directors there's a clear distinction between those for whom directing is a very personal experience and those able to take on commercial work, distance themselves from it, and produce what the client wants, earning a healthy fee in the process. Glazer is clearly of the former school and is brutally honest in his opinion of his work: it rarely hits exactly what he's looking for. But it's not the final result so much as the medium he's working in - Glazer doesn't feel advertising requires the kind of depths he wants to take it to. He's not an adman.

The irony is, of course, that in his quest for perfection he's come up with some of the best adverts in recent years, although this not a fact he seems particularly proud of.

"I'm angry that I've landed for the early part of my career in that field - yes, of course it's given me incredible benefits: a house, holidays when I want holidays. For fuck's sake, I have nothing to complain about other than the fact that I'm in an area which demands something of me which I'm uncomfortable with, which is like: 'We don't want it to be that emotional, we don't want it to be that honest, we don't want it to be a truthful piece of work, we just want to sell our jeans thank you very much.' They're willing to cut off at that point and I'm not. So I'm kind of in the wrong business.

"Advertising has never been something that I've aspired to and has never been something that I've driven myself towards," he says. The pleasure he derived from having his surfer commercial voted as best ever by the readers of the Sunday Times and Channel 4 viewers is because it's a public vote of confidence, not a dry industry panel choosing to anoint one director over another. He also points out that polls are often about timing.

But the mere fact that we're sitting talking about a commercial that is now nearly two years old is testament to the fact that in some way it has managed to transcend that notion of timing.

Glazer's showreel views like a dream CV for most directors - the Guinness Swimmer advert; the Stella Artois Jean de Florette pastiches; music videos for Radiohead's Street Spirit and Karma Police and, of course, Guinness Surfer. But he's not a man to rest on his laurels or re-tread a safe path. Its black-and-white film stock and voice-over artist apart, Dream Club is about as far removed from the atavistic simplicity of Surfer as a director can get.

"Surfer was immediately accessi ble - it was one for the boys. It's a dream scenario for somebody who's paying a million quid to have their pint advertised, and the pressures are to repeat that," he says.

While he claims not to have felt any external pressure to come up with something that would trump Surfer, he gives the impression that he was impatient with the whole idea of doing something again and probably afraid that he wouldn't enjoy himself in the process. The last thing he wanted to do, he says, was create a rod for his back by trying to remake the advert.

Glazer's career began in the cutting room, creating TV trailers for films. A skill which has probably shaped his ability to tell a story in a short time. "You're telling stories in cuts, you're being succinct. And there's an energy and pace that comes from that you could say is a bad habit," he explains.

A bad habit, perhaps, but an essential skill when it comes to creating a commercial. When I press for his slant on his success, he's quick to cite the team behind him. He says that only painters and writers have the ability to produce great work without collaborating. He says he can't do it.

"The things I've made in commercials I've only been able to do because of those collaborations," he says, going on to point out that on his cur rent commercial he had another sack of Guinness's money to spend relatively freely. When three scenes he'd shot were dropped from the final cut Guinness were informed, not asked - a job left to the commercial's writer, Walter Campbell from Abbott Mead Vickers, who smooths these decisions over with the client.

"I can only read the colour of his face every time I see him to realise what battles he goes through. I couldn't have made it without him," claims Glazer.

He predicts that Dream Club is his last Guinness commercial and admits that if the film projects were there and rolled into production in the same way that his commercials and promos work has, he'd give up adverts all together.

Last year he directed his first feature - Sexy Beast, a gangster film which garnered critical acclaim and managed to stand out from the crop of Brit gangster flicks around at the time. Glazer was, of course, unhappy with the film.

"I remember reading this Gore Vidal thing the other day and he said he was watching a film and it was like 40 commercials looking for a product. I thought: 'God forbid that I should be that.' The films I admire aren't that, and the films I want to make aren't that. But Sexy Beast, to an extent, was that."

Glazer's fear is that he's not going to be able to make the transition into what he really wants to be and claims he'd rather drive a cab than do anything in a mediocre way.

Is he just another commercials director with a craving for film credibility? "To be honest with you, it's not a new thing at all," he says, citing directors like Ridley and Tony Scott, conceding that the work that ex-advert directors are producing is probably better and more influential than it used to be.

One of the curses of being a perfectionist is never being able to see the wood for the trees - audiences, peers and judging panels enjoy something in Glazer's work which he remains unhappy about. Industry gongs such as his unprecedented two D&AD gold arrows for That Advert go some way to ameliorating a feeling of anger at being left stranded in the commercials market, but the ability to get out and make work without any limitations is what really matters to Glazer, a freedom he's only really experienced in his music video work.

"If you're working with an artist who has the confidence to know what they're about, then it's you and them and that's it, the business takes care of itself because it's a better product ultimately, so they sell more albums and everyone's happy. As long as they do that it affords you choice and freedom."

He believes he'll get this freedom with his next film. It's unclear which of the three projects he's currently working will make it, but the most interesting would be a collaboration with veteran French screenwriter Jean-Claude Carrière (The Tin Drum, Belle de Jour). Glazer doesn't want to talk in detail about it, but at its simplest it's a personal project about a 10-year-old boy falling in love with a 35-year-old woman. It will, of course, be made with Glazer's near obsessional attention to detail. Something he feels he'll never get with commercials, a situation he's obviously wrestling with.

fields.headline: Man with no tie shock
fields.standfirst: Bruce Haines wants advertising to ditch the suited and booted image and embrace its fluffy side.  Claire Cozens  reckons the new president of adland's trade body can make everyone dress down
fields.trailText: Bruce Haines wants advertising to ditch the suited and booted image and embrace its fluffy side. Claire Cozens reckons the new president of adland's trade body can make everyone dress down.
fields.body:
Advertising agencies have traditionally been made up of two distinct breeds of people: the creatives and the suits. The creatives make the ads and the suits deal with the clients who, so the received wisdom goes, will feel more comfortable dealing with a smooth-tongued university graduate in a designer suit than some temperamental visionary.

It is a system that Bruce Haines, the new president of the institute of practitioners in advertising (IPA), wants to change. He has put promoting creative talent at the top of his agenda, believing that in its desperation to ditch its fluffy image and be viewed as a grown up business, advertising has relegated its most saleable aspect.

That might seem obvious, but it is a pretty radical rethink for an industry that has spent the last few years trying to prove the effectiveness of what it does in scientific terms.

Haines plans to start the process by getting creative people more involved in the IPA, which currently has just two agency creative directors serving on its council.

He seems perfectly placed to do so. As chairman of Leagas Delaney, Haines runs one of Britain's most creative advertising agencies, responsible for Adidas and Barclay's campaigns and for the BBC's award-winning promotional film Perfect Day. Leagas Delaney is also the only major British agency to have a creative, Tim Delaney, as its chief executive.

There was initial scepticism about the willingness of creative types to become involved in a trade body. But since he called for support in a speech last week, Haines has been bombarded with emails from creative directors expressing their willingness to participate. One had filled in the subject field with the words, "stating the bleeding obvious". The creative contingent is clearly hungry for change.

"It seems to me a nonsense that you could have an advertising trade body with no role for creative people," he says. It is the one subject during our conversation on which Haines speaks with obvious passion. A naturally self-effacing character, at Leagas Delaney he is regarded as the calm that follows the famously explosive Delaney's storm.

The pair first teamed up in 1986, when Haines was invited to be managing director of Leagas Delaney. Under the creative directorship of Delaney the agency was producing great work, but it was struggling commercially. Since then it has gone from being a small London agency employing 25 people to a multinational company with offices in Paris, Rome and San Francisco.

But, unlike many agency chairmen, Haines is still not particularly well known, preferring to stay out of the limelight.

The contrast with Rupert Howell, Haines' predecessor at the IPA, could hardly be more marked. Haines is low-profile, Howell a famous self-publicist. Haines grew up in a council house in Wales, Howell is an old Wellingtonian. Haines is into fashion and the arts, Howell is a big sports fan.

"Someone as dynamic as Rupert was always going to be a hard act to follow," says John Bartle, one of the founders of Bartle Bogle Hegarty and, as a former IPA president, one of those who nominated Haines for the job. "You obviously don't set out to find someone different to the last person, but you want someone with a strong agenda of their own. Bruce is thoughtful, he's very popular, and in the end he met all the criteria."

Haines is all too aware of the inevitable comparisons with his predecessor, but says he is happy to be the public face of the advertising industry.

"It would be true to say that Rupert is a very outgoing character - I am less so," he says with deliberate understatement. "But I doubt that there are any issues where you could get a cigarette paper between us in terms of our attitudes. What we have is a vastly different style of expressing some of those views. But we share a determination to modernise and to get things done." He'll need some of that determination to steer the industry through what looks like being a difficult year for advertising, and some may well feel that focusing on creativity is a case of fiddling while Rome burns.

The economic slowdown, the ever-present threat to advertising aimed at children, the planned ban on tobacco advertising and the continuing encroachment of other marketing disciplines such as PR and online marketing are just a few of the issues to be tackled.

Haines admits that the prospect of a recession is preoccupying the industry at the moment. Across the Atlantic, tales of advertising agency redundancies and even closures abound and, as Sir Martin Sorrell is so fond of saying, when the US sneezes we all catch a cold.

But for now at least, Haines is upbeat. "At the beginning of the year, many people were genuinely expecting quite a substantial downturn. It has not been our experience that that is coming through," he says. "Lessons have been learned from previous times in the economy where people slashed their budgets only to find they had to spend twice as much to regain their position when market conditions improved."

The ebullient Howell presided over a boom time for advertising agencies, thanks to the spending frenzy of technology companies and the dot.coms. Now, agencies are tightening their belts and there is a feeling of uncertainty in the air. It may be more by accident than design, but Haines' quiet authority seems somehow in tune with the times.

fields.headline: My New Media
fields.standfirst: Delia Smith
fields.trailText: Delia Smith
fields.body:
What are your favourite websites?

My favourite is the Norwich City Football Club site, where I can keep up to date with the fans and team news. I spend so much time travelling from London to my home in Suffolk, so the Railtrack timetable is also bookmarked on our computer. I'm also impressed with BBC Online, which covers a massive range of subjects from the local weather to the latest world news.

What was your last online purchase?

My latest purchase was a couple of cases of wine from Berry Brothers. They arrived exactly on time and the wine was delicious.

Have you ever been in a chat room?

I'm live once a week on deliaonline.com. I really enjoy chatting with our members, and I learn an awful lot.

What was your last technological faux pas?

I am the most un-technological person in the world so it's difficult for me to even make a faux pas. I don't get that far.

What news source do you use on the web?

I don't really look to the web for my news information on a regular basis but if I did it would be BBC Online.

What is the most useful website?

I like using savvysearch.com. All you need to do is type in the subject, no matter how obscure it is, it searches all the engines and hey presto comes up with a list of websites! It saves loads of time, and it couldn't be easier to use.

What kind of site is least likely to succeed?

Anything that isn't user-friendly, hasn't got lots of worthwhile information and which has no one's personal drive behind it.

What is the least useful site?

Any site just created on someone's whim. I never saw it but I was told about a site that set out to match lost gloves. It would have been easier to buy a new pair, for heaven's sake.

Do you use a screensaver ?

No.

What do you find most irritating about the internet?

My eyesight isn't what is used to be, and I do find it hard to read some sites - particularly the ones that use weird colour combinations.

Do you still use old media?

I certainly do. Although I'm awestruck by the potential of the internet, it will never replace other forms of communication. They said television would kill off the written word. Well, it hasn't yet.

www.deliaonline.com

fields.headline: Geeks
fields.trailText: What happens when the spotty teenager with an obsessive interest in computer games and science fiction grows up? They get married and lead a life of domestic bliss in suburbia. Geeks now make up 3% of the UK adult population, some 1.37m individuals, a fifth of them female.
fields.body:
What happens when the spotty teenager with an obsessive interest in computer games and science fiction grows up? They get married and lead a life of domestic bliss in suburbia. Geeks now make up 3% of the UK adult population, some 1.37m individuals, a fifth of them female.

Has age taught them any fashion sense? No. Clothes are bought for comfort and practicality and fashion remains an irrelevance. Own-brand labels will always be bought in preference to high-street brands, and geeks see no merit in attempting to look stylish. The geek dismisses the importance of being attractive to the opposite sex.

So what media do they consume? The geek has a keen interest in current affairs. Television is an important source of information, if only for a daily glimpse of the BBC or ITV evening news bulletins. Radio is particularly popular; geeks spend a considerable amount of the working day in their cars. Middle-of-the-road rock stations with news updates entertain the typical geek for up to three hours a day.

Presumably geeks are right up there with the digital revolution? Many geeks have access to satellite and cable TV channels but these are rarely used for prolonged viewing. Geeks prefer to be entertained rather than stimulated. Sport is popular - especially formula one and football - as are EastEnders, Coronation Street and The Simpsons. "I look forward to a night in front of the box after a day at work. It doesn't really matter what's on - it's just nice to unwind," is a typical Geek comment.

Do they like any other media? Geeks are not big magazine readers and, for the most part, newspaper supplements satisfy any demands for additional reading. Cinema is even less important - 20% of geeks haven't been to watch a movie in the past three months and 40% claim that they "never go to the cinema these days".

Are geeks still big technology buffs? Geeks are not that ahead of the game when it comes to new gadgets. Just over a third claim to "keep up with advances in technology" and only slightly more have internet access at home. It seems their love of gadgets is hampered by income. "I like to play around with gadgets, but don't really get the time these days. Money, I suppose, means that I can't buy new stuff when it comes out but by the time I can afford it something is else is out and I'll think 'yeah, I'll wait and buy that'," is a typical observation.

Data supplied by MediaCom

fields.headline: New Media Diary
fields.trailText: • After all his internet ups and downs at the turn of the year, Lord Hollick must now be breathing a huge sigh of relief. Last week, he at last managed to rid himself of the albatross around his neck. Yes, LineOne was finally sold after five months of being on the market, but for the knock-down bargain price of £62m. In puny recompense for years of expansion, promotion and boundless funding, the two parties - United Business Media and BT - only got £6.2m apiece to bank, and £24.9m in Italian internet giant Tiscali shares. It's a bargain considering that LineOne's original asking price was £250m. After a spending spree, Tiscali is now the UK's fourth largest ISP, so isn't it about time it started to flex its branding muscles over here?
fields.body:
 After all his internet ups and downs at the turn of the year, Lord Hollick must now be breathing a huge sigh of relief. Last week, he at last managed to rid himself of the albatross around his neck. Yes, LineOne was finally sold after five months of being on the market, but for the knock-down bargain price of £62m. In puny recompense for years of expansion, promotion and boundless funding, the two parties - United Business Media and BT - only got £6.2m apiece to bank, and £24.9m in Italian internet giant Tiscali shares. It's a bargain considering that LineOne's original asking price was £250m. After a spending spree, Tiscali is now the UK's fourth largest ISP, so isn't it about time it started to flex its branding muscles over here?

 Speaking of flexing muscles, Formula One baron Bernie Ecclestone is getting even tougher on a small British dot.com which runs the unofficial site of F1 racing, Formula1.com. Lawsuits have been flying around since last year, but the latest witnesses Bernie trying to counteract a Formula1.com damages claim by attempting to wrest away control of the domain name. fields.headline: Media monkey
fields.trailText: • Media Monkey took a horrified call from a top ITV source last week. It seems that Crossroads, the invisible soap, is having a terrible time - gathering only a 4.4% share for its lunchtime showing last Wednesday in the Tyne Tees area. Monkey's motel insider whispered "This is a historic low", but had to rush off to find a petrol can and some matches. Something about an insurance scam?

fields.headline: The great libel saga
fields.standfirst: The longest-running libel action in the British courts involves a specialist newsletter, Africa Confidential, being sued by a group of Saudi businessmen.  Brian Whitaker  and David Pallister  on why the case has lasted six years
fields.trailText: The longest-running libel action in the British courts involves a specialist newsletter, Africa Confidential, being sued by a group of Saudi businessmen. Brian Whitaker and David Pallister on why the case has lasted six years.
fields.body:
Despite the streamlining of civil libel cases by the Woolf reforms, which were designed to speed up a torturous process, one unusual libel action remains on the books almost six years after it began. It involves a specialist fortnightly newsletter, Africa Confidential, and a group of Saudi businessmen who were not even named in the offending article.

Within the next two weeks the newsletter - which has so far spent £300,000 preparing its defence - will ask the High Court to strike out the case on the grounds of extreme delay and failure by the plaintiffs to provide documentary evidence of the link at the heart of their complaint. The hearing will be an important test of the new Civil Procedure Rules, which are intended to save time and costs, while dealing with cases fairly.

Last week, several libel lawyers said that they were aware of only one other case which has been outstanding for so long: Khilili v Bennett, which was struck out in 1999 but later reinstated on appeal.

The Africa Confidential case arose out of a report on the attempt to assassinate President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt during a visit to Ethiopia in June 1995. The article said the Ethiopian authorities had "arrested a Sudanese, Siraj Mohamed Hussein, who claimed to work for the Addis branch of Moafak el Hairiya [Blessed Relief]", which it described as an "agency" of the National Islamic Front government in Sudan.

Whether Moafak el Hairiya is in fact an agency of the government will be decided if and when the case comes to court.

On August 1995, Peter Carter-Ruck, the London libel specialists, issued a writ against Blackwell Publishers (the owners of Africa Confidential) and the newsletter's editor on behalf of six Saudi businessmen. The Saudis claimed that the article defamed them because they were the trustees of the relief organisation concerned.

Three days after receiving the writ, Africa Confidential's lawyers wrote back asking the plaintiffs to identify themselves properly. The defendants say they have repeated this demand many times since then, but without success. They also say that the plaintiffs - despite having provided some 500 documents - have still not provided adequate information, such as their full names and home addresses. Besides that, the defendants say, they have failed to establish their connection with the Sudanese Moafak el Hairiya.

On the other side, the plaintiffs say that they are trustees of Muwafaq Foundation, registered in Jersey, and directors of a company called Muwaffaq [sic] Limited, which is registered in the Isle of Man.

The connection between these bodies and the relief organisation in Sudan and Ethiopia is a matter of dispute. The view at Africa Confidential is that the complainants have not disclosed documents which corroborate their assertions that they control Moafak el Hairiya, or that any links they may have with the Sudanese organisation were sufficiently well known for readers to identify them.

Commenting on delays in the case, Patrick Smith, the newsletter's editor, says: "At the outset the complainants said they wanted an urgent remedy but there has not been much sign of it. We haven't even got down to exchanging witness statements. It's normally up to plaintiffs to set the pace. Obviously defendants are not going to push things forward and run up costs unless they are sure the plaintiffs are going to take the case to trial."

Solicitors for the plaintiffs, Peter Carter-Ruck and Partners did not respond to the Guardian's requests for a comment on the cause of the delay last week.

Several media lawyers were amazed to hear that the case is still running after almost six years. Geraldine Proudler, of solicitors Olswang, says: "That's a hell of a long time. In the past, if someone was delaying and the other side allowed it, a case could just drag on for ever. But with the reform of High Court rules everything has speeded up and the courts are supposed to be much more interventionist in moving cases along. The length of time still varies. It can take a year, but not six years, for an ordinary case."

In cases which have started since the new rules came into force, both sides submit copies of their documents to the court, which monitors progress. This would not necessarily happen with an old case, Proudler says - unless one side or the other alerted the court to delays.

In the other long-running case, Khilili v Bennett, a London art dealer sued the Evening Standard and the Mail on Sunday over articles published in January 1995 about his likely arrest for possession of a stolen ancient Persian helmet. Nothing happened in the case between March 1996 and May 1999, when the plaintiff served a notice of intention to proceed. The defendants successfully applied to have the case struck out.

This was the first defamation case to be struck out, under the new rules, for want of prosecution, but the Appeal Court overturned the judge's decision and reinstated it. Although courts have a duty to ensure that cases are dealt with expeditiously, their overriding duty is to ensure that justice is done.

The art dealer's explanation was that he had been waiting for the outcome of a criminal case in France before going ahead with his libel action. The Appeal Court agreed that awaiting criminal proceedings that were relevant to the case was a good reason for the delay.

fields.headline: Selling the same old story
fields.standfirst: South Africa may be a country which is trying to put its racist past behind it, but  Jacques Peretti  finds that its admen are still peddling depressing apartheid-era bigotry
fields.trailText: South Africa may be a country which is trying to put its racist past behind it, but Jacques Peretti finds that its admen are still peddling depressing apartheid-era bigotry.
fields.body:
There's a South African ad for an insurance company and it goes like this: a hospital cleaner shuffles into the intensive care unit. She's black. She looks round for somewhere to plug in her vacuum cleaner, and guess what happens next? It'll kill you. She unplugs the patient.

As lights flash and sirens wail, white nurses rush in to resuscitate the patient and the cleaner sails blissfully off down the corridor. "Expect the unexpected" is the pay-off line. In Britain, the ad would be banned, but in South Africa it won an award.

Channel 4 is showing some of these award-winning ads each night this week as part of the South Africa Celebrates festival. Ironically for a country trying to put its racist past behind it, the first thing that strikes you is how racist many of the ads are.

Apartheid may have fallen apart in 1994, promising a new start for the country and an economic boom fuelled by the creation of a black middle class, but is this black middle class being served by advertising? The president may be black, but in adverts white businessmen still run the country, serviced by cleaners who live in happy-clappy townships.

The plot for the typical township ad goes like this: poor black kids play cricket with cans, parents laughing in slow-mo on the porch. It all looks very expensive and tasteful, and is shot, naturally, in black and white. In fantasy township, there is no poverty. Instead, the experience of growing up without electricity or running water is sentimentalised into a Soweto version of the Hovis ad.

It's no accident that the kids play cricket. Sport provides one of the few black/white crossovers in the new South Africa: an area relatively free from racial tension and thus perfect for advertisers. An ad for sports drink Isatonic Game also capitalises on sport, showing two rugby players - one black, one white - taking time out to compare injuries. "I broke my arm scrumming, man" says the white bloke. "That's nothing, I snapped my arm in two places. You should have seen it hanging," replies the black guy.

Take away the South African accents and it could have been made in Britain. Unlike fantasy township ads, the Isatonic Game campaign makes no reference to the past, and sees nothing uncomfortable about a white and black man arguing over who has hurt the other more. It's as if apartheid never happened.

Castle Lager also uses the buddy tactic. A black man and a white man get to know one another, not as a result of a car-jacking or mugging, but over a pint of beer and a game of cricket. In the ad, they discuss the intricacies of the Timeless Test - a legendary South African cricket victory over the English in 1938. The ad disingenuously claims the moment as a source of equal pride for black and white.

Aside from the friendly arena of sport, most South African ads are suffused with an undercurrent of paranoia. The threat of black violence towards the white minority permeates every campaign: bolted doors, patrolling dogs defending gated communities and dark figures cocking guns in the shadows appear even in ads for toilet paper and popcorn.

In an ad for online shopping service, thelot.co.za, a woman in an antique shop pops open a bottle of wine and the customers drop to the floor, pulling guns. A teaching service promoting a Zulu course for whites holds out the promise that speaking Zulu will prevent you getting mugged.

South African commercials are never more than a trigger's click from race. In one natural history spectacular for clothing firm Men of Africa, a black man becomes a wild animal and says: "Never underestimate me or doubt my pride, because I am a man of Africa," while flanked by a stuffed lion and a zebra drape.

Afrikaner history is also a rich vein for advertisers. German car manufacturer VW uses the founding myth of the nation: the Boer trek to freedom from the British, crossing the Orange River to found the Orange Free State, in order to advertise saloon cars. In Afrikaans, as in German, the initials VW stand for people's wagon, a phrase explicitly invoking the spirit of the Boer wagon train. In an ad for the Passat, a white South African man bonds with his son over the wheel of the family saloon, passing on the baton of the Boer pioneers by demonstrating how to escape a car-jacking with some nifty handbrake turns.

Not surprisingly, multinationals take a far safer course with the black consumer, often using the vast scale of the country as a metaphor for virgin land untouched by capitalist hand. Coca-Cola's ads, for instance, drop bottles of fizzy drink on happy children, as if they were distributing UN aid.

Indigenous South African advertising may appear comparatively unpolished (the country has only had an industry to speak of since the late 70s), but at least it tackles the subject of race without recourse to bland global images. In a campaign for Scalextric, a black baby is born to a white couple (surprise!); and in an ad for a fast food outlet, a black boss drives a group of white workers on top of his van. "Here's something else you've never seen before," says the tag-line.

Keen to promote itself abroad, the South African Tourist Board uses the country's best known brand, Nelson Mandela, fronting an epic multiracial tableau featuring, inevitably, lots of children. Very similar, in fact, to the kind of ad we could see for Tony Blair in a month's time.

The last word, however, must go to the ultimate promo for South Africa, made by Castle Lager. Shot on a Manhattan roof terrace, 20-something ex-pats enact the sacred rituals of South African life: beer, barbecue and male bonding. It's modern, it's multiracial and it's got Africa by Toto on the stereo. Most importantly, for young South Africans, it takes place in a country that isn't South Africa.

Jacques Peretti is the producer of Advertising South Africa which begins on Channel 4 tonight at 7.55pm

fields.headline: Message mania on MTV
fields.trailText: 8.30am: MTV is hoping to cash in on text messaging mania by introducing text messaging services on all its channels, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
MTV is hoping to cash in on text messaging mania by becoming the first broadcaster to introduce text messaging services across all of its channels.

Since February viewers have been able to request tracks on many MTV channels by text message.

The service has been so popular the broadcaster wants to extend it to all MTV channels.

"It wasn't expected to be as successful as it was, so now they're looking at integrating SMS into other shows," said a spokesman.

Unlike the internet, text messaging does not drag viewers away from the TV.

According to MTV figures, the service appears to be boosting ratings, with the number of viewers increasing from 295,000 to 500,000 per show.

The 25,000 text messages received each show on average has prompted MTV to change its afternoon schedule to give it three interactive shows.

These include the daily chart show and MTV Select, hosted by George Clooney's girlfriend, Lisa Snowdon, both of which allow for voting, requests and song dedications.

MTV claims to be the only TV company using SMS for live shows, although other broadcasters have tested it.

The BBC has said it is looking at developing SMS elements for its shows while Channel 5 ran a campaign for viewers to enter an SMS competition around the weekly "blockbuster movie", which dwarfed the internet side of the campaign sixfold.

Last year Channel 4 did a basic news service for Big Brother by SMS, while BSkyB is also said to be looking at developing SMS strategies for programmes.

fields.headline: TV still top advertising medium
fields.trailText: 8.30am: TV advertising is still by far the most effective advertising medium according to research, reports Ashley Davies.
fields.body:
The TV advertising market may be going through a rough patch but it is still by far the most effective advertising medium, according to research from the Chartered Institute of Marketing.

The research, published today, confirms that terrestrial TV is still streets ahead of other media in terms of recall and goodwill.

It also suggests advertising on posters is worryingly ineffectual.

"The internet and other new media have now moved into the mainstream as an essential element in the marketing mix," said a spokeswoman for the CIM.

"However, it is clear that the new media have a long way to go before they are as important to advertisers as television."

The figures come at a time when terrestrial broadcasters are bracing themselves for a slump in advertising revenue.

Merrill Lynch last month warned it expected ITV's advertising revenues to dip by up to 20% year on year

Three-quarters of respondents to the CIM's research said they never saw adverts on digital TV, mobile phones or internet banners.

The same number of people did remember seeing a TV advert within the last day.

Three-quarters said they found TV advertisements interesting, informative and a source of entertainment.

Only 7% said the same of newspaper adverts, 5% for radio and an alarmingly low 2% for posters.

Half of those interviewed said they would respond to a TV advert. But only 14% would respond to adverts in newspapers or magazines, 3% to radio and 1% to posters.

fields.headline: Alarm at superstate plan
fields.standfirst:
Eurosceptics attack Schröder vision of a federal Europe

Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: Eurosceptics attack Schröder vision of a federal Europe.
fields.byline: John Hooper in Berlin and Patrick Wintour in London
fields.body:
A blueprint drawn up by Germany's chancellor, Gerhard Schröder, putting forward a radical vision of a federal Europe, last night elicited an appalled response from Eurosceptics.

It envisages a superstate with its own unelected ministers, its own indirectly elected president and a two-chamber parliament with full control over public spending.

The plan creates a huge headache for Tony Blair and Robin Cook as the prime minister and his foreign secretary gear up for a general election. It will allow the Conservatives to claim that the government's friends in Europe are working on ideas which would make a mockery of national sovereignty.

By a coincidence that elicited groans from Labour MPs, the German chancellor's proposals are to be discussed by his party colleagues in Berlin next month on the day Mr Blair is due to visit the city for a meeting of the Party of European Socialists.

Francis Maude, the shadow foreign secretary, said: "We strongly disagree with Chancellor Gerhard Schröder, but at least he has the courage of his convictions.

"Tony Blair doesn't want to talk about his vision of the EU because he knows how out of touch Labour is on Europe with the mainstream majority of the British people." A report in today's edition of the news magazine, Der Spiegel, says that the draft envisages turning the unelected European commission into a government with wide-ranging powers.

It would be headed by a president chosen by one or both of the chambers in a remodelled European parliament. The existing legislature would become the lower house. The council of ministers, the existing forum for national governments, would become an upper house.

National governments would choose representatives to speak for them in the upper house so that national leaders like the British prime minister and the French president would, in effect, become Euro-senators. The European parliament as a whole would have "full control" over the central government's spending.

There was no immediate response from Downing Street, but proposals to make the council of ministers a second chamber clash with Mr Blair's idea that national parliamentarians should form a second chamber and act as a brake on centralisation. Mr Blair has, however, supported the idea of developing the council of ministers and strengthening financial controls over the EU. France and Spain have both expressed deep reluctance to follow Germany down the road to a federal Europe. But the plan is likely to be given a warm reception at the commission. And it holds out to Mr Schröder the tantalising prospect of a place in history as the spiritual father of a united continent.

Mr Schröder's plan for a superstate is contained in one of five policy papers being prepared for the conference in November of his Social Democratic party (SPD). The chancellor took personal responsibility for the preparation of the paper that deals with Europe.

webTitle: China will allow US to 'inspect' spy plane

fields.headline: China will allow US to 'inspect' spy plane
fields.standfirst:
Gesture will allow talks on 'compensation' to begin

Special report: China
Special report: George Bush's America
Special report: Taiwan and China
fields.trailText: China is to let the US inspect its spy plane on Hainan island, having completed its own "investigation and collection of evidence" in the month since the EP-3 was forced to land after a mid-air collision with a Chinese fighter jet.
fields.body:
China is to let the US inspect its spy plane on Hainan island, having completed its own "investigation and collection of evidence" in the month since the EP-3 was forced to land after a mid-air collision with a Chinese fighter jet.

The concession will allow negotiations on the clash to move forward, but it comes as as US-China relations deteriorate in the wake of the US decision to sell more weapons to Taiwan.

The US will be allowed to inspect the plane at Lingshui airport on Hainan", the Chinese news agency continued, with out suggesting that the plane would be returned as the US has demanded.

It said the US had agreed "to consider making payments to China", presumably for the loss of the Chinese fighter, whose dead pilot is being hailed as a national hero.

"The two sides will conduct another round of negotiations on the specific amount of the US payment and the items to be covered," it said.

The US vice-president, Dick Cheney, said it was an "encouraging sign, but denied that Washington had agreed to reimburse China for any costs other than those concerning the "recovery of the aircraft".

"We certainly have not offered any compensation other than the costs [of recovery]", he said."They obviously got a good look at the aircraft - but I see it as an encouraging sign that they are willing to proceed."

The Chinese parliament is discussing a law on "national defence education" in primary and secondary schools and colleges which will stress the humiliations suffered by China in the past and the continued existence of "US hegemonism".

One MP has proposed creating a special day for national study on September 7, the 100th anniversary of the treaty which China was forced to sign after the failure of the Boxer Rebellion against the foreign settlements in China.

Although the arms sales to Taiwan announced last week excluded the most sensitive items, such as the Aegis radar combat system, any moderating effect that might have had was offset by President Bush's tough remarks about defending the island in the event of an attack from the mainland.

Senior Chinese officials who are committed to a long-term relationship with the US find the shift away from Washington's previous "constructive ambiguity" on Taiwan increasingly hard to explain.

Another area of confrontation has emerged with China's demand that Washington should refuse to allow the Taiwanese president, Chen Shui-bian, to visit the US next month. It was revealed at the weekend that Taiwan's foreign minister, Tien Hung-mao, has left for the US to arrange Mr Chen's visit.

While insisting on the right to use armed force in the last re sort if Taiwan finally rejects reunification, Beijing has made a new offer of talks with the offshore island.

Wang Daohan, the Chinese official who arranged the 1992 understanding with Taiwan, says the mainland is willing to resume talks based upon that understanding, "without [making] any new demands."

webTitle: Skopje peace talks in peril after massacre of patrol

fields.headline: Skopje peace talks in peril after massacre of patrol
fields.standfirst: Special report: Macedonia
fields.trailText: Talks aimed at ending the conflict in Macedonia were in doubt yesterday after eight members of the security forces were killed in an ambush near the Kosovan border, and a further six injured.
fields.body:
Talks aimed at ending the conflict in Macedonia were in doubt yesterday after eight members of the security forces were killed in an ambush near the Kosovan border, and a further six injured.

The attack on Saturday on a joint patrol of 16 soldiers and police officers was the most serious single incident since fighting erupted in February, and ended a month-long lull.

It put a serious question against negotiations between the government and opposition parties for a new coalition which, it was thought, could pave the way for many of the reforms sought by the ethnic Albanian minority.

Reports that the ambush victims' had been mutilated further reduced that prospect.

The incident was discussed at an emergency cabinet meeting yesterday afternoon and the national security council, which encompasses the army, police, intelligence services and the presidents office, was due to decide last night what action to take.

Officials said the patrol was ambushed near Vejce village, 12 miles north of Tetovo.

"They were hit by everything," said Nikola Dimitrov, security adviser to President Boris Trajkovski. "They used hand grenades, rocket launchers and machine guns."

He said the guerrilla's had gone out of their way to disfigure the corpses. "It's unbelievable, and it's going to damage the political process. Now it will be so difficult to proceed."

The Macedonian media blamed the National Liberation Army (NLA), whose commanders denied breaking the unofficial ceasefire that has been in place since March.

The NLA's spokesman, Ali Ahmeti, told Reuters that his troops had not attacked, although they might have acted in self defence.

Mr Trajkovski cancelled a planned visit to Romania to attend the cabinet meeting. He is due to fly to Washington today for talks with President Bush.

Arben Xhafari, leader of the Democratic Albanian party, and a member of the government, condemned the ambush.

"I think it will endanger the progress of negotiations and will deepen the polarisation between Macedonians and Albanians," he said.

Talks about a new government were due to conclude by the end of the week. Many Albanian politicians have expressed frustration at what they see as a lack of progress. Albanian parties want constitutional change, and more language and employment rights.

The NLA says it has the same goals, but Saturday's ambush reinforced the view held by many majority politicians that the guerrillas merely want territory and are not interested in dialogue.

"The roots of this crisis are not in the system of the state - they want a state for themselves," Mr Dimitrov said.

Western military experts in Skopje agreed.

"It's what the Macedonians feared. They are trying to make no-go areas; they want territory and not institutional change," a western diplomat said, adding that the rebels might have wanted to provoke a Macedonian army counter-attack.

"They want an over-reaction - they want a Racak" - the massacre of ethnic Albanians in Kosovo which led to Nato's bombing campaign against Serbia.

webTitle: Bush daughter busted for a beer

fields.headline: Bush daughter busted for a beer
fields.standfirst: Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: President George Bush celebrates his 100th day in office today facing fresh embarrassment over the behaviour of his daughter Jenna.
fields.body:
President George Bush celebrates his 100th day in office today facing fresh embarrassment over the behaviour of his daughter Jenna.

The 19-year-old, a student at the University of Texas at Austin, faces a court appearance and fine for being in possession of alcohol while under age. The legal drinking age in Texas is 21.

Miss Bush was rounded up with five others during a police check on a bar and issued with a citation, which means she faces a $200 (£125) fine or community service for drinking beer at the Cheers Shot Bar.

Although the elder of the president's twin daughters did not appear to be drunk, the official police citation read: "Glass of beer - drank from it." She is expected to appear before a court on Wednesday.

Two secret service agents accompanied her to the bar, but local police said they remained outside during the bust. Assistant police chief Mike McDonald said: "Both girls were very cooperative, as were the secret service. They [the agents] didn't interfere in any way."

The White House refused to discuss the incident yesterday. Noelia Rodriguez, spokeswoman for Laura Bush, said: "We respect the privacy of this young woman and we're not going to comment on her personal life."

Last month Jenna was taken by official car to rescue her boyfriend from a detox cell of a local prison after he police raided a party.

Although the White House has tried to keep Jenna and her twin, Barbara, out of the public eye, Jenna's behaviour has been compared with that of her father, who has admitted drinking too much when he was younger.

fields.headline: Mr Bush's bad dream
fields.standfirst:
Conscienceless conservatism runs amok

Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: That Field of Dreams is George Bush's favourite film provides a clue to his presidency, now 100 days old. Set in mid-west Iowa farm country, the movie is about baseball, Mr Bush's abiding passion.
fields.body:
That Field of Dreams is George Bush's favourite film provides a clue to his presidency, now 100 days old. Set in mid-west Iowa farm country, the movie is about baseball, Mr Bush's abiding passion.

And it is about fantasy as, one by one, the all-time greats of the game's bygone eras emerge from the towering maize, bat and gloves in hand, to live and play again. Picking up the theme, Mr Bush's main concern since taking office has been to put the clock back. His has been shown to be a peculiarly narrow, inflexible interpretation of America's conservative tradition. He appears overly influenced, if not led by the nose, by hawkish old-timers such as vice-president Dick Cheney and defence secretary Donald Rumsfeld. But more than this, Mr Bush seems set in a time-warp, to be harking back to an America that he thinks perhaps existed in his 1950s childhood but has long since disappeared back into the corn.

Mr Bush's inherited political fantasy is of an America that is homogeneous at home and dominant and unchallengeable abroad. It is of an American society that is God-fearing, uniform and structured, that upholds the old values because they are simply the best, that leads the world because the world simply knows it is right. That Mr Bush is not a deep thinker has become apparent to all. Nor is that so terrible. But what is terribly troubling is that this president does not seem to question or delve beneath the superficial images that flicker across his screen, be they of China (atheistic communists), Iraq (evil dictatorship), or environmentalists (anti-business liberals). He is beguiled by fatuous ideas of the make-believe past, by its false certainties and old totems.

Mr Bush pays lip service to multiculturalism and other aspects of modern, changing America. But that is all. He has a sure grasp on what never was but little purchase on what may be in future. His father called it the "vision thing". He lacked it - and so, too, does his cliche-confounded son.

Mr Bush portrays himself as a moral man. He is a regular churchgoer, a fitness fanatic who sees in a healthy body the foundation of a healthy mind. Having vowed to give the Oval Office a "good scrubbing" after Bill Clinton's depredations, he has banned informal dress in the White House and ordered that "naughty bits" (sex and violence) be excised from films shown aboard Air Force One. Mr Bush has invited faith-based groups to play a role in government and, for example, banned overseas aid for organisations offering abortion services. His increased education funding is linked to his concern for traditional family values. He repeatedly justifies his decisions as "the right thing to do".

Were he a more insightful man, Mr Bush might glimpse the contradictions between reality and this risible self-righteousness - and the outrage that results. What is remotely moral about the systematic rollback of industrial, business, environment and workplace regulations and safeguards described last week by Julian Borger in G2?

How does Mr Bush square his sworn duty to lead the nation as a whole with his regressive tax cuts and his abject surrender to special interests such as Big Oil, Big Tobacco and what used to be called the military-industrial complex? There can be very little moral justification for building new generations of treaty-busting missiles, risking a revived cold war with Russia, unnecessarily antagonising China over Taiwan, pouring scorn on the Korean peace process, and giving Israel's Ariel Sharon a virtual free run.

When he blithely tears up the Kyoto global warming protocol and instructs his treasury secretary to block IMF-World Bank bailouts for developing world economies, little wonder many ask what ethical universe Mr Bush inhabits. Born again Christian or not, these and other Bush actions at home and abroad in the first 100 days have been deeply immoral. They proceed not from faith and principle but from arrogance and ignorance.

This is fantasy politics at its most destructive. And yet the biggest contradiction of all is that this so-say moral man did not rightly or fairly win last November's election - and but for the Florida fix, would now be back in Texas watching ballgames. Living with Mr Bush in future will require a clear understanding of his limitations but also of these basic self-deceptions. Let us meanwhile bury that "compassionate" tag once and for all. This is conscienceless conservatism. And it is dangerous to your health.

webTitle: G7 signals commitment to global free trade

fields.headline: G7 signals commitment to global free trade
fields.standfirst: Special report: globalisation
fields.trailText: The world's richest industrial nations have pledged to prevent world trade talks in Qatar later this year from becoming a repeat of the Seattle stalemate, with promises of joint action to facilitate a new round of liberalisation.
fields.body:
The world's richest industrial nations have pledged to prevent world trade talks in Qatar later this year from becoming a repeat of the Seattle stalemate, with promises of joint action to facilitate a new round of liberalisation.

Prompted by signs that preparations for November's meeting of the World Trade Organisation are stalling, the G7 has sought to give fresh impetus to the moves to ensure freer trade.

"We strongly support efforts to launch a new WTO round later this year, to reduce trade barriers in both industrialised and developing countries," the G7 finance ministers and central bank governors said in their communiqué released after its meeting on Saturday. "We will work together to achieve the goal of free trade."

Following the breakdown of negotiations in Seattle, the director-general of the WTO, Mike Moore, has insisted that the framework for the launch of a new round should be in place by summer.

Divisions among the rich countries, and opposition from some of the leading developing nations, has raised fears that the Qatar meeting will be little more than a week of empty talk, however.
