fields.headline: Village rescued by wired goings-on
fields.standfirst: More internet news
fields.trailText: It is natural to see new technology as a threat to traditional values and behaviour: an attitude I tend to share when, for example, I see my younger son addling his brains playing a football game on the computer for the umpteenth time. It need not be so, and its potential is particularly benign in the countryside.
fields.body:
It is natural to see new technology as a threat to traditional values and behaviour: an attitude I tend to share when, for example, I see my younger son addling his brains playing a football game on the computer for the umpteenth time. It need not be so, and its potential is particularly benign in the countryside.

Take Little Hopping, somewhere in leafy England, in 2001. Its primary school is threatened; the proprietor of its only shop is hanging on by her fingertips, the cottage hospital in the local market town closed last year.

Increasingly, whatever people need, they have to get into their cars and drive miles to get; heaven help those without a car, or those who venture to walk or cycle in the narrow lanes which connect Little Hopping to the outside world. The local farmers, if they are lucky enough to get a contract with Sainsco, have to produce in large quantities and despatch the results in a huge truck many miles to a central warehouse.

Return in 2011. Little Hopping is wired and has been for years. Most of its households order standard grocery items from Sainsco Online, which sends a van with deliveries every Tuesday evening. The more conservative villagers write their orders on a piece of paper and hand them to Mrs Brown in the local shop, who sends them on to Sainsco Online for a modest commission.

While they are about it, they buy fresh food sent to Mrs Brown from local farms and gardens - which their web-wise neighbours do, too, now that they have stopped doing an all-in-one shopping trip to Sainsco. Many of them have a regular routine of glancing at Mrs Brown's website to see what she has in fresh this morning.

The school is safe from closure: mixed-age classes are all the rage now that teachers' own knowledge can be supplemented by web-based learning. In one corner, three or four nine- and 10-year-olds are having a web-based French lesson. In another, a parent is helping with the younger children, one of a group of parents who take turns. The deal is, they get IT instruction from the older children in exchange.

The healthcare situation has improved a lot, too: it is still a long way to the hospital, but it is not far to the community nurse. She has the latest diagnostic equipment which she can take with her even on home visits. Her mobile phone, with fold-away monitor and voice recognition input, connects her to all the world's medical knowledge plus the patient's medical records; and she knows old Mrs Jones' tendency to exaggerate. She can make a provisional diagnosis with the speed and confidence that only a consultant could have managed in 2001.

The local farmers' lot has improved. They still sell most of their produce to Sainsco but now that produce goes in smaller quantities to its new warehouse 40 miles away, most of it for sale in the region. Government arm-twisting helped to get that change but the main reason was that the net and IT generally have lowered per-transaction costs, making it more economical to deal in small volumes.

The villagers depend less on their cars now; some have taken to putting their planned trips to town up on the Hopping website, offering lifts. It is much safer to walk and cycle locally. What really made the difference was the system of speed cameras which the parish council decided to invest in, in consultation with local police. Fines paid for the cost of installation. Revenue is much less now, because people know they will get caught, but it costs very little to run and it doubles as a burglar-detection system. The local burglars have to come into Little Hopping by car, and their comings and goings are recorded by the cameras. They have learnt that the odds are stacked against them.

Do not imagine that the villagers have stopped talking to each other, glued to their PCs. You should have been at the village meeting last week, convened, of course, via the net. After a lively debate it was agreed by a comfortable majority not to oppose a local farmer's application for a small wind farm on his land. He gave guarantees on noise and visual aspects, but the main attraction was the contract to supply the whole village with electricity at two-thirds the current price (he will have a gas turbine back-up for calm days). That sort of small-scale electricity production and sale would have been hopelessly uneconomic without the latest IT systems.

The Little Hopping of 2011 will not just happen: it will have to be worked for, by politicians and others.

But the technological scope for it is there. New technology brings more opportunities than threats.

My son's brains, incidentally, have not been addled by too many computer games. He gave me some useful comments on the first draft of this article.

Andrew Tylecote is professor of the economics and management of technological change at the University of Sheffield

fields.headline: Secs in the City
fields.trailText: Thursday April 26, 5.30pm. Just going to pop over the road for a quick drink with the others. Home in time to watch The West Wing, no problem. Nice to be able to have civilised early evening glass of wine, before we all head off on our separate ways for the night.
fields.body:
Thursday April 26, 5.30pm. Just going to pop over the road for a quick drink with the others. Home in time to watch The West Wing, no problem. Nice to be able to have civilised early evening glass of wine, before we all head off on our separate ways for the night.

Thursday April 26, 7pm. A third glass of wine? Oh, why not? Only early, after all. That's the good thing about coming out straight from work - it doesn't eat into your evening too much. Must remember The West Wing, don't want to miss it.

Thursday April 26, 9.45pm. Sod The West Wing! Let's go for some food! No! Let's not! Takes up space that could be used for wine! Isn't wine brilliant? So nice to work with people who drink wine! So nice to work with nice people and nice wine. Even Nice New Girl Sara has stopped drinking stupid mineral water and is drinking nice wine, nicely. Ooops! Sara has fallen off her chair. Nice.

Thursday April 26, 10pm. Mark and Tom are lining up tequila shots on the bars. Genius!

Thursday April 26, 11.30pm. Bar is kicking us out! Bastards! Eh? Closing time? What?

Friday April 27, 12.20am. Clubbing! Isn't dancing brilliant? Ooooh - they're playing Ricky Martin! C'mon Tom, let's dance. Come on. Come on. COME ON.

Friday April 27, 1am. Only drinking cocktails from now on. Don't give you hangovers, y'see? Barman, more cocktails, so we don't get hangovers.

Friday April 27, 1.30am. Someone's spinning the room around. Please stop it! Stop it! Go to the Ladies, that's better. Ladies are spinning now too. Can you see them spinning, Sara? Sara? Oh. Sara's not very well. Oh. Lie on the floor. That's better. Nice floor. Nice and cool. Might just have a little sleep here.

Friday April 27, 2am. The thing is, right, is that I really, really love you guys. I do. I love you, Mark, cos you rescued me from the nasty toilets, and I love you Tom, I really, really love you and you dance like Ricky Martin. No! Better! Better than Ricky Martin! Better! And Sara, Sara. Even though you're quite annoying, I love you too. And we've all got to work together forever and ever, because we all love each other and there's not enough love . . . what was I saying? Ouch, ouch. Fell over. Pavement hit my head. I love the pavement.

Friday April 27, 9.30am. My. God. The pain. I hate you all.

fields.headline: Not just a secretary
fields.standfirst: Robert Laird is the new Secretary of the Year and he has the gold medal to prove it. Now, as he tells  Ian Boughton, management is but a step away
fields.trailText: Robert Laird is the new Secretary of the Year and he has the gold medal to prove it. Now, as he tells Ian Boughton, management is but a step away.
fields.body:
'Anyone who says they're 'just a secretary' is making an excuse," says Robert Laird firmly. "A few years ago secretaries passed on problems to managers - now PAs are key managers, and we deal with things ourselves."

As Britain's top PA, Laird puts his finger on something that is quite revolutionary in office admin matters - that modern training and qualifications have begun to recognise the direct progression from secretary to a senior-management role. Laird is PA to Rae Angus, principal of Aberdeen College - which, with 35,000 students, 500 staff, and a budget of £13m, is equivalent to a small town.

Last week, Laird took the UK Top Secretary Award, comprehensively beating 1,500 others in the London chamber of commerce and industry (LCCIEB) examinations board executive secretary's diploma, and topping another 1,000 who entered the exams from 86 countries, barely stopping to collect five distinctions and two medals along the way.

He was one of only five students, identified by superb "raw" marks across the five compulsory subjects, which had taken a year's study at an average 12 hours a week, who were called in to be grilled by the examinations board about their under standing of their roles as a secretary manager, and for their qualities of management, tact and diplomacy.

In doing so, the board demonstrated admirable tact itself, backing up its tag of "the world's most prestigious title" - there are dozens of PA qualifications, certifications and awards, and dotted around the world are several that are suspect.

"Some 'secretary-of-the-year' awards tend to select winners on a subjective basis," was the careful observation from Dawn Postans at the LCCIEB. "The Top Secretary Award is based on both objective aggregate performance and personal interview - it is the range of skills and experience which makes it the most demanding secretarial qualification."

What exactly are today's key secretarial skills? Beside the obvious English for business, business administration, principles and practice of management, and transcription at 110/120 wpm, the examinations board introduced a fascinating practical test - each candidate watched a 25-minute video of a meeting, then had an hour and a half to produce an accurate record of it.

"This," observed the board quietly, "is an exam which all managers could use!" Such training, says the LCCI, now recognises that the PA is in a changing role. "The secretary is still an 'organiser', but most now play a part in company decision-making, act as a sounding board for managers' ideas, and are expected to offer feedback. They analyse information, and advise on the most effective way to complete projects."

And, as Candy Daniels, president of the American Secretaries, has notably observed: "We are the first worker-group to test and master new office technology - so our status is information managers of the information age, the 'information central' of the digital office."

Notably, the British award still uses the word "secretary", when the America, Europe, Australia, New Zealand and some of the far eastern countries have gone over to "administrative professionals", or "management assistants", or, in America, just "admins". Together with the most advanced secretarial nation on the earth, the Brazilians, the examination board still uses the traditional title.

"To me, 'personal assistant' sums it up best," says Robert Laird, the first male PA to win the board's UK gold medal in 45 years. "We must remember that we are a supporting role - but I can be fulfilled in it because I am recognised as part of the management team. And with this title, I get exemption from some sections of the Institute of Administrative Management diploma - this shows the direct route from secretarial work to management."

But . . . a man? Gender equality is about breaking down stereotypes, such as the concept of the PA route to senior management, observes Laird, adding calmly: "I'd have a problem working with any organisation that couldn't see this."

There are several things employers don't see, said runner-up Clare Salt, who has just got a new job as PA to a director at Barclays Bank. "I wanted to be a top PA, and this has given me the confidence of knowing that I really can do it - and we can do a lot more than our bosses know, particularly in IT. The PA is now the office helpdesk!"

With this progress, the gap between good PA and bad is getting wider, says Ann O'Riordan of Blackpool, Wyre and Fylde community trust, who took third place. "My last qualification was more years ago than I'll tell anybody, but I thought I'd cracked it, and that I was a good secretary . . . well, this course made me rethink things I'd been doing for years.

"There's a bigger difference today between a great secretary, a good one, and an indifferent one - so heaven help the boss who has a poor one!"

webTitle: How PA skills are regarded around the world

fields.headline: How PA skills are regarded around the world
fields.trailText: • From November, American "admins" will have a new certification, the Certified Administrative Professional. The exam will include sections on finance and business law, office systems and advanced administration, management and organisational planning. The existing qualification is held by 58,000 admins, and the American association says this is worth an extra $2,200 a year on average.
fields.body:
 From November, American "admins" will have a new certification, the Certified Administrative Professional. The exam will include sections on finance and business law, office systems and advanced administration, management and organisational planning. The existing qualification is held by 58,000 admins, and the American association says this is worth an extra $2,200 a year on average.

 47% of the delegates at last autumn's conference of Britain's Institute of Qualified Private Secretaries had their attendance fees paid by employers. Several of the LCCIEB winners are members, which completes a circle - the IQPS was started by the first LCCIEB Diploma winners, back in 1957.

 The New Zealand Secretaries, at their recent conference, advocated the novel technique of planning a career backwards. The idea is to identify the qualities needed to do the job you want to hold in five years' time, and then work backwards from that down training steps until you get to where you are today. Reverse the list, and you have your training programme.

 In an American PA survey, a majority of respondents wanted Secretaries' Day to be marked by their boss sending them on a seminar, a skills course, or to pay the subscription to their association. In practice, about 20% got a lunch, and a few received a gift. But one employer gave out paperweights embossed with the company logo, one manager had flowers delivered in bulk to his secretary, who divided them out; and one gave a generous two hours off with pay, valid over the following 12 months!)

 The most entertaining argument over recognition of skills came last year when NALS, the American legal secretaries' association, added a tagline to its name, reading "the association for legal professionals". Lawyers objected, but NALS president Connie Maslowski responded robustly. "We are the skilled authorities in our chosen occupation, and we are proficient, learned, capable, competent and efficient. The term 'professional' applies to those who know what ethics are and live by them, conduct themselves with dignity and grace when a situation becomes strained, respect the rights of others and understand frailties, admire strengths and understand teamwork, and make the office a better place." The lawyers shut up!

 The world's best-trained secretaries are in Brazil, where by law PAs have to be registered with a government agency, and since 1985, the title "secretary" can be achieved only after a four-year university programme.

 Internationally, the greatest demand for enhanced training has come as the PAs bear the brunt of corporate downsizing, and take on the jobs of those who have gone. This is why secretarial leaders have called for PAs to promote their place as the most IT-competent people in the average office. However, some PAs haven't just haven't clicked - one American admin recently complained: "With emails volleying back and forth between us and clients, the paperwork is out of control . . ."

However, some PAs haven't just haven't clicked - one American admin recently complained: "With emails volleying back and forth between us and clients, the paperwork is out of control . . ."

fields.headline: WPM
fields.trailText: • What is it about spring that seems to fire the loins of businesses everywhere? Really, they're at it like rabbits. Left, right, centre they're pairing off and riding into the Technicolor sunset together. Sue Cooke Recruitment, for example, has been wedded to King and Toben. Workthing, the online employment network from the Guardian Media Group (hey, WPM doesn't know who the hell those Guardian guys are, but they sure sound like they know what they're doing) has just agreed to a 12-month partnership with Youreable.com, a new portal aimed at people with disabilities.
fields.body:
 What is it about spring that seems to fire the loins of businesses everywhere? Really, they're at it like rabbits. Left, right, centre they're pairing off and riding into the Technicolor sunset together. Sue Cooke Recruitment, for example, has been wedded to King and Toben. Workthing, the online employment network from the Guardian Media Group (hey, WPM doesn't know who the hell those Guardian guys are, but they sure sound like they know what they're doing) has just agreed to a 12-month partnership with Youreable.com, a new portal aimed at people with disabilities.

It's a sensible idea, this 12-month thing. Sort of a trial run. Rather like living together to check that you can cope - day in, day out - with the fact that one of you never empties the dustbin and the other never butters his toast to the edge. WPM hopes that Sue Cooke Recruitment has not rushed into its new union. What if Sue can't stand the way Toben spits out his toothpaste? What if King takes umbrage at the way Sue combs her hair? Tomato, tomato, potato, potato. You have been warned.

 Match.com has been in touch with WPM this week, to tell her just what a rip-roaring success last week's first UK Singles Event was. The screening of Bridget Jones's Diary was allegedly gatecrashed by none other than Marianne Faithfull, who flounced out halfway through, in order to do something much more exciting, doubtless involving Mars Bars and motorbikes, and all that lies in between. Back at the Gate Bar with the singles, there were, in fact five (5!) couples united in L-O-V-E by close of play that evening, and - WPM's sources tell her - one girl who broke many hearts (not, alas, WPM herself, although not for want of trying).

 Actually, WPM is still reeling from seeing Bridget Jones. Well, more particularly from seeing Colin Firth, in the snow. That night she fell asleep, smiling softly, dribbling gently, dreaming of Colin. In the snow. And woke up happy, thinking of Colin. In the snow. This is a rather roundabout way of telling you about EBeDo, which will coach you in how to use the telephone (WPM is very well-versed in how to use the telephone, it's a very simple "lift receiver and dial" procedure, but if some of you find that a tall order, WPM isn't going to mock your affliction). Anyway, the good people at EBeDO want to know who your dream client would be. Doubtless, they are just concerned for your welfare.

Your mission, should you choose to accept it, is to hand-pick 50 of your juiciest words to describe this perfect client of yours. Easy peasy, lemon squeezy. The winners (yes, plural, there are four) will each receive a place on one of its Virtual Assistant Mastery Courses, which are worth a stonking £290, and that's one helluva lot of shoes. Simply email your masterpiece to easy@ebedo before May 7 (that's next Monday, kids). Here, as an example for you all, WPM has crafted her very own 50-word answer (no copying, mind): "WPM's dream client would be Mr Colin Firth. Colin is obviously a very easy client to work for because of his clefty chin, and the way he wraps his coat around ladies in the snow. He is also very good at walking out of lakes, when necessary." Ha! Beat that Buster! That Virtual ssistant Mastery Course is as good as gone!

 No, ladies and gentlemen, your eyes do not deceive you. That is indeed Tamara Beckwith, legendary It girl and professional blonde, standing open-mouthed, scissors aloft in the new branch of Adecco in Knightsbridge. (You might be forgiven for not recognising Adecco - it is after all, so brand spankingly new, but Tamara, Tamara is unmistakeable. Indeed Mlle Beckwith could evidently barely contain her excitement at having been asked to open this 12th London branch of Adecco. By the end of 2001 there will be 30 Adeccos to collect nationwide. Calm down, Tamara.

This latest addition to the family is stationed at 150 Brompton Road, and offers 1,512 sq ft (which is almost as big as the QE2) of sheer, unadulterated, computerised candidate assessment, training facilities and one-to-one personalised service. WPM thinks you know what she's saying. Tamara appears to be having a whale of a time, and frankly who wouldn't, with such an exciting array of colours in one blouse?

fields.headline: After hours
fields.trailText: At the end of the day, when you're all hunched up, your shoulders feel like macramé and your eyes are smarting from the glare of the computer screen, what you need is somewhere to soothe your furrowed brow. Never mind herding into the nearest bar for a dry white wine - or seven - with the rest of the office rabble.
fields.body:
At the end of the day, when you're all hunched up, your shoulders feel like macramé and your eyes are smarting from the glare of the computer screen, what you need is somewhere to soothe your furrowed brow. Never mind herding into the nearest bar for a dry white wine - or seven - with the rest of the office rabble.

Yo! Sushi brings you, well, sushi, on a conveyor belt, so you need barely lift your weary paws to grab the nearest, prettiest fish dish. You can even imagine that you are a contestant on some fabulous daytime TV quiz show, scooping up prizes as they whirr past, and egged on, perhaps, by Dale Winton.

The real glory of the Yo! Sushi chain (of which there are nine in London and one due to open in Edinburgh in July) is the Yo! Below bar, where you'll find self-serve beer taps, the staff singing karaoke and - oh yes - free massages. What more could you wish for after a hard day at the office than endless plates of raw fish and seaweed, and a lady belting out Meatloaf as she kneads your aching muscles?

fields.headline: The inside track: Dot.com disillusion
fields.trailText: It is not just investors who have lost faith in dot.com industries. It seems that internet users are beginning to go cold on the medium as well. The annual salary survey from secretarial consultancy Maine-Tucker reports that 26% of its candidates regularly use the internet to search for jobs. This time last year the figure was 60%.
fields.body:
It is not just investors who have lost faith in dot.com industries. It seems that internet users are beginning to go cold on the medium as well. The annual salary survey from secretarial consultancy Maine-Tucker reports that 26% of its candidates regularly use the internet to search for jobs. This time last year the figure was 60%.

It is difficult to account for the falling off. Maine-Tucker's spokespeople have no pat answers, although they suggest that when secretaries use the internet to search for jobs they prefer the "clicks and mortar" sites - that is websites attached to well-established companies. Maine-Tucker reports that use of its own website is on the increase.

Although many recruitment companies distance themselves from their online activities by giving their websites distinct names, a well-known name is reassuring. The wild frontier image of the web does not help the spread of internet commerce. There have been rumours of wildcat agencies pirating other agencies' jobs, or even pooling candidates' CVs so that while you are quietly planning to move on, your employer could download your CV from a site you may not even be aware of. This worries the recruitment industry, but is unlikely to be deterring individuals from online job-searching.

A more likely explanation is that the glamour for all things internet has faded. Last year, secretaries were clamouring to work for dot.coms, not just for the chance of share options, but for their air of informality and the possibility that in a new industry there was more potential for role development. Like all IT enterprises, the dot.coms took on few admin staff but when they did they gave them enhanced job titles - such as assistant rather than secretary. Many traditional businesses believed they would have to relax dress codes and other formalities to compete for staff.

What a difference a year makes. Now it is the dot.coms which are struggling to recruit and people seem relieved to return to the certainties of the suit after the flirtation with chinos.

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: In a column called The diary of a parent governor, page 4, Education, April 24, we suggested that the national curriculum (in primary schools) had not been compulsory for more than a year, not since the literacy and numeracy hours came in. That is wrong. Schools are required to teach all of the national curriculum, which was last modified in 1999. For two years, while the literacy and numeracy strategies were introduced, primary schools were exempted from the requirement to teach the full curriculum but that exemption has now ended. The DfEE says the literacy and numeracy strategies are complementary to the national curriculum and do not change the legal status of the national curriculum requirements.

fields.headline: Emirates expansion to boost Britain
fields.standfirst: Rolls-Royce likely to benefit from Dubai's tourist boom
fields.trailText: Emirates is hoping to establish itself as the world's fastest growing airline, with plans to triple its fleet over the next 10 years - a potential investment of £15bn which may secure thousands of jobs in Britain.
fields.body:
Emirates is hoping to establish itself as the world's fastest growing airline, with plans to triple its fleet over the next 10 years - a potential investment of £15bn which may secure thousands of jobs in Britain.

The move could enhance Rolls-Royce and its plant at Derby, which produces most of the engines powering the Middle East airline's fleet. A decision on how many engines the airline will order in the first phase of its rapid expansion will be made in the next few months.

Sheikh Ahmed Bin Saeed Al Maktoum, Emirates' chairman, said the rapid expansion of tourism in Dubai from 3.5m now to an expected 15m by 2010 had made the decision inevitable. The airline's senior managers have been told to scrap existing plans and start afresh.

As a first step, the company will place a £1bn order with the European consortium Airbus, doubling to 10 the number of A380s it is seeking from the aeroplane manufacturer.

Emirates was the original launch customer for the A380, the world's largest jumbo jet due to begin delivery by 2006.

The Airbus order is the first step towards Emirates increasing its mainly wide bodied fleet from 35 to at least 110 by 2010. It will turn Dubai into one of the world's leading airline hubs.

Rolls-Royce is certain to benefit from this enormous expansion. Although a decision on whether Emirates will use the Rolls' Trent 900 for its new fleet of Airbus superjumbos has still to be taken, senior sources in the airline suggested that Emirates' long relationship with Rolls was a powerful factor and would not easily be cast aside.

It is a history that stretches back more than 15 years to Emirates' establishment in 1985. Since then the airline has spent about £15bn on Rolls Royce engines.

Maurice Flanagan, Emirates managing director, is to visit the United States this week to discuss a possible order for Boeing's new 750 mph "sonic cruiser". The aircraft, which is said to be capable of flying at heights of 45,000 feet and distances of more than 9,000 miles in one hop, could start receiving orders next year.

Mr Flanagan said he was interested in the new plane but had received only sketchy information on Boeing's plans for the delta wing aircraft. Sheikh Ahmed made it clear that Emirates would not "put down any money" towards research on the "sonic cruiser".

But Mr Flanagan said Boeing's new plane could help boost Emirates' expansion plans. He said it could complement the A380, for which more orders will have to be placed beyond the 10 the company is now seeking.

fields.headline: Firkin founder in fund hunt
fields.trailText: David Bruce, founder of the Firkin pub chain, is struggling to raise funds for a string of managed pubs he hopes will provide an antidote to the high street branded bar.
fields.body:
David Bruce, founder of the Firkin pub chain, is struggling to raise funds for a string of managed pubs he hopes will provide an antidote to the high street branded bar.

Having attracted £5.3m from more than 200 private investors - who stand to benefit from tax breaks under the Enterprise Investment Scheme - Mr Bruce has been forced to extend the hunt for funds to June 22. He remains hopeful of meeting the £10m target, and of attracting interest from City institutions.

With Mr Bruce as chief executive and Clive Watson, co-founder of Tup Inns, as finance director, Capital Pubs hopes to buy the freehold on up to 12 managed pubs in Greater London catering for drinkers over 25 yearsold. The company plans to sell to a regional brewer or float on the stock exchange in three years.

Mr Bruce, who oversaw the rollout of SFI Group's minimalist pine-furnished Slug and Lettuce chain, said Britain was saturated with design-led bars. By contrast, he said, Capital's image would be "carpets, comfy seating and log fires".

"We will be looking primarily for pubs that are not on the high street," he said. "Where you don't have to pass a doorman to get in and where you can hear yourself think above the music."

Mr Bruce was also highly critical of the Firkin chain, which he sold to Allied Domecq in 1988 for £6.6m. Since then the 12-pub chain has grown to more than 200 properties.

"It was complete overkill," said Mr Bruce. "There was Firkin toilets, Firkin salt and Firkin pepper, Firkin everything. Allied lost the plot."

The estate's present owners, Punch Taverns and Bass, have begun phasing out the brand.

Capital's finance director Clive Watson is best known for his role in a controversial profits warning issued by Regent Inns in 1998. After resigning as finance director he was blamed by the company for events which led to the warning - allegations he denies.

Regent said accounting "inaccuracies and inconsistencies" had led profit expectations to be falsely inflated. The company's market value halved when the news broke.

fields.headline: Monday briefing
fields.trailText: Observer
fields.body:
Observer

A host of top City figures face subpoenas over their knowledge of financier Andrew Regan's attempt to takeover the Co-operative Wholesale Society four years ago. Mr Regan's lawyer, Ian Burton, defending his client on charges of stealing £2.4m, has already written to the likes of Michael Foot, the head of banking regulation at the financial services authority, and UBS corporate financier Brian Keelan, requesting information.

Carl Cushnie, founder of trade finance house Versailles which collapsed last year, is suing his former finance director, Frederick Clough, for £12m allegedly missing from Mr Cushnie's private investment company.

Scottish Power is contemplating a £2bn takeover of Oregon utility Portland General in a move that would bolster its US west coast operations.

Sunday Business

British Telecom plans to raise up to £10bn through its expected rights issue - twice the level expected. The company is said to be encouraged by growing investor confidence that it is serious about undertaking painful organisational change.

The government is unable to guarantee that next year's football World Cup will be shown live on terrestrial TV, despite the tournament being listed as a "crown jewel" event which must be made available to free-to-air broadcasters. Kirch, the German media group which owns the rights to the tournament, has said it will sell the British rights to the highest bidder.

Railtrack is under pressure to scrap its end-of-year dividend payment to shareholders when final figures are released in a month's time.

Sunday Times

Angus Monro, ousted as chief executive of discount stores group Matalan, has told friends that he was ambushed at a board meeting and "astonished" at his sudden dismissal.

Research from the investment banking wing of HSBC suggests NTL, the country's biggest cable company, would have run out of money within two months but for a £270m cash injection from America's GE Capital on Friday.

PPL Therapeutics, the biotech firm behind Dolly the Sheep, is planning a fresh attempt to raise money in the City after abandoning a £45m share offer earlier this month.

Sunday Telegraph

webTitle: Faithful trust in prayer to keep Wahid unimpeached

fields.headline: Faithful trust in prayer to keep Wahid unimpeached
fields.standfirst:
20,000 rally peacefully for Indonesian president

Special report: Indonesia and East Timor
fields.trailText: More than 20,000 fanatical followers of President Abdurrahman Wahid held a mass Islamic prayer rally in the Indonesian capital Jakarta yesterday to demonstrate their unwavering loyalty to their revered but embattled idol.
fields.body:
More than 20,000 fanatical followers of President Abdurrahman Wahid held a mass Islamic prayer rally in the Indonesian capital Jakarta yesterday to demonstrate their unwavering loyalty to their revered but embattled idol.

Although it was billed as a peaceful gathering to pray for the nation, it is no coincidence that it was held the day before parliament is expected to issue Mr Wahid a second, and final, censure.

If he fails to respond to its satisfaction within 30 days, parliament can begin impeachment proceedings. More than three quarters of the MPs are actively opposed to him.

Mr Wahid spoke briefly and led some of the prayers. He called on his supporters to refrain from the violence thousands had promised to start before and during the parliamentary session.

"We are here to pray, not destroy," he said. "We are strong. Don't do anything that will cause losses to us all. Hopefully after this, all of you will go home straight away."

But he could not resist making a dig at his critics in parliament, just a few hundred yards from the car park where the rally was held.

"Tomorrow we will see what these people will do," he said. "We are strong, therefore we cannot act like children."

Those taking part were virtually all members of Nahdlatul Ulama (NU), Indonesia's biggest Muslim organisation, which was founded by Mr Wahid's grandfather.

Mr Wahid led it for 15 years before becoming Indonesia's first democratically elected president in 1999.

Most of them came from Mr Wahid's heartland, east and central Java. They were armed with nothing more than umbrellas stamped with Mr Wahid's picture to protect them from the sun.

"We have come here to pray," said Abdillah Sholeh Fatah, an elderly NU leader. "The more of us that gather together, the stronger our prayers will be. We'll leave the politics to the politicians."

The violence predicted last week failed to materialise, except for a couple of small petrol bombs which went off as the prayers were about to begin.

The tens of thousands of police officers and soldiers deployed throughout the deserted capital had nothing to do except direct the hundreds of buses leaving the city after the rally.

Most of the participants were adamant that there was no need to depose Mr Wahid.

"He is doing nothing wrong," said Syaful Rachman, a teacher from central Java. "It is just that the opposition is jealous because they are not in power."

He said he would not take any direct action if parliament continued to seek Mr Wahid's removal.

"It's all in the hands of Allah," he said. "If he has done wrong in Allah's eyes then nothing can save him."

Parliament used Mr Wahid's unproved involvement in two financial scandals as an excuse to issue the first censure.

It is expected to extend its list of complaints against him today to violating the constitution and deviating from his mandate.

webTitle: Iraq seeks Gulf war uranium check

fields.headline: Iraq seeks Gulf war uranium check
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Iraq
Special report: depleted uranium
fields.trailText: Iraq and Kuwait have separately asked for an independent assessment of the health hazards to local people and soldiers of the depleted uranium ammunition, used in battle for the first time in the Gulf war 10 years ago.
fields.body:
Iraq and Kuwait have separately asked for an independent assessment of the health hazards to local people and soldiers of the depleted uranium ammunition, used in battle for the first time in the Gulf war 10 years ago.

The requests were revealed yesterday by Pekka Haavisto, head of the Balkans depleted uranium assessment team, who has been asked to take on the job

His team has just completed an investigation for the UN Environment Programme of the nine tonnes of depleted uranium used in the Nato assault on Serbian forces in Kosovo. The mineral is used to reinforce the tips of armour-piercing munitions.

In the Gulf war, 350 tonnes were used in attacks on Iraqi armour, but no independent study of its dangers has ever been made, partly because of Nato resistance. Both Iraq and Kuwait have a potentially deadly problem of uncleared DU ammunition.

Iraq asked the UN secretary general Kofi Annan to help, and Kuwait approached the International Atomic Energy Agency in Vienna.

US and British veterans of the war to expel Iraq from Kuwait suspect that depleted uranium is the cause of Gulf war syndrome, the unexplained illnesses suffered by many of those who served in the conflict. Iraq has blamed it for a rash of childhood cancers.

The team's findings in Kosovo have gone a long way to dispel fears that the mildly radioactive ammunition will have a long-term effect on the health of local people.

But in the Gulf it may be a different story. The hot, dry climate and the volume of ammunition used may mean there is a far greater and continuing hazard.

Dr Haavisto gave his final report on the Kosovo study at the Djakova garrison, near the Albanian border, where 300 DU rounds were fired. The garrison is one of 120 sites in Kosovo where such ammunition was used.

Criticising Nato for delays in telling his team where DU was used, he said it was clear that some shells had been found and removed before it arrived on the scene.

Some rounds had penetrated concrete foundations and were buried deep in the soil beneath. Even so, detectors at the point of entry registered 15 times the normal level of background radiation.

Dr Haavisto said research in Kuwait and Iraq would be hampered by the passage of time. The large number of tanks destroyed in the Gulf war by depleted uranium rounds meant that a great deal of toxic dust had been released. Since there was virtually no rain, the dust could still be blowing around, he said.

Until the team arrived it was impossible to tell how much of a threat threat remained. "But radioactivity does not go away," he said. "We should be able to find enough evidence to try and assess the present risks to health, and something of the past."

There was no such dust to worry about in Kosovo because the team had not found no armour had actually been hit with such rounds. Most of the armour-piercing rounds had burrowed into the ground, probably as much as two metres deep.

Where ammunition was known to be buried, as at Djakova, any risk could be removed by covering the area with concrete.

He recommended the local authorities to test the water supply routinely to see if there was depleted uranium present. It was not known how long the uranium would take to seep through the soil but it could appear in the water supply in 10 years.

This summer Dr Haavisto's team hopes to investigate Bosnia, where three tonnes of the ammunition was used five years ago. The main purpose was to assess claims of a higher incidence of cancer in some villages, and to check the water supply.

He also criticised the US because traces of uranium 236 - an isotope found only in spent nuclear fuel - and plutonium had been found in the Kosovo armour-piercing rounds. The tiny amounts did not increase the risk to local people, but it was "a little bit alarming".

webTitle: Indicted ANC man alleges Mbeki plot

fields.headline: Indicted ANC man alleges Mbeki plot
fields.trailText: The South African government's investigation of three leading politicians alleged to be plotting against President Thabo Mbeki is based on statements made to the police by a disgraced ANC youth leader who is facing prosecution on dozens of fraud charges.
fields.body:
The South African government's investigation of three leading politicians alleged to be plotting against President Thabo Mbeki is based on statements made to the police by a disgraced ANC youth leader who is facing prosecution on dozens of fraud charges.

The ANC plans to meet all three - the party's former secretary general Cyril Ramaphosa and two former provincial premiers, Mathews Phosa and Tokyo Sexwale - this week. It has failed to persuade them to endorse the investigation in the hope of defusing the crisis.

The man responsible for the allegations is James Nkambule, 29, a formerly influential ANC activist who was suspended from the party as a "factionalist". He has been charged with 77 offences of theft and fraud by allegedly siphoning millions of rand from state coffers using front companies. He admits taking the money but says it was done to pay for ANC election campaigns.

Mr Nkambule has signed two affidavits which attempt to implicate the three men under investigation and a number of other senior ANC politicians, including the deputy president, Jacob Zuma, and the former defence minister Joe Modise, in a bizarre string of alleged crimes.

The documents outline a convoluted "plot" which begins with a covert arms shipment on behalf of some ANC leaders to Mozambique nine years ago.

According to Mr Nkambule's signed statement to the police a week ago, the former Communist party leader Chris Hani discovered that other ANC officials were profiting from the weapons deal and threatened to expose them.

He was then murdered by white rightwingers who were allegedly "influenced" by Mr Mbeki because he supposedly wanted to make sure Hani did not challenge him for the leadership of the ANC.

Mr Nkambule claims that the three men under investigation saw an affidavit from Janus Walus, a Polish anti-communist exile convicted of murdering Hani, which said Mr Mbeki had a role in the killing.

Mr Nkambule says they planned to use the information to topple the president by "briefing" ambassadors of other African states and the foreign press.

The source of the allegations will be a further embarrassment to the government, which has so far failed to shake off the accusation that the investigation is a witch-hunt against Mr Mbeki's potential rivals for leadership of the ANC.

Nelson Mandela gave his backing to Mr Mbeki during a visit to London yesterday.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Nasa clears way for Tito
fields.body:
Nasa clears way for Tito

The world's first space tourist, Dennis Tito, will arrive at the International Space Station today, Nasa having cleared the way for the Russian Soyuz capsule to dock.

Nasa asked the Russians to stand off until its astronauts had finished solving computer problems in the station and its shuttle Endeavour could leave without a risk of collision with the Soyuz.

Jane Martinson, Washington

Riots threaten Algerian regime

A minority party in the Algerian coalition government is threatening to quit in response to riots in Kabyle, in the north-east, where it has its power base among the Berber population. Fifty people have died.

The Rally for Culture and Democracy said its council would decide tomorrow about quitting.

AP, Algiers

Manila troops on coup alert

The Philippines' army was put on a coup alert yesterday after huge opposition protests and two simultaneous explosions in a suburban Manila shopping mall. At least 37 people were hurt.

It is unclear whether the explosions were politically motivated , but they added to the tension after five days of rallies supporting the deposed president Joseph Estrada.

AP, Manila

Army abandons gains on Jaffna

The Sri Lankan army retreated from territory recently gained on the Jaffna peninsula after a counter-attack by Tamil Tiger rebels yesterday.

Sources said that 1,600 government soldiers were wounded in the recent fighting after the rebels ended a unilateral four-month truce.

AFP, Colombo

webTitle: Arafat so near yet so far in long march to Jerusalem

fields.headline: Arafat so near yet so far in long march to Jerusalem
fields.standfirst:
In his first interview since the intifada began, a relaxed Palestinian leader tells how the peace process can be restarted

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: In his first interview since the intifada began, a relaxed Palestinian leader tells how the peace process can be restarted.
fields.body:
Yasser Arafat often describes his struggle as a "long march" to the "spires and minarets" of Jerusalem, capital of his Palestinian state-to-be. "And I hope that the next time you see me," he said, "will be in my mother's house." It was next to the Wailing Wall, he explained; and it had only been partly destroyed when the Israelis demolished the ancient Mograbi quarter, immediately after their conquest of East Jerusalem in 1967.

Here in Ramallah he is as physically close to his goal as he can get, a mere 10 minutes by car. But whether, politically, this really is his last way-station on the road to Jerusalem depends on the outcome of the intifada.

At the moment, like all the town's inhabitants, he is under siege. He received me in the Muqata'a, or district headquarters, from which the British, Jordanians and then Israelis had formerly administered the town.

The night before, it had come under fire, another of those now almost banal intrusions of warfare into lives which have many outward aspects of normality. Ramallah is beset by Israeli settlements. The exchanges between them and the Palestinian Shabiba, or "youth", have taken on a routine pattern. Sometimes the Shabiba start them, with their ineffectual Kalashnikovs, sometimes the settlers or Israeli army, with much heavier weapons, including tanks. On this occasion, locals said, it was the latter. From the settlement of Psagot, quite out of the blue, they shot and wounded a 12-year-old boy in the Hashimiyah school playground, 300 yards or so away. The Muqata'a, said an Arafat aide, was hit several times by machine gun fire.

Intensifying the sense of siege, for Mr Arafat, is the difficulty of movement. His private helicopter has been grounded since the former prime minister Ehud Barak "pushed his forces into our towns and cities on September 28". Now he has to rely on a Jordanian helicopter. And simply to get to Gaza, the other segment of his domain now almost entirely cut off from the West Bank, he has to go first to Amman, take a flight to al-Arish, and then go by road through dangerous, settler territory to his local headquarters.

I first met the president, as he now styles himself, in Jordan's Ghor valley in 1968, shortly after his guerrilla movement had emerged, in an aura of heroism and great expectations, from the clandestinity that Israel and hostile Arab governments had imposed on it. At the time, as the mere "spokesman" of the collectively led Fatah organisation, his rhetoric was fiery and his objectives uncompromising: the complete liberation of Palestine, and by armed struggle alone.

It was apparently owing to this long association that he agreed to be interviewed. Nonetheless it came as a surprise to me, all the more so in that, as a result of my last visit to the occupied territories - Gaza 1997 - when I had written about the corruptions of the Palestinian Authority, he had instructed his representative in London to sue me in the British courts. But Mr Arafat was ever a man of reconciliations. He is about to consummate a far more spectacular one, to go to Damascus to see Bashar Assad, son of the ruler he used to describe, in some of his darkest hours, as the co-conspirator, against the Palestinian cause, of Israel itself.

So if they stopped causing funerals every day, you could tell your people to stop? "Definitely. But they also have to follow up the agreement." That is to say, to return to the peace process where it had been left off, not at last July's Camp David summit, but at the Taba talks held on the eve of the Israeli elections.

At those, he said, the two sides had come closer than ever to an agreement. He repudiated the Israelis' contention that it was he who had caused the peace process to collapse, by rejecting the "most generous offer" Israel ever made, an offer measured - in its territorial dimension - as 96%, or thereabouts, of the occupied territories. If there was a generous offer, he said, it was the Palestinians', with their renunciation of 78% of their original homeland.

None the less, at Taba, the Israelis had yielded far more than ever before - far more than at Camp David. "For the first time they agreed to give up 80% of the settlements. Besides, "I don"t think he will try to kill me; he is now the first man in Israel - and I have a hotline to him." A hotline? "Yes, Omri is my hotline" - Sharon's son, now becoming a regular visitor to the Muqata'a.

It would seem from such methods of communication that you are "Arabising" the Israelis? "But they are Arabs," he shot back, calculating that 70% of them are of Middle East origin.

The important thing here, he said, was that President George Bush and the Europeans had told Mr Sharon to stop.

So you believe that international intervention is indispensable? "This is what happened all over the world, in Bosnia, in Kosovo." Some Israelis believe that you will do anything, even engineer another massacre, another Sabra and Shatila, to bring that about? "It has been done already - 25,000 people wounded. And what about all that destruction to houses, installations, schools, mosques and churches; even the synagogue of the Samaritans in Nablus has been bombed."

Was it not possible, if things got worse, that, instead of completing his "long march" to Jerusalem, he would be captured and put on a plane to Tunis, his former headquarters in exile, as some Israelis were urging? "I will return. I have my ways, you know. I always used to come here secretly. This is my land. Here I shall die."

fields.headline: Doubts over trial ceasefire
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: The Israelis and Palestinians agreed in principle yesterday to a ceasefire aimed at ending seven months of bloodshed. But no date has been set and disagreement remains on the specific details, such as how long it will last.
fields.body:
The Israelis and Palestinians agreed in principle yesterday to a ceasefire aimed at ending seven months of bloodshed. But no date has been set and disagreement remains on the specific details, such as how long it will last.

The Israelis want the trial ceasefire, which they see as a test of whether the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, can be trusted, to last up to eight weeks. The Palestinians have proposed four weeks.

More significantly, major differences remain over what should happen after a ceasefire is in place.

The diplomatic flurry, the most intensive since Ariel Sharon, a rightwinger, became Israeli prime minister two months ago, was undermined by a weekend of violence that left two Palestinians and an Israeli soldier dead.

The ceasefire arrangement was contained in a joint Jordanian-Egyptian peace plan put forward a month ago and supported by the Palestinians.

The Israeli foreign minister, Shimon Peres, initially rejected it but yesterday edged towards an agreement. He flew to Cairo to meet the Egyptian foreign minister, Hosni Mubarak, and then to Jordan to meet King Abdullah.

Mr Mubarak said afterwards that Israel and the Palestinian Authority had reached an understanding on a ceasefire. An Israeli official travelling with Mr Peres confirmed this: "It is not a breakthrough but there are reasons not to be pessimistic. It has been a good day."

Under the Jordanian-Egyptian plan, in return for Palestinians ending attacks, Israel would lift its blockade that has brought economic life in the West Bank and Gaza Strip almost to a standstill. In an apparent goodwill gesture, Mr Peres yesterday lifted a ban on Palestinians working within Israel proper.

The negotiations are taking place in spite of Mr Sharon having made an election pledge not to talk to Palestinians until violence ended.

Mr Peres's response to the plan was relayed by Cairo and Amman to the Palestinians, who will give a response to Mr Peres on his return to Israel on Thursday from talks in Washington. The initial Palestinian response was not positive.

Under the Jordanian-Egyptian plan, the ceasefire would be followed by a resumption of negotiations based on US proposals put on the table at Taba early this year aimed at resolving Israeli-Palestinian differences over borders, the status of Jerusalem and the future of Palestinian refugees.

Mr Peres said yesterday: "There are still issues that we have to clarify and I don't want to claim that everything is OK."

Mr Peres rejected the plan to resume with the Taba proposals. He favours a more limited peace settlement.

A Palestinian shot dead in Bethlehem on Saturday was buried yesterday. In a separate incident, an Israeli soldier was killed the same day. A Palestinian, described by the Israeli army as a suicide bomber, apparently blew himself up near Nablus on the West Bank and another was injured.

fields.headline: Mark Lawson
fields.standfirst: Film stars will often discuss their battles with drink and drugs. But never their obsession with looking young. Can a documentary about Hollywood plastic surgeons explain why?
fields.trailText: Film stars will often discuss their battles with drink and drugs. But never their obsession with looking young. Can a documentary about Hollywood plastic surgeons explain why?
fields.body:
In EL Doctorow's novel The Waterworks, set in 1871, a New Yorker believes that he has seen his recently-deceased father alive and being transported across the city in a coach with some other elderly men. It turns out that this is not an apparition: along with other rich old guys, pop has faked his death and submitted to a mysterious clinic which promises to achieve eternal life.

The book was based on various longevity scams of the past (predecessors of cryogenics) and readers probably laughed at the credulity of our ancestors. But Hollywood Knives (BBC1) reminds us that a similar Methuselah fantasy is offered by respected Californian doctors today.

Promising to defy not death but gravity, the cosmetic surgeons of Los Angeles have been the subject of several recent television films. This one, however, shows a slightly different face. It deals specifically with famous faces.

At any cosmetic clinic treating stars, a crucial procedure involves sewing up the lips of the staff immediately after the operation. So, while the film is clearly trying to imply that Michael Douglas has been nipped and tucked, it is unable to provide any evidence to counter his denials that his looks have been helped by the knife. It's a pity, because lying about plastic surgery is perhaps the only literal example of being two-faced. In the same way, Demi Moore is shown to have changed noses from one photograph to the next but thumbs her new neat schnozzle at anyone who asks the trick behind this transformation.

The stories the documentary can tell involve famous faces long gone to ash or soil. One anecdote will make you look as startled as a Beverly Hills matron after her third face-lift. Jolie Gabor - mother of Zsa-Zsa and Eva, both of whom also had several faces during their lives - instructed the surgeon before one of her tucks that, were she to die on the operating table, she wished to have the procedure completed so that she might go to her grave looking young.

Widely regarded as the world's most beautiful woman, Marilyn Monroe felt her chin to be indifferent and submitted to an implant shortly before she killed herself. This case makes explicit the underlying theme of the documentary: that part of the deal between film stars and audiences is that the performers will go on looking young. The reason that stars keep it so secret is that their preservation is supposed to seem supernatural.

Certainly, among Monroe's psychoses was a fear of getting old. On the hot night that she took the pills she was able to ensure that this wouldn't be a problem.

It's often said by critics that, while actresses are pressured to rearrange their faces, the ageing of male performers is tolerated: she is grizzled; he is craggy. The usual basis for these claims is Jack Nicholson or Sean Connery who, in later films, have even dared to dispense with hairpieces.

Hollywood Knives, however, counters this theory with the cases of John Wayne and Frank Sinatra. From the outside they seemed to be two guys who were happy in their skin. Wayne's looks were frequently compared to granite and you might have thought that a certain weathering would be accepted. But the film convincingly shows that his face was secretly lifted after making True Grit. Sinatra, in his mid-50s, suddenly had fixed a deformation of the ear caused by a forceps delivery. Surgery became part of the mid-life crisis: a new car, a new wife, a new face.

Denied access to any famous enhanced faces with breath still coming out of the mouth, the film concentrates on Susan Miller, a small-time actress who allows her face-lift to be filmed. John Woo's movie Face/Off has already shown us the moment cosmetic surgeons call "the peel", when the skin is cut around the face and their face is suddenly pulled upwards like a magician's handkerchief. This documentary's most extraordinary image is from the pre-op preparation. The dots and lines of the planned incisions are marked on the patient's face with a pen so that she looks like a granny playing cat faces with her grandchildren. Bruised and swollen after the surgery, she looks like the victim of a crime which, morally, she very possibly is.

The sharpest historical detail is that the LA rejuvenators are using versions of techniques developed during the second world war to treat disfigured soldiers. The fact that medicine intended to make the lives of heroes bearable is now being employed to help the pampered attract younger sexual partners is one of the more depressing commentaries on the advance of civilisation.

Two paradoxes emerge from the film. When Gary Cooper submitted to surgery to rejuvenate his jowls, his publicist put out that he was having a cyst or lump fixed. The actor would rather let people think he had cancer than admit to prettification. Expanding on that point, one plastic surgeon remarks that his famous patients chat happily to magazines about their alcohol or cocaine addiction but nothing ever passes their suspiciously pert mouths about cosmetic surgery.

This trashy but entertaining film, though, shows why, in actors' eyes, there's nothing hypocritical about this distinction. People can get over drugs or drink but it's impossible to be in recovery from ageing. And so denial of the cycle of life remains the last true celebrity taboo, making the facial surgeons of Los Angeles very rich.

 Hollywood Knives, Wednesday, 9pm, BBC1.

fields.headline: Country Diary
fields.standfirst: Feather in your cap
fields.trailText: The five o'clock start and the biting north-easterlies were painful, but to witness the dawn lek of 15 black grouse made it all worthwhile.
fields.body:
Moorfoot Hills

The five o'clock start and the biting north-easterlies were painful, but to witness the dawn lek of 15 black grouse made it all worthwhile. During its breeding display the blackcock has to be one of Britain's most beautiful and impressive wild animals.

About the size of a large cockerel, it emphasises its best features by a series of ritualised contortions. The head, which is crowned by two swollen scarlet "eyebrows", is thrust forward and arched downwards from the upper back, while the feathers of the neck and throat are raised to intensify their silky blue-black sheen. As the bird struts stiffly towards its male rivals the flight feathers droop downwards revealing a sequence of white "eyes" on the wing's leading edge, and the undertail coverts are raised above the bird's back to create a white bustle framed within a lyre-shaped spread of jet tail feathers.

All this testosterone-charged pageantry is accompanied by a dove-like cooing note. The sound has a soothing quality and, if the charge of anthropomorphism were not so serious, I'd swear it sounded like softly-spoken love talk. While a black grouse lek is one of the most impressive pieces of sexual theatre in the British upland scene, we and our neighbours have been powerless to avert a catastrophic drop in the bird's European population. In Britain there are thought to be just 6,500 males left. While it is still legitimately shot as a gamebird, the main reason for its disappearance is widespread agricultural intensification. fields.headline: Jean-Gabriel Albicocco
fields.standfirst: French film director, famed for extravagance, ended up penniless in Brazil
fields.trailText: The French film director Jean-Gabriel Albicocco has died, aged 65, in Rio de Janeiro, where he was living, forgotten and destitute.
fields.body:
The French film director Jean-Gabriel Albicocco has died, aged 65, in Rio de Janeiro, where he was living, forgotten and destitute. It was a tragic end to a career that started so promisingly - by the age of 30 he had made one of the French cinema's greatest successes.

Of Italian ancestry, Albicocco was born in Cannes, the son of the cinematographer Quinto Albicocco. By the age of 10, he was already proficient in the use of a ciné camera, shooting his own 8mm movies around the town. While still in his teens, he worked on documentaries for the cinématograph service of the French army. By 1957, the 21-year-old was assistant director on Jules Dassin's ambitious adaptation of the Greek writer Nikos Kazantzakis's novel Christ Recrucified, retitled He Who Must Die.

After directing a number of well-received shorts, Albicocco made his first feature. Following in the wake of the French new wave, it was The Girl With The Golden Eyes (La Fille Aux Yeux d'Or, 1961), about a fashion designer who falls for a young woman, whom he discovers is the lover of a female colleague. It would be hard to guess that this chic, stylish and stylised lesbian tale, excellently photographed by Albicocco's father and set in the Paris fashion houses of the early 1960s, was based on a Balzac story.

The film was a great success for the director, and for 20-year-old Marie Lafort in the title role, whom Albicocco was soon to marry. He followed it up with Le Rat d'Amérique, starring Lafort and Charles Aznavour, and it was selected for the 1963 Cannes film festival.

Then came his biggest hit of all, Le Grand Meaulnes (The Wanderer, 1966), based on Alain Fournier's popular young people's classic. In fact, Albicocco was the first person in 30 years to persuade Isabelle Rivière, who co-wrote the screenplay with him, to allow her brother's work to be filmed.

Again working with his father as cinematographer, Albicocco attempted to recreate the fairy-tale atmosphere of the poignant story of the young Augustin Meaulnes in search of a beautiful and mysterious girl and his lost adolescence. Though it was often too frenetic and flashy for its own good, the film was, nevertheless, visually impressive, and became one of France's biggest box-office successes of the year, as well as making an impact abroad.

But his extravagant style - it was noted that Albicocco rhymes with rococo - and rather sentimental approach seemed to lose favour with critics and the public, and his next two films, Le Coeur Fou (1969) and Le Petit Matin (1970), were flops. The latter was a roseate view of the occupation, and featured the celebrated stage director and actor Jean Vilar in his last role.

Thereafter, Albicocco decided to give up film-making and work behind the scenes of the industry. He founded the French Film Directors Union in 1968, and organised the directors' fortnight at Cannes. But in the early 1980s, with a certain amount of regret and bitterness, and now divorced, he suddenly went to live in Brazil.

"I no longer belong in France," he announced, although he was instrumental in forging links between the French and Brazilian cinemas. But his investment in a chain of cinemas, to counteract the influence of the torrent of Hollywood movies, led only to penury.

A few days before his death, when it was reported that he was gravely ill, a call went out in France to fellow cinéastes to help Albicocco. Sadly, it was too late.

Jean-Gabriel Albicocco, film director, born February 15 1936; died April 10 2001

fields.headline: Tony Gibson
fields.standfirst: Conscientious objector who became the smooth image of the RAF
fields.trailText: Tony Gison, who has died aged 86, was imprisoned as a conscientious objector while his image was used in a Brylcreem advert to promote the RAF
fields.body:
In 1939, the society photographer, Howard Coster, was commissioned to portray a handsome young man to advertise the hair gel Brylcreem. His choice was HB "Tony" Gibson.

In those days Tony, who has died aged 86, was eaking out a living posing for art school life classes. His habitually uncontrolled black hair was made neat and shiny for the advertisement, thanks to one of Brylcreem's competitors - the barber had no Brylcreem. By 1940, one of the ensuing portraits was being used repeatedly in full-page magazine advertisements. During the Battle of Britain, thanks to retouching, the "Brylcreem Boy" was given a Royal Air Force uniform. Meanwhile, Tony was in prison - as an unregistered conscientious objector.

In real life, Tony was an anarchist, a psychologist, the first president of the British Society of Experimental and Clinical Hypnosis, the inventor of the Gibson spiral maze psychomotor test, and the founder of the psychology department at Hatfield Polytechnic, now the University of Hertfordshire.

Born in Romford, Essex, the son of a wealthy family and the youngest of seven children, he absconded from Cranleigh school, in Surrey, at the age of 16 and, after living on the streets of Soho and Bloomsbury, was briefly a medical student at King's College London, until his father cut him off without a penny. Then came the life class modelling, the ads - and jail.

At that time, Tony and his lifelong companion, Betty Gibson, were members of the Forward Movement, an anarchist group within the Peace Pledge Union. He served three prison sentences, the maximum permitted for refusing military service. Thereafter, he worked as an ambulance driver and an agricultural labourer, and was one of the temporary editorial team of the anarchist newspaper War Commentary, when most of the regular staff were imprisoned in 1945.

From then until 1954, he and Betty worked at the progressive Burgess Hill school, in Hampstead. During this period, Tony's father died intestate, and his estate was distributed - so the estranged son came into money once again, which enabled him to resume his education, at the age of 40.

Having graduated with first-class honours in sociology from the London School of Economics, he studied psychology and clinical psychology, and became a research assistant at the Institute of Psychiatry, in south London, studying hypnotism in a three-strong team with Professor Hans Eysenck and Desmond Furneaux. Tony did most of the hypnotising.

A chartered clinical psychologist, he took a doctorate from the institute in 1962, researched at the Institute of Criminology in Cambridge, lectured at the Institute of Psychiatry, and, from 1970 to 1976, headed the new department of psychology at Hatfield. When it became a university, he was appointed a senior research fellow, and, in retirement, an honorary senior research fellow.

He remained active to the end, both as an anarchist and as a psychologist, writing articles, lecturing, and appearing in legal cases as an expert witness on hypnosis and suggestibility. His books include Hans Eysenck: The Man And His Work (1980), in which he compared Eysenck to Sigmund Freud as a "conquistador", and works for the medical profession and more general audiences on hypnosis, pain and the psychology of ageing.

In most of his books, he is listed as HB Gibson, but Youth For Freedom, Freedom For Youth, (1952) and Love, Sex And Power In Late Life (1992) were published by the Anarchist Freedom Press and are in the name of Tony Gibson.

His partner died in 1984. He is survived by two grown-up children.

fields.headline: Bryon Butler
fields.standfirst: Sports journalist admired within the worlds of football and cricket
fields.trailText: If there were one word to associate with the football journalist, historian and broadcaster Bryon Butler, who has died of cancer aged 66, it would be "decency".
fields.body:
If there were one word to associate with the football journalist, historian and broadcaster Bryon Butler, who has died of cancer aged 66, it would be "decency". Unfailingly pleasant, honest, reasonable and objective, possessed of an endearing humour, he was much valued and respected by famous figures in the game - and this at a time when relations between the media and football professionals have seldom been so strained.

Butler was born in Taunton, Somerset, and educated at Taunton school. At the age of 16, he started on the Exeter Express and Echo in his home town. His national service was as an officer with the Somerset Light Infantry, after which he joined the Nottingham Evening News and went on to the Leicester Mercury. The News Chronicle brought him to London and, after that paper closed in 1961, he joined the Daily Telegraph, where he would make his name.

While writing for the Telegraph, Butler began to broadcast for the BBC, and, in 1968, he became the corporation's football correspondent. Though neither in his radio commentaries nor his writing did he tend to excess, there was nothing pedestrian about him. Blond, crinkly-haired and pipe-smoking, he was the quintessential Englishman, with an abundance of friends.

As a football commentator, he was fluent and popular. Once, when we were discussing the legendary, but somewhat impressionistic, Raymond Glendenning, Butler told me: "If he was around today, he wouldn't get a job." This was said without hubris, but simply to reflect the fact that football commentating had moved on - that to be merely mellifluous was no longer enough.

Butler had an excellent voice, but he was dedicated to paying attention to the nuts and bolts of the game. "This", he once said, "is one of the best jobs in the world. The drumbeat of the job is a constant one. Never a dull day, never a day without a story. It never stops. Even in the close season, there are always new stories breaking."

But he was more than a mere trader in ephemeral facts and figures. Devoted work went into his massive Official History Of The Football Association and his Pictorial History Of The Football League. These books, like himself, were never controversial. He did not see sports journalism as an adversarial trade, any more than he exploited his radio commentaries for self-projection. The kind of banter between commentators which has become fashionable was quite alien to him.

Stanley Matthews, Tom Finney, Bobby Moore and Bobby Charlton - one of his admirers - were among his favourites. So was that star-crossed maverick, George Best, whom he placed alongside Pele, Alfredo Di Stefano, Johann Cruyff and Franz Beckenbauer as among the best of all time.

His BBC job lasted until 1991 and he was still writing a knowledgeable, good humoured weekly column for the Telegraph to the very end. Nor should it be forgotten that he loved cricket, and wrote about it with the same objectivity as he did football.

He is survived by his wife, Barbara, two sons and a daughter.

Ewart Bryon Butler, journalist, born June 5 1934; died April 26 2001

fields.headline: Saint's remains rekindle Ireland's faith
fields.trailText: Tens of thousands of Irish people are lining the streets to see the arrival of the bones of St Therese, a 24-year-old French nun who died of TB more than 100 years ago.
fields.body:
Tens of thousands of Irish people are lining the streets just for a glimpse of her tour vehicle. They're strewing the roads she travels with roses and queuing for hours to get near her.

The source of this adoration is not Madonna, nor Julia Roberts, nor the Dundalk-born songstress Andrea Corr, but a 24-year-old French nun who died of TB more than 100 years ago.

The arrival of the bones of St Therese, the Little Flower, for a 75-day trip to towns and cities across Ireland has provoked remarkable religious fervour in a predominantly Catholic, but increasingly secular, country.

The Catholic church in Ireland has been battered by scandals over the past decade. Church attendance is dropping, fewer young men are taking up the priesthood and recent surveys have shown fewer than a quarter of Catholics agree with the strict teachings of the church on moral matters.

Yet if the first few weeks are indicative of the whole trip, more than 2m people will see the relics, as many as turned out to see Pope John Paul II on his 1979 visit.

A 75,000-strong crowd came to see Bishop Brendan Comiskey bless the 400lb gold and silver casket containing the relics after it was carried ashore at Rosslare, Co Wexford, by a special ceremonial unit of the Irish army on Easter Sunday.

The casket is travelling to a different church every day in a six-tonne Mercedes Sprinter, which the clergy have dubbed the Theresemobile, donated by a retired regimental sergeant major, Pat Sweeny.

"She is a crowd-puller, no doubt," said Father Linus Ryan, the Carmelite priest co-ordinating the visit. "The casket arrives at a location, rests in a church for the afternoon and we have huge queues, of half to three-quarters of a mile long, to pay their respects.

"The atmosphere is one of quiet reverence. It's amazing to see people, three or four abreast, packing the aisles, but in complete silence with only the steady rustle of feet."

Therese Martin was born in the town of Alencon in north-west France in 1873, the youngest of nine children, four of whom were already dead.

She almost died from a kidney infection when she was 10 but claimed she was cured by a vision of the Virgin Mary. At 15, she entered a Carmelite convent where she lived in simplicity until her death from tuberculosis at 24 in 1897.

Her autobiography, Story of a Soul, was published a year later. Translated into 50 languages, it is one of the best-read Christian books.

Therese was canonised in 1925, and in 1997 the present Pope declared her a Doctor of the Church, only the third woman to be given this title.

Several people who visited her grave in Lisieux were allegedly healed of ailments and it is said when her body was exhumed to look for the evidence necessary to canonise her, the area was filled with the scent of roses for months.

Father Ryan said: "The healings are well documented in the church archives. People who were paralysed have walked and the blind able to see again.

"The French singer Edith Piaf was blinded by meningitis when she was three years old, and had her sight restored at the age of seven when her grandmother brought her to Therese's grave. She wore a tiny medallion in the saint's honour for the rest of her life."

The relics have already been to Argentina, Mexico, Brazil, the US, Vietnam and Russia, as part of a world tour since the centenary of her death in 1997.

webTitle: HIV jab threat made in car hijack

fields.headline: HIV jab threat made in car hijack
fields.trailText: A couple were abducted in their car at knifepoint yesterday by a robber who threatened to inject them with a syringe filled with HIV-infected blood, before forcing them to drive 40 miles to a cashpoint.
fields.body:
A couple were abducted in their car at knifepoint yesterday by a robber who threatened to inject them with a syringe filled with HIV-infected blood, before forcing them to drive 40 miles to a cashpoint.

The ordeal began near Taunton, Somerset, when a man climbed into the back of their Mercedes after they stopped at traffic lights on a slip road from the M5, as they headed home to Dorchester, Dorset, at about 1am, police said.

The pair were threatened with the syringe, which the robber claimed held HIV positive blood, and ordered to drive south. They drove to a Tesco superstore just off the M5 and were told to withdraw £1,000 from a cash dispenser. As the male driver got out to do so, his wife escaped from the car. The robber then drove the vehicle away. It was later found burned out, near Teignmouth, Devon.

The couple, who were found "in a state of fright having been subjected to abduction and robbery", were treated in hospital for bruising and minor cuts, the police said.

A 38-year-old man and a woman aged 37 were arrested in Newton Abbot, Devon, in connection with the incident. They were being questioned in Exeter last night.

It is believed the attack may be linked to others in the west country over the past two weeks. Last Tuesday, a taxi driver in Cirencester, Gloucestershire, was twice locked in the boot of his car as a knife-wielding man first robbed him then directed him to his bank and used his cash card to withdraw £250.

On April 19, a female taxi driver from Warminster, Wiltshire, suffered a two-hour ordeal as a passenger held a syringe to her throat, told her to drive to Poole, Dorset, then took her car along with her handbag and wages. Her car was found in Kinson, Dorset.
