On April 19, a female taxi driver from Warminster, Wiltshire, suffered a two-hour ordeal as a passenger held a syringe to her throat, told her to drive to Poole, Dorset, then took her car along with her handbag and wages. Her car was found in Kinson, Dorset.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Police still held over drugs
fields.body:
Police still held over drugs

Three police officers were among five still being questioned yesterday on alleged possession and supply of cocaine and cannabis in Derbyshire. Five others, including another officer and a national crime squad officer, both suspended from duty, were released on bail.

Margaret's role left in doubt

Princess Margaret, 70, was resting at Kensington Palace after her loss of vision, understood to be linked to her last stroke. It is thought she will now bow out of public life.

Tube talks seek to stop strike

London Underground managers meet the rail union and TUC general secretary, John Monks, today to try to resolve the dispute and avert a May 2 tube strike.

Fire death leads to three arrests

Police made three arrests linked to the death of David Barnaftershaw, 30, who was kidnapped in September 1999 from the Moss Rose pub, Greater Manchester, and burned in the boot of a car. Three men, aged 27, 29, and 38, were being questioned.

Unfit poultry may be stained

Unfit batches of poultry and low-risk red meat could be stained with indelible ink to stop them entering the food chain, the food standards agency said. The action follows the jailing of five men convicted of a £2.5m fraud diverting unfit poultry for human use.

Icy trek makes Arctic record

Glenn Morris, 43, Paul Walker, 36, and John Starbuck, 45, claimed to be the first to ski and sledge 400 miles north across the island of Spitsbergen. The Britons ended the trip at Verlegahuken, having braved polar bears and frostbite at -38C.

Two share £11.3m jackpot

Two ticketholders shared the £11.3m jackpot in Saturday night's national lottery rollover. The winning numbers were 2, 25, 33, 40, 44 and 47 , the bonus 17. No one won the lottery extra jackpot. The Thunderball numbers were 2, 7, 11, 12, 23 and the Thunderball was 9. One ticket won £250,000.

webTitle: Mandela looks to the future at celebration concert

fields.headline: Mandela looks to the future at celebration concert
fields.trailText: For three decades they flocked here to play their part in the long and terrible struggle against apartheid. Over the years, thousands of protesters attended pickets, vigils and marches outside South Africa House, home of the country's high commission.
fields.body:
For three decades they flocked here to play their part in the long and terrible struggle against apartheid. Over the years, thousands of protesters attended pickets, vigils and marches outside South Africa House, home of the country's high commission.

Last night the campaigners returned to Trafalgar Square, with 30,000 people crowding into the heart of London to join Nelson Mandela at a concert celebrating seven years of democracy in South Africa.

The free show was billed as a thank you to the people of Britain for their part in the struggle.

"The end of apartheid was a joint victory," Mr Mandela said yesterday. "It was achieved through the strong and committed partnership that exists between our two countries.

"Today the people of the United Kingdom, especially the youth, again take our hand in partnership, lending their support so that we do fully realise our aim of a better life and future for all in South Africa."

It was the first pop concert held in the square, which Ken Livingstone, London's mayor, is keen to promote as a venue for future events.

The show brought back memories of the huge Wembley stadium Freedom Concert in 1988, and the concert to celebrate Mandela's release at the same venue two years later.

This time the line-up was eclectic, if not downright odd. The teen pop act Atomic Kitten and the 80s crooner Billy Ocean played alongside the Corrs, South Africa's Ladysmith Black Mambazo and Hugh Masekela and headliners REM. It was little wonder the resident pigeons seemed so disoriented, perhaps taking the loud guitars for Ken Livingstone's latest weapon in his war against them.

For many the event also evoked memories of past protests. In 1960 the Boycott Committee protested in Trafalgar Square against the massacre of 69 protesters at Sharpeville. Four years later they turned out again after Mandela and other leading members of the ANC were imprisoned.

The brightest moments in its history came on February 11 1990, when thousands gathered to celebrate his release, and in July 1996, when he addressed the crowds from the balcony of the building as the president of South Africa.

Whether most of those present last night remembered these events was debatable. Many appeared to see it as a free night out. Cynics might also suggest that while all the artists played for nothing - waiving a total of around £2m in potential fees - they received plenty of free publicity.

But almost everyone was happy simply to enjoy the event as a sign of South Africa's progress over the past seven years. Ben Jackson, director of Action for Southern Africa, which succeeded the Anti-Apartheid Movement, said it was a strange contrast to his years on the picket line.

"It's an amazing experience," he said. "So much of the focus on South Africa is about their problems, but if you think that even 10 years ago the idea of Mandela standing on a balcony watching this would have been unbelievable, it's the rapidity of the change that hits you.

"Of course South Africa has immense problems but there is still a tremendous sense of hope."

webTitle: Cancers blamed on nuclear power plant

fields.headline: Cancers blamed on nuclear power plant
fields.trailText: An apparent cluster of childhood cancers near a nuclear power station on the river Severn has been blamed on radiation from the plant.
fields.body:
An apparent cluster of childhood cancers near a nuclear power station on the river Severn has been blamed on radiation from the plant.

Chris Busby, a scientist, said he had uncovered evidence of significant levels of leukaemia among children under four years old living near the ageing Oldbury reactor.

He believed cancer statistics for an area in and around nearby Chepstow, south Wales, between 1974 and 1990 revealed excessive numbers of myeloid leukaemia, a condition usually linked to older people, and sometimes involving exposure to radiation.

Three cases were recorded when there might have been expected to have been either one or none.

In all there had been seven cancers among under fours, one-and-a-half times the national average. This mirrored a previously accepted leukaemia cluster at Seascale, near the Sellafield nuclear plant in Cumbria, where there were four deaths of children under 14 from 1950 to 1983.

Dr Busby, a member of the campaign group Green Audit, and adviser to the European parliament's green group, said: "This is the discovery of a new nuclear site child leukaemia cluster. The high level of myeloid leukaemia suggests that radiation is the cause."

He believed older people living downstream from Oldbury were also more likely to suffer cancers. Defenders of the nuclear industry accept the existence of clusters but point out these also occur in areas where there are no plants.

British Nuclear Fuels said no one knew the cause of the Seascale cluster, but Dr Busby's work was never peer reviewed, and if his previous work was anything to go by, the study could be discounted.

webTitle: 'It takes a bang for people to sit up and listen'

fields.headline: 'It takes a bang for people to sit up and listen'
fields.trailText: Barry is a senior gas leak engineer with Transco. He describes his work conditions.
fields.body:
Barry is a senior gas leak engineer with Transco. He describes his work conditions:

It's worst in the winter. We up the pressure in the pipes to cope with demand, and that's when the leaks become bigger. The last two years, we've really noticed things getting worse.

It's when it's your turn on emergency call-out that's the problem. You're on standby from 6am, then you go straight into your normal day at 8am, but you don't get home at 5pm - you have to work on, often till 1am or 2am. You just get home to bed and then you get called out again at 3am. That's the pattern in London.

I've done 16 hours without a break at weekends. You have to keep going until the work stops. You can take a break, but if the call centre holds lots of escapes they put a lot of pressure on you to go, as they have to respond to a call within an hour by law.

If, say, you're out till 2am, you don't have to go in till 10am, but you can't really perform then. I've been woken up by the police several times. You take a quick 15-minute break and crash out on the steering wheel of the van. It's been really bad like this for 18 months. The local managers are worried but their hands are tied, they can't recruit.

The first job of the day, I've usually got my wits about me. You remember not to ring the door bell because it might create a spark which might explode the place, but by the end of 15 hours you start to forget.

A lot of the time it's straightforward leaks. But you might find that 40 or 50 houses have got no gas, and it's a mains leak. You can't hurry those.

The externals [leaks outside] are nearly all the old metal pipes. We end up deferring a lot. You'll be out at 10pm and you've got a reading that says this leak needs work, so you ring in and ask for a team to fix it, but you're told there are no teams left, we'll have to do it tomorrow.

It takes a bang for people to sit up and listen. We all think that's just around the corner because we haven't got enough people to work on the gas escapes. It's been luck so far. We seem to be saying "we all know the work needs to be done, but sorry, we're too busy at the moment", but that's a Hatfield, isn't it?

 The engineer's name has been changed. Interview by Felicity Lawrence

webTitle: Jailed mothers test baby age limit

fields.headline: Jailed mothers test baby age limit
fields.standfirst: Special report: child protection
fields.trailText: Two women prisoners who are threatened with having their toddlers taken from them and put into care will ask the high court today to rule that the Home Office's upper age limit of 18 months for babies in prison is unlawful.
fields.body:
Two women prisoners who are threatened with having their toddlers taken from them and put into care will ask the high court today to rule that the Home Office's upper age limit of 18 months for babies in prison is unlawful.

The case, brought under the Human Rights Act, is the first challenge to the rule, though lawyers have been anticipating such a claim since the act came into force last October.

The case is seen as so important that it was rescheduled from later this week to Monday and Tuesday, so that the lord chief justice, England's most senior judge, could hear it. The two women will seek a confidentiality order before the hearing begins today, and their lawyers were reluctant yesterday to give many details of their personal circumstances.

The two children are believed to have already passed the 18-month age limit and will have to go to foster parents soon unless the court intervenes. One of the women is serving a five-year sentence and her earliest date of release is just over a year away. The other has been jailed for eight years and faces deportation at the end of her sentence.

In family court cases, judges take account of the serious risk of permanent psychological harm to young children in removing them from their mother. The women's lawyers will argue that the prison service ignores this in operating its upper age limit.

"The blanket policy means there could be grave injustices to individual children," said Harriet Wistrich of the London law firm Thanki Novy Taube, which acts for one of the women.

"There seems to be a conflict between the basic principle that the court should always act in the best interests of the child and these cases where there is a blanket policy which could be totally against the best interests of these children."

Richard Gordon, the women's QC, will argue that there is no objective justification for the rule. He will contend that it breaches article eight of the European convention on human rights, the right to respect for private and family life, and article 14, the ban on discrimination, because it discriminates between the children of prisoners and those of others.

Lawyers for the Home Office are expected to argue that the 18-month limit should remain pending further research.

There are only 72 places in prison mother and baby units, though more than 1,000 women prisoners at any one time have children under five. The Home Office is considering proposals for increasing the number of mother and baby units, and for special units to accommodate children up to the age of four with their mothers.

A report last year from the Council of Europe's social, health and family affairs committee concluded that prisons were not an appropriate environment for children, often causing long-term developmental retardation. "Yet, if babies and children are forcibly separated from their mothers they suffer permanent emotional and social damage," it said.

The report recommended that prison should be a last resort for mothers of young children, and should be used only for those women convicted of the most serious offences who represent a danger to the community.

They should be housed in small secure and semi-secure units with social services support, and access to the outside world under supervision.

In Germany and Spain, mothers are allowed to have their children with them in prison until the age of six, in the Netherlands until four in one prison, and until three in Portugal and Switzerland. One German jail has an open unit outside the prison walls in which each mother has her own apartment.

webTitle: Leader: Ukraine's struggle is just beginning

fields.headline: The wrong man resigns
fields.standfirst: Ukraine's struggle is just beginning
fields.trailText: Viktor Yushchenko's forced resignation as Ukraine's prime minister has intensified the sense of political crisis that has gripped Kiev since last autumn when President Leonid Kuchma was accused of ordering the murder of an investigative journalist.
fields.body:
Viktor Yushchenko's forced resignation as Ukraine's prime minister has intensified the sense of political crisis that has gripped Kiev since last autumn when President Leonid Kuchma was accused of ordering the murder of an investigative journalist.

Mr Yushchenko's tearful departure after losing a parliamentary confidence vote sparked renewed street protests of a kind that in recent months have frequently threatened to spiral out of control. But his overthrow has had a broader impact, affecting confidence in Ukraine's still immature democracy and in the country's ability to tackle its economic problems. The vanquished prime minister's market reforms and pro-western stance had begun to show results, with GDP growing by 6% last year, industrial production up by 12% and steel exports to the US and the EU on the rise. The figures reflected the first yearly growth recorded since Ukraine became independent 10 years ago, a period that saw real GDP plummet by about two-thirds. Now big lenders such as the US and the World Bank-IMF are likely to hold back until the dust settles.

That may take a while. Mr Yushchenko alienated powerful business interests - the Ukrainian equivalent of Russia's oligarchs - who feared his reforms would loosen their often corrupt hold on Soviet-era state monopolies. He was badly served by his divided allies and fiercely opposed by old-style communists. In courting the west, he increasingly represented an obstacle to President Vladimir Putin's evident ambition to re-establish Moscow's sway in the most important part of what Russians proprietorially call their "near abroad". And Ukraine is in any case dependent for its energy supplies on Russia, still its biggest trading partner.

Mr Yushchenko was further undermined by Mr Kuchma, a weakened and oppressive figure who has good cause to fear his prime minister's grassroots popularity. In truth, it is the president who should have resigned.

These underlying tensions and divisions will not be dispelled by this latest upheaval. On the contrary, they may only grow worse, ultimately undermining Ukraine's briefly-held independence (as in the case of Belarus). "I am not abandoning politics. I am going away in order to return," Mr Yushchenko said. He is now expected to try to rally the opposition ahead of elections next year. That offers a glimmer of hope. But it also suggests the crisis will deepen.

webTitle: Housing scheme for key workers 'may go belly up'

fields.headline: Housing scheme for key workers 'may go belly up'
fields.trailText: The government's flagship scheme to house nurses, teachers and social workers could be wrecked by a hidden tax "bombshell", it emerged today.
fields.body:
The government's flagship scheme to house nurses, teachers and social workers could be wrecked by a hidden tax "bombshell", it emerged today.

The £250m starter homes initiative (SHI) has been introduced to house 10,000 key public sector workers currently priced out of the housing market.

But housing professionals have warned that the initiative could "go belly up", because under the scheme key workers will face a tax bill of hundreds of pounds a year.

The problem, which has been concealed until now, has only emerged in new government guidance to those bidding for the scheme. The guidance, which has provoked widespread alarm, explains that if key workers get help with housing this could be counted as a taxable benefit from their employer for as long as they live in the home.

Even though the homes will be provided by housing associations, the tax problem arises because a requirement of the scheme is to involve the employers of key workers such as councils, police forces and health trusts as part of each bid.

It is feared that many key workers will be reluctant to take up the initiative because of the tax involved. But there is also concern that the viability of many of the schemes being put forward will also be threatened.

Most of the bids submitted to the government involve some form of so called shared ownership housing, under which key workers have to raise a mortgage for some of the cost of buying a home. Housing associations have pointed out that if key workers have to pay extra tax this will adversely affect their ability to raise money.

One housing association manager, who did not wished to be named for fear that criticism of initiative would affect his bid for cash under the scheme, estimated that the tax would reduce a key workers ability to borrow by up to £8,000.

He said: "On a low income in a marginal housing market like London, that could make all the difference between buying a house or not."

Under his housing association's scheme, teachers would face tax bills of up to £550 a year.

London Housing Federation policy officer Dino Patel said: "The who thing could go belly up if they don't sort this out. It's like a tax bombshell. This is about the lack of joined-up thinking in government. The left hand doesn't seem to know what the right hand is doing."

He also pointed out that employers such as councils could pull out of the scheme to avoid landing teachers and social workers with large tax bills.

"It is possible that they might get cold feet, which will undermine the whole concept of the starter homes initiative."

One London council official appeared to confirm those fears. She said: "We are very worried about it. If we did not see some resolution by October or November we would have to consider our position."

Another housing association director who did not wish to be named said: "When you realise the tax implications you can see how stupid it is, especially when this is targeted at people on low incomes in areas of high demand. It is a fairly adverse tax problem which seems to be run completely counter to the whole initiative."

Graham Douglas, deputy director of estates at the Metropolitan Police Force, which is bidding with a number of housing associations for cash under the scheme, said: "This would seem a little counterproductive and I hope that, having been made aware of it, DETR will negotiate with the Inland Revenue."

He added: "The danger is that the response to the scheme will be less than enthusiastic. I am concerned about anything that damages the initiative, because it is such a good idea and it has been needed for some time."

In a statement the DETR said: "Guidance on the tax implications of bids under the starter home initiative was included in the bidding guidance issued by the DETR last December. fields.bodyText: The government's flagship scheme to house nurses, teachers and social workers could be wrecked by a hidden tax "bombshell", it emerged today. The £250m starter homes initiative (SHI) has been introduced to house 10,000 key public sector workers currently priced out of the housing market. But housing professionals have warned that the initiative could "go belly up", because under the scheme key workers will face a tax bill of hundreds of pounds a year. The problem, which has been concealed until now, has only emerged in new government guidance to those bidding for the scheme. The guidance, which has provoked widespread alarm, explains that if key workers get help with housing this could be counted as a taxable benefit from their employer for as long as they live in the home. Even though the homes will be provided by housing associations, the tax problem arises because a requirement of the scheme is to involve the employers of key workers such as councils, police forces and health trusts as part of each bid. It is feared that many key workers will be reluctant to take up the initiative because of the tax involved. But there is also concern that the viability of many of the schemes being put forward will also be threatened. Most of the bids submitted to the government involve some form of so called shared ownership housing, under which key workers have to raise a mortgage for some of the cost of buying a home. Housing associations have pointed out that if key workers have to pay extra tax this will adversely affect their ability to raise money. One housing association manager, who did not wished to be named for fear that criticism of initiative would affect his bid for cash under the scheme, estimated that the tax would reduce a key workers ability to borrow by up to £8,000. He said: "On a low income in a marginal housing market like London, that could make all the difference between buying a house or not." Under his housing association's scheme, teachers would face tax bills of up to £550 a year. London Housing Federation policy officer Dino Patel said: "The who thing could go belly up if they don't sort this out. It's like a tax bombshell. This is about the lack of joined-up thinking in government. The left hand doesn't seem to know what the right hand is doing." He also pointed out that employers such as councils could pull out of the scheme to avoid landing teachers and social workers with large tax bills. "It is possible that they might get cold feet, which will undermine the whole concept of the starter homes initiative." One London council official appeared to confirm those fears. She said: "We are very worried about it. If we did not see some resolution by October or November we would have to consider our position." Another housing association director who did not wish to be named said: "When you realise the tax implications you can see how stupid it is, especially when this is targeted at people on low incomes in areas of high demand. It is a fairly adverse tax problem which seems to be run completely counter to the whole initiative." Graham Douglas, deputy director of estates at the Metropolitan Police Force, which is bidding with a number of housing associations for cash under the scheme, said: "This would seem a little counterproductive and I hope that, having been made aware of it, DETR will negotiate with the Inland Revenue." fields.headline: Mongrels are best
fields.standfirst: Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: William Hague tossed away a few votes recently with his hapless "more Blair equals a foreign Britain" speech. Did the Tories learn a lesson? Of course not; they're not the "stupid party" for nothing.
fields.body:
William Hague tossed away a few votes recently with his hapless "more Blair equals a foreign Britain" speech. Did the Tories learn a lesson? Of course not; they're not the "stupid party" for nothing.

Last week the retiring, if not shy, Tory MP John Townend took Hague's dim argument and sunk it into the gutter. Another Blair government, says pure, blue-blooded Townend in his five-minutes-of-fame speech, and we'll all be mongrels. Beg pardon? Mongrels, sir.

Like many of us who are British-born, I am a mongrel and happy to be one. English and Irish, with a touch of Scottish and a jot of Basque. At school - RC and so doubtless pretty rum as well as decidedly left-footish to the right-marching Townend - many of the other boys were mongrels, too. Anglo-Irish, Anglo-Scots and Anglo-whaddayagot: Indians, Poles, Italians and others. The last seemed the luckiest mongrels of all because their mothers cooked so exceptionally well.

As for mongrel dogs, those of us who have spent our lives in the company of thoroughbreds and mongrels know that, on most counts, mutts are the best. They are healthier, brighter, easier to train, loving and great fun to be with. Of course, all dogs were cross-bred at one time or other. No cross-breeding, no mongrels, no King Charles spaniels. The same holds for plants and flowers. The finely scented roses so loved by the British, especially I should imagine by retired Tory MPs, are floral mongrels bred into a new form of earthly delight.

Britain's successes - cultural, technical and architectural - have often been a result of cross-breeding. Whichever way you turn. What is, say, the most British car of all? You might say Bristol, but Tony Crook's gloriously blimpish, hand-crafted chariots are powered by Chrysler V8 engines. American. So too is the wonderfully cranky Morgan with its timber chassis and Buick-based engine. Another Anglo-American hybrid. The most stylish Aston-Martins, the DB4 and James Bond DB5 were a fusion of British engineering and Italian styling (coachwork by Touring of Milan). Sir William Lyons based the shape of his show-stealing 1948 Jaguar XK120 on pre-war experimental BMWs and Alfa-Romeos. He wasn't stupid.

Well, what about our great railway locomotives, eh? Johnny Foreigner couldn't hold a candle to Mallard, could he? Mallard? Fastest steam locomotive in the world - 126mph in 1938. Yes, but Mallard was only so fast because her designer, Sir Nigel Gresley, chief mechanical engineer of the London and North Eastern Railway, had incorporated the latest research of André Chapelon, genius of French steam and the greatest locomotive engineer of all. Gresley's other famous locomotive, Flying Scotsman, was modelled in part on the hugely successful K4 Pacific of the Pennsylvania Railroad. The best of our legendary locomotives were, in the best possible way, mongrels. All the best designers, because the brightest, have always garnered and edited ideas from around the world.

As with cars and locomotives, so with architecture, fashion and music. Our medieval cathedrals, at their best, are inspired fusions, artistic junction boxes through which flow the ideas of Normans and locals. Later on, we stirred decorative designs - half-baked it's true - drawn from the architectural recipe books of Renaissance Italy into our Tudor palaces and country houses. The Palladian movement, led by Lord Burlington, was a cross-breeding of the peerless Tuscan farmhouse and Venetian church architecture of Andrea Palladio with English, Scottish and Anglo-Irish sensibilities.

As for St Paul's Cathedral, even Hague and Townend must know that it's a resourceful cross-breed between Gothic planning and Baroque design, a brilliant compromise. They must surely hear and taste as well as see the success of cross-breeding through the centuries in Britain. Listen to how Handel, a German, influenced British music when he came to live and compose in London. See how successful Jimi Hendrix became when, through the agency of Chas Chandler, his Geordie manager, he fused American blues with British pop. Eat chicken tikka masala, spaghetti bolognese (as we know it), King Edward potatoes, Jersey tomatoes or Cadbury's chocolate (all American in origin) tucked up in your pyjamas safe inside your bungalow (Anglo-Indian slumberwear and home), and you're snuggled quite happily in a mongrel culture.

Townend and his type might best be put into the care of Battersea Dogs' Home for the next few months in exchange for cross-breeds that need good homes. Although these mongrels bark as loudly as racist Tory MPs, they are unlikely to lose elections.

jonathan.glancey@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Nice and sleazy
fields.standfirst: The Almeida brings a touch of class to vice-ridden King's Cross, says  Jonathan Glancey
fields.trailText: The Almeida brings a touch of class to vice-ridden King's Cross, says Jonathan Glancey
fields.body:
This one may not run and run. The Almeida theatre, in King's Cross, London, is only meant to be temporary. It will close as soon as the remodelling of the Almeida's permanent home in Islington, a mile or so up the road, is complete next year.

Yet we may come to mourn the loss of this curious guttersnipe of a building. Cheap it may be and few buildings of this scale and ambition have been raced up at such a cracking pace (£850,000, 524 seats and 12 weeks are the statistics), yet it possesses a rough-and-tumble, greasepaint magic all of its own.

Since it opened last month, this back-alley theatre has played to full houses almost every night. This is in part due to the choice of Frank Wedekind's erotic play, Lulu (directed by Jonathan Kent and starring Anna Friel, formerly of the TV soap opera Brookside), yet the intrigue of the theatre and its suitably sleazy location might just have something to do with its success, too.

There is something special about the approach to the theatre's ragtag foyer and bar. It is located down a rat's alley, grandly called Omega Place (and certainly the last place you would expect to find an arts venue), in an area dotted with organic juice bars, nudge-nudge video shops and what look like crack joints and whorehouses. Nice. And very Lulu.

What looks like a long glowing lizard's tongue (designed by a Bauhaus architect) unfurls up the alley towards the drab Caledonian Road and seems to pull passers-by into the mirror-walled foyer. This view down towards the theatre entrance looks impressively surreal by night. During the day and early evening, it's just rather odd. And enchanting.

The tongue, concealing a passageway and stair connecting foyer and auditorium, licks out from walls of . . . grass. These are blooming nicely just now. They conceal old corrugated steel cladding.

The whole caboodle looks like a cross between one of those "ones that we prepared earlier" for the BBC's Blue Peter team, all toilet rolls and sticky-back plastic, and an early design by Frank Gehry of Guggenheim Bilbao fame. In fact, Gehry's Californian home - a sculptural trick of chicken wire and the least likely building materials available from city-edge DIY stores - was a source of inspiration for the Almeida's architect, Steve Tomkins of Haworth Tomkins.

"The grass was never meant to be a gimmick," says Tomkins. "It's just the cheapest form of sound and thermal insulation we could buy, and get quickly. The theatre is built up, around and through this old bus and coach station, a very simple but spacious building; it wasn't what you'd normally call architecture, yet we could hardly believe how big it was, hidden away by surrounding streets. Remarkably, some of the interiors have nearly perfect classical proportions; it might be made of tin, but it has a secret grandeur."

The turf-roofed tin and concrete foyer is unexpectedly generous. To keep costs to a minimum, the battered concrete floor of the former garage has been scrubbed and sealed (no fancy timber, tiles or carpet here) and the furniture, aside from a cluster of swivel stools from Ikea, has been culled from wherever it could be found: the tall, straight-backed chairs are from the set of the Almeida's production of Richard II.

The smokey splodges on the wall are the ghosts of the oily exhausts of the collection of Jaguars, Ferraris, Alfas and Astons that used to be kept here until recently when the garage was the home of the smart Classic Car Club.

Tomkins, acclaimed for his delightful and practical reconstruction of the Royal Court Theatre in Sloane Square, London, has made the most of what is far from being a set of fast-track functional boxes. Some of the spaces, especially the passageway set behind the bright tongue curling up Omega Place, are almost beautiful.

Here daylight slants between shadows through the translucent wall, creating, with the right sort of sunset, the kind of numinous patterns of light you expect from a Le Corbusier or Louis Kahn.

Stairs from this passage lead up to the wide-shouldered auditorium. It is little more than a big, black box with padded bench seating. There is no hierarchy here: every seat has a good view and the sound is remarkably even.

Stage and backstage are voluminous. Back of backstage, building work is cranking along on the construction of a second, horseshoe shaped auditorium. This really does comes as a surprise; how can there possibly be so much space free for outfits such as the Almeida so very close to the centre of London?

King's Cross, although on the up, remains a dive. It is like being in a play here sometimes. The bish-bash-bosh streets are cruised angrily by villainous-looking cars driven by villainous-looking types. Hookers stop you more frequently than Big Issue vendors. There are sticky snooker halls, striptease pubs and mean-looking youths lurking inside hoody sweatshirts on too many corners for bourgeois comfort.

And yet, walk three or four minutes south and they vanish like actors at the end of an act. Where do they all go? Are they on some sort of purgatorial urban loop that keeps them, battered cars and all, on the surly stage we call King's Cross?

Back behind the Almeida stage, there is a maze of slapped together changing rooms, green room and staff rooms that link as directly as possible to the stage, its entrance and exits; however makeshift some of the architecture seems, its planning is impeccable.

This is punk or guttersnipe architecture at pretty much its best, that and an intelligent make-and-mend re-use of a city building that might otherwise brood uneasily for another three or four years doing nothing whatsoever, except decaying.

More than this, it suggests a future use for this site not premised on yet more office space. There have been several grand plans for the redevelopment of King's Cross over the past 15 years, yet perhaps what it needs is a less dogmatic and a more organic working through with affordable new homes as well as arts buildings, markets and studio space for small enterprises and shops selling more than grubby mags.

The whole area is deeply theatrical in a dark and broody way. Most of its drama is rough stuff: the Almeida shows how the arts can come to prod the insensitivities of King's Cross without the place going all la-la rather than Lulu.

· Lulu is at the Almeida (020-7359 4404) until May 12.

fields.headline: Love thy neighbourhood manager
fields.standfirst: New neighbourhood managers will be deployed in deprived areas to ensure the government's money is used properly. But will they have any bite?
fields.trailText: New neighbourhood managers will be deployed in deprived areas to ensure the government's money is used properly. But will they have any bite asks Aaron Cahill.
fields.body:
One of the social exclusion unit's big ideas for regeneration is now becoming a reality. Neighbourhood managers are emerging from the job pages on to the streets. But how will they survive once this not-so-new idea loses its gloss?

In principle, people have very little problem with the notion of neighbourhood management, and its fundamental premise is a simple one: there's a lot of money already going into deprived neighbourhoods, it needs to be used better. Much of the government's neighbourhood renewal agenda has been all about this anyway.

The government is already trying out - or intends to try out - this idea through the 39 New Deal for Communities (NDC) pathfinders that are at various stages of approval or execution. The neighbourhood management brief here will be to sustain the benefits of 10 years' investment that the NDC schemes will bring.

But another pathfinder programme for neighbourhood management proper ended its first stage bidding round last week. Eighty-three local authority districts were eligible to submit one bid each for this programme, but only 15 will be approved at the finishing line in December 2001.

This means we can at least be reasonably sure that the bids currently being considered by the DETR (Department of Environment, Transport and the Regions) will result in 15 job adverts for neighbourhood managers by January 2002. A meagre number though this is, we are promised at least another 15 neighbourhood management schemes at some point in the future.

Each of these partnerships will be eligible to a maximum of £4.3m over seven years from the government. This, of course, is a lot less than the £50m or more that is (or will be) available to the 39 NDC partnerships - 22 of which were announced today.

An interesting research exercise for the future will be comparing the two pathfinder programmes. Which approach gets better outcomes - the one with a lot of money thrown at it, or the one with very little? Because this goes to the centre of the government's neighbourhood renewal, and even their sustainable development agenda. How do you make better use of what you've got, and get more for less? Getting this - and much more - from the neighbourhood agenda will depend heavily on the new animal called the neighbourhood manager.

But who are these people, and which discipline are they coming from? What are they going to be doing? And how are they going to be equipped to work from and for the neighbourhood with the health authorities, local authorities and police who the new managers will want money and power from? Whichever way it is looked at, there needs to be a shift of power from other places - local authorities in particular, but not exclusively - to get neighbourhood managers the pound for pound weight they're going to need.

Naturally the housing sector is staking their claim to the new neighbourhood management mantle. Various job adverts have emerged from the housing association and local authority sectors with neighbourhood prefixed to the job title, which is a start of sorts.

Other disciplines such as town centre management, and more tenuously, the education and health professions might be able to offer people. But that is part of the problem: there are not many people out there who can obviously do the job, particularly when the skills and knowledge needed for this new model profession are currently less than clear.

Handily, the recent DETR neighbourhood management guidance gives some clues with a matrix of the skills and knowledge required. And the recent action plan highlights the need for a learning and development strategy that the government is committed to delivering, via the new DETR-based Neighbourhood Renewal Unit.

But if these neighbourhood managers are to be anything, they will be brokers or intermediaries (depending on your preference), and will need to be patient with it. Because they will be spending much time persuading local service providers to deliver services that suit the needs of local people rather than the demands of the "clients" who commission services, but who may be a little removed from the reality of the service delivery process itself. They'll also be spending a fair bit of time managing local people's expectations of the new agenda that is very bottom-up and community-focused, or at least the rhetoric is.

Much as we would like neighbourhood managers to be "in charge" of local resources, in the short term, we're looking at evolutionary step-change. Criticism has repeatedly been levelled at local authorities for not being "joined up" and strategic enough in their work, but the criticism should be spread a lot further if these rather easy criticisms are to be fair ones. Other players will have to look at their work also, and housing associations are not exempt. And how the education and health money will filter down to the neighbourhood level can only be speculated on.

But these two issues are interesting in their own right. The government has recently announced proposals to reduce bureaucracy and administration in the health service and to re-allocate saved money to frontline services provided by primary health groups. The Conservatives, in the meantime, have long been talking about abolishing local education authorities and giving a saved £500+ per pupil to school heads. And who would bet against New Labour lifting this idea for themselves?

Cutting red tape and bureaucracy, and squeezing resources from the ivory towers to the frontline will always strike a chord with politicians and get a headline. What will be difficult for neighbourhood managers will be marshalling these resources to local priorities. The new local strategic partnerships have a clear remit to ensure neighbourhood managers get the support they need, and how they work with local authorities will be crucial on this point.

But one of the problems that gets little coverage is the heavy cost of across-the-board local management approaches. Two local authorities in London - Tower Hamlets and Islington - tried out neighbourhood approaches to service delivery. Both approaches have their defenders and detractors, but they would probably both agree that the approach is commonly expensive. Economies of scale, successful and sustainable outcomes will hopefully result from future approaches to neighbourhood management, but the short-term bottom line cash cost will still count in many people's minds.

And this is why the neighbourhood management agenda is potentially a threat to many local service providers, in a way that the regional agenda is a threat to local authorities. Duplication of roles is simply not sustainable and will need to be resolved in the fullness of time. And if it means more money, more expertise, more management at the frontline, just who will - or should - be standing in front of the neighbourhood manager, instead of behind them?

But how will they survive once this not-so-new idea loses its gloss? In principle, people have very little problem with the notion of neighbourhood management, and its fundamental premise is a simple one: there's a lot of money already going into deprived neighbourhoods, it needs to be used better. Much of the government's neighbourhood renewal agenda has been all about this anyway. The government is already trying out - or intends to try out - this idea through the 39 New Deal for Communities (NDC) pathfinders that are at various stages of approval or execution. The neighbourhood management brief here will be to sustain the benefits of 10 years' investment that the NDC schemes will bring. But another pathfinder programme for neighbourhood management proper ended its first stage bidding round last week. Eighty-three local authority districts were eligible to submit one bid each for this programme, but only 15 will be approved at the finishing line in December 2001. This means we can at least be reasonably sure that the bids currently being considered by the DETR (Department of Environment, Transport and the Regions) will result in 15 job adverts for neighbourhood managers by January 2002. A meagre number though this is, we are promised at least another 15 neighbourhood management schemes at some point in the future. Each of these partnerships will be eligible to a maximum of £4.3m over seven years from the government. This, of course, is a lot less than the £50m or more that is (or will be) available to the 39 NDC partnerships - 22 of which were announced today. fields.headline: £1.1bn boost for deprived neighbourhoods
fields.trailText: Twenty-two of the most deprived neighbourhoods in England learned today that they will benefit from a £1.1bn fund under the government's flagship new deal regeneration programme.
fields.body:
Twenty-two of the most deprived neighbourhoods in England learned today that they will benefit from a £1.1bn fund under the government's flagship new deal regeneration programme.

The money, available over the next 10 years, was announced today under the second round of the new deal for communities (NDC), set up to narrow the gap between the poorest areas and the rest of the country.

Locally, each of the 22 NDC partnerships has developed a detailed 10-year plan to transform their areas through a wide variety of community-based initiatives and programmes, focusing particularly on reducing crime, improving people's health, tackling joblessness, raising educational achievement and improving the physical environment.

Local proposals given the green light include:
 Plans to wire up neighbourhoods with internet and new technologies
 Capacity-building schemes, which aim to provide a decent environment for people to live in
 Integrated drug reduction and education schemes
 Neighbourhood management schemes
 Community health centres
 Resident advice centres linking key employment and education advisory services.

Twenty-one are new partnerships, which join the 17 "pathfinder" partnerships awarded £774m in the first round.

Announcing the details today in north Fulham, one of the funding winners, regeneration minister Hilary Armstrong said: "This announcement reaffirms our commitment to help people in the most deprived communities in England to bridge the gap between their neighbourhoods and the rest of the country."

"This money will allow people through their NDC partnerships to make a real, positive change to the places where they live and work - according to their own priorities."

But success relied upon the NDC partnerships engaging all the local "stakeholders", such as residents, local businesses, voluntary organisations and service providers, she added.

Regeneration organisations broadly welcomed the announcement - with some caveats.

Councillor Chris Clarke, chairman of the Local Government Association's social exclusion executive, said: "It's certainly welcome to see the continuation of this programme, which, in some locations, is helping to revitalising communities.

"It is particularly welcome that the projects are required to draw in people from the communities with the affected neighbourhoods. No one needs better what really needs to be done than the people who live within these hard-pressed communities."

However, there were two broader concerns, he said. "These project funds are beginning to add to the distortion of funding of local authorities, so careful attention is needed to stop others missing out."

Moreover, he said, the plethora of projects, initiatives and programmes linked to regeneration and social exclusion needed rationalising. "The future lies in joint working through community planning within local strategic partnerships," he said.

Aaron Cahill, National Housing Federation regeneration policy officer, said: "This represents one of the last stages of the 'old' new deal for communities programme, where community regeneration partnerships are being given around £50m each to undertake 'bottom-up' neighbourhood renewal."

"The £2bn commitment that the NDC programme represents shows how much these initiatives cost. It is disappointing that there is unlikely to be a NDC round three in the near future. But perhaps we should just be pleased with what we've got: £2bn is a lot of money."

For a full list of the 22 areas to be offered funding, see link below.

fields.headline: Dacourt's endeavour deserving of higher recognition
fields.trailText: After his imperious midfield display against Chelsea, how much longer can France coach Roger Lemerre afford to ignore Olivier Dacourt?
fields.body:
Chelsea, we learnt last week, are not interested in signing Josep Guardiola, the linchpin of successive Barcelona teams over the past decade. Having seen their team well beaten on Saturday by a Leeds United side in which Olivier Dacourt produced a magnificent display of the art of the ball-winning midfield player, perhaps Claudio Ranieri will think again. Guardiola may be 30 years old but his calm competence in front of the back four might have saved the London side from an embarrassing and costly late collapse.

Players of such presence and resolution are the key to a successful modern team. In the Premier League, the examples of Roy Keane, Patrick Vieira and Steven Gerrard illustrate the increasing importance of their role. They may not necessarily be spectacular performers. Dunga was almost invisible when Brazil won the World Cup in 1994, at least to those enthralled by the flair of Romario and Bebeto, but his contribution provided the side's heartbeat. Didier Deschamps, similarly, attracted few plaudits for the aesthetic quality of his play in 1998 and 2000, yet his presence was fundamental to France's two great championship wins.

At 26, Dacourt is two years older than Vieira, who occupies the position in the current French team which swept Portugal's golden generation aside so convincingly in Paris on Wednesday. The Leeds man is not even a member of Roger Lemerre's squad, but many more displays like the one for which he received the man of the match award on Saturday will surely create a persuasive case for his recognition.

Dacourt went into the match in the lead of one of the Carling Opta tables, his 147 tackles representing the highest total recorded by any player in the Premier League so far this season. He lived up to the statistic against Chelsea, his combative excellence provoking fouls which should have reduced the visitors to nine men before the end.

After starting the match in imperious mood, Marcel Desailly, the current captain of France was subjected to an increasing catalogue of indignities, culminating in his inability to prevent Mark Viduka running through him to volley Leeds' second goal. On this occasion Alan Smith, who likes to collect the shirts of his heroes, did a swap with John Terry, his pal from the Under-21s.

Desailly, it will be remembered, reached his peak at club level playing in front of AC Milan's back four, where he succeeded Frank Rijkaard in combining the functions of interdiction and creation. It will be interesting to see whether his rapport with Lemerre extends to a warm mention of the part Dacourt played in Chelsea's downfall on Saturday, the sort of recommendation that could lead to the Leeds man's emergence as Vieira's understudy.

Although Dacourt was the victim of the two most potentially dangerous fouls of the match, he was largely absent from the sort of petty scuffles which traditionally disfigure this fixture. The long-running dispute between Dennis Wise and David Batty even resumed a minute after the final whistle, when what appeared to start as an exchange of affectionate salutes quickly turned nasty. But then those two will probably still be at it when the only thing at stake is the last free sun-lounger by the pool at the Premier League's retirement home.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to football.editor@guardianunlimited.co.uk
